HEADLINE: U.S. Keeps Balkan Talks Alive Despite Impasse on Peace Maps

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Frustrated and exhausted after 20 days of negotiations to end the war in Bosnia, United States diplomats struggled today to keep alive peace talks that seemed on the verge of collapse.
Despite a decision by American envoys on Sunday to shut down the talks this morning no matter what the outcome, the United States backed down from its pledge and plunged ahead with more negotiations all day today and through the night to break the impasse among the three parties. 
 The determination of the American side not to give up was underscored by the personal involvement of Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who cut short his trip to Japan last Friday to return to the site of the talks at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near here to press for an agreement.
Mr. Christopher, a 70-year-old lawyer, shuttled among the parties throughout the night last night, sleeping for 70 minutes and resuming work shortly after 7 A.M. today. But by tonight there still was no breakthrough. So he and his team again worked into the night and were planning to stay and negotiate at least until Tuesday.
Earlier today, some senior officials of the Muslim-led Bosnian Government said that the negotiations had failed and that the Serbs were to blame. But some negotiators said it was the Bosnian Government that had raised the final objections. Later, however, the same officials reported some progress in the talks, although no one was either claiming victory or predicting defeat.
"The last two days have been the diplomatic equivalent of a roller coaster ride," Carl Bildt, the former Swedish Prime Minister who is negotiating on behalf of the European Union, said in a telephone interview. "There have been times when I was dead certain we were there and times I was certain we had failed."
The State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, denied reports from the Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, that the peace talks had collapsed, telling reporters that Mr. Christopher would continue his efforts to reach an agreement.
"The talks have not broken down," Mr. Burns said. "They are ongoing. We're into extra innings, and when you're in extra innings and you think you have a chance to succeed, you don't give up at the last moment."
But other officials involved in the talks said the more time that passes, the more remote the chance that the three Balkan Presidents -- Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia, Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia -- would sit down at a table in the Hope Conference Center at the Air Force base and initial the final documents and maps before they go home.
Early this morning, it seemed as if there might be an agreement. Negotiators said that at 4 A.M., the Serbs and Bosnians appeared to have resolved the most difficult issue that divided them: the width of a crucial 30-mile-long passage, known as the Posavina corridor, linking Serbian-held eastern Bosnia with its territories in the northwest, around the city of Banja Luka.
But the agreement quickly began to unravel, and the Balkan parties exchanged bitter recriminations about who was to blame.
According to a senior Bosnian official, the tentative deal fell apart when the Serbs issued new demands, insisting on more land in the corridor and other bits of territory to insure that its side got a full 49 percent of the country's territory as they had been promised.
Bosnia was also furious that the United Nations Security Council was poised to suspend its crippling trade sanctions against Serbia as soon as the Serbs initialed a peace agreement, the official said.
The Bosnian Government wanted written assurances from the United States that it would arm and train the Bosnian Army as soon as an agreement was reached -- a pledge the United States refused to give.
But a senior negotiator blamed the Bosnian Government for recoiling from a peace that required it to relinquish claims to nearly half of Bosnia's territory. Indeed, while the stated goal of the peace talks is to lay the foundation for coexistence among the peoples of Bosnia, it would not force them to live together, but require 60,000 NATO troops to insure that they are divided.
"It is no longer a matter of territory," the negotiator said. "It is a matter of political will."
The negotiations were further complicated today when Serbs and Croats got into a fierce argument over the fate of a small pocket of Croat-held land lining the Posavina corridor, northwest of the town of Brcko. The Serbs want to control the so-called Orasje pocket in order to make more secure their access to Banja Luka, the biggest Serb-held town in Bosnia.
But the Croats today refused to give up the territory, and President Clinton called Mr. Tudjman, the Croatian President, this afternoon to urge him to resolve the remaining territorial problems, a White House official said.
Coming just a few days after Serbs and Croats appeared to settle their last territorial differences, the dispute underscored just how volatile the issues are and just how deep the distrust is in an area where bitter fighting was raging only weeks ago.
If the initiative fails, it means that the three parties will have lost what the Americans had called the "last best chance for peace" in a war that has claimed more than 200,000 lives.
The Clinton Administration had brought the full force of American prestige to the bargaining table, parading a series of Cabinet officials and generals to Wright-Patterson Air Force base here to pressure the parties to reach a peace agreement.
Mr. Christopher is so personally involved in the process that he has made four trips to Dayton since the talks began, and a State Department official said the Secretary would be spending the night in Dayton. Even President Clinton was poised to fly into Dayton today if his presence could have brought the talks to a successful conclusion.
But the Bosnians did not yet seem ready. And the Serbs appeared unwilling to go along with a partial success that would not secure their main aim: relief from the international economic sanctions that have crippled their economy for the past three-and-a-half years.
Mr. Burns said that if the talks fail, there will be a number of options available to the parties. He did not elaborate.
The failure of the talks also would raise the possibility that the diplomatic gains already agreed to since the beginning of September could be lost, and called into question the future of the cease-fire, which began on Oct. 10 and is scheduled to last only 60 days.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1166 words

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Dow Conquers 5,000 Mark, Riding Surge of Confidence

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average moved decisively past 5,000 yesterday, adding another notch to one of the most extraordinary bull markets in history. The move came less than nine months after the market's most widely watched index passed 4,000 for the first time.
After flirting with the number for several days and briefly piercing it on Monday, the Dow jumped 40.46 points, to 5,023.55, with much of the gain coming in the final hour of trading. 
 The latest surge in the market has been helped by falling interest rates, quiet inflation and rising profits, as well as by one of the hardiest markets ever. And it has been fueled by an unprecedented flood of money going into stock mutual funds.
Although the market had a history of at least pausing after hitting a new millennium mark, it did not do so after hitting 4,000 and most on Wall Street believe that continued rises are all but inevitable.
"At these prices, investors are paying for 1995 earnings, but not paying much for 1996 earnings," said Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-head of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs. Like many on Wall Street, she thinks the economic cycle has a long way to go.
Byron R. Wien, the chief United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley, said, "Bull markets are destroyed by the Federal Reserve tightening, as are economic expansions." But now, he said, the Fed is likely to ease as soon as a final deal is reached on the Federal budget.
Mr. Wien thinks that long-term interest rates, which have fallen sharply this year after rising in 1994, could go back up a bit, holding down future gains in share prices. He is forecasting a 10 percent rise in the Dow over the next year, a move that seems tame both in comparison with what has happened -- the Dow is up 37 percent since last Thanksgiving -- and with many other forecasts.
"We easily go to 6,000 from here," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, the chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company. He cited both the economic outlook and "the level of confidence" that investors feel in financial assets.
That confidence level may never have been greater, in part because bad experiences in the stock market have been rare in recent years. Not since 1990 has the Dow fallen more than 10 percent from a high to a subsequent trough, by far the longest such period in the history of that average.
In fact, the level of bullish rhetoric now heard makes a forecast of 6,000 seem tame. Edward E. Yardeni, the chief economist of C. J. Lawrence, is talking about "10,000 by 2000" -- a doubling of the Dow within five years.
"Many of the same trends that brought us from the depths of the 1987 crash to where we are today are likely to continue to work to push the stock market even higher," Mr. Yardeni said in an interview. "I'm impressed by how well the U.S. economy has adapted to new economic forces unleashed by the end of the cold war."
Mr. Yardeni cautions that -- notwithstanding the steady ascent since the market fell in 1990 when Iraq invaded Kuwait -- "the business cycle has not been repealed." He predicts that early in 1996, profits for many companies will be below the levels of a year ago, and says there might be a full-fledged recession as well. If so, he thinks the major stock averages could fall 10 percent or 15 percent.
Charles I. Clough Jr., the chief equity strategist at Merrill Lynch, is also worried about earnings, saying they "could be the Achilles' heel of this stock market." He says it is clear that many companies are having trouble raising prices for what they sell, and therefore may have trouble showing rising profits.
"The market has to deal with these earnings problems," he said. "But I can't make a case for any serious pullback here." He said the overall market might stall for a time, but added, "If the economy is really weak and the Fed starts to ease, we haven't seen the highs of this bull market."
To some, there are already signs of the market stalling for a time. Technology stocks, which were the stars of most of 1995, have started to weaken. And the Nasdaq composite index, weighed down by technology shares, fell 4.48 yesterday, to 1,024.99, leaving it 4 percent below its peak, reached more than two months ago.
There is a tradition of the market stalling either just before or after reaching a new millennium. The legendary example was the first, when the Dow neared 1,000 in 1966, only to fall back and not exceed the level until 1972. Then it fell back again, and did not top the mark for good until late 1982.
It took nine months from the time the Dow first approached 3,000 for it to surpass that level, and then the market stalled again; it was eight months later that the Dow traded under that figure for the last time. And the Dow fell back after nearing 4,000 in early 1994 and did not get back to that level until this past February. But then it tarried only two weeks in that area before surging ahead.
The exception to the rule of pausing was when the Dow went over 2,000 in early 1987. It did not pause for even a day. But later that year came the crash, and it was not until Feb. 23, 1989, that the Dow last closed under 2,000.
If earnings start to fall for many companies, it will be interesting to see how well stock prices hold up. For among traditional valuation measures, only those that relate prices to earnings do not show extreme overvaluation.
But measures based on things like dividends or book value show extremely high valuations for stocks. For example, before this year the dividend yield on the Standard & Poor's 500 -- the income from all the stocks in the index -- had never gone below 2.6 percent -- a level that was reached both before the 1973-74 bear market began and before the 1987 crash. Now it is at 2.3 percent.
"This is a temporary new era from a valuation standpoint, just like 1929 was," said Steven C. Leuthold of the Leuthold Group in Minneapolis, one of the few market seers still focused on such valuation measures. He has been negative on the market since early 1994, and has missed a lot of profits as a result. "This is the most treacherous market I've seen, and I've been in the business for 34 years," he said.
And what will change it? Only a change in public attitudes, he said, noting that mutual fund cash flows were running at unprecedented levels, with $36 billion going into American stock funds in the third quarter of the year.
In the meantime, this is a market that is rewarding shareholders and -- especially -- the founders of companies that have a hot story to tell. Boston Beer, the maker of Sam Adams beer, went public yesterday at $20 a share. Many insiders were among the sellers at $20, but that did not stop eager investors from bidding up the shares to $28 -- a price that is almost 100 times annual profits. That level can be seen as a forecast of rapid growth, or it can be viewed as an indication that lots of people are leaping into a hot stock, assuming it will go up even more.

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: THE OVERVIEW;
ACCORD REACHED TO END THE WAR IN BOSNIA; CLINTON PLEDGES U.S. TROOPS TO KEEP PEACE

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The presidents of three rival Balkan states agreed today to make peace in Bosnia, ending nearly four years of terror and ethnic bloodletting that have left a quarter of a million people dead in the worst war in Europe since World War II.
The leaders -- Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia, Franjo Tudjman of Croatia and Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia -- initialed the peace agreement and 11 annexes in a hastily-arranged ceremony in the same conference room at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base where they opened their talks 21 days ago. 
 The agreement is to take effect when it is formally signed by the parties in Paris in mid-December.
Unlike previous peace accords that have collapsed, this one was reinforced by widespread fatigue of a war that has uprooted two million people from their homes and appalled the world with scenes of harrowing atrocities, and by the promise of enforcement by 60,000 NATO troops. President Clinton, hailing the agreement in a White House Rose Garden ceremony, reiterated his pledge that the NATO force would include 20,000 Americans.
"The agreement is a victory for all those who believe in a multi-ethnic democracy in Bosnia," said Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who spent several exhausting days brokering the final details of the accord. "It offers tangible hope that there will be no more days of dodging bullets, no more winters of freshly dug graves, no more years of isolation from the outside world."
But underneath the self-congratulation of today's ceremony was a grim awareness that the basic questions the parties failed to settle before the war remain: Can Bosnia, with its mutually suspicious populations of Muslims, Serbs and Croats, survive as a single state? What degree of self-government should be given to the Serb minority within its borders? And does Mr. Milosevic have the power to force the Serbs of Bosnia to do what he says?
Today the Bosnian Serb representatives who served in a delegation headed by Mr. Milosevic did not show up for the ceremony to initial the various annexes that affect the Serbian part of Bosnia.
The Bosnian Serbs were particularly upset by the military annexes in the agreement, which they charged essentially made NATO an occupying force, American and European negotiators said.
Under the agreement, NATO will have the right to remove or relocate specific forces and weapons from any location in the country whenever it determines that they constitute a threat to its troops.
The Bosnian Serbs were even more enraged by the map of the capital, Sarajevo, which turned Serb-held neighborhoods over to the Bosnian Government. One American negotiator said that when the Bosnian Serbs saw the map -- which Mr. Milosevic refused to show them until today -- they went "berserk."
"The agreement that has been reached does not meet even the minimum of our interests," said Momcilo Krajisnik, president of the self-styled Bosnian Serb parliament.
The Bosnian Serb pParliament scuttled a peace settlement in the spring of 1993, after the same three presidents signed the so-called Vance-Owen peace plan that divided Bosnia into 10 provinces along to ethnic lines.
But in the antiseptic, fluorescent lit conference room in the Hope Conference Center, the mood was palpably upbeat, as the Balkan presidents took turns at the podium to explain -- in English -- why making peace was important to them.
For Mr. Milosevic, who longs to be embraced again by the West, the war in Bosnia was a merely "civil war" that "should be left to the past." What was important now, he said, was not only peace and understanding but also economic and cultural development. He portrayed himself as a conciliator, saying, "the solutions achieved here include painful concessions by all sides, however; without such concessions it would be impossible to succeed."
For Mr. Izetbegovic, who is determined to preserve Bosnia as a multiethnic democracy, the importance of the agreement is that it guarantees the sovereignty and territorial integrity of his country, he said, as well as the "development of an open society based on tolerance and freedom."
In announcing the agreement earlier in the day, President Clinton said, "The people of Bosnia finally have a chance to turn from the horrors of war to the promise of peace." He added, "Something stirred among the leaders themselves and they decided that they should not let this moment pass."
But it also means that he now will have to make good on his pledge both to the allies and to the Balkan nations to send American troops to Bosnia as part of the NATO-led force.
The agreement calls for the preservation of Bosnia as a single state. But it also divides Bosnia into two almost-equal parts, with one side controlled by a Muslim-Croat federation and the other by a Serb republic.
The plan also envisages a central government with an elected president and parliament, the return or compensation of refugees, the separation of Bosnian and Croatian troops on one side and Serbian troops on the other, and the reconstruction of the country. But it is not at all clear how a government made up of enemies who only recently have put down their arms will function.
The capital, Sarajevo, remains united -- a key demand of the Bosnian Government -- but some eastern suburbs, including the Bosnian Serbs' headquarters in Pale -- are to remain under Serb control.
The agreement also leaves unresolved the fate of Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the two Bosnian Serb leaders who have been indicted by an international war crimes tribunal.
Although the agreement prohibits any indicted war criminal from running for office, it does not meet the initial demand of the Bosnian Government that Mr. Milosevic turn the two men over to the United Nations-sponsored tribunal.
The agreement is to be followed by actions by the United Nations Security Council. One would suspend trade sanctions that have crippled the Serb economy in the last three-and-a-half years. Secondary sanctions, like a ban on Serbia's membership in the United Nations and access to World Bank loans, would remain until the Serbs showed compliance with the peace accord.
Another Security Council resolution would gradually lift the arms embargo on the six republics of the former Yugoslavia, beginning 90 days after the agreement is signed. The embargo is believed to have handicapped the Bosnian Government during the course of the war against the better-armed Serbs.
But while the embargo is to end, the rivals agreed today to temporarily forswear arms purchases.
Each side is to retain its own army. Throughout the talks the Serbs refused pleas by the negotiators to give up their heavy weapons, and the Bosnian Government was unable to get a side agreement with the United States pledging immediate American help in arming and training its army.
In a news conference after the ceremony, European negotiators, who will be responsible for organizing a plan to reconstruct Bosnia, stressed that success depends on how the agreement is put into effect.
"These agreements are not self-implementing," said Pauline Neville-Jones, the head of the British delegation. Even Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American negotiator, warned that on every page of the agreement "lie challenges to both sides to set aside their differences," which he called "raw and open wounds." He added: "On paper we have peace. To make it work is our next and our greatest challenge."
Until this morning, there was no deal and the rollercoaster, marathon talks seemed doomed.
At first, the sticking point seemed to be the width of a 30-mile-long passage linking Serbia with the Serb-held territory in northwestern Bosnia, around Banja Luka. Last night the United States thought a deal was near, after the Serbs agreed to the Bosnian demand that the corridor be no wider than three miles.
At 10 P.M. Mr. Christopher went to the Bosnian delegation with a last, take-it-or-leave-it offer.
"If you can agree we have a final agreement and we can initial a peace," he told them. "If you don't, these proceedings are going to have to be suspended."
He said he needed their answer at 11:30 and went to bed. By that time, the Bosnians had no answer. Mr. Christopher called Mr. Clinton, told him he wanted to suspend the talks and went to bed.
About midnight the Bosnians issued a new demand -- control over the town of Brcko in northern Bosnia, which is currently under Serbian control and is in the middle of the corridor linking the Serbs' Bosnian territories. By morning there was no accord. The defining moment came after all three presidents agreed that the issue of Brcko could be resolved by a still-undetermined method of arbitration over the next year.
The first tangible sign that the deal was complete was a gesture as the ceremony opened. On the first day, Mr. Christoher did not shake the hand of Mr. Milosevic, who is widely blamed for starting the war. Today he did -- twice.
It was a personal achievement for both Mr. Christopher and Mr. Holbrooke, and the result of an extroardinarily complicated negotiating process in which the United States brought together the three Balkan presidents and their delegations and negotiators from Britain, France, Germany and Russia.
It also represented the evolution of Mr. Christopher's own thinking. Even before he was confirmed as Secretary of State, he was skeptical that diplomacy could bring peace to Bosnia. But he later came to the conclusion that the only way for the parties to make peace was if the United States seized control of the negotiations from the Europeans and pressured all the parties.

GRAPHIC: Photos: SERBIA -- Slobodan Milosevic, President; BOSIA-HERZEGOVINA -- Alija Izetbegovic, President; CROATIA -- Franjo Tudjman, President; UNITED STATES -- Warren Christopher, Secretary of State. (Reuters)
 
Map/Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: The Dayton Accord: A Peace Agreement for ther Balkans"
The settlement is a compromise amongconflicting aims. For the Muslim-dominated government of Bosnia, it affirms the legal integrity of the country and restores the unity of the capital, Sarajevo. The Serbs get -- if not the separate state they want -- a semi-autonomous republic. The Croats secure their national borders and will be able to nurture ties to Croats within Bosnia.
An elaborate governmental structure is spelled out, involving a central elected presidency and parliament presiding over two entities -- a Bosnian-Croat Federation, and a Serb Republic. Some issues, such asthe fate of Bosnian Serb leaderswho have been indicted as war criminals, are not fully addressed. The agreement does not take effect until it is formally signed, expected in Paris in mid-December.

 The Final Disputes

 Sarajevo: The Serbs wanted some parts of the city to be part of the new Serb Republic; the Bosnian government wanted and won a unified, open city, the symbolic heart of the unified nation it seeks.

 Serbian corridor: The Serbs wanted a wider corrider around the town of Brcko, linking the Serb-held areas of eastern Bosnia with the city of Banja Luka. This will be decided by arbitration.

 Path to Gorazde: The Bosnian government regains control of a swath of land linking Sarajevo with now-surroundedGorazde, strengthening its presence in the east.

 War criminals: People indicted by the international tribunal cannot hold elected office. The governments pledge to cooperate with the tribunal but are not explicitly required to arrest indicted people, who include top Bosnian Serb leaders.

 The Broad Outlines
 
Territory
The Bosnian-Croat Federation will control roughly 51 percent of the land, the Serb Republic 49 percent. Some areas of current control are given up by each side.

Constitution and Elections
A constitution creates a central federal government with a group presidency, a two-house legislature, a constitutional court and a central bank. The two sub-entities, the Bosnian-Croat Federation and the Serb Republic, will each have their own presidents and legislatures as well. Officials at all levels are to be chosenin internationally supervised elections next year. How much power the central government will have, in practice, over the Serb Republic is a major question.
 
Military Pull-back
Parties must withdraw forces behind agreed cease-fire lines within 30 days, with demilitarized zones along the lines. All heavy weapons and forces will withdraw to barracks areas within 120 days. Arms imports to all sides are temporarily halted and negotiations will begin on numerical limits for heavy weapons and combat aircraft.

Peacekeepers
 Current United Nations forces will withdraw and be replaced by a peacekeeping force under NATO command, headed by an American general. The force will monitor the cease-fire and control the airspace. It will be "an active, robust force capable not only of implementing a peace agreement but also of defending itself vigorously."

 Refugees
 Displaced people will have the legal right to reclaim their homes or receive compensation. All parties will respect basic human rights and a commission will investigate violations.

 Next Steps

 The United Nations will lift the arms embargo against all states of the former Yugoslavia. Trade sanctions against Serbia will be suspended, but limits remain on its participation in international organizations.
 The peace agreement will be formally signed in Paris in December, after which a NAT0-led force, including some 20,000 American troops, will enter Bosnia to police the settlement. (pg. A10)
 
"HIGHLIGHTS"
 
TERRITORY Bosnia would maintain its current borders, but be divided into two entities -- a Bosnian-Croat federation and a Bosnian Serb republic.
 
 A central Government, with a parliament and presidency, would remain in a united Sarajevo.
 
 WAR CRIMINALS Would not be allowed to hold office, but no requirement to arrest them was specified.
 
 TROOPS Forces would be withdrawn to agreed positions and an international force sent in to keep the peace. NATO has outlined a plan for a 60,000 member force-- one-third of it American -- to act as peacekeeper.
 
 REFUGEES Would have the legal right to return home; human rights would be monitored by an independent commission. (pg. A1)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Tentative Pact Allows Enron To Continue Project in India

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
A regional government of India tentatively agreed yesterday to let the Enron Corporation go ahead with a $3 billion power plant project, signaling that India will probably continue to embrace, however hesitantly, the foreign investors it so desperately needs.
The state's nationalist Hindu leaders had scrapped the plant, the nation's largest foreign project, in August, but lately had softened their opposition in the face of legal threats and the country's huge power needs. 
 The reversal could relieve other investors who, following the case intently, were asking whether the world's second most populous market justified the aggravation and risks.
Manohar Joshi, chief minister of Maharashtra state, told reporters in India that Enron and a panel appointed by his government had agreed to reduce the costs of the project and of the electricity produced. Negotiators were discussing a possible $300 million cut in the plant's total cost to allow an 8 percent reduction in initial electricity charges. Enron and the Maharashtra State Electricity Board had already agreed, at least in principle, for the board to buy at least a 30 percent stake in the project, but neither side said whether the sale would take place.
Enron, which is based in Houston and is the largest natural gas company in the United States, was invited into India by Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao, whose national Government guaranteed the project's fulfillment. But newly elected Maharashtra politicians accused Enron of padding the project's costs by more than $700 million and corrupting politicians to win high electricity rates without competitive bidding.
The attacks on Enron cast doubt on India's four-year-old commitment to economic change and openness after decades of socialist self-reliance. India has become one of the few emerging Asian markets where American companies have bounded in ahead of Japanese competitors, with Clinton Administration officials regularly leading groups of executives there.
Yesterday's agreement, by a three-member panel of experts, must still be approved by the Maharashtra Cabinet, which expects to act by Dec. 10. Until then, Enron has agreed to suspend an arbitration case in London in which it hoped to recover at least $300 million in expenses, and as much as $2 billion including lost profits.
The Maharashtra government faced a crucial arbitration meeting in that case this Friday in London. Although legal experts call Enron's arguments strong, they note that foreign companies sometimes take decades to collect from agencies or corporations in India. Enron's costs for mothballing the project with only its foundations in place amounted to $250,000 a day.
The state's leading Shiv Sena Party eventually reconsidered its opposition, and began formal negotiations with Enron less than two weeks ago. However, a dispute with a large minority party in the governing coalition could still block the Cabinet's approval. That party, the Bharatiya Janata, plans to challenge Prime Minister Rao next year.
Despite the political discord, Ronald J. Barone, who follows Enron for Paine Webber, said that the state government was likely to back the project and that Enron would still enjoy attractive returns.
The power plant, on the rocky coast of the Arabian Sea 100 miles south of Bombay, Maharashtra's capital, is meant to supply more than 2,000 megawatts of power to a nation where industries have to generate their own power, operate at night or face chronic brownouts and blackouts.
Among the terms being negotiated was whether the first $990 million phase of the plant, to be completed in 1997, would be fed by fuel oil, probably imported, or by India's own naphtha. The next phase, costing $2 billion under the initial plans, would be fueled by liquefied natural gas that Enron plans to import from Qatar.
Enron, fearful of irritating India's officials, refused to say much more yesterday beyond blandly confirming the agreement. "We are pleased with these developments and believe we have reached a mutually beneficial settlement," said Diane Bazeledes, a company spokeswoman.
Jagdish Bhagwati, a Columbia University trade specialist who was born in Bombay, said the Enron case should alert American investors to avoid deals that seem too friendly. The lack of competitive bidding and boasts by American officials of the benefits they had won for American companies gave Indian nationalists an inviting target, he said. "It was a boil that had to come up and be lanced," as he put it.
Diplomats said that several foreign companies had delayed or reconsidered their investments until the resolution of Enron's problems. Enron's deal brought cheer especially to CMS Energy, which threatened to pull out of two Indian power projects worth a total of $800 million if politics killed the Enron plans. "To the extent they've been able to reach an agreement to keep that project going, we view that as a positive," said Kelly M. Farr, speaking for CMS, the parent company of one of Michigan's largest utilities.
Mr. Rao initially made the Enron project the leading example of his nation's new desire to attract foreign capital and to start catching up with rapidly modernizing Asian neighbors. Since 1991, India has won only about $2 billion in foreign investment, less than China draws each month.
But as elections next spring approached, nationalist politicians derided the Enron investment as evidence of Mr. Rao's plans to sell India off to foreign exploiters. Nationalists have also staged protests against the Indian operations of Coca-Cola, McDonald's and Pepsico's Kentucky Fried Chicken, whose first restaurant in India was briefly closed by local authorities in September.
Enron owns 80 percent of the Indian project, with Bechtel Enterprises and GE Capital, the General Electric Company's finance arm, splitting the rest. Enron, which would continue to own the plant with its partners, has a contract to sell electricity, with rates tied in part to the plant's costs. The company has wanted to reduce its share of the project, but it is unclear whether the Maharashtra state electricity board can raise the money to invest.

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: IN BELGRADE;
For Milosevic, a Chance at a New Lease on Political Life

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Nov. 21

 BODY:
President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, who presides over an economy in a shambles, a state that has been internationally branded as a pariah and a populace exhausted by war, will return to Belgrade carrying the one thing he hopes will keep him in power: a signed peace agreement.
"The war is finally over in Bosnia-Herzegovina," Mr. Milosevic said in remarks broadcast from Dayton, Ohio. "It is now time for all to turn to peace, reconstruction and economic recovery." 
 Mr. Milosevic told Serbs that the Balkan peace agreement meant that sanctions would be lifted against the truncated Yugoslavia, opening the road to "economic development."
The Security Council is expected to consider suspending sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro and lifting the arms embargo on all former Yugoslav republics.
And some of the President's fiercest critics acknowledged his accomplishment and said they feared its success would strengthen Mr. Milosevic's grip on power.
"Milosevic's dream of restoring Communism is not over," said Vuk Draskovic, an opposition leader. "Now that this deal is signed the biggest problem we face will be how to stop Milosevic from consolidating his totalitarian state."
Despite his triumphant tone, the last four years have been devastating for Mr. Milosevic and the Serbs. He was largely responsible for the war that led to the dissolution of Yugoslavia, the death of more than a quarter of a million people and the economic sanctions. And he has serious problems with a recalcitrant Bosnian Serb leadership, on whose behalf he negotiated, and who he must now cajole into abiding by the agreement.
Defending the deal, Mr. Milosevic said talks were long, but had given the Serbs a fair share of territory. And he said the division was better for the Serbs than a previous peace plan drawn up by the major powers.
"Everyone has now forgotten that Milosevic started the war," said Dusan Jaksic, a 30-year-old engineer. "What is important is that he ended it."
The 54-year-old President could call for new elections as early as next spring, diplomats say. He faces no real opposition, and the lifting of the sanctions will prove a potent weapon in his hands.
But the decision by Mr. Milosevic to push the Bosnian Serbs into this agreement is also a gamble, especially if they defy him, as they have in the past. Mr. Milosevic could also face growing unrest from workers who called a series of strikes around Belgrade last week, if the moribund economy does not begin to improve.
The President's toughest battle when he returns will be with the Bosnian Serb leadership. Government-run news outlets in Belgrade said today that the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, and the military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, had agreed to resign in exchange for assurances that they would not be handed over to an international war-crimes tribunal.
The President intends to force the two men out of power soon after returning to Belgrade, Western diplomats said. But the two Bosnian Serb leaders said they would remain in their posts. And the Bosnian Serbs, many of whom dislike the agreement, say they are in no mood to follow dictates from Belgrade.
"What they should do with Milosevic is hang him from the nearest tree," said Mico Kovacevic, a soldier in the Bosnian Serb army, who is in Belgrade visiting friends. "There will never be peace here. There is too much hatred on both sides."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sarajevo residents closely followed the peace talks. Hospital patients, refugees from an area under Serb control, watched President Clinton. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Solectria Says Car Passed Crash Test

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
An advanced electric car with a body made of composite materials has passed the Federal crash test for head-on collisions, according to its manufacturer.
The development is significant not only for the company, Solectria, of Wilmington, Mass., which hopes to mass-produce the cars, but also for the three major American car companies, which are cooperating to design a high-mileage, low-pollution car, one that is likely to be made of composites. 
 The car, a four-passenger sedan called the Sunrise, broke a record in May when it went 238 miles on a single charge, in the Tour de Sol, an annual electric car race in the Northeast.
The car, which has twin air bags, passed the standard 30-mile-an-hour head-on test, Solectria said. "This full frontal crash test demonstrates that a comfortable high-performance electric vehicle comprised wholly of composite materials can provide a high degree of passenger safety," Mark Dockser, Solectria's vice president of planning and business development, said in a telephone interview. Mr. Dockser said the composite body had "consistent and predictable" results in tests on the components and on the whole vehicle.
Ford, Chrysler and General Motors, in partnership with the Federal Government, are trying to develop a "next-generation vehicle" that would achieve a fuel economy of 80 miles per gallon of gasoline, or its equivalent in other fuels.
Robert M. Chapman, the chairman of the partnership's technical task force, said today that passing the crash test was "a very positive accomplishment."
The partnership, which was formed two years ago and is still choosing which technologies to invest in, is seeking a 40 percent reduction in the weight of a midsized vehicle, he said, and "we recognize that to do so, we're going to have to go to some advanced materials." Composite materials are usually made of strands of glass and carbon fiber that are embedded in a plastic or metal matrix.
The Sunrise weighs 1,800 pounds, which is 500 pounds less than Solectria's previous car, an electric version of the Geo Metro called the Force. The Force, which has a steel body, carries three people and goes less than half as far as the Sunrise.
The Sunrise falls short of the goals for the next-generation vehicle, but appears to be creeping up on them. The Big Three want to see a car that goes from 0 to 60 miles an hour in 10 seconds, but the Sunrise, which is engineered for range, takes a sluggish 18 seconds. The next-generation car is supposed to go 380 miles on the highway on a single charge -- an optimistic estimate of the range of a midsized car today -- compared with about 238 miles now for the Sunrise.
But the 80-mile-per-gallon or equivalent goal has been met. The Sunrise carries an electrical equivalent of less than two gallons of gasoline, meaning its mileage exceeds 100 miles a gallon. And while some safety tests remain to be done, including tests on the defroster, Solectria believes the safety standards are well within reach.
The next-generation car is also supposed to cost about the same as a conventional car. Solectria believes that with enough orders -- about 20,000 a year -- it can produce its Sunrise competitively. But that depends on further cuts in the cost of batteries.

HEADLINE: Republicans Look to a Governor Who Stood Firm

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 21

 BODY:
As John M. Engler prepared to run for his second term as Governor of Michigan two years ago, his pollsters, relieved to see Mr. Engler's approval ratings rebounding from dismal lows, started asking voters what animal he brought to mind.
Some politicians might have hoped for "thoroughbred horse" or "golden retriever." But the voters delighted Mr. Engler's staff by suggesting creatures like "badger" -- not because of Mr. Engler's build, but because of his determination. 
 "It was, 'Man, if he says he's going to do something, you better get out of his way,' " said David B. Hill, Mr. Engler's pollster.
As they drop in the polls and await the next election, Speaker Newt Gingrich and many other Republican lawmakers take heart from Mr. Engler's example. The Governor, who fulfilled promises to cut taxes and state programs, was overwhelmingly re-elected last November. And Republicans say the lesson from his comeback is this: Whatever their short-term disapproval, voters will ultimately reward politicians who deliver on promises.
But Mr. Engler, with a four-year term, had twice the time as first-term Representatives for his policies to pay off. He also focused on a few issues, like welfare, whose beneficiaries, the poor, do not have much political influence. Congress, with its proposals to overhaul Medicare, the Federal health care program for the elderly, risks alienating a more powerful group.
Mr. Engler's critics and some independent analysts also say he was fortunate to preside over a booming state economy.
Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., the Florida Republican who heads the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Human Resources, said he had spent "countless hours" cnsulting with Mr. Engler on changing the welfare system. Mr. Shaw said the Governor's experience had shown that "the people will like you if you do the right thing and continue to do it and don't worry about the polls."
"He really did have a massive turnaround in the polls," Mr. Shaw added. "That man was dead meat for a while."
But Mr. Engler had four years to achieve his turnaround.
William S. Ballenger, editor of Inside Michigan Politics, a nonpartisan newsletter, said, "It's very obvious what the big difference is, and that is two years versus four years, or, you could say, one year versus three years."
The advantage of a longer term also applies to first-term Governors like George E. Pataki of New York, who has three years to turn around his flagging approval ratings.
Mr. Pataki, who hired Mr. Engler's budget director, is pursuing an agenda similar to Mr. Engler's.
"A lot of the things we're trying to do in New York, Governor Engler has been successful doing in Michigan," said Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman.
But Mr. Ballenger noted that in addition to time Mr. Engler also had superb timing.
"Whether he had a lot of luck, or a lot of skill, or a good measure of both -- and frankly I think it was the latter -- everything seemed to gel for him at exactly the right time last year," he said.
For Mr. Engler's staff, one of the grimmest moments was a meeting in November 1991 at which the pollster Mr. Hill told Mr. Engler that 40 percent of the voters "strongly" disapproved of him and 15 percent "somewhat" disapproved. Only 31 percent approved.
"It was the most depressing meeting I ever sat through," said John Truscott, the Governor's press secretary. While other polls showed Mr. Engler hitting different low points at different times, state analysts agree on his overall political trajectory. "By the end of '91 and into '92, he had tremendously low ratings," said Bernie Porn, president of EPIC/ MRA, a polling firm.
Having inherited a $1.8 billion debt, Mr. Engler eliminated the Department of Licensing and Regulation and cut 20 boards and commissions. He also eliminated a program that gave grants to unemployed adults without children, and in his first two years reduced the state payroll by about 5,000 positions, or more than 7 percent.
Less than a year into Mr. Engler's first term, television reports showed people being thrown out of low-rate hotels, attributing the evictions to state welfare cuts. An "Englerville" of tents sprouted on the Capitol lawn.
In surveys, Mr. Hill said, voters were describing the Governor as "mean, no account, doesn't care about anybody."
But rather than try to soften his image, Mr. Engler and his staff turned his perceived toughness into an asset, refusing to back down on his cuts. And Mr. Engler took another calculated risk by pushing for a reduction in the property tax, coupled with an increase in the sales tax, to change the state's approach to financing public schools.
Apparently because voters did not believe that property taxes would actually go down, Mr. Engler lost two referendums on versions of his financing plan. But after tinkering with the formula to broaden its appeal, he won overwhelming support for the measure in its third appearance on the ballot, in March 1994.
Later that year, with the state running a surplus and voters relishing the property tax cut, Mr. Engler ran for re-election on a slogan of "Promises Made, Promises Kept" and walked away with 61 percent of the vote. His approval ratings have remained high.
Mr. Engler owes some popularity to an economy that he, like other governors, has little control over. His tax and spending cuts came as the auto market strengthened. During that grim meeting in 1991, the state unemployment rate was 9.5 percent; last month, it was 4.4 percent, the lowest in at least 25 years.
In an interview, Mr. Engler said that in demonizing Republican policies Democrats were making the same mistake nationally that they had made here.
"Things started to change for us in 1992 as people began to see that the scare tactics that had been used just literally months before didn't come to pass," he said. "It's a little like now, when you've got the White House and the Democrats in Congress scaring old people."
Mr. Engler argued that voters would approve of the Republican Congress for sticking with its program. "We had a lot of people saying, 'He's doing what he said he would do,' and that's exactly what you can say about this Congress," he said. "That's a powerful thing, at a time when there's a great cynicism about people in public office."
But it is not certain that Congress can expect that accolade. Mr. Engler's critics argue that those most hurt by his policies -- the poor -- lack political influence. Republicans in Congress risk alienating more politically powerful constituents, the elderly. And while Mr. Engler focused on a few issues, Congress could be judged on everything from cutting agricultural subsidies to rewriting lobbying laws.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. John Engler of Michigan, at lectern, rebounded from dismal poll ratings early in his first term in part by keeping his word to cut taxes and trim state government. It is a message that he and political analysts say Congressional Republicans should keep in mind. Mr. Engler and Speaker Newt Gingrich appeared at a news conference yesterday during a meeting of Republican governors in New Hampshire. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises vs. Yen and Mark; Trading Quiet Before Holidays

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday in quiet trading ahead of holidays in the United States and Japan.
Some market participants said that they expected wrangling over the United States budget and economic crosscurrents to keep the dollar in narrow ranges for the rest of the year. 
 "We're in a real quiet zone here for the dollar," said Karl Halligan, strategic currency trader for CIC Bank New York.
On Monday, the dollar rose in early trading after a temporary spending agreement was reached between Congress and the Clinton Administration, but fell back as market participants realized arduous negotiations for a balanced budget were ahead.
The dollar bounced back yesterday, and currency traders viewed the move as a continuation of the dollar's up-and-down pattern within tight bands. In the last two months, the dollar has traded in ranges of 97.50 to 104.14 Japanese yen and 1.3810 to 1.4440 German marks.
"The budget thing being pushed off into December makes it difficult to do anything on the dollar," said Richard Koss, currency strategist for MFR Inc., a money management and consulting firm.
Bruce English, manager of institutional currency sales at ABN-Amro Bank in Chicago, predicted that the dollar would trade in ranges of 1.38 to 1.44 marks and 98.50 to 104.50 yen until the end of the year.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 101.47 yen from 101.35 yen on Monday. The dollar also rose to 1.4076 marks from 1.4067 marks, but fell to 1.1369 Swiss francs from 1.1375 Swiss francs. The British pound rose to $1.5580 from $1.5539.
Financial markets will be closed tomorrow in observance of Thanksgiving Day, while the market in Japan will be closed for Labor Thanksgiving Day.
In other trading yesterday, the Canadian dollar surged along with Canadian bond prices after a leader of Quebec's secession movement, Lucien Bouchard, said he would run for premier of the province and would not call for a referendum on independence until at least 1997. Quebec separatists narrowly lost a referendum on independence on Oct. 30.
"We have addressed a major source of political uncertainty here," said Michael Gregory, a fixed-income analyst with Lehman Brothers in Toronto.
The Canadian dollar rose as high as 74.22 United States cents before retreating. It settled at 73.92 United States cents, down from 73.98 cents on Monday.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Securities Are Weaker

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices weakened yesterday as market participants, faced with additional new supply, squared their positions ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday.
Prices were hurt in part by retail sales data that suggested that consumers were stepping up their buying as the holidays approached. The market was also weighed down by the Treasury's auction of new 10-year notes. While the $13.5 billion sale drew strong demand, some traders and analysts said the results were not as impressive as Monday's auction of three-year notes. In any case, prices are typically weaker when there are auctions as the market braces to absorb the new supply. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 10/32, to 108 /32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.26 percent, from 6.24 percent on Monday. 
 The market shrugged off the day's first retail sales report. The Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim chain store sales index for the week ending Nov. 18 showed a gain of one-tenth of 1 percent. Analysts said the gain represented a slight rebound from a depressed pace in October.
Later in the day, however, the more closely followed Johnson Redbook report surprised market watchers, showing a 2.2 percent gain in retail sales for the first three weeks of November. Many market participants had expected sales growth to ease below 2 percent.
With Congress away until next Monday, negotiations over a balanced budget and debt ceiling extension will not begin in earnest until next week, so the market had only the auction and retail data to focus on yesterday.
At yesterday's auction of new 10-year notes, which marks the conclusion of the Government's quarterly refunding, the average yield at auction was 5.90 percent. It was the lowest yield since Feb. 9, 1994, when the yield was 5.92 percent.
The Treasury is expected to anounce at noon today the size of next week's two- and five-year note auctions.
Activity usually quickens ahead of a Treasury auction as yields rise when dealers and traders lower prices trying to make the new issue more attractive to investors and make an easy sale to clear old inventory from dealers' shelves.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst with Chase Securities, said the market was dealing with the supply, and that the absence of fresh numbers would keep it on hold.
Trading is expected to be light today, ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday. The Public Securities Association has recommended that the cash market close early today, at 2 P.M. The cash and futures markets will be closed tomorrow and will reopen on Friday.
Today, the University of Michigan survey of consumer confidence in November will be released.
In futures trading, analysts said the December bond futures contract was approaching a critical level.
Robin Mesch, a fixed-income analyst with Thomson Research of Boston, said 117 22/32 to 117 17/32 was a major barrier of resistance "and today we were down to 117 10/32 at the close."
"I expect a fight at between 116 20/32 and 117 20/32, with the winner taking all," she said.

HEADLINE: New Buyer Being Sought For Coliseum

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
After more than a decade of pitched neighborhood battles, court fights, environmental studies and last-minute deadlines over the fate of the New York Coliseum, the state and city have now decided to turn the clock back to 1984 and look for a new buyer for the valuable Columbus Circle site.
Yesterday, Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of New York State's economic development agency, announced that the state, the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the Coliseum, would issue requests for new development proposals before the end of the year. 
 "We are open to a variety of possibilities," Mr. Gargano said. "We would consider any project that would provide the most value for the M.T.A., the city and address the interests of the surrounding community."
The decision marks a significant reversal on the part of the M.T.A. Ever since a deal with Mortimer B. Zuckerman to create a huge retail and residential complex there fell through, the transit agency and the Giuliani administration have feuded bitterly over the future of the Coliseum.
While city officials wanted to look for another buyer -- a process that could take months, if not years -- the M.T.A. argued that it should lease the building as a way of generating quick income.
And not only is the agency changing its financial goals, it also seems to be relinquishing its role as the lead agency in determining the fate of the Coliseum.
Mr. Gargano said the involvement of his agency was a reflection of Gov. George E. Pataki's continuing interest in turning some government functions over to private enterprise. "Gov. Pataki is looking toward privatization wherever possible," he said. "We want to put a sharper focus on the effort to determine the best use for the development of the site."
But it is also a reflection of the political realities in Albany. The transportation authority is now run by a Pataki appointee and close associate of the Governor, E. Virgil Conway. His predecessor, Peter E. Stangl, had staunchly resisted efforts by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to press for a sale of the property, particularly at a time when real estate prices were depressed.
Mr. Conway did not respond to telephoned requests for comment yesterday. But in a written statement he expressed support for the initiative and seemed comfortable with his agency's secondary role in the matter.
"For far too long, the Coliseum has been a political football and the subject of endless feasibility studies," Mr. Conway said. "The time for studies has ended. The time for action is now. The Coliseum will be developed and Columbus Circle and all of New York will benefit."
John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for economic development, also said the Giuliani administration welcomed the state's involvement. "We very much want it back in private hands," Mr. Dyson said. "Much more reasonable minds are running the M.T.A. now, which will help keep the focus on development."
Mr. Gargano said the terms of the requests for proposals for the redevelopment of the Coliseum had not been finished, and he said he would be willing to consider proposals for only portions of the site, like just the Coliseum itself, or just the adjacent office tower. In addition, he said officials would also consider a long-term lease.
But Mr. Dyson said the city still believed it would benefit most from some type of convention facility on the site. While Mr. Dyson said that a convention center was not stipulated in the request for proposed uses, he added that, "Our economic study plainly shows that the city would best be served from the taxes, hotel and entertainment uses generated by a convention center."
The announcement that officials would seek new bidders is only the latest in a tortuous series of moves and countermoves that began when the M.T.A. first put the Coliseum up for sale in 1984. At the time, the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center was under construction, and officials felt that the Coliseum's business was certain to fall off sharply once it was built.
After an intense struggle among several developers, Boston Properties, headed by Mr. Zuckerman, was awarded the development contract, agreeing to pay $455 million. But after a series of court challenges and after the stock market crash of 1987, the proposal was scaled back considerably. But even that was not enough to save the proposal, and it collapsed in acrimony in the summer of 1994.
That the Coliseum has been the subject of intense and emotional interest from neighborhood groups, public officials and private developers is understandable. Occupying a 3.4-acre parcel near the southwest corner of Central Park at 59th Street, a new development could offer spectacular views of the park and midtown Manhattan. The property's development potential resides in both its proximity to Central Park and its position as the gateway to the Upper West Side, one of the city's most popular residential neighborhoods.
But no matter what sort of project emerges with the support of the state and city, any development would still face intense scruitiny from community groups and be subject to the required public review process.
In announcing the plan to seek developers, city and state officials referred to the recent revival of Columbus Circle and the development on the Upper West Side.
Directly across the street, Donald J. Trump, the developer, in partnership with General Electric is redeveloping the former Gulf and Western building. Mr. Trump is transforming the former office building into a combination hotel and apartment building. Near Lincoln Center another development company, Millennium Partners, is completing a mixed-use project including offices, shops, a movie theater and apartments.
While the city, state and M.T.A. for the first time in years appear to agree on what to do with the Coliseum, not all city officials were pleased with the renewed efforts to develop the property.
Ronnie Eldridge, a city councilwoman whose district includes the Coliseum site, said she feared that the state's involvement would make it more difficult for people in her community to have a say in project's future. "I am stunned by the abruptness of this move," Ms. Eldridge said. "I regret that they did not talk to us before making the announcement. Many of us had hoped to be part of any comprehensive plan for the use of the Coliseum and Columbus Circle."
Ms. Eldridge said she believed the initiative to put the Coliseum back on the market was a reflection of budget shortfalls for both the city and the state. "Both the city and the state are facing such severe gaps," said Ms. Eldridge, who supported plans for an interim use of the Coliseum, "that we are in a race to control those items that will bring in as much revenue as possible."
The Giuliani administration has been pressing for a sale because of the jobs new construction would create and because a new development would send a message that the city's economic recovery was under way. The M.T.A. argued that it would be more lucrative to lease the building for 10 years or more for quick revenue and wait for the real estate market to recover. After the deal with Mr. Zuckerman fell apart, the agency considered proposals ranging from a television studio to a roller-skating rink to retail stores.
After months of wrangling over the fate of the Coliseum, last spring the city and the M.T.A. appeared to have found common ground on the issue. Based on a report by city economists showing that a successful convention center could earn up to $30 million in taxes and create 10,000 jobs, the city and the M.T.A. agreed to reopen the Coliseum as a convention center.
Last month, the Coliseum resumed full operation and is booked well into the early part of next year.

HEADLINE: Talking, Thinking, Cooking Turkey;
When Menus Are Long and Time Is Short, Stress Is Served

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
For Barbara Anne Livingstone, the days before Thanksgiving have been filled with premonitions of disaster. Her second-worst fear: that she will neglect her 24-pound turkey for mere seconds and burn it to ashes. Her worst: that she will not clean it properly, and sicken her husband and their seven guests.
"This is my first Thanksgiving," said Mrs. Livingstone, 30, of Butler, N.J., a relatively new homeowner who has little experience with large poultry. "I want it to be memorable, but not that way." 
 For Arline Tarte, the days have been filled with a sense of blessed relief. In previous years, Ms. Tarte, who lives on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, would return home from long hours at the office and cook past midnight for a party of 20. This year, she has hired a chef to come to her apartment and do it for her.
"I can relax, sleep late and not look harried and exhausted," said Ms. Tarte, 53, an executive with a printing company. "What a pleasure."
Around the New York region this week, people readied themselves for a holiday with a famously long menu and notoriously complicated family logistics, but perhaps no two of them committed themselves to the same level of fussing, and perhaps no two felt the same excitement and apprehension.
For some, Thanksgiving promised to be a reminder of the bounty in their lives: a large family, close friends, the means to spread out a lavish and sumptuous smorgasbord. For others, it was a sad reminder of their loneliness or poverty that held out the possibility of a brief respite from deprivation in the form of a turkey handout.
Janet Burgos, who stood on a long line outside a food pantry in Manhattan yesterday, said she had not yet devised a Thanksgiving menu for herself, her husband and their four children, because it all depended on what was in the bag of free groceries she would soon receive.
"I've already spent all my food stamps for the month," said Ms. Burgos, 33, who lives two blocks from the Yorkville Common Pantry, on the border between the Upper East Side and Harlem.
Ms. Burgos said she would love to invite relatives over, or to cook something special in addition to a turkey. "I've always wanted to make lamb roasts the way I've seen them on TV, with the little paper bows," she said.
But she and her husband are both unemployed, so Ms. Burgos arrived at the pantry promptly at 9 A.M. yesterday so she could be near the head of the line and lay claim to one of the biggest birds.
A few dozen blocks to the north and south, streets and stores buzzed with different kinds of holiday activity. On the Upper East Side, patrons filed into William Greenberg Jr. Desserts to fetch one of the hundreds of boxes of pumpkin and apple pies stacked in tall, leaning towers. In Harlem, Thora Seeley, 53, came away from an open air produce market on 137th Street with a plastic bag of collard greens that weighed 16 pounds and was more than half as large as Ms. Seeley herself.
Although she is not the host for her family's celebration in the South Bronx, she said she always makes the collard greens. She usually buys them at the same place and follows the same recipe, using plenty of smoked pork and a small amount of vinegar.
"I'll wake up at 5 A.M. on Thursday to do it," Ms. Seeley said in a tone that hovered between harried and proud.
Sleep deprivation and the burden of upholding a traditional Thanksgiving menu were common themes among those shouldering the responsibilities for cooking.
"At Christmas, you can fudge a little bit," said Maria Nunes, 31, a corporate image consultant who lives and works in Manhattan. "This is a little more complicated, because there are things people expect, and it's not Thanksgiving without them."
Five years ago, when Ms. Nunes's mother died, she and her older sister, a professor at Columbia University, inherited the holiday cooking chores for the family, even though both women work 60-hour weeks.
They now have it down to a science. Yesterday, Ms. Nunes's sister faxed a menu and list of recipes to their father in Milford, Conn., so he can do the shopping today. Tonight, Ms. Nunes will arrive by train in Milford at 10:30, inspect the groceries, run out to an all-night store to remedy any mistakes and then bake until at least midnight.
Her sister will join her on Thanksgiving morning to prepare the turkey, stuffing and mashed potatoes for a dozen other family members. It's an endeavor exhausting enough that the Nunes sisters have prodded their father to take cooking classes.
"We've started to mutiny," Ms. Nunes said.
Andrew Bergh, a 33-year-old waiter and playwright in Manhattan, has negotiated a different route out of the kitchen. Although he is supposed to bring a dessert for his family's celebration in Armonk, N.Y., he said, "I'm not above buying a cake and putting it in some Tupperware and saying it's mine."
In terms of scale, nobody was preparing like the Salvation Army. The organization expects to serve Thanksgiving dinners to 3,000 people at its headquarters in Manhattan on West 14th Street. The grocery list is staggering: one to one and a half tons each of turkey, stuffing, mashed potatoes and kernel corn; 1,000 pounds of cranberry sauce; 250 apple and pumpkin pies.
A more unusual kind of preparation unfolded early this week at the Catholic Migration Center job training site in Brooklyn, where 10 immigrants learning to be chefs received a lesson on this holiday's menu.
The instructor, Carl Esposito, had to digress when one student quizzed him about the meaning of Thanksgiving. Mr. Esposito spoke of Pilgrims and Native Americans, religious persecution and corn on the cob, then moved on to the fine points of oven temperature and safeguards against bacteria in a turkey.
When he finished, a student from Poland innocently asked: "Why bother?"
Mrs. Livingstone, a receptionist at an insurance company, has an answer for that. As soon as she and her husband, a postal worker, bought their first home a year ago, she set her sights on making this Thanksgiving as her debut as a host, a baptism by fire. But first, she and her husband had to do something about their stove, which was too small to cook a decent-sized turkey.
A new stove arrived last week. Mrs. Livingstone said she hoped it would be a charm for the first turkey she has ever roasted.
"My sister said to me, 'Call me as soon as you get up that morning and I'm going to tell you everything you have to do, step by step,' " Mrs. Livingstone said. "I think she's a little afraid."
 
Designing Dudley
 Among the familiar faces that will appear in Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade tommorrow, there will be three new ones. One has scales, a goofy grin and a cute little dental problem - Dudley the dragon, the star of a children's show on PBS. Here is a look at how Dudley was brought to life.
 
1. Sketches Are Made
At an unassuming warehouse in Hoboken, designers study the character and produce a number of sketches, with the emphasis on capturing the personality of the character.
2. A Clay Model Is Made
Clay is applied to a steel frame to produce the first three-dimensional model of the balloon.
3. Fiberglass Model
A mold is made of the clay sculpture. The mold is then used to make a fiberglass model at a scale of half an inch per foot. This model is painted for realism.
4. The Fabric Is Cut and the Balloon Constructed
Fabricators at another factory cut panels for the balloon from a very strong, rip-resistant, flash-coated urethane fabric to make 16 air chambers. The panels are then heat-sealed and the completed balloon is sent back to the studio in Hoboken.
5. Finally, the Balloon Is Painted
The balloon is brought to the center of a large three-story room, inflated and painted using the fiberglass model as a reference.
6. Inflating the Balloon: Air vs. Helium
Air is combined with 10,500 feet of helium to inflate the 13,000-cubic-foot balloon. The mixture varies chamber by chamber to help the balloon stand up straight. The lower chambers of hte balloon are virtually all air to keep the balloon stable.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Confidence in Economy Drops

BYLINE: By SUSN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The business community's confidence in the state economy has declined from last year's eight-year high, according to a survey released yesterday by the New Jersey Business and Industry Association.
Only 56 percent of the survey's 2,000 respondents -- mostly small-business owners -- said they believed the state's economy was expanding or recovering, compared with 78 percent of respondents last year. The survey was mailed to association members in September. 
 "In terms of economic growth, 1995 wasn't a barn-burner and 1996 isn't likely to be one either," said Joseph P. Gonzalez Jr., the association's executive director. "The message from this survey is: slow growth ahead."

HEADLINE: Clinton Neglected Promises on Economy;
A Promise He Kept

 BODY:
To the Editor:
William Safire, my favorite conservative columnist, surely knows better. In his Nov. 16 column he wrote: "On taking office in 1993, the previously centrist Clinton made a surprise 'lurch to the left,' raising taxes and proposing new spending." 
 Candidate Bill Clinton was the most liberal Democratic nominee since 1972. He repeatedly promised to raise taxes on the wealthy. (That promise appears four times in the first 15 pages of the campaign book "Putting People First.")
He also promised dramatic new investments in infrastructure (remember high-speed rail?) and education. "Putting People First" promised $50 billion a year in new investments. Mr. Clinton virtually ignored that great "centrist" obsession, the deficit; he was content to abandon that issue to the also-rans Paul Tsongas and Ross Perot.
Once President Clinton was in office, as Bob Woodward has detailed in his book "The Agenda," he made a surprising "wrench to the right."
He surrounded himself with deficit hawks like Lloyd Bentsen and Leon Panetta, who persuaded him to abandon the investment strategy and instead cut spending to reduce the deficit. The 1993 budget contained over $200 billion in spending cuts, but less than $10 billion in "investments."
Mr. Clinton did fulfill his promise to raise taxes on the wealthy, but, fearful of antagonizing Wall Street, he failed to highlight that fact in his public campaign for his budget. Mr. Woodward recounts that the political adviser Paul Begala was apoplectic at Mr. Clinton's failure to emphasize the tax on the rich -- for good reason: A March 1993 poll showed that 82 percent of Americans supported the idea of raising taxes on the wealthy.
Mr. Clinton paid a fearful political price for his rightward turn. The public, who find the deficit a boring and confusing issue, gave Mr. Clinton no credit for reducing it. A November 1994 Newsweek poll showed that most Americans incorrectly believed that the deficit had gone up during Mr. Clinton's turn. And, since Mr. Clinton failed to emphasize that he was taxing the rich, Republicans managed to deceive two-thirds of Americans into believing that the middle class, rather than the rich, had borne the brunt of "Clinton's tax increases."
 
STEVEN NOVICK
Washington, Nov. 17, 1995
 
The writer is a senior attorney in the Justice Department's environmental enforcement section.

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW;
Double A Trio And the Music Debates

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
In a recent interview in Guitar World magazine, Robert Fripp explained the epiphany that led him to reform his influential art-rock band, King Crimson, as a double-trio (two drummers, two guitarists, and two people playing the Chapman stick, which combines guitar and bass). It occurred when he was driving down a street with a school on the left and a church on the right. Here were two institutions intrinsic to human history but also teaching lessons that conflict with each another.
On Monday night at the Longacre Theater, in the first of a series of five concerts that concludes on Saturday, King Crimson worked toward reconciling conflicting musical styles. In past incarnations of the band, which formed in 1969 and regrouped this year after a decadelong hiatus, this meant melding improvised and composed music using blues-rock, modal jazz, early-20th-century classical music and electronic technology. 
 But as a double-trio, each pair of players came to embody a dialectic. Mr. Fripp sat stiffly in the dark at the back of the stage, navigating his guitar with an extreme economy of hand and arm movement, while Adrian Belew stood in the spotlight in front of him, producing the sounds he wanted from his guitar with flashy moves like warping the neck and punching the strings. On percussion, Pat Mastelotto played like a slightly ambitious rock timekeeper while Bill Bruford complicated the sound with a repertory of jazz and avant-garde frills and flourishes. And on Chapman stick, Trey Gunn played rogue and rookie to Tony Levin's large arsenal of techniques and instruments. When building their mannered progressive-rock, they no longer seemed to be using divergent styles, but rather to be working together to create a smooth, linear sound with pointillistic playing.
Since it last performed in New York in June, the band has become much more fluid, and has grown comfortable with the songs on its new album, "Thrak" (Virgin). The instrumental "Vrooom," with Mr. Fripp's beautiful computer-processed guitar picking, and the languorous "Walking on Air," with Mr. Belew abandoning his arty squawk for Bryan Ferryesque smoothness, held up to older songs like "Elephant Talk" and "Frame by Frame."
In the new "Dinosaur," a wry comment on King Crimson's old-timer status, one could hear the sound of Adrian Belew's pick striking his guitar strings with a dry, brittle crack. But what came out of the speakers was digitally altered into a lush, orchestral string sound. This ability to turn simple and ordinary and into the erudite and unusual made Monday's concert a welcome return.
