HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW;
A Money-Mad Mirage From Scorsese

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
Of all the bravura visual effects in Martin Scorsese's dazzlingly stylish "Casino," it's a glimpse of ordinary people that delivers the greatest jolt. Strategically timed to offset three hours' worth of vintage Las Vegas glitter, it's a reminder that Mr. Scorsese has given this film's setting the surreal and breathtaking intensity of a money-mad mirage. The real world looks shockingly impoverished by comparison.
With its rivers of cash and mountains of neon, its high rollers and lowlife hoods, "Casino" luxuriantly explores the anatomy of America's gaudiest (and now most cinematically popular) playground. The place is quagmire enough for an epic morality play, but this film's tone is staunchly journalistic, as borne out by its matter-of-fact last words: "And that's that." 
 So "Casino," based on reportorial work by Nicholas Pileggi, comes equipped with the liabilities of investigative journalism: no conveniently sharp focus, a plot built like a centipede and characters with lives too messy to form conventional dramatic arcs. But the material unearthed by Mr. Pileggi also features truths much stranger than fiction, wildly histrionic showdowns, intricate mob trivia and people whose Faustian conniving and obsessive fury fit perfectly into the Scorsese canon. Mr. Scorsese has been here and done this already in "Goodfellas," but not with his new film's blistering bitterness or its peacock extravagance. The long, astonishing Copacabana sequence in "Goodfellas" was only a warm-up for this.
Mr. Pileggi, Robert De Niro and Joe Pesci, all "Goodfellas" alumni, are back in familiar capacities, joining Mr. Scorsese to do what they do best. But "Casino" also has a new ingredient in Sharon Stone, who will be nobody's idea of Hollywood fluff after this spectacular, emblematic performance. As Ginger McKenna, a gorgeous hustler who falls from the ranks of Vegas's royalty to its lowest depths, she represents the full range of this film's stark extremes. Like all the film's principal characters, Ginger is a renamed and slightly modified version of the woman described in Mr. Pileggi's book. But her most crazily extreme behavior is true to his account.
"Casino" is chiefly about a gambling prodigy -- called Sam (Ace) Rothstein in the film -- who supervised a thriving hotel casino in its glory days. More number-cruncher than swaggering mobster, Ace was fastidious enough to regulate the number of blueberries in his restaurant's blueberry muffins. When it came to the showgirls in his nightclub, he kept track of their exact weight without, it seems, even bothering to ogle.
So Ace depended on the mad-dog energies of his vicious best friend, Nicky Santoro -- at least until Nicky became a menace. "We made a great pair," Ace recalls in the voice-over, which is one of the film's bolder moves, since one of the two narrators turns out to be speaking from beyond the grave. "I made book, and Nicky made sure we always collected."
From those simple beginnings, with Mr. De Niro and Mr. Pesci cast ideally as Ace and Nicky, "Casino" spins a gigantic web. It outlines the intricacies of casino cheating; the complex financial structure linking casino profits to mob bosses in Kansas City; the greased-palm etiquette ruling all Las Vegas, from its politicians to its valet parkers; the Federal investigation that had Ace and Nicky dodging surveillance planes, wiretaps and lip-readers, and even the blinding peculiarities of local fashion and interior decor.
Outlandish and yet becoming, the flashy 1970's costumes are a movie in themselves thanks to Rita Ryack and John Dunn, who show off Ms. Stone to traffic-stopping effect and find Ace more colors than there are in the rainbow. Costume and character are well linked, as when Ace sits in his office in a shirt, white socks and turquoise loafers, keeping his turquoise pants on a hanger unless company appears. Meanwhile, Dante Ferretti, a long way from "The Age of Innocence," contributes wonderfully witty and affectionate production design.
Sometimes the film overloads its audience's capacity to absorb arcane schemes or fiscal data; sometimes it takes off on abrupt tangents. Occasionally it seems repetitive, but most of it is agile and enveloping, economically packing in a wealth of detail.
In a town where even marriage is a business deal, Ace makes a gambler's proposal to Ginger: "Wanna take a chance?" She responds in kind, demanding jewelry from Ace without abandoning an old boyfriend whom the film slyly calls Lester Diamond. Played with suitable sleaze by James Woods, Lester is described by Ace as "a moocher, a card cheat, a country club golf hustler chasing dentists for a few bucks." Even this film's many minor figures are sharply drawn.
Lester, Nicky, booze, greed and hubris all contribute to the breakdown of Ace and Ginger's marriage, culminating in a riotous, terrible meltdown that makes for one of the most scorching episodes Mr. Scorsese has ever filmed. "Casino" depicts some savage gangland violence (most of it brief), but its chief viciousness is reserved for the domestic arena. Look elsewhere for moral lessons or warm, fuzzy accounts of true love.
"Casino" doesn't do as much as it might have with the tale of Ace and Ginger's merger, which shares the whole film's taste for gleaming surface over inner depth. But it does know why Ace's first sight of Ginger, on a black and white surveillance camera scanning the casino, is enough to stop him cold. At pivotal moments, the film's terrific pop score (supervised by Robbie Robertson, ranging from "Stardust" and soul to the Rolling Stones and Devo) delivers just the right ironic commentary on the action. At Ginger and Ace's wedding, "What a Difference a Day Makes" says it all.
 
"Casino" is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It includes frequent profanity and several quick but graphic violent episodes involving beatings, a stabbing and a head caught in a vise.

HEADLINE: Classic Holiday, Anyone?

 BODY:
THE average Thanksgiving dinner at home this year will include 12 people and will cost $8.79 a person. The favorite pie will be pumpkin; the most popular side dish, mashed potatoes.
Those findings are part of a study, the Lenox Report, commissioned by Lenox Brands in Lawrenceville, N.J., a manufacturer of china, crystal and gift ware. 
 The report is based on a nationwide telephone survey of 1,000 adults. It also revealed that nearly all planned some kind of Thanksgiving celebration, virtually half of these events at home.
And if they travel, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration warns, overeating, which induces drowsiness, is as dangerous for drivers as drinking.
As for ideas for leftovers, Martini & Rossi, the vermouth company, will have home economists ready to answer questions on Friday from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Eastern standard time, at (800) 972-2784.

One thousand adults were queried ina national telephone survey conducted from Oct. 13 to 19 by a U.S. Consultants in Media, Pa.

HEADLINE: Pilgrims Wear Different Hats In Recast Thanksgiving Tales

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
Plymouth Rock and the Mayflower were nowhere to be found in the Thanksgiving story that Kate Seid read to her fourth-grade class at Public School 87 on the Upper West Side this week.
Instead, there was a band of "strange-looking people" who landed a "big airship" in a family's backyard and proceeded to ransack their house, cut down their trees, kill their pets and take tomatoes from their garden. 
 Across town at P.S. 6 on the Upper East Side, Rebecca Applebaum's first graders heard another Thanksgiving tale about boat people who fled a tropical dictatorship and braved a perilous journey to become refugees in America.
"The story shows how anyone can be a Pilgrim," Ms. Applebaum said. "A lot of people came to America because they weren't free in their country to believe what they wanted to believe."
In schools in New York City and across the country, Thanksgiving is getting a makeover, as teachers recast the Pilgrim-and-Indian story to reflect the political and cultural sensibilities of the 1990's. In some cases, as in the allegory about the aliens, the lessons veer sharply from traditional American history to cast the European settlers as selfish trespassers. In others, as in the refugee tale, teachers are cleaving to the original interpretation but seeking to put a history lesson in a contemporary context.
Just as Christopher Columbus has been transformed in many classrooms from brave explorer to false hero, the Thanksgiving holiday is being reconstructed, even celebrated differently. Feathered headdresses and pointed black hats are out in some schools, while others make sure such costumes are only one part of the celebration. Harvest festivals and multicultural feasts are in. Depending on the teacher, the Pilgrims have been likened to tree-cutting aliens, emigres from oppressive countries or pioneers who worked with the Indians to plant and harvest crops.
Experts on history are wary that some of the creativity may lead to distortions. "It's nice to give Thanksgiving some cultural relevance," said Kenneth C. Davis, the author of "Don't Know Much About History" (Crown Publishers, 1990). "It's important to make contemporary parallels. But let's not throw out the real history either."
Across the country, the Thanksgiving story is increasingly being taught as an immigrant story, an invasion story, a cultural-exchange story or some combination of the three, said James R. Giese, executive director of the Social Science Education Consortium in Boulder, Colo., a national organization that trains social studies teachers and develops curriculum. The best schools "are trying not to look at it as good guys, bad guys," he said, but are emphasizing the complexity of the relationship between the Pilgrims and the Indians.
The New York City Board of Education does not take a position on the Thanksgiving story, but trains teachers that "you have to look at things like this from many different perspectives," said Barbara Gerard, assistant director of multicultural education.
Three years ago, the principal of P.S. 150 in Sunnyside, Queens, began to feel that the traditional version of Thanksgiving held little meaning for a school with immigrants from 75 countries.
"We did some research and found out that a lot of countries have harvest festivals that happen more or less around this time of year," said the principal, Gloria Guzman. "And then, going back and rethinking the whole Thanksgiving piece, we decided that was also a celebration of the harvest. We try to emphasize the Pilgrims as pioneers, and we talk about the how the Indians helped the Pilgrims plant vegetables."
So now, on the day before Thanksgiving the school's first graders hold a harvest festival and bring in food from their native countries. Classes learn about Thanksgiving alongside harvest rituals from South America, Asia and Africa.
Schools are also increasingly defining Thanksgiving as a time to help the homeless, the elderly, the sick and other people in the community. Food banks and other programs say donations are up this Thanksgiving from schools.
"What we'll do is celebrate it as part of a community, but not take time from the curriculum to sort of stop and study Thanksgiving," said Frank DeStefano, the principal of P.S. 41 in Greenwich Village, which held both a food drive and a coat drive this year. Mr. DeStefano was momentarily dismayed this week when he saw a kindergarten class making Indian headbands.
"I thought, 'Oh no, are they doing Indians for Thanksgiving?' " Mr. DeStefano said. "But it turned out it was actually a follow-up to a trip" to the National Museum of the American Indian.
Some elementary school classes, especially for the older pupils, talk about Thanksgiving mostly in the context of regular social studies courses, like a fourth-grade lesson about immigrants or a third-grade class on world cultures. For second graders at P.S. 6 this week, Thanksgiving discussions were supplemented with an exercise in another piece of 17th-century American history, a Dutch Day, in which children pretended to be in New Amsterdam with Peter Stuyvesant-era costumes, dunce chairs and horn books.
But some schools are sticking with tradition.
At P.S. 42 in Far Rockaway, Queens, where 95 percent of the students are African-American, Hispanic or both, children still dress up as Pilgrims and Indians, said the principal, Juanita Bass. The school stays away from interpretations that depict the Pilgrims as interlopers because "we consider that one of the negatives of history and we like to emphasize the positive," she said.
Mr. Davis, the author, said he worried that some of the new Thanksgiving stories may lead to actual distortions of history, swinging from the traditional glorification of the white settlers to the romanticization of the Indians.
Schools that paint the Plymouth settlers as political refugees, for instance, are not entirely right, he said. Only half the passengers on the Mayflower were Pilgrims who were persecuted for their religious beliefs; the others were economic opportunists called Strangers, he said. Rather than treating the main characters as either good or bad, he added, history suggests a "tremendous amount of cooperation and peacefulness between the Indians and the Europeans."
Do the various modern interpretations of Thanksgiving sink in with children?
Leila Tamari, a 6-year-old at P.S. 87, seemed to get the message this week, as she and other first graders baked pumpkin pies for homeless and elderly people.
"Thanksgiving means to be happy and glad and healthy and careful, and you got to care for another people, not just yourself," Leila said. "I pray for the homeless people and the sickness people."
But in Ms. Seid's fourth-grade class, the impact was a little murkier. When she reached the end of her story, at which the aliens announced they were staying put in the backyard and invited the bewildered homeowner to a celebratory feast, she explained that the homeowners represented the American Indians in this allegory.
"Here you are living in your homes with your pets, your vegetables, your trees and your stream and somebody comes and starts killing your pets, eating your vegetables and cutting down your trees," Ms. Seid said. "I want you to think about that and how you would feel."
Dzavid Pjetrovic raised his hand.
"Well," he asked, "what kind of pets were they?"

HEADLINE: Budget Bill, Following Tradition, Offers Its Share of Tax Oddities

SERIES: The Fine Print -- A close look at G.O.P. tax plans.

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
As long as the United States has had tax laws, politicians have twisted them for political reasons. The very first such law, approved by the First Congress, levied a tax on Jamaican rum -- not so much because the Founding Fathers wanted to discourage drinking the demon rum but because they wanted to give an advantage to the Kentucky bourbon industry being developed by the Rev. Elijah Craig.
There was no exception this year in the way the Republicans handled the tax sections of the big budget legislation that Congress approved this week. 
 The way the capital gains provision was written, it would cost the Treasury billions of dollars in lost revenue every year after 1996 except one. The only exception is 2002, not coincidentally the year Congress has promised that the budget would be balanced. In that year, according to calculations by the Congressional tax staff, the cut in the capital gains tax would miraculously increase Government revenues by $1.5 billion.
Another anomaly is that taxpayers would get the first benefit of the $500 tax credit for each child next October, just before the election, and not in April when tax returns are normally filed. No matter that this would cost the Internal Revenue Service an extra $300 million to process the additional forms.
Here is still another oddity: Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, maintains that more than three-fifths of the tax cuts would go to families with incomes below $75,000. The Treasury Department figures that about three-quarters of the benefits would go to families with incomes above $75,000. Both sides have figures to back up their claims.
Take the capital gains question first.
The budget bill would make two main changes in the way individuals must pay taxes on capital gains, which are the profits from the sale of investments. First, for all stocks and bonds and other property sold after Jan. 1, 1995, the maximum tax rate would be reduced to 19.8 percent from 28 percent. The new rate would be the lowest since the Eisenhower Administration.
Then, beginning in 2001, the purchase price of the property, for tax purposes, would be adjusted for inflation. Thereafter, taxpayers would have to pay capital gains taxes only to the extent that their profit exceeded the inflation in the economy over the period the property was held.
Taxpayers who want to take advantage of the inflation indexing after 2001 without selling their stock (or whatever else they own) would be permitted to pay a tax that year on their capital gains that have accumulated since they made their investments. From then on, the cost of their property would be adjusted annually for inflation.
In terms of lost revenue for the Government, according to the staff of the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation, the capital gains provisions would lose $2.7 billion in the 1997 fiscal year, $6.8 billion in 1998, $7.5 billion in 1999, $8.2 billion in 2000 and $8 billion in 2001.
Then, in the 2002 fiscal year, it would raise $1.5 billion in additional receipts.
After that, the revenue loss would mushroom: $10.5 billion in 2003, $12.2 billion in 2004 and so on.
The reason for this anomaly (first brought to light by Iris J. Lav, a tax specialist at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research institute) is that investors who wanted to take advantage of indexing would pay the additional taxes on their accumulated gains in April 2002 when they filed their tax returns for calendar year 2001.
This would give the Government a one-time-only increase in revenues of about $10 billion in the 2002 fiscal year. As Ms. Lav observed, "Most of these revenues simply represent taxes the Federal Government would have collected anyway in subsequent years, when the assets actually would be sold."
But without the extra revenue, the estimates would show a budget deficit in 2002, the year the Republicans in Congress have promised a balanced budget.
Ari Fleischer, the spokesman for the House Ways and Means Committee, said that the timing was purely coincidental. Mr. Archer "wanted nothing more than to maintain indexing from the first day," Mr. Fleischer said.
"When it became clear that as a result of the various changes made to all aspects of the budget package, we could not afford it from the beginning," Mr. Fleischer said, "he acquiesced in putting it into effect at the earliest possible date."
On the matter of the family tax credit, the measure would give couples with incomes up to $110,000 and single parents with incomes up to $75,000 a $500 tax cut for each child under 18. But the budget writers decided that this would be too expensive for the Government if it were fully effective this year. So they decided it would go into effect for one-quarter of the year, as of Oct. 1, 1995, and that the credit in the first year would be $125 for each child.
Under the bill, the I.R.S. would be instructed to send taxpayers a notice of the credit next February and to send them the form and instructions in June. Taxpayers would have to file for the credit by August, and a refund based on the credit would be paid in October 1996.
This means that taxpayers would get their refunds just before the 1996 election. It also means that the cost would be shifted to the 1997 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, 1996, keeping the budget for the 1996 fiscal year from being way out of whack.
When this odd procedure was approved last week, Mr. Archer and other lawmakers said the reason was that the I.R.S. would not be able to handle the change on the regular tax forms for 1995, which are already printed and due next April 15. But this turns out not to be the case.
In a letter sent on Tuesday to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Margaret Milner Richardson, wrote: "Neither the Senate nor the House formally asked the I.R.S. how best to implement the credit. If the I.R.S. had been consulted, I can assure you that we would have strongly encouraged Congress to use the normal Form 1040 return filing process to implement the credit and thus minimize the burdens on both taxpayers and the I.R.S."
Mrs. Richardson calculated that the procedure Congress devised would cost her agency $308 million in additional mailing and processing expenses.
On the question of who would be the main beneficiary of the new measures, Mr. Archer said last week that 61.1 percent of the dollar value of the tax breaks would go to taxpayers with incomes from $30,000 to $75,000 and that 80.2 percent would go to those with incomes below $100,000.
"Middle-income Americans will emerge as big winners," he declared.
Then this morning, at a breakfast meeting with reporters, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said that most of the tax break would go to the wealthy. He released tables showing that 66.5 percent of the dollar value of the tax breaks would go to taxpayers with incomes above $75,000 and that 47.5 percent would go to those with incomes over $100,000.
Who is right? Where you stand depends on how you count.
The main difference is that Mr. Archer's data are based on the first five years the bill would be in effect. The Treasury figures are based on the benefits when the bill was fully effective, which in some cases would not be until the next century. The provisions involving capital gains and individual retirement accounts would become especially expensive down the road with most of those breaks received by upper-income taxpayers.
Other differences involve the way benefits from capital gains and the earned income credit are figured.
Also, the Treasury calculates that 12.1 percent of taxpayers have incomes over $100,000. Congress puts it at 6.2 percent. The reason is that their definitions of income are quite different.
But that's another story altogether.

The Fine Print
This series of occasional articles examines less-noticed facets of Federal legislation, laws and regulations.

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: THE PLAY-BY-PLAY
21 DAYS IN DAYTON: A special report.;
In U.S. Eyes, 'Good' Muslims And 'Bad' Serbs Did a Switch

BYLINE: The following article is by Elaine Sciolino, Roger Cohen and Stephen Engelberg. 

 BODY:
The wine was drunk and a lavish lobster dinner eaten, and it was time to resolve one of the most delicate issues in the Bosnian peace talks: a route for the Bosnian Government from Sarajevo through Bosnian-Serb territory to the beleaguered Muslim enclave of Gorazde.
President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia made his way to a high-tech auditorium to play Powerscene, the Pentagon's computer mapping program that reproduces terrain on a vast movie screen. The Serbian leader was adamant that the corridor could be no more than two miles wide. 
 Lieut. Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the senior American military official at the negotiations, whisked Mr. Milosevic off on an imaginary aerial tour of the region to show why such a narrow corridor made no strategic sense. "As you see, God did not put the mountains two miles apart," General Clark said.
Mr. Milosevic downed a large whisky, considered this topographical fact, and the deal on a five-mile-wide corridor was consummated. It became known as the Scotch Road.
Throughout the 21 days of talks at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base outside Dayton, from the wary chill of the opening to the sleep-deprived marathon and near collapse at the end, the American negotiators established a remarkable rapport with Mr. Milosevic. The Muslim-led Bosnian Government, which the Americans initially saw as their friend and the victim of the war, ended up not fitting into the fraternal Realpolitik in which negotiators cut through days of stalemate over slugs of whisky.
The Bosnians, convinced after years of Serbian barbarity against Muslim civilians that they were merely defending their homeland, ended up being badgered into agreement. By the end American officials spoke with disappointment and anger of what they saw as the vacillation, internal conflicts and sometimes cynical maneuvering of Bosnian officials.
The only party more isolated than the Bosnian Muslims was the delegation of Bosnian Serbs. Although their cooperation is essential for any peace plan to succeed, they were not shown any of the proposed peace maps until a few hours before the talks ended. Their three representatives in Dayton, kept out of the actual talks because Mr. Milosevic insisted on representing them, mostly say around trying to find out what was going on.
And so, as all the parties left Dayton, the least happy of all were those representing the two largest groups of Bosnians -- the Muslim-led Government, which was deeply uneasy, and the Bosnian Serbs, who felt betrayed.
For four days at the end, arguments raged, nerves were frayed, sleep was scarce. Failure often looked certain. Just hours before an agreement was finally announced, the Clinton Administration drafted a statement explaining a collapse of the talks.
Progressively, the niceties of international intercourse were abandoned. At one point Warren Christopher, the unfailingly polite Secretary of State, started yelling at the President of Bosnia when he accused Mr. Christopher of breaking his word. At another, Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American negotiator, grabbed the Prime Minister of Bosnia by the shoulder after he disappeared for a snack at a critical moment.
In the end, it took the combination of Mr. Christopher and Mr. Holbrooke -- two negotiators with vastly different styles -- to make the agreement happen.
Meetings rooms and corridors became popcorn-littered expanses reeking of stale fast food. Versailles it was not.
The result of this careening enterprise was an improvised settlement that is at once a tribute to the force of revived American diplomacy in the Balkans and an unfinished road map for peace riddled with potential for confusion and conflict.
It is founded on uneasy relationships whose evolution will become a crucial issue as President Clinton tries to convince Congress and the people that 20,000 American troops will have to go to Bosnia to enforce the peace.
The scenario looks potentially menacing: A Bosnian Government lacking any real conviction about a peace it resisted until the very last moment, and potentially restive Bosnian Serbs who were kept largely in the dark about the settlement.
"We have to have the strategic consent of all the parties," General Clark said. "We will not go in as an invasion force." That consent, it is clear, has not yet been secured.
 
The Start
Trying to Dispel The Bitterness
 The tone for the talks was set at the outset on Nov. 1. Despite pleas by Mr. Christopher to discard a bitter past and build a future for the children of the Balkans, all the antipathy and mistrust among Mr. Milosevic, President Alija Izetbegovic of Bosnia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia was evident in the perfunctory handshakes and averted eyes at the opening ceremony.
American officials, led by Mr. Holbrooke, spent much of the first week trying to dispel this tension by creating a convivial atmosphere in the small quadrangle of red-brick buildings where the delegations were housed -- a tactic they used throughout.
At one point, the Americans gave a dinner in the shadow of a massive B-52 bomber at the Air Force Museum at which a military band played Glenn Miller, but not everyone was in the mood. At another, Mr. Holbrooke and Mr. Tudjman worked on a formula for one outstanding territorial dispute between Serbs and Croats for Eastern Slavonia, the last remaining area of Croatia in Serbian hands, between sets of tennis.
At still another, Mr. Milosevic, who started the war, sidled up to the piano in the Officers' Club to sing "Tenderly."
But underneath the veneer of politesse, the American negotiating strategy was clear: First, strengthen the Muslim-Croat federation to present a united front to the Serbs on the critical question of land in Bosnia; then settle the one outstanding territorial dispute between Serbs and Croats to increase the pressure on the Bosnian Government to opt for peace.
And finally, with a mixture of economic blandishments and displays of American power, to persuade all the parties that this was last, best chance to end the barbarity.
But problems were immediately apparent.
Mr. Izetbegovic, a devout Muslim with a distant gaze who was twice imprisoned by the Communists of the former Yugoslavia for leading movements of Muslim protest, kept a reserved distance. He preferred to eat alone; he never talked of the future or economic reconstruction; to American officials, he seemed strangely unmoved by the suffering of his people.
Of course, the Bosnian President felt he was being asked to give away half his country to Bosnian Serbs who had repeatedly massacred and abused Muslim civilians in pursuit of their dream of secession.
American officials, however, felt that the 70-year-old President was missing the point. If peace really took hold, if money poured in, if the West was firmly behind the reconstruction of Sarajevo, then the old divisions might fall away. Rather than losing half of Bosnia, the Bosnian Government might ultimately have a hope of gaining something inaccessible through more war: a unified and multi-ethnic state.
"Izetbegovic was occasionally animated in front of maps, but never before suffering or the prospect of rebuilding his country," an American official said. "He's a very stubborn, very elusive man."
Negotiating with the top Bosnian delegates was further complicated by the fact that they seldom saw eye to eye. Mr. Izetbegovic, Prime Minister Haris Silajdzic and Foreign Minister Muhamed Sacirbey became known as "Izzy, Silly and Moe." Their spats were interminable and often vitriolic.
When an American official suggested that Mr. Silajdzic might constitute the "swing vote" in this shifting cast, a furious Mr. Sacirbey screamed at Mr. Holbrooke, "There's only one swing vote here, and that's the President."
For much of the time the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister would not speak to each other. Occasionally Mr. Silajdzic would disappear for a prolonged sulk. Just what, if any, objectives the three men shared was almost impossible for the American team to assess.
Mr. Milosevic, whose vitriolic nationalism unleashed the Balkan wars in 1991, was the exact opposite.
His determination to get three-year-old trade sanctions on Serbia lifted made him flexible; his taste for drink and hearty meals made him accessible; his utter domination of the Serbian delegation made him, as one person put it, "one-stop shopping."
For much of the time, moreover, he was trading land that was not his but held by the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, a personal rival of Mr. Milosevic. This tended to make the Serbian President unusually amenable, even over issues as complex as Sarajevo, a city, he once confided to one American official, "that Izetbegovic has earned through what happened in this war."
 
The Croats
Resolving the Issue Of East Slavonia
 As for Mr. Tudjman, the Croatian President, he had arrived in Dayton already a victor. Having retaken all but Eastern Slavonia from the Serbs through military conquests over the last six months, he had relatively limited concerns.
His advice from the Administration were clear: honor the nominal alliance with the Muslims in Bosnia and resolve Eastern Slavonia through diplomacy as the price for continuing American support. A man whose shrewd instincts are often underestimated, Mr. Tudjman was ready to oblige.
By Nov. 10, nine days after the conference began, an agreement to strengthen the strained Muslim-Croat federation was ready. It was more theater than substance, since the real issues between Muslims and Croats will be solved only on the ground where mutual suspicion is still rampant after the 1993 war. But it did at least open the way for discussion to turn to the more serious issue of Eastern Slavonia.
Mr. Christopher, on the second of his four visits to the conference, spent most of his time on this question. The conflict between Serbs and Croats had come down to this: Should there be a transitional period of one year, as favored by Mr. Tudjman, or two years, as favored by Mr. Milosevic, before the restoration of full Croatian sovereignty over the Serbian-occupied area.
"Let's call it 12 months of transitional rule, plus a second period not to exceed the first period," Mr. Christopher suggested. That way, the only number the volatile Mr. Tudjman would hear and have to relay to his people was the one he wanted to hear: a single year. Meanwhile, Mr. Milosevic could call it two years.
The two men, whose sparring for territory and hate-filled propaganda propelled Yugoslavia toward disintegration, reviewed the matter for about an hour. Then they came into Mr. Holbrook's suite, sat together on the sofa, and Mr. Tudjman said, "Mr. Secretary, we've solved Eastern Slavonia."
The breakthrough was kept secret until two days later, when it was announced in Zagreb, the Croatian capital. It immediately set an upbeat tone as the talks moved into what officials hoped would be the final days.
When Carl Bildt, the European Union representative, asked Mr. Milosevic about the remaining Bosnian problems after the accord, he waved his arm dismissively. "The rest is nothing," Mr. Milosevic said. "I will take care of it. The war is over now."
This remark reflected the Serbian President's intimate conviction that Serbs and Croats set the terms in the Balkans, while the Muslims are a mere side show. It was thus in 1991, when Mr. Milosevic and Mr. Tudjman agreed to carve up Bosnia. He believed it was thus still in 1995. But three years of struggling to survive had given the Bosnian Government a stubborn new conviction.
 
Sarajevo
Milosevic Ready To Yield the City
 But the negotiations deteriorated rapidly as soon as the talk turned to the map.
When Mr. Christopher arrived Nov. 17 for the final push, nearly all of the most contentious territorial issues remained in dispute, including the status of Sarajevo.
No issue was of greater symbolic importance to all sides. Many of the Bosnian Serb leaders come from Sarajevo. They have never wavered in their insistence that the city be divided, and that the Serbian quarter become capital of a Serbian republic.
And now, on a Saturday night in Dayton, Mr. Milosevic was preparing to give it away. He appeared unannounced at Mr. Holbrooke's room and said, "I was in your neighborhood and did not want to pass your door without knocking." He sat down, and began an intense discussion of how Sarajevo could become a unified city.
The next morning, on Sunday, the Americans decided to set a final deadline of 10 A.M. Monday. If things could not be worked out by then, there would be a news conference announcing why the talks had failed.
Almost immediately, another snag arose. The Americans' high-tech mapping computers showed the Serbs' concessions on Sarajevo and Gorazde had whittled their holdings from 49 percent to 45 percent. Mr. Milosevic told participants that he could not sell the deal in Serbia, or to the Bosnian Serbs, if Serbs had less than 49 percent.
"The problem was, our technology was too good," an American official said ruefully. "They had agreed on the lines on the map. They said it looked good. Then, they found out the percentages, and it all came apart."
Thus began the desperate scramble to come up with more land for the Serbs. And the Bosnians added more demands.
Mr. Milosevic met late Sunday night in Mr. Holbrooke's suite with Mr. Silajdzic, the Bosnian Prime Minister, to sketch out a new map. Midnight came and went, and still they argued.
"What do you want, what are you seeking?" Mr. Milosevic repeatedly asked.
The Serbs made an additional small concession around Gorazde. Then, Mr. Silajdzic, who was leaving the room every half hour for instructions, came back with new demands for land around Sarajevo.
Mr. Milosevic had already told his Bosnian counterpart, "You deserve Sarajevo; you stayed there through the siege and shelling." Now, he stiffened and said, "There's a limit to what I can give." Even so, he bowed to Mr. Silajdzic's request.
In the end, Mr. Milosovic gave up his demand to widen a crucial route linking his country to Banja Luka, the largest Serb-held town in Bosnia.
With all this settled, the Bosnians proposed a map that would expand the Bosnian Serbs' holdings with some land carved out of western Bosnia. Nearly all of it came from the Croats.
Finally, at 4 A.M. Monday, there was a deal. The Americans scrounged up some California white wine to celebrate.
Mr. Izetbegovic was awakened to look over the agreement. He arrived a few minutes later, dour and groggy, wearing an overcoat over his nightshirt, his hands in his pockets. Mr. Christopher extended his hand and kept it in midair until Mr. Izetbegovic shook it.
 
The Bosnians
Muslim Leader Remains Reluctant
 But Croatia was still not on board.
The Americans summoned Mate Granic, the mild-mannered Croatian Foreign Minister, to bless the culmination of 19 days and nights of work.
"Thank you very much; this is very interesting," one participant quoted Mr. Granic as saying. "Now, may I please have the map."
When he saw the map, he exploded. Serbian territory had been expanded almost wholly at the Croats' expense. "Impossible, impossible, zero percent chance of acceptance by my Government," he shouted as he swept the map off the table.
As Mr. Granic grew angrier, Mr. Izetbegovic seemed to become happier. The deal about which he was deeply ambivalent was unraveling.
The deal had held for 37 minutes.
Mr. Christopher went to bed at 6 A.M. and resumed work 70 minutes later.
By early afternoon on Monday, Mr. Clinton intervened. He phoned Mr. Tudjman, and asked him to use his influence with the Bosnians to break the deadlock. "The time is now," Mr. Clinton said.
The Croats gave up most of the land needed to give the Serbs their 49 percent.
Mr. Christopher insisted that the Bosnians come up with the additional territory, that the Croats had already done enough. When Mr. Izetbegovic accused Mr. Christopher of lying to him, the Secretary of State exploded, ordering him to come back at 11:30 P.M. with a final map.
"This is as far as I can take these negotiations," Mr. Christopher told the Bosnian President. "If that is not good enough, you have to make that judgment. You have until 11:30 to make a decision."
Mr. Christopher also called Mr. Clinton and said that if the Bosnian President did not agree, "our work is done -- we'll suspend."
Mr. Clinton said, "If that's your judgment, go ahead."
A deal still seemed possible. But the Bosnians resurrected an old demand: The status of the Serb-held town of Brcko would have to be determined by international arbitration. Mr. Sacirbey, Bosnia's Foreign Minister, delivered the message, and said he was deeply saddened that his side could not agree to terms without Brcko.
The flabbergasted Americans refused to reopen the issue.
Instead, a few minutes later, the Americans delivered to three Balkan Presidents a two-page statement that would lock in gains already agreed on and close down the talks the next day.
Mr. Milosevic said that no matter what the Bosnians did, he wanted to initial the agreement for the Serbian delegation and would ask Mr. Tudjman to do the same for Croatia. Mr. Milosevic seemed confident that the Bosnians would eventually go along, . , particularly if the other two delegations signed.
"You Americans think this is more complicated than it is," he said.
When Mr. Christopher went to bed late Monday night, a statement of failure was composed for him to deliver the next morning.
At 8 A.M., Mr. Christopher met with his negotiators. They watched from their window as Mr. Milosevic trudged out in the snow to visit the Croats.
A Croatian official said the Serbian President had proposed that the Serbs and Croats jointly announce that the talks had failed because of Bosnian intransigence.
Mr. Tudjman, this official said, instead told Mr. Milosevic that the fate of Brcko was too small an issue to derail a peace settlement, and he suggested that the question be referred to an international commission that would render its ruling in six months.
A few minutes later, Mr. Milosevic told Mr. Christopher that he would accept the commission on Brcko. The Secretary then took the news to the Bosnians and the Croats. Mr. Izetbegovic was reluctant to the end. "Well, it's not a just peace," he said. "But my people need peace."
A short time later, Mr. Milosevic sought out Mr. Christopher, who told him the deal was struck. The Serbian President raised his left hand in triumph. Tears came to his eyes, and he impulsively hugged Brig. Gen. Donald Kerrick, an Army general on the negotiating team.
 
The Hard Part
Will Bosnian Serbs Accept the Peace?
 Even as the participants exchanged congratulations at the initialing ceremony, the signs of discord were evident. The Bosnian Serbs, enraged that Mr. Milosevic had negotiated without them, boycotted the ceremony.
They were fuming at the agreement's military annex, which, they told Carl Bildt, the representative of the European Union, made the NATO troops an "occupying force."
Just as serious was the way Mr. Milosevic had ceded Sarajevo to the Bosnian Government. The Bosnian Serbs did not realize until the morning of the ceremony that they had lost the Sarajevo suburbs of Grbavica, Ilidza, Vogosca and Ilijas, which they have defended with an iron will since the beginning of the war.
Mr. Milosevic had purposely withheld this information, telling American negotiators, "I'll only show them the map at the end."
Shortly after midnight, hours after Mr. Christopher, the Europeans and the three Balkan Presidents had flown out of Dayton for good, a group of Bosnian Serbs who stayed behind turned up at the base's military headquarters to confront General Clark about Sarajevo.
Huddling over a printed map in the auditorium where the Powerscreen mapping system operates, the Bosnian Serbs politely but firmly explained how Mr. Milosevic had given their roads and neighborhoods away.
"The red line is Milosevic's," General Clark patiently explained. "You can't change it. It's agreed."
"It may be Milosevic's line," one of the Bosnian Serbs said, "But it's our road."
"The line doesn't mean anything anyway," the general continued. "Freedom of movement is guaranteed."
The Serbs were dubious. Finally, General Clark said, "It's best to let it alone for now and allow this to sort itself out."
But the problem of Sarajevo remained far from sorted out. The mountain road overlooking the city's southern edge -- a road from which the Serbs have regularly shelled the city over the last 43 months -- is a road that NATO troops are supposed to patrol in a few weeks.
"Now for the hard part," said James Pardew, a senior Pentagon official who witnessed the exchange. "The glory's over."

Chart/Map: "The Sticking Points"
 
Division of Territory
 When the Serbs were finished conceding land, it was discovered that they had given away too much, and that instead of controlling 49 percent of the country, as called for under the peace plan, they would hold only 45 percent. When it was proposed that the imbalance be redressed by handing a chunk of Croat-held land to the Serbs, the Croats hit the roof, but were brought back by a call from President Clinton to President Franjo Tudjman.
 
Brcko
 The Bosnian Government wanted Brcko, a Serb-held town in the middle of the narrow lifeline linking Serb territories in northwestern Bosnia with eastern Bosnia and Serbia proper. In the face of Serbian intransigence, the Bosnians at first acquiesced, then demanded binding arbitration of the issue. The talks teetered on the verge of collapse before the Serbs accepted arbitration.
 
Gorazde
 Milosevic wanted to cede only a narrow corridor connecting the Muslim enclave of Gorazde to the rest of Bosnian Government-controlled territory. But after a large whiskey and a virtual-reality tour of the corridor, Milosevic accepted the wider version insisted on by the Bosnian Government.
 
Sarajevo
 After Milosevic asserted that the Bosnian Government had "earned" control of all of the Bosnian capital by their suffering in the war, he ceded the Serb-held suburbs of the city. The Bosnian Serbs, cut off from the negotiations, were appalled.
 
Eastern Slavonia
 Croatia's main aim in the talks was to regain the region from the Serbs. The Serbs arrived ready to make a deal, but wanted a two-year transition period. The Croats insisted on a one-year transition. Warren Christopher came up with a circumlocution that satisfied both sides.

HEADLINE: Government Shutdown Cost Is Estimated at $700 Million

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
As the Administration considered its strategy for next week's budget negotiations with Congress, the White House disclosed today that last week's Government shutdown cost taxpayers $700 million to $800 million. And it said it could not promise Federal workers that another shutdown would not occur in a few weeks.
Roughly half of the estimated costs, White House officials said, are the salaries of the 800,000 workers furloughed for four work days. As in past Government shutdowns, these workers will be paid for the time they were sent home. The other half consists of lost Federal revenues, some of which may be recouped. 
 At the same time, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin disclosed that the Administration was developing plans to keep paying the nation's bills into early next year in the event that Congress refuses to raise the nation's borrowing limit as part of the negotiations over a balanced budget.
At a breakfast meeting with reporters, Mr. Rubin also hinted at President Clinton's strategy in those negotiations, saying the Administration would seek to bridge the huge gulf between Congressional and White House economic assumptions and to pare down the Republicans' proposed tax cut.
Other Administration officials say they have no indication that the first- and second-year Republicans in Congress, who have clung to the Congressional Budget Office's economic assumptions as an article of faith, are willing to find a middle ground between those numbers and the figures used by the Administration.
The Congressional estimates about how the economy will perform are less optimistic than those of the Office of Management and Budget, which the White House prefers, and would require far deeper cuts to reach a balanced budget in seven years. But Mr. Rubin acknowledged today that any estimates that reach seven years into the future were by their nature a bit fanciful.
Asked today if there was any way to balance the budget in that time period -- one of the goals specified in the agreement reached last weekend -- without abandoning the Congressional Budget Office figures, a senior Administration official thought about the question for a second and then said simply, "No."
That response underscored how little was resolved in the agreement struck last weekend, an accord that brought the 800,000 furloughed workers back until at least Dec. 15 and permitted Congress and many in the executive branch to depart for the Thanksgiving holiday. But over the past several days, it has become clear that neither side has moved on the broad disagreements over a budget.
Mr. Clinton acknowledged the possibility of a continuing impasse in an open letter to Federal workers.
"We can't promise you that your jobs and your lives won't be disrupted again," he wrote. "Too much is at stake for America."
It also does not appear likely that Congress is about to act soon on raising the debt limit, in part because Republicans believe the prospect of default gives them additional leverage in budget negotiations. Mr. Rubin conceded today that last weekend the Administration abandoned its effort to have the debt limit raised as part of its short-term deal. And while he insisted that Congress should "act on a clean debt limit extension" soon, Mr. Rubin made clear by his tone that the Administration was not counting on early action.
"There are numerous measures we can take," said Mr. Rubin, who has been accused by Republicans of creating a crisis over imminent Government default, then sidestepping the problem with a few quick financial maneuvers. "How far and long it can go, I do not know."
It seems clear that using maneuvers similar to the ones he announced last week, Mr. Rubin can get through January. Inside the Treasury and the Justice Department, however, lawyers are struggling to find ways that the fiscal balancing act can be kept going until early April. After April 15, when taxes are due, the Government will be flush with cash, giving Mr. Clinton considerably more room to negotiate without fear that Congress could force a default.
Mr. Rubin's comments today came as more and more Administration officials are discussing the possibility that there will be no budget settlement, and that the parties will leave the issue of the Federal Government's role in major entitlement programs like Medicaid and welfare to next year's Presidential campaign.
A few of Mr. Clinton's political advisers even favor that strategy, arguing that it would allow Mr. Clinton to present himself to the voters as a budget-cutter who is also the savior of some of the nation's most politically popular programs. There is also some suggestion that Congress may not send Mr. Clinton the balanced budget bill that it passed on Monday night because Republican leaders want to deprive him of the opportunity for a ceremonial veto in front of the cameras. It was only after Mr. Clinton's certain veto that the two sides were expected to get down to serious negotiations.
Mr. Rubin argued today that a budget agreement was critical, implying that failure to reach one would harm both the stock market rally and the steady decline in interest rates.
But he added that reaching a balanced budget in seven years, while still preserving all of Mr. Clinton's budget priorities, "will be very difficult." He also said that the $245 billion tax cut that lies at the heart of the Republican budget plan "needs to be substantially reduced."

HEADLINE: Baltimore Opening High-Tech Central Booking Center

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: ALTIMORE, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Just beyond the vast renewal efforts that have made Baltimore a model of urban redevelopment in recent years, another new building stands ready as a tribute to the city's modernization.
On Tuesday, the doors will open at the Baltimore Central Booking and Intake Center, a high-tech detention center that will replace the less-sophisticated booking operations now conducted at nine police district buildings around the city. It is designed to save countless hours of manpower and paperwork, and experts on prisons and criminal justice say there is nothing like it in the country. 
 In centralizing the system and using computers for identification, background checks, mug shots and fingerprinting, the new center drastically cuts the time arresting officers spend writing reports, getting them back on the street that much faster. City officials say that, at a time city officials are trying to improve law enforcement through community policing, the new center will also return as many as 160 officers to street patrols who have been performing booking duties.
"It frees up cops, and that's the biggest bang for the bucks," Bishop L. Robinson, Secretary of the Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services, said today, as officials previewed the center for reporters and Lieut. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, who was booked, photographed and fingerprinted as a demonstration.
The idea for a central booking center in Baltimore grew out of rising concerns over a crowded prison system that was further choked by a sluggish and inefficient booking process. Almost 30 percent of the arrests in Maryland are made in Baltimore, but suspects were sometimes detained for days before a court judge reviewed charges against them and set bail.
When the state assumed responsibility for operating the city penal system in 1991, the Legislature set aside $54 million for construction of a booking center and $10 million for equipping it with the latest technology, anticipating at least as much savings in manpower redeployment.
Mr. Robinson and other officials visited prisons around the country to study technologies already in use, and they said they devised a process that combines the best of them, which had not been done anywhere else. The result is a system that replaces ink-pad fingerprinting with electronic scanners, uses video links with courtrooms to eliminate transporting suspects and allows local officials to exchange information with other jurisdictions and law-enforcement agencies instantly by computer.
If the center operates as expected, local officials predict that people detained could be released hours after arrest if they post bail or if a judge determines there is no probable cause to hold them.
"Some of the technology has been used before," said Rod Bottoms, a senior corrections specialist with the National Institute of Corrections Information Center in Longmont, Colo. "But this is very, very high tech, used all together. Very high tech. Most facilities don't have this number of things state-of-the-art."
The new center was constructed beside a penal complex that has been in use for nearly 200 years. Ground was broken for the original building, a foreboding castlelike structure of rocks and cement, during Thomas Jefferson's Administration, in the early 1800's. Five more buildings have been added over the years. All six, as well as part of the state prison down the block, now serve as pretrial detention centers, to accommodate Baltimore's pretrial population of 4,000 people, the seventh-largest in the country.
But now, the point of entry into the system will change. Instead of being hauled into the nearest police station, any person arrested in the city will be driven into the downtown booking center, given a bar-coded wristband that enables cameras and computers to track his movements, interviewed by prison personnel, photographed, fingerprinted, then placed in a one of the center's 120 holding cells while officials discuss bail with a court commissioner, who determines whether charges should be pursued.
If bail is set, the person arrested will appear by video-telephone before a local judge, who reviews the amount of bail. If a suspect either is denied bail or cannot post it, he will be held for trial in the same building or one of the prison cells.
Officials say time will be saved every step of the way.
Sitting at a computer today, typing in made-up charges against Ms. Townsend as part of his training, Sgt. James Sharpe said he had spent up to two and a half hours writing out reports in longhand.
"With this," he said, pointing to his computer station, "I could do the same thing in maybe an hour."
"And," he said with a laugh, "the new system has spell-check."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strong Export Sales Shrink U.S. Trade Deficit
American exports rose to new heights in September and the trade deficit inched down, to $8.35 billion, the lowest level of the year, the Commerce Department said. The American deficit with Japan narrowed for the sixth consecutive month, and even the deficit with China declined.
The results indicate that the economy's growth rate during the latest quarter is likely to be revised upward significantly. [A1.]
 
Dow Sets Yet Another Record
The Dow Jones industrial average continued its remarkable surge, though broad indexes fell a bit. By increasing 18.06 points, to 5,041.61, the Dow set its 61st record this year. [D9.]
 
Chrysler Director Resigns
Joseph E. Antonini surprised Chrysler by resigning from its board, thus increasing pressure on the company to replace him with Kirk Kerkorian's strategist, Jerome B. York. Chrysler shares jumped $1.50, to $51.25. [D4.]
 
Masco Sale Draws $1.1 Billion
Masco sold its home furnishings business to investors assembled by Morgan Stanley Capital Partners for $1.1 billion. [D2.]
 
Government Shutdown Was Costly
The Government shutdown cost taxpayers $700 million or more, the White House said. Meanwhile, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said he was developing plans to keep paying the nation's bills into next year. [B20.]
 
Politics goes hand in hand with the tax laws, as seen this year in capital gains policy and tax credits for children. [A1.]
 
$5.3 Billion Offer for Forte
Granada Group offered $5.3 billion for Forte of Britain, whose shares rose sharply on the prospect of a higher bid. [D7.]
 
Borland's Founder Is Leaving
Philippe Kahn, the flamboyant founder of Borland, quit as chairman to work on a start-up company, Starfish Software. [D4.]
 
Harrah's Jazz in Chapter 11
The fledgling gambling industry in New Orleans suffered a big setback when Harrah's Jazz filed for bankruptcy protection. [A17.]
 
Hilton Investors Are Perplexed
Hilton Hotels left investors puzzled as to whether it really plans to split itself into separate hotel and gambling companies. Hilton's president resigned Tuesday. [D8.]
 
Nestle to Sell Vineyards
Nestle plans to sell its California wineries, including Beringer Vineyards, to focus on its other foods and beverages. [D7.]
 
OPEC Continues Output Ceiling
OPEC decided to continue its production ceiling through the first half of next year, even though a number of its members violate it. Some analysts said prices could drop. [D7.]
 
Smucker to Sell Pie Business
Smucker is selling its Mrs. Smith's frozen pie business, which it bought 18 months ago for $84 million. The company also reported a 24 percent drop in quarterly earnings. The buyer of the pie business, SBI Brands, is headed by Scott Rahn, who ran Conagra's frozen food division. [D4.]
 
Japanese Plan for Failing Banks
Tokyo Kyodo Bank, a special bank set up in March to take over two failed Tokyo credit cooperatives, will have a vastly expanded role to deal with any other failures of financial institutions, the Finance Ministry said. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Be Less of a Target, House Republicans Urge Gingrich

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Despite a year of legislative successes, Speaker Newt Gingrich enters the final stage of budget negotiations with a public image so battered that the Democrats see it as one of his party's prime vulnerabilities. Congressional Republicans, including some of his staunchest loyalists, are increasingly concerned.
Mr. Gingrich dismisses his poll ratings, which dropped significantly during this month's budget maneuvering, as transitory, the short-term price of pushing for long-term change against the fierce opposition of a party that he asserts is bound to distort his program. "When people learn the facts over the next five or six months, we'll be fine," he told the Republican governors this week at their meeting in Nashua, N.H. 
 But Democratic Congressional strategists want the public to see Mr. Gingrich and his party's economic platform as a single, unattractive package: intellectually challenging, perhaps, but chilly and arrogant, and simply too extreme. And some Republicans on Capitol Hill, clearly frustrated at their difficulty in getting their message across to the American people, are increasingly worried that this image of the Speaker is getting in the way.
They bitterly complain that the Democrats have mounted a concerted, systematic campaign to "demonize" Mr. Gingrich and thereby discredit his agenda. But some of them also acknowledge that Mr. Gingrich himself occasionally gives ammunition to his enemies. The furor he prompted on Tuesday when he linked a bizarre Illinois murder case to "the moral decay of the world the left is defending" and his lengthy complaints last week over his treatment aboard Air Force One were two such instances.
"He has truly been demonized," said Representative Christopher Shays, Republican of Connecticut. "And I don't know how he can take it. Some of us want to put our arms around him and say, 'How do you hold up?' But at the same time, we want to say: 'Don't give them ammunition. Don't give them superficial things that they can magnify.' "
Mr. Shays said he and other Gingrich loyalists had conveyed their concerns to the Speaker in recent days, urging him to rest more and to focus his energies on broad strategy instead of day-to-day tactics. "When Newt Gingrich is upbeat and positive, nobody can touch him," Mr. Shays said. "When he's tired and angry, he's a mere mortal. The Democrats know that he really is the center of our gravity, and, in military terms, you identify the center of gravity and go after it."
Eddie Mahe, a Republican consultant who is a longtime friend of Mr. Gingrich, said: "Anybody who's not worried about it is not being realistic. Having said that, whenever you're on the cutting edge of the fundamental change we're trying to put in place, it was inevitable that he was going to have this problem, although clearly he's contributed to it with some of his less-than-wise statements about the back of the plane and all that nonsense."
A new round of polls released this week showed that Mr. Gingrich's job approval ratings, already lacking, dropped significantly during this month's budget impasse and partial Government shutdown. A CBS News poll showed that only 27 percent approved of his performance in office -- compared with 59 percent who disapproved, including a plurality of Republicans. In contrast, President Clinton's approval rating held stable at 48 percent; 40 percent disapproved.
Democrats say they now view Mr. Gingrich's public persona as a source of political opportunity. Representative Martin Frost of Texas, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said, "We've been telling our challengers for some time now that their opponents' middle name is Gingrich."
Congressional Democrats also make Mr. Gingrich the issue in the ongoing struggle for the moral high ground on the budget -- and favorable coverage on the nightly news. They were gleeful last week when he suggested that the budget impasse had been prompted in part by his treatment aboard Air Force One to and from Yitzhak Rabin's funeral. Stoked by the Democrats, the episode overwhelmed what could otherwise have been two very good news days for the Republicans as they tried to turn the debate back to their goal of a balanced budget and gained conservative Democratic support for their cause.
A Democratic strategist close to the Clinton Administration said, "You can't separate the message from the messenger," arguing that Mr. Gingrich's persona gets in the way "even when the words make sense and are relatively persuasive."
Still, as Republicans are happy to note, it was the Democrats who were convinced in the fall of 1994 that Republicans had made a huge mistake by signing on to the Contract With America, the campaign manifesto on which the Republican majority came to power.
Moreover, whatever the qualms about the polls, Mr. Gingrich remains immensely popular among House Republicans. Representative Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of upstate New York, said party caucuses still had the flavor of pep rallies for the Speaker. "A guy who's carried us this far, thus far, is going to be cheered on and not shunted to the sidelines," Mr. Boehlert said.
Strategists nonetheless acknowledge that as a messenger, Mr. Gingrich has not only strengths but also weaknesses. "He has a sound-bite problem," argued Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster, "in that TV will click in on the harshest eight seconds and run it on the national news. If you let him communicate in long form, in these half-hour or 40-minute C-Span shows, he scores off the chart. It takes two minutes for people to warm up to him. It takes five minutes for people to really respect him. And it takes 10 minutes for people to be enthralled with him."
Mr. Luntz acknowledged a warmth factor but said: "He comes across as very intellectual and very visionary. That's what he's best at. I'd never put a baby in his arms, but I would have him talk about the future of the country."
And Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, asserted that it was simply too early to be thinking about polls. "Next fall I'll be worrying about polls," he said. "The only reason to worry about polling in an odd-numbered year is if you think the poll numbers are hurting your ability to achieve your legislative goals -- and it's not."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1705 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
His Goal: No Room at the Inns

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla.

 BODY:
Dismissed by the Walt Disney Company in 1972, Harris Rosen lived in a tiny apartment for the next two years as he struggled to make a living selling carpets. Even after he scraped together $20,000 toward a down payment on a hotel that was about to be foreclosed on, he bunked down in two of its rooms for the next seven years.
Now one of the most successful independent hotel owners anywhere, Mr. Rosen can stay pretty much where he wants -- including in any of the 1,334 rooms of the recently opened Omni Rosen here. "But I still can't get to sleep," said Mr. Rosen, who is 56, "until I know all my hotels are filled." 
 To an astonishing degree, he has succeeded. In the Orlando area, where the average annual occupancy rate has not exceeded 78.8 percent in the last decade, Mr. Rosen's hotels have averaged 96 percent over that time and were below 92 percent only once -- at 87.9 percent in 1985. Occupancy at the Omni Rosen, Mr. Rosen's sixth property, already averages 74 percent in its fourth week of operation, and few people here doubt that it, too, will reach the stratosphere.
"The man's ability to fill hotel rooms from the day he opens is amazing," said Brendan Ebbs, the president of Rodeway Inns, a chain with two hotels in Orlando -- including one run by Mr. Rosen. "He's like no other hotel owner I know."
Mr. Rosen's secret is fairly simple: Much to his competitors' dismay, he openly cuts prices during the day, often to a rock-bottom $29.95 at his lower-priced properties, to lure the last weary traveler to the last empty Rosen room.
He likens this fine-tuning to the airlines' practice of yield management -- lowering fares at various times on seats that may otherwise remain unsold. Also used by cruise ships, the technique has not yet caught on in the hotel industry, where many operators fret that cutting prices, at least openly, may tarnish the polished image of their chains.
But if the hotel-management companies that dominate the industry in this city -- and elsewhere -- do not have the foresight to follow his example, Mr. Rosen says, that is their problem. "Most of them would rather wind up with empty rooms than drop the price, in order to preserve the sanctity of their average daily rate," he scoffs.
Privately, other hotel operators here complain that Mr. Rosen's fixation on filling rooms is holding down room rates, which now average $66 a night and have risen an average of less than 1 percent a year since 1989.
Yet Mr. Rosen's success, exemplified by his name emblazoned across the 24-floor Omni, has made hoteliers reluctant to criticize him publicly. In a rare on-the-record jab, Linda W. Chapin, the head of Florida's Orange County Commission, told Lodging magazine this year, "He is a control freak; he has a monumental ego and he wants to run things."
Mr. Rosen brushes off that outburst as inconsequential. "Linda was angry because I opposed an increase in the hotel-room tax to build a baseball stadium," he said. "But that's past, and I don't feel any animosity toward her."
Mr. Rosen professes not to understand the broader controversy. "I'd like higher rates, too, because our average rate has increased only about 1 1/2 percent since 1980," he said. "But isn't the question, 'Why would anybody build a hotel and not try to fill every room every night?' "
He tries very hard. On days when it appears his properties may not fill up, electronic message boards outside three of them -- with rates normally averaging $39 to $59 a night -- begin flashing "$29.95."
Mr. Rosen's hotels consist of two Quality Inns, a Comfort Inn and the Clarion Plaza, as well as the Omni and the Rodeway. All told, they account for about 4,850 of the Orlando area's 84,400 hotel rooms. All but one of his properties, the Comfort Inn in Lake Buena Vista, are on International Drive, the main tourist strip that snakes through the triangle connecting Disney World, Universal Studios and Sea World. Posted rates at the Clarion run from $89 to $135, and those at the Omni will soon rise to a range of $165 to $195.
But at a Rosen property, actualrates depend on occupancy levels, time of day, maybe even phase of the moon. As principal owner of Tamar Inns, the company that runs his six hotels, Mr. Rosen decides whether and when to change prices, based on intuition and intimate knowledge of each property. (About a half-dozen friends hold a minority stake of roughly 25 percent.)
He has much leeway to move prices, he says, because his company's debt is "a minuscule 5 to 10 percent of the value of our properties, so we don't need to keep rates high to pay off the interest." The Omni Rosen, built for $75 million (not including the bargain price he paid five years ago for the 20-acre site), is debt free.
"Harris doesn't believe in a slow season," said Bob Franz, an assistant manager at the Clarion Plaza, taking a pause one recent evening from working the phones to fill the six remaining unoccupied rooms in the 810-room hotel. One way he does that is by honoring the rates of Tamar's lower-priced hotels that send him walk-in customers they cannot accommodate.
Each night at 11, Mr. Rosen calls the front desk at each property to see if the hotel is sold out -- and if not, why not. After getting a daily 6 A.M. wake-up call, he is on the phone with the night auditors, recapping the previous day's occupancy rates, average room rates and food and beverage revenue. Then he discusses the coming day's room rates -- that is, the starting rates.
Mr. Rosen makes no bones about his obsession with detail. When his hotels were being built, he says, he negotiated the price of everything from elevators to light fixtures. Today, he could easily be mistaken for a handyman as he prowls his properties, picking up scrap paper and cigarette butts. When he strolls through his hotels' lobbies and down their corridors, he greets many of his 2,500 employees by name.
"He loves to micromanage, and he's so driven it could drive you crazy if you worked for him," said Michael French, vice president of hotel operations at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., and the former manager of the Orlando Peabody hotel. "But if I owned a business I'd want him to run it."
Mr. Rosen sees the big picture, too. He built the Omni Rosen and the Clarion on either side of the Orlando/Orange County Convention Center, which attracts 2.1 million people a year to 15,000 events. The two hotels have 44 meeting rooms of their own, with 200,000 square feet of space. Because convention business is usually booked years in advance, the hotels' proximity to the center gives them a buffer against swings in the economic cycle.
Moreover, while some hotels shun tour buses, tour groups account for as much 65 percent of Tamar Inns' business.
"The classic way is to go after bus tours when business is down, but when business is up to ignore them, because they're low profit," said Gerald W. Petitt, the co-chairman of Choice Hotels International, the unit of Manor Care Inc. that franchises the Quality, Clarion, Comfort and Rodeway brands. "But Harris early on identified the importance of the group tour business."
This prescience has transformed him into a millionaire 100 times over, according to an estimate by Lodging magazine. Standing outside the Omni, Mr. Rosen would say only, "Everything I own is in this hotel, and if it succeeds it could easily be worth $300-to-$400 million in five years. If it doesn't . . . "
Despite criticism of his style, few would question his generosity: He established a foundation that provides a preschool program for children in a low-income neighborhood bordering International Drive and that pays for older students to go to vocational school or college. He built a clinic complete with a full-time doctor to treat his employees and their dependents for minor ailments.
But his critics say he gets impatient if he does not get his way. "He does some wonderful things for the community, but he does not believe in consensus," said Cheryl D. Taubensee, the executive director of the Central Florida Hotel and Motel Association.
Mr. Rosen resigned from the association a few years ago, Ms. Taubensee said, after contending that it was too slow to adopt safety and fire regulations."He didn't understand," she said, "that an association can't just dictate to its members."
Mr. Rosen was born and raised on Manhattan's Lower East Side. His father was the safety engineer at the Waldorf-Astoria and an amateur artist who sketched some of the hotel's famous guests in his spare time. Jack's, the restaurant in the Clarion Plaza, is named for the elder Mr. Rosen, and its walls are lined with his drawings of Winston Churchill, Pablo Picasso, Babe Ruth and many other famous faces.
After graduation from the hotel school of Cornell University and three and a half years in the Army, Harris Rosen joined the Waldorf as a clerk, then spent the next decade in a variety of hotel positions with Hilton Hotels and Walt Disney.
"It wasn't that I was doing a bad job for Disney," he said of his dismissal. "They said I didn't conform. They were right. My inclination is to raise my hand and say, 'But.' "
Mr. Rosen turns a competitive drive toward everything he does. His swimming is "only a little better than average," he said, but that has not stopped him from training daily to compete in the Y.M.C.A. Masters nationals swimming meet here next April. And he remained single until six years ago because, he said, "Before that I knew I wouldn't have the time to make a marriage work." With three sons and a daughter ages 9 months to 5 years, he appears to be making up for lost time.
Sometimes, Mr. Rosen tries to take charge beyond his own turf. Mr. French, the former Orlando Peabody general manager, recalls how Mr. Rosen set himself up as guardian of International Drive in the 1970's when unkempt hotels and tacky shops suddenly starting popping up along the highway. "Once he phoned a T-shirt shop and told the owner to paint a light pole outside the place," Mr. French recalled.
Mr. Rosen remembered the incident. "But I didn't phone him," he said. "I drove over to his place. And after getting his permission, our people painted it for him."

GRAPHIC: Photos: To keep occupancy rates high at his hotels in the Orlando, Fla., area, Harris Rosen cuts prices during the day at some of the properties. The new Omni Rosen, with 1,334 rooms, is the sixth hotel owned by his company, Tamar Inns. (Photographs by Joe Skipper for The New York Times)
