LENGTH: 643 words

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: THE SERBS;
A Town Feels Betrayed by Milosevic and Talks of Fighting On

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: ILIDZA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Just past a French checkpoint that straddles the front line outside Sarajevo, there is a grumbling that grows louder with every pass of the bottle and every mention of peace.
Ilidza, a Serb-held suburb, is set to return to the Bosnian fold. For the soldiers and civilians who crowd the checkpoints on the road into town, this provision of the peace agreement reached on Tuesday has brought nothing but pessimism and pain. 
 "We feel like losers," said Milenko Djukic, 46, a truck driver, as he passed a half-empty bottle of rakija, local brandy, to a friend. "The Muslims have gotten everything, and we have gotten nothing out of this agreement.
"The status of Sarajevo was the reason for this war, and we have a right to our piece," he added. "The city has to remain divided. The Muslims cannot come back to Ilidza."
The unification of Sarajevo under Bosnian Government control is a point of bitter contention among the Serbs who ring the city and have been indoctrinated with a well-worn belief that they cannot trust their former neighbors. Most of them do not believe that they will be allowed to remain in their homes if the deal is signed. Few of them want to.
And some of them talk about not giving up the fight, despite the peace agreement.
Mr. Djukic said he had lived in Sarajevo until the authorities there gave his apartment to some refugees. He said he had spent five days on the streets and that his escape had cost $350 and left him with only the clothes on his back.
He said that if the Muslims came knocking for entrance into his new sanctuary, he would certainly not stay. "They scare me," he said. "I would just pack my bags and leave."
The decision by President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to sign the agreement on behalf of the Bosnian Serbs was met by protest from many in the Serbian-held portion of Bosnia.
Momcilo Krajisnik, the speaker of the Bosnian Serbs' self-proclaimed parliament, called Mr. Milosevic's decision to sign "an especially big mistake." He said Mr. Milosevic had been warned that "nobody has the right to sign that plan or accept those maps."
Today, people on the street mimicked the remarks Mr. Milosevic made at the peace talks in Dayton, Ohio. They intimated that he was satisfied with the lifting of economic sanctions against Serbia and not concerned with seeking a fair future for his brethren in Bosnia.
"We have been betrayed by Milosevic," said one Bosnian Serb soldier, propping up his black sunglasses. "He was not thinking about our people. He was thinking about his."
Another soldier added: "Everybody is against us. We have lost the war and will have to move away from here."
Muslims in Sarajevo have expressed a willingness to live with Serbs as they once did and said they were even looking forward to seeing their old Serbian neighbors and friends. But fear has gripped the Serbs.
Their political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and their military commander, Gen. Ratko Mladic, are about to lose their offices and face war crimes indictments in The Hague, a fate that many soldiers worry could be their own.
"Who will decide who was a war criminal and who wasn't?" asked one 26-year-old soldier. "I have lived in Ilidza my whole life and defended my home. For them, that makes me a criminal. They would not allow me to live a normal life."
These Serbs had nothing but complaints about the Ohio agreement, from the corridor that will link Sarajevo and Gorazde to the lifting of the arms embargo. That, they said, assures that Bosnia will become the flash point of World War III.
Only one hope remained: that what came to pass in America would falter on Bosnia's winter ground.
"Only a just agreement can carry peace," Mr. Djukic said, "and this is not justice. We are all sick of the war, but the Muslims have gotten too much. On the basis of this, we will fight to the end."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Boeing Outlook Hurt by Labor's Rejection of Pact

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
The surprise decision by 32,000 machinists to continue their six-week strike against the Boeing Company led analysts yesterday to cut their earnings estimates once again for the fourth quarter. If the strike continues long enough, they said, the company, the world's leading maker of commercial aircraft, will face a loss.
On Tuesday, 61 percent of the votes by members of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers were against the contract, even though union leaders had unanimously recommended it. The sticking point appeared to be a requirement that workers either join a health maintenance organization or pay an insurance premium for health care for the first time. There was also concern that the contract did not contain strong enough language regarding the use of overseas contractors, negotiators said. 
 Analysts said that at the least the continuation of the strike would lower the quarter's earnings for the company, which is based in Seattle. But they said that most airlines are not that eager to take delivery of planes in the immediate future because of their own slow recovery, so the ultimate effect may be merely to delay some sales and earnings. Boeing shares shook off the short-term earnings worries and rose 75 cents, to $74.125, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
"I've already taken a substantial whack out of my fourth-quarter estimate, and now I've got to take it down further," said William B. Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle. He said he had lowered his per-share earnings estimate from 73 cents to 18 cents on the assumption of a strike ending this week after 47 days. "If you assume the strike goes through the whole quarter you probably get to a negative number," he said.
In the fourth quarter last year, Boeing earned $157 million, or 46 cents a share. Sales totaled $5.12 billion. Before the strike, some analysts had predicted quarterly earnings of 80 cents a share.
Union leaders, Boeing executives and Federal mediators appeared to have misread the sentiments of rank and file union members, and it was not clear where negotiations could lead. Boeing officials have said they will not consider using replacement workers because of safety concerns.
"We're extremely disappointed," Paul Binder, a spokesman for Boeing, said. "Both the company and the Federal mediator had been assured by the union negotiators that the proposal we submitted would be acceptable to the employees represented by the union. Obviously it wasn't.
"At this point we have to assess what alternatives are available to us."
Tensions between employees and the company may have been exacerbated by the awarding of millions of dollars of stock options to senior management just as the contract went to a vote. The executives obtained the options as part of a plan that rewards them as Boeing's stock rises, according to their compensation package. To profit, the executives must exercise the options and sell the shares. So far, only Phil Condit, Boeing's president, has exercised a portion of his options, the company said.
"Frank Shrontz and the top Boeing executives got multimillion-dollar bonuses today because the company's stock is doing so well," Bob Gregory, a lead negotiator for the union, said in a statement, referring to the company's chairman and chief executive.
"Yet here is Boeing, insisting they have to cut our health care, and that they can't afford to do anything more in the way of wages or benefits. Our members have fought long and hard, and they're not going to start building airplanes again until Boeing improves that offer."
Even as analysts cut their estimates for the fourth quarter, most remained optimistic for the longer term. "As long as it doesn't get acrimonious, we should expect normal production sometime in the first quarter," Howard Rubel, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said.
In addition to deferring revenue for the company, the strike has a direct effect on the communities surrounding Boeing plants. Boeing machinists' wages in the Seattle area alone amount to about $18 million a week, according to Dick Conway, editor of the Puget Sound Economic Forecaster newsletter. Thus, a nine-week strike would reduce income directly by $162 million, he said, with the ripple effect on other businesses bringing the total lost to about $300 million.
"These guys are going to be pulling back on spending, at least for a time, and that's going to have an impact on retail trade and services, particularly on big-ticket items," Mr. Conway said. "Back in 1989, when we had the last Boeing strike, you could actually see a spike in auto sales in the city of Seattle right after the strike was settled."

HEADLINE: Governors Tussling Again, With Port Authority Jobs at Stake

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, two Republicans who agree on most issues, are feuding again over the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey -- this time over control of jobs, contracts and policy at the multibillion-dollar agency.
Mr. Pataki is holding up the appointment of a new Port Authority chairman because he is seeking a guarantee from Mrs. Whitman that his appointees to the authority's board will oversee hiring and finances, officials said. He is also looking for assurances that the authority will not be biased in New Jersey's favor and will continue to cut its budget. 
 The nominee for chairman, Lewis M. Eisenberg, was selected by Mrs. Whitman, who as New Jersey's governor traditionally fills that position. But Mr. Pataki has until Tuesday to veto the choice, and is threatening to do so.
Mr. Pataki wants his two appointees, Charles A. Gargano and Peter S. Kalikow, to lead two board committees that would give the governor more power over jobs and contracts. The board chairman names committee heads, so Mr. Pataki is trying to extract a promise that Mr. Gargano and Mr. Kalikow will get those posts before he accedes to Mrs. Whitman's choice, authority officials said.
"They should go to the governor's people," a senior Pataki adviser said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
The quarrel has surprised some board members because Mr. Eisenberg is a well-known Republican who has close ties to Mr. Pataki, having served on his transition committee and raised money for his gubernatorial campaign last year. Mr. Pataki and his wife have even eaten at Mr. Eisenberg's home. Mr. Eisenberg, an investment banker, is also an adviser to Mrs. Whitman and is one of her appointees on the authority's 12-member board.
Senior Whitman aides said they were also caught off guard by the quarrel, with some suggesting that it was retribution for the last time the two governors were at odds over the authority. When Mr. Pataki took office, he was criticized by Mrs. Whitman after he named George J. Marlin to be the authority's executive director without consulting her first.
Yesterday, some board members accused Mr. Pataki of seeking control of the two committees, operations and finance, because it would strengthen his hand in filling jobs at the authority with his supporters. Already, the operations committee is considering hiring the son of Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon. Mr. Hatfield is an ally of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is the political patron of Mr. Pataki.
Harvey Valentine, a spokesman for Mr. D'Amato, said Mr. Hatfield's son, Mark O. Hatfield Jr., applied on his own for the job in the press office of the authority. He listed Mr. D'Amato as a reference, and when authority officials called Mr. D'Amato, he gave Mr. Hatfield a strong recommendation.
The operations and finance committees are now headed by board members who were appointed by Mr. Pataki's predecessors.
Mr. Pataki's aides have said in recent days that Mr. Pataki was annoyed that Mr. Eisenberg did not meet with the New York Governor before Mrs. Whitman put his nomination to the board on Nov. 9. The board approved Mr. Eisenberg by a vote of 8 to 2, with Mr. Gargano and Mr. Kalikow voting no in an unusual breach of etiquette. Either governor can veto any move by the board.
Mr. Gargano, who is the Governor's top economic adviser and also vice chairman of the authority, said yesterday that the dispute could have been avoided if Mr. Eisenberg had gone to see Mr. Pataki before the vote.
"I think that the Governor is interested in finding out whether New York will be treated in a fair way," Mr. Gargano said.
Mr. Gargano declined to say whether Mr. Pataki would veto Mr. Eisenberg's nomination. "That is available to the Governor, if he would like to use the veto," Mr. Gargano said.
Mr. Kalikow declined to comment.
Mr. Pataki's spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, said Mr. Pataki was not delaying the nomination over the committee posts. She said the governor wanted to make his priorities clear to Mr. Eisenberg, and would focus on the committees later on.
"The issue is regarding the Governor's concerns about downsizing," she said. "And the Governor has in the past expressed some concerns that the Port Authority has not always acted favorably toward New York."
Asked about the veto, Ms. Mucha said, "The Governor is reviewing his options."
Becky Taylor, a spokeswoman for Mrs. Whitman, said Mrs. Whitman had no objection to a meeting between Mr. Eisenberg and Mr. Pataki. She and other Whitman officials emphasized that Mr. Eisenberg had made repeated attempts to contact the Pataki administration in recent weeks, adding that he received a response only yesterday.
And she said that Mrs. Whitman had called Mr. Pataki before the board vote to alert him that she was nominating Mr. Eisenberg to replace Kathleen A. Donovan, who is stepping down as chairwoman.
Mr. Eisenberg declined to comment. But other officials in New Jersey said they did not believe that the dispute was over a courtesy call.
"This sort of ranks up there with Newt Gingrich being treated badly on the airplane," a senior Whitman official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "I don't know who is doing this or why. It just doesn't hold water."
Robert C. Janiszewski, a board member from New Jersey, said the explanation from the Pataki administration was a smokescreen.
"What is the big deal about their insistence on some chat?" he said. "It has got to be something else. There is something behind this."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
OPEC Keeps The Ceiling On Oil Output

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today that it would maintain its production ceiling through the first half of next year, even though some members were pumping more oil than allowed.
After OPEC ended its meeting, some analysts warned that prices could drop if the organization did not crack down on members who exceeded their quotas. Prices are already $4 to $5 a barrel below OPEC's target of $21. 
 Since 1993, OPEC has had a production ceiling of 24.52 million barrels a day, but some members are exceeding this by about 900,000 barrels a day. It has tolerated that overproduction, hoping that rising demand would be sufficient to lift prices. That has not happened.
"The real issue is the compliance," said Leo Drollas, chief economist for the Center for Global Energy Studies in London, who came to watch the OPEC meeting. "The market's looking for confidence."
But OPEC must also worry about larger amounts of oil coming onto world markets from countries that do not belong to the group, and analysts said this too might undermine prices next year.
In New York, crude oil gave up early gains to end 1 cent lower at $17.96 a barrel for January delivery, indicating that traders had little confidence that OPEC would be able to lift prices.
 The issue of exceeding quotas was a main focus for many gathered in Vienna this week and several ministers said they would seek ways to crack down on the cheaters, although OPEC has never found an effective way to accomplish that.
Two oil ministers, Abdallah Salim el-Badri of Libya and Abdulmohsen al-Mudij of Kuwait, said that OPEC might better police output by monitoring oil as it flowed out of wells, replacing the current system of reporting oil sold on the market or placed in overseas storage.
But changing the way quotas are measured would be a delicate proposition -- as is the topic of quota violators.
OPEC's Secretary General, Rilwanu Lukman of Nigeria, held a news conference on Tuesday and refused to answer a question about a looming supply glut mentioned in an internal OPEC report.
Venezuela's oil minister, Erwin Jose Arrieta, opened the meeting Tuesday by attacking booming production from non-OPEC sources like North Sea operators.
OPEC holds back production to support prices, but these other producers abuse the situation by pumping at capacity, he said. "There is a serious anomaly here," he said. OPEC managed to withhold production, he said, despite the fact that "OPEC's proven oil reserves are three times the size of those of non-OPEC, vastly more accessible and less expensive to exploit."
OPEC members are Algeria, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: THE SANCTIONS;
U.N. Begins to Lift the Embargoes on Balkans

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 22

 BODY:
The Security Council, fulfilling its part of the Bosnia peace agreement, began today to lift economic and military sanctions that had been imposed to end fighting in the Balkans.
One resolution, adopted without opposition but with Russia abstaining, suspends indefinitely the arms embargo that was imposed in September 1991 after Yugoslavia disintegrated. 
 The other resolution, which passed unanimously, lifts the trade sanctions first imposed in May 1992 on Serbia and Montenegro, the remaining two republics in the Yugoslav federation, but will not apply to the Bosnian Serbs until their military forces have pulled back to zones specified in the peace agreement.
Russia, which was a co-sponsor of the resolution to end trade sanctions, abstained on the arms embargo because of "serious doubts and concerns" about an interpretation of arms control that lets the outgunned Bosnian Army acquire more heavy weapons while requiring the Serbs to scale down their larger arsenal.
The Russian delegate, Sergei V. Lavrov, said allowing new arms into the region "does not fit into the logic of the political process." China and the Czech Republic also expressed reservations about arms transfers but voted for the resolution.
The United States delegate, Madeleine K. Albright, defended balancing the arsenals.
"Our plan is to discourage an arms race and to encourage a stable balance of military power," she said. "Our desire is to nourish a conviction on all sides that no side will seek to evade or take military advantage of this agreement."
The arms embargo will remain in effect for 90 days once the peace agreement is formally signed, which is expected to take place in Paris in mid-December. During the following 90 days, it will be lifted on lighter defensive weapons, but not on heavy offensive weapons like tanks, artillery and aircraft.
At the end of the 180 days, the embargo will be terminated and the system for controling and reducing the total number of heavy weapons in the region will go into effect.
Bosnia's Foreign Minister, Muhamed Sacirbey, who addressed the council after the vote, said that if the arms embargo had been lifted earlier, "peace would have come much sooner and at a lower cost." But he pledged that the Bosnian Government would not misuse its opportunity to buy arms.
"Weapons in the hands of the victim will not be used to redress yesterday's wrongs," he said.
The suspension of economic sanctions, Belgrade's major incentive to cooperate in the peace negotiations, will lead to a full termination after free and fair elections have been held in Bosnia. But they could be reimposed if the Serbian side did not respect the peace agreement.
The suspension of the economic penalties extends to the frozen assets of the former Yugoslav Government as long as there are no are claims against them. But the resolution sidesteps the competing demands by the five countries emerging from the breakup of Yugoslavia. Ms. Albright said the United States favored "an orderly and equitable distribution" of property among the successor nations.
"The United States does not intend, itself, to release any assets until all assets are examined against possible claims by the successor states, and against outstanding commercial or private claims," she said. Both resolutions were sponsored by the United States, Britain, France and Germany, which along with Russia form the so-called contact group that has worked to find a solution to the Balkan wars.

HEADLINE: Meshing the Sacred and the Secular;
Floyd Flake Offers Community Development via Church and State

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
On the corner of Merrick Boulevard and Sayres Avenue, the old Allen African Methodist Episcopal Church is like the knotted bottom of an old oak tree, its long arms stretching out in all directions across St. Albans, Queens.
Down the street is the Allen Christian School, where Allen's pastor, the Rev. Floyd H. Flake, preaches on Sunday mornings to his swelling, 8,400-member congregation. To the west, there's the 300-unit apartment complex for the elderly built by the parish 15 years ago with Federal housing loans. Next door are about four dozen two-family homes that the church's real estate arm is helping to build with city and state housing dollars. Dotting the neighborhood are 75 more houses that the church acquired or developed and sold to private home buyers. 
 Just below the school, the church also owns a strip of shops and offices: a pizzeria, a beauty shop and a home health care agency.
And up the road, on Merrick Boulevard, lie the flattened grounds of Allen A.M.E's most ambitious project yet: a $16.5 million, 2,500-seat cathedral that the parish is building, along with a three-story parking lot, a fast-food franchise and a health clinic.
Mr. Flake, 50, the pastor of Allen A.M.E. Church for nearly 20 years, refers to his parish as the model of "African-American development for the future," pointing to the $25 million it has pumped into the neighborhood.
As he also happens to represent part of Queens in the United States Congress, however, the neighborhood has greatly benefited from his savvy at funneling dollars from Capitol Hill into a variety of housing and commercial development projects, mostly around his church.
This year alone, his aides said, the Sixth Congressional District, which Mr. Flake, a Democrat, represents, has been blessed with $230 million in Federal money, the bulk of it for a United States Food and Drug Administration testing facility at York College, a stone's throw from the Allen A.M.E. Church.
He has helped secure Fannie Mae loans for several hundred houses being built nearby by the Southeast Queens Clergy for Community Empowerment, a nonprofit group that helped launch Mr. Flake's political career more than 10 years ago. And the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development is now interested in financing a proposed retail strip along Guy Brewer Boulevard, sandwiched between York College and the two-family homes that Allen A.M.E. is now helping to build and sell.
Critical of black leaders who he says are wedded to government-financed social programs, Mr. Flake's mantra for uplifting urban African-Americans is filled with the language of trickle-down economics.
"I'm interested in investment,' he said, "as a way to generate in those particular communities jobs, commercial strips, entrepreneurs, small businesses that can hire people who will not become welfare recipients, who will not become people who occupy these jail cells."
The Congressman's success at funneling Federal money to his district, his admirers and critics agree, rests largely on his willingness to befriend powerful Republicans abhorred by most New York City Democrats. Prominent among his allies on the other side is Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
With a rhetorical backhand slap, Mr. Flake, who has been in Congress nine years, says his liberal critics have failed their constituents by not reaching out to the Republicans. "Most African-American politicians in my community produce nothing,' said the Congressman, whose 25-year-old Chief of Staff comes from a conservative lobbying firm. 'And the reason they produce nothing is that they don't understand the two-party system."
Senator D'Amato earlier this year encouraged Mr. Flake to run for the New York City Mayor's office in 1997, but in an interview last week in Washington, Mr. Flake said he had decided against joining the next mayoral race.
In Mr. Flake's neighborhood of single-family homes and wide boulevards, some people praise him for bringing in Federal and private dollars for projects that have spruced up what was once a bleak stretch of St. Albans. But others say the rest of his Congressional District has not yet enjoyed the same level of public or private investment.
"It is important that the benefits reach other areas in his district, other than downtown Jamaica and the area in close proximity to the church," said Stephen Jackson, a Jamaica resident who ran unsuccessfully for the 33d State Assembly seat two years ago.
Still others applaud Mr. Flake's financial acumen but say that his emphasis on building houses and strip malls has not addressed the needs of the most disadvantaged residents of southeastern Queens -- those who can neither afford to buy a home nor run a business.
"The poorest in the community need a champion," said Solomon Goodrich, who heads the Southern Queens Park Association. "I have yet to see a commensurate amount of energy given to mass employment projects and an emphasis on the poorest of us."
Mr. Flake counters that his church builds two-family homes that can serve renters and home buyers. He maintains that his church has not received any new funds from Washington since he took office in January 1986, although long-term commitments continue. He also points to $48 million in Federal money that he helped secure this year for renovations and commercial development at the public housing projects in distant Far Rockaway, also part of his Congressional district.
In the church world, Allen A.M.E.'s real estate ventures are nothing new. The Catholic Church holds an impressive real estate portfolio. And over the last decade, many black churches have taken up the task of building housing and running neighborhood businesses at a time when the Federal Government has largely abandoned urban economic development.
Mr. Flake's parish, however, has built more and spent more than most other churches in the city, leveraging government dollars with bank loans and contributions from its middle-class congregation. Last year, the church raised more than $5 million from its members, and its nine profit-making and nonprofit subsidiaries reported $27 million in assets. In turn, Mr. Flake has built a cadre of political foot soldiers and fund-raisers among his 8,400-member church and its tenants.
"He just spread his wings in all these areas and became a political and economic force with that church base," said Nat Singleton, a veteran political activist who helped Mr. Flake get elected to Congress in 1986. 'You can't get a better base for politics."
Aptly enough, his desk in his Capitol Hill office prominently displays a three-volume set of books called "God and Government," a fitting symbol of the two hats Mr. Flake simultaneously wears. His political and pastoral activities can sometimes be intricately entwined: his onetime chief of staff, Edwin Reed, for instance, served on the board of directors of the Allen A.M.E. Housing Development Corporation while he was the Congressman's right-hand man on Capitol Hill.
But Mr. Flake can't be bothered by the questions that are raised by this meshing of church and state. "I've never been one to have a serious problem with the role of church and state," he said, shaking his head. "I don't think African-American communities can allow themselves to get caught in that trap while their communities are dying."
Allen A.M.E.'s complicated mix of sacred and secular ventures has not escaped scrutiny, however. In August 1990, after a former church secretary's testimony to a grand jury in Brooklyn accused Mr. Flake of financial improprieties, Federal prosecutors charged the Congressman and his wife, Margarett Elaine, with not reporting $177,578 in income from the church and dodging Federal income taxes. In April 1991, three weeks into the trial, prosecutors, their approach derailed by an early ruling by the judge, dropped the charges against the Flakes.
But later that year, the Justice Department brought a civil suit against Mr. Flake accusing him of improperly using Federal housing funds to build a portion of the church school. In a settlement last year, Mr. Flake and his church agreed to repay the $500,000 loan with interest but admitted to no wrongdoing.
In addition to his Congressional salary, Mr. Flake earns a $17,000 salary at Allen A.M.E. Until less than two years ago, while he was serving in Congress, the church paid for his family's house in Rosedale. He and his wife bought the house in 1993. The church, he said, had initially refused to sell it to them.
Allen A.M.E.'s latest expansion along Merrick Boulevard is not without critics in the surrounding community. Last month, the local community board approved the church's bid to rezone a three-block stretch of Merrick Boulevard, where it proposes to build a parking lot and open a Burger King franchise and a health clinic.
But some homeowners complained that there would be too much traffic from the new cathedral, while others worried that a fast-food establishment would bring rats into their homes. And some frowned on the rezoning proposal and bristled at the way in which church officials had failed to inform neighborhood residents of exactly what they want to build and where.
James Richardson, whose home lies just behind the proposed Burger King site, said he worried about what else could be built along that stretch of Merrick Boulevard if it is rezoned for commercial use. "At this time," Mr. Richardson said, "the people have no way of knowing what will be put there."
The City Planning Commission will review the church's zoning application and hold a public hearing.
In Washington, Mr. Flake dismissed the neighborhood naysayers, saying that nearly every Allen A.M.E. project had encountered some resistance from homeowners who did not understand the church's economic development agenda.
"In the end," he said, "we get done what we want."

HEADLINE: GAINS IN EXPORTS CUT TRADE DEFICIT

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
American exports unexpectedly continued to climb to new heights in September as the nation's trade deficit inched down to $8.35 billion, the lowest level of the year, Commerce Department figures showed today.
At the same time, the American deficit with Japan narrowed for the sixth consecutive month to a level nearly one-third less than in the spring. And even the deficit with China, which has been swelling rapidly to rival Japan's, contracted. 
 The gap narrowed with most trading partners in the Far East, and approached balance with Western Europe.
The Clinton Administration was quick to boast of the latest results, which, among other things, indicated that the economy's growth rate during the third quarter was likely to be revised upward significantly.
Exports jumped 1.6 percent, to $67.2 billion, after an even larger August surge that many specialists thought could not be maintained. Imports rose by about the same amount, to $75.6 billion. The decline in the trade deficit was small -- to $8,349,000,000 in September from August's $8,359,000,000, which had originally been reported at $8.8 billion.
"The trade deficit appears to have peaked," said Ronald H. Brown, the Commerce Secretary. "President Clinton has pursued a trade policy that aggressively promotes exports and presses for open markets abroad."
But today's report did not hold only good news for the Administration. The nation's trade deficit has been widening significantly with Mexico and Canada. Administration officials have already been bracing for Republican attacks over President Clinton's promotion of closer trade ties with Mexico through the North American Free Trade Agreement, and on the American bailout for Mexico after the peso crashed last December.
And today's figures also showed that the United States experienced a small deficit in trade of advanced technology products, the first time this traditional source of large surpluses had been negative.
The trade deficit, the amount by which a country's purchases of foreign goods and services exceed what it sells abroad, is widely watched as a gauge of the appeal of American wares in the global market. If they are seen as not being good value, foreign orders may go elsewhere and jobs could be lost here. One rule of thumb is that $1 billion of exports keeps nearly 20,000 Americans at work.
Trade figures also reflect fundamental trends in how a nation uses its resources. Since the United States does not generate enough savings, it relies on borrowings from abroad to cover its Federal budget deficit. The foreigners get the cash to finance the United States deficit by selling more here than they buy.
Although reports of the nation's trade position, which are published only after a considerable lag, normally do not generate talk of a shift in monetary policy, September's export surge was strong enough to at least cloud expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut short-term interest rates at its next scheduled policy meeting the week before Christmas.
"Nevertheless, we don't believe that the trade report will keep the Fed from further easing," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist with Merrill Lynch & Company. "All recent evidence suggests that domestic demand remains sluggish."
Other analysts also expressed the view that exports would need to remain strong if the economy, which has been expanding for more than four and a half years, is to prosper in 1996.
"The challenge is to maintain export growth into Japan when the Japanese economy is so weak and with the dollar having recovered from its lows," said David H. Resler, chief economist for Nomura Securities International in New York. He attributed much of the recent decline in the trade deficit with Japan to the dollar's particular weakness against the yen during the first half of the year.
Today's figures on individual countries, which are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation, showed the deficit with Japan narrowed by $800 million, to $4.3 billion, in September, the smallest since May 1993. About half that change reflected higher exports to Japan, including new cars, and the rest lower imports.
September was the first month this year in which the year-to-date deficit was lower than in 1994, according to Joseph E. Stiglitz, the President's chief economic adviser.
The deficit with China contracted to $3.6 billion from $3.9 billion.
On the other hand, the deficit with Canada widened to $1.9 billion from $1.5 billion, as did the deficit with Mexico, which grew to $1.3 billion from $1.1 billion. Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, attributed much of this to weakness in recent months in the currencies of those two countries. "That has made a huge difference," Mr. Kantor said in a telephone interview with a group of reporters.
Private analysts said the results would provide more ammunition to those seeking to prevent an expansion of the North American Free Trade Agreement, an effort that has already stalled.
The deficit with Western Europe nearly evaporated in September, totaling just $125 million compared with $769 million in August.
Mainly reflecting higher imports, the United States posted a $30 million deficit in advanced technology products in September after a surplus of $672 million in August. For the first nine months, the surplus is now $10 billion, compared with an $18.7 billion surplus in the comparable 1994 period.
"Finally our archaic controls on high-technology exports have caught up with us," contended Willard A. Workman, a vice president and trade specialist for the United States Chamber of Commerce.
A separate Commerce Department report found today that inventories of unsold goods climbed three-tenths of 1 percent in September, the 18th straight increase, while sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent but less robustly than in August.
And in a more current survey, covering the latest two weeks, the Labor Department said that first-time claims for unemployment insurance totaled 371,000 for the week ended last Saturday. This was little different from the 370,000 reported for the preceding week but analysts said they had become a bit nervous over the fact that the monthly average had now risen to 372,250, nearly 7 percent above its level in mid-October.
"Claims have approached new heights" indicating "only tepid growth" of the job market, economists at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette told clients.
The claims figures covering last week were published a day early because of the Thanksgiving Day holiday; those for the week ended Nov. 11 were delayed from last Thursday because of the partial shutdown of the Government.

(Source: Commerce Department) (pg. D8)

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
In a Land Lush With Cash, the Robbers Cash In

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Morimatsu Saito barely knew what hit him. The 63-year-old securities company employee was walking through Tokyo's financial district carrying a bag containing $400,000 to his company. Just as he reached his building, a man wearing a helmet approached him, sprayed a debilitating gas in his face, and ran off with the money.
The robbery, which took place in September on a busy street in broad daylight, was one of several recent episodes that have shocked normally safe Japan. But why would someone walk unguarded through the streets with $400,000 anyway? 
 The answer is that Japan runs on cash. Personal checks have never caught on here. Credit cards have recently been spreading rapidly, but even their use is not that well ingrained.
Instead, people often pay bills amounting to thousands of dollars in cash. Postal service employees visit customers' homes on red bicycles to collect cash for life insurance premiums or savings account deposits. And on the 10th and 20th of each month, traffic is said to be particularly heavy as businessmen visit suppliers and clients to pay bills or receive payment in cash.
In Mr. Saito's case, he was bringing the money from a nearby bank because his company, Kyoritsu Securities, needed it to pay customers, who like to receive their proceeds from stock sales in cash, even in amounts up to tens of thousands of dollars.
A result is that Japanese often carry what, by American standards, are large amounts of cash, even given the high prices here. This habit has made Japanese tourists tempting targets for pickpockets around the world. But in Japan, where robberies are rare, it has hardly been a problem.
Shigeru Nomura, an 80-year-old man who emerged from a securities company near where Mr. Saito was robbed, said he sometimes carried tens of thousands of dollars in a paper bag. "I get a little nervous," he allowed -- but not nervous enough to have someone accompany him.
Recently, however, the number of robberies, while still very low by international standards, has been rising. The police have been issuing warnings to those who transport large amounts of cash not to travel alone and to change routes frequently.
But so far people "don't feel the danger keenly," said Kiichi Shiraishi of the National Police Agency's community safety planning division. "It is said that Japanese people believe you can get safety and water free of charge," he said.
So the robberies keep occurring. In late October, Satoshi Murao, 33, an employee of Fuji Bank, visited three customers to pick up cash for deposit. When he emerged from the last customer, a hospital, he was stripped of $130,000 in a robbery.
When asked why people do not use checks, Japanese are likely to be puzzled by the question. "In a way, I wonder how Americans can trust personal checks," said Seiichiro Saito, a professor of economics at Rikkyo University. Accepting a check requires verifying or trusting the check writer's identity and financial resources.
In Japan, people can pay bills by having money automatically deducted from their bank accounts. Or they can deposit money in another party's account using sophisticated automated teller machines that give exact change.
Personal checks will also not do for bribery or tax evasion, two popular practices here. In a famous scandal a few years ago, a trucking company executive sent a bribe of about $4 million to a powerful politician. The politician's secretary had to wheel the bills in from the parking lot on a dolly.
In 1989, passers-by found moldy packets of cash worth $1.7 million in a bamboo thicket in Kawasaki, a Tokyo suburb. A businessman later admitted he had dumped the money rather than prompt a tax audit by putting it in the bank.
How hard it will be to break the cash habit might best be seen in the case of Toshio Miyaji, the president of Jonan Denki, a chain of discount electronics stores. "I feel very lonely if I have less than one million yen in my pocket," he said, referring to an amount equal to $10,000.
Mr. Miyaji's office contains an automatic cash-counting machine, the type normally found in banks, which bundles 10,000-yen notes into packages worth one million yen and spits them out onto the floor. Every day, Mr. Miyaji's aides insert one of those bundles into his wallet.
But Mr. Miyaji is most famous for his Louis Vuitton attache case, which can hold up to one million dollars in fresh 10,000-yen bills. He is often seen on television being driven around in a red or sky-blue Rolls-Royce, dispensing bills from his attache case to buy products for his stores. Paying cash, he said, allows him to get bigger discounts.
One would think this behavior would make Mr. Miyaji a conspicuous target. Sure enough, he has been robbed seven times, losing an amount equal to $390,000 at today's exchange rates.
In one case, his own driver made off with an amount equal to $65,000 at those rates. "After spending all the money he committed suicide 10 days later," Mr. Miyaji recalled. He added that he blamed himself for tempting the poor driver by leaving his attache case in the car.
Despite the robberies, the feisty 67-year-old Mr. Miyaji still carries cash around without security. "If I start worrying, it's just like closing down the store," he said.
He has, however, made a few changes. After he was robbed in his own office last year, he installed some burglar alarms there. And, oh yes, he now takes his attache case with him when he leaves the car.

HEADLINE: Dow Continues to Surge, But Broad Market Is Flat

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average continued its remarkable surge yesterday, while the broad stock market remained relatively flat.
"The day's story was that the economically sensitive stocks rose," said Barbara G. Marcin, vice president of Citibank Global Asset Management. "And the Dow is made up of 30 economically sensitive stocks." 
 By increasing 18.06 points, to 5,041.61, the Dow not only set another record -- its 61st this year -- but also marked its ninth gain in the last 11 trading days. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 1.84 points, to 598.40, while the Nasdaq composite index dropped 3.75 points, to 1,021.24.
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange narrowly topped declining issues, 1,202 to 1,104. Volume on the Big Board maintained its heavy pace, with 405 million shares changing hands, compared with 408.3 million shares on Tuesday.
Analysts cited a Commerce Department report that showed a narrower-than-expected United States trade deficit as an important factor in the Dow's rise. The deficit in goods and services shrank to a nine-month low in September, as exports registered a new high.
Cyclical stocks that benefit the most when the economy accelerates were yesterday's market standouts. With the Morgan Stanley index of cyclical stocks jumping 6.24 points, to 342.97, key advancers among manufacturing issues included Alcoa, up 2 5/8, to 57 3/4; United Technologies, up 1 1/4, to 92; Du Pont, up 2 1/8, to 67 1/4, and Goodyear, up 1 3/4, to 42 3/8.
"People were looking for stocks in sectors that have underperformed this year," Ms. Marcin of Citibank said. "So their attention was focused on the cyclicals."
Paper companies with large export sales showed strength that was attributed to the foreign trade report. International Paper closed at 36 3/4, up 1 1/4; Georgia-Pacific finished at 75 3/8, up 2 3/8, and Champion International closed at 46 3/4, up 1 3/4.
Many technology stocks lagged once again, as traders rotated out of a number of this year's high-fliers. Microsoft fell 5/8, to 87 3/8; Intel declined 1 1/8, to 61 7/8; Micron Technology dropped 2 7/8, to 47 3/4, and Motorola lost 1 1/4, to 59 7/8.
Oil issues were also lower, following the announcement by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries that it would retain its current production ceiling for another six months, despite slower demand. Mobil declined 2 3/8, to 105 1/2; ARCO slumped 1 1/8, to 109 7/8, and Chevron fell 1 3/8, to 49 1/2.
Newbridge Networks advanced 1 3/4, to 41 3/4, after reporting stronger-than-expected fiscal second-quarter profits on Tuesday. IMC Global rose 3 3/8, to 76 3/8, after being upgraded by Dean Witter. And Boston Beer, which jumped 8 when it went public Tuesday, gained another 1 3/8 yesterday to close at 29 3/8.

HEADLINE: Ernest Jarvis, 92, a Contractor Who Lighted Theaters and Road

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Ernest Jarvis, who began his career as a 14-year-old union electrician and ended it 64 years later as head of his own contracting company, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Morristown, N.J. He was 92 and had outlived many of his most famous projects, from the illuminated West Side Highway in Manhattan to a string of Loews movie palaces across the country.
Mr. Jarvis, who bore such a striking resemblance to his second cousin, Jacob Javits, that the Senator's bodyguards were forever being fooled, could be a case study of the social and economic saga of 20th-century America. 
 His father, Louis, an immigrant from Russia who changed the family name from the original Hebrew, settled in Newark, where he went to work for a hat factory and helped organize the work force at a time when union organizing was not an especially genteel activity: He almost went to jail after the factory happened to burn down.
Mr. Jarvis himself obtained his first electrician's union card in Newark in 1917, and maintained it long after he became a senior executive at the old Hoffman & Elias electrical company, which operated in some pretty tough times. As his son Michael, also an electrical contractor, recalled yesterday, when the union electricians showed up for a job, "the bulges under their coats weren't sandwiches."
Despite the security of union work, Mr. Jarvis was so determined to improve himself that, although he lacked academic credentials for admission, he virtually camped out at the dean's office at Columbia University until he was accepted into its engineering school in 1925.
He did well in his courses, but a lack of funds forced him to withdraw without a degree two years later. This was a galling failure for a man who prided himself on finishing everything he started, so much so that decades later, whenever asked to receive a civic award, he invariably declined, to avoid calling attention to his lack of college degree.
Moving from union to management ranks when he joined Hoffman & Elias, Mr. Jarvis was so impressive that while still in his 20's, he was operating as chief estimator, calculating projected costs before bids are submitted for a job. He advanced the process considerably in the 1930's when he developed a unit estimating system that is the basis of procedures in use today.
In addition to working on many theaters, including the old Roxy at Seventh Avenue and 50th Street and other movie palaces in New York as well as a number of Loews theaters across the country, Mr. Jarvis was in charge of the electrical work on the Julius Miller Highway, along the West Side of Manhattan, which is recalled as both the Depression's largest construction project and the nation's first elevated urban highway.
Other big projects included the Jersey City Medical Center, where Mr. Jarvis's daughter, Joyce, was the first baby born, in the Martha Hague maternity unit after it was completed in 1932.
After leaving Hoffman & Elias in the late 1930's, he worked for other contractors, and supervised several projects, including the installation of the Edison Memorial Light in Edison, N.J. He formed a company, Ernest Jarvis & Company, in Newark in 1940.
Striking out on his own was a daring move given the economic times, but Mr. Jarvis had some key financial backing -- a revolving $600 loan from his mother-in-law.
"That money went back and forth a dozen times," his son said, recalling that every time his father would repay the loan he would need to borrow it again.
The company, which specialized in industrial work, was eventually so successful that half a dozen branch offices were opened before Mr. Jarvis retired in 1972.
Since then, changing entertainment patterns and urban development have doomed the Roxy and many of the other theaters he worked on. Much of the once-wondrous West Side Highway has been torn down for safety measures. That, of course, was hardly Mr. Jarvis's fault. It was not, after all, flaws in the highway's lighting system that caused the demolition.
Indeed, as for the quality of his work, city officials said yesterday that the memorial light Mr. Jarvis helped install in Menlo Park, at the base of a tower erected on the spot where Thomas Alva Edison invented the light bulb, has been burning continuously since 1938.
Mr. Jarvis's wife, Dorothy, died in 1960. In addition to his son, of Livingston, N.J., he is survived by his daughter, Joyce Hoch, of Morristown; a sister, Sylvia Margolis of Dallas, six grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Issues Down a Bit In an Abbreviated Session

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were slightly lower in an abbreviated session yesterday.
The consolidation came despite the release of a number of economic reports -- including data on the nation's trade deficit and business inventories -- that had been delayed by the Government's partial shutdown last week. 
 "The reports," said James Hale, a fixed-income analyst at MMS International in San Francisco, "with the exception of the export data, were all mildly bullish for the market, but not enough to draw in fresh buyers ahead of the long Thanksgiving holiday."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond slipped 5/32 of a percentage point, to 108 2/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, edged up to 6.27 percent, from 6.26 percent on Tuesday. The market will be closed today in observance of Thanksgiving Day.
The cash market for Treasury securities closed at 2 P.M. yesterday; the Public Securities Association, an industry trade group, has recommended that the market close early tomorrow.
Yesterday, most market participants chose to square positions as the market began to look ahead to next week with more supply looming and fresh economic data. The Treasury announced yesterday the size of its two-year and five-year note auctions. Both sales will be $500 million more than previous auctions. On Tuesday, the Government will sell $18.25 billion of new two-year notes and on Wednesday, $12 billion of five-year notes.
In when-issued trading late in the day, dealers were offering the two-year notes at a price to yield 5.51 percent and the five-year notes at a price to yield 5.71 percent.
Mr. Hale of MMS International attributed the market's weakness in part to concerns over supply and to the trade and export data, which suggested there were still some pockets of strength in the economy.
The Commerce Department said the United States trade deficit shrank one-tenth of 1 percent in September, to $8.3 billion of goods and services. September's gap was smaller than the $9.7 billion that economists had expected, and could prompt some economists to raise their estimates for third-quarter gross domestic product.
The Government also said that business inventories grew at a rate of three-tenths of 1 percent in September, slower than their pace of four-tenths of 1 percent in August. The report was in line with analysts' expectations. Sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent in September after gaining 1.8 percent in August.
Other data gave a modest lift to bond prices. The University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index showed a drop, to 88.2 from 90.2, in October, traders and analysts said. The numbers were noticeably weaker than than the initial numbers of the index reported earlier this month, analysts said. The consumer sentiment survey is released only to subscribers.
In futures trading, which was also an abbreviated session, the December Treasury bond contract closed at 117 13/32, near its high for the day of 117 17/32. Robin Mesch, fixed-income analyst for Thomson Research of Boston, said the critical support level for tomorrow appeared to be 117 8/32. "If it stays over that, the price could go as high as about 117 22/32," she said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 657 words

HEADLINE: Washington's Statistical Wars

 BODY:
The chairman of the House's tax-writing committee, Bill Archer, has defended the fairness of the budget bill Congress passed this week by pointing to his staff's estimates that only about 9 percent of the Republicans' tax cuts would go to families earning over $200,000, the richest 1 percent.
The Democrats did not believe the figures, and yesterday the Treasury showed why. It estimated that the richest 1 percent would rake in almost twice as much, or 17 percent, of the tax cut. Indeed under the Republican bill the poorest 20 percent of families, taken as a group, would pay higher taxes as a percentage of their income. But the bill would reduce taxes by steadily increasing amounts as family incomes rise. The biggest tax cut would go to the richest families. 
 Confused? So was Congress when it voted. It relied on misleading estimates by its tax analysts. The Treasury analysis can be challenged, but in the main it followed guidelines that independent economists would agree with. The Treasury figures are solid evidence that the Republican tax cut is heavily weighted toward the rich.
The Republican distribution tables are distorted in at least four ways. First, they underestimate the benefit to wealthy investors of the cut in the tax on capital gains. The Republicans and the Treasury start off by calculating how much less tax investors would pay under the new, lower rates on the amount of sales they would normally undertake. But the Republican analysis reduces this estimate by the amount of extra taxes investors will voluntarily pay because they decide to sell off more stocks and bonds than usual.
This bizarre reduction makes the total tax savings to investors look small because it treats voluntary tax payments -- triggered by a gift from Congress -- as a burden.
Second, the estimates ignore the distribution of corporate tax cuts, which help the wealthy more than the poor. Third, Mr. Archer's numbers look only at the first five years of the tax cut. Treasury's estimates calculate the benefit when the taxes are fully phased in. For example, the tax bill gives high-income families the option of depositing money into a new type of tax-advantaged retirement account. Over the next few years, wealthy families might pay more because of this change. But several years later, they will reap big savings. The Treasury captures these benefits, the Republicans ignore them.
Fourth, Mr. Archer's figures fail to consider the fact that many low-income families will lose rebates they now receive under the earned-income tax credit -- a subsidy for low-wage workers. Indeed, according to the Treasury's estimates, almost eight million low-income families will pay higher taxes under the G.O.P. plan even after taking account of the $500 child credit and a higher standard deduction.
The Treasury figures can also be challenged. They, like Mr. Archer, ignore cuts in estate taxes, the benefit of which would go primarily to wealthy families. Impartial analysts can differ whether the Treasury apportioned corporate tax cuts correctly. But over all, the Treasury methodology is much less partisan -- and similar to what Congressional staffs used to provide.
Besides taxes, the Republican budget bill also tilts spending cuts against the poor. Federal spending under current laws would total in the year 2002 about $2.2 trillion, of which about $333 billion, or 15 percent, would go to the needy -- mostly for food stamps, welfare, Medicaid and tax credits for low-paid workers. The Republican budget in 2002 would cut these need-based programs by almost twice their share, a whopping 24 percent.
Congress and voters will engage for at least the next several weeks in an intense debate about the merits and demerits of the Republican budget. Before people make up their minds, they need to know unvarnished facts. The Treasury may not have provided the last word, but its word is truer than Mr. Archer's.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Biting Bosnia's Bullet

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
For years, those of us who believed the world had an obligation to stop Serbian aggression in Bosnia favored "lift and strike": First, lift the U.N. arms embargo that blocked the Bosnians from matching the far superior Serbian firepower; then, strike hard from the air to stop the aggressors while a balance of power was being achieved.
The idea was to get ineffective U.N. troops out and make possible a peace between military equals. This road was not taken. 
 Instead, after the hand-wringing by President Clinton and our NATO partners led to intolerable bloodletting, the decision was taken to "strike and peacemake." Air power was at last used to scare the Serbs to the peace table, and the promise of NATO troops, including 20,000 Americans, was made to persuade the Muslims to give up half their country and accept on-site protection.
So here we are. The Clinton Administration -- acceding to our allies' nail-nibbling demand for American leadership in Europe -- has brokered a peace requiring another American expeditionary force. .
By so doing, Clinton has painted all of us, hawks and doves, into a corner. He made an ill-considered promise in May 1993 -- with no public debate or thorough internal review or consultation with Congress -- to send U.S. ground troops to carry out what was called the Vance-Owen plan, concocted in a previous era.
Now he tells us that unless his "commitment" of troops is honored and supported here, the Balkan carnage will begin again, NATO will become a dead letter and the word of the American President will be revealed as worthless.
Unfortunately, that's true. Like it or not, our choice is to go along with him or repudiate and humiliate him. That's Hobson's choice, which is no choice at all.
We'll go along. Why? Because he may be mistaken in his method, but his belated Bosnia activism is not foolhardy, U.N.-subordinated, mean-spirited or immoral. With luck, it could even work.
Rather than grump about the rejection of "lift and strike," air-power interventionists should recognize that Clinton's policy is better than another year of his demeaning vacillation. Rather than sit back and say to the President, "Convince us," Congress and the public should help him refine and define his new policy.
In his Monday night speech he should declare that if any side hits our peace-enforcers we will not cut and run, as in Lebanon and Somalia. The full division of Americans based in Tuzla will respond with ferocity, even as our allies plead with us to be "proportionate."
The agreement negotiated in Dayton suggests that the Administration at last understands the need to create a balance of power. Clinton must make clear to Congress that the half of Bosnia that is Muslim-Croatian will have more tanks and artillery and electronics than the part that is Serbian, because the Bosnian Serbs have backup forces in Serbia.
Does that mean we are making peace by building up one side? Yes; we are obligated to build the defenses of the weak, who did not start the war. If, as Defense Secretary Perry keeps hoping, the aggressors achieve balance by a "build-down," fine; but let's not count on it. Forget evenhandedness; remember who the victims were and which entity remains most threatened.
At the same time, the President should make clear to Muslims and Croats that further reliance on Iran is unacceptable. With the embargo lifted, Pakistan and Poland can work out the transfer of ex-Soviet arms.
Clinton should emphasize that we expect more war-crimes indictments, and will put economic heat on the parties to give up those indicted for trial at The Hague. That goes for one mad psychiatrist and the butcher of Srebrenica as well as individual murderers and rapists.
Should the President ask Congress to authorize this use of troops? That was decided long ago. In an Oct. 20, 1993, letter to then-majority leader George Mitchell, Clinton brought up the possibility of sending an unspecified number of troops to "implement" a peace agreement, and said he would "welcome and encourage Congressional authorization of any military involvement in Bosnia."
Congress should listen, probe, debate, caution -- and then, on Bob Dole's motion, give him the authorization he needs.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SHARES OF LUND INTERNATIONAL HOLDINGS DROP 23%

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
Shares of Lund International Holdings Inc. fell 23 percent yesterday after the company said late on Tuesday that sales for its second quarter, ending Dec. 31, would be lower than expected. The company, which makes accessories for light trucks and vans, attributed the outlook to a soft retail economy, a decline in light truck sales and other factors that caused expanded inventory at distributors. Lund, which is based in Anoka, Minn., said it had cut its work force by 10 percent and had consolidated its operations. In last year's second quarter, Lund earned $1.65 million, or 37 cents a share, on sales of $11.1 million. Lund's shares were down $3.375, to $10.75, in Nasdaq trading.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
DOUBLETREE IN DEAL TO DEVELOP EXTENDED-STAY HOTELS

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Doubletree Corporation has signed an agreement to develop an extended-stay, economy-priced lodging brand with Jack DeBoer, the founder of Residence Inn. Doubletree, a Phoenix-based manager or franchiser of 110 hotels in the United States, plans to invest an initial $15 million in the project and to own a 50 percent stake. Mr. DeBoer, who will serve as president and chief executive, will own the other 50 percent. The venture, to be based in Wichita, Kan., and to be called Candlewood Hotels, will charge less than $50 a night for a suite with a kitchenette. The properties, which are aimed at travelers who plan stays of several days or more, will have an average of 135 rooms and will cost about $4.7 million to $5.4 million to build.

LENGTH: 1800 words

HEADLINE: Liberal Urging Has Given Way To Eerie Hush

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
With the Republican Congress moving to slash many Federal social programs, an odd hush has fallen over Washington: the sound of liberal advocacy groups that have been unable to create much of a clamor against the most drastic cuts in decades.
"If you compare what's going on now to the health care debate two years ago, you can't help but wonder why there is such an eerie silence on issues that are so central to so many people's lives," said Alan Ehrenhalt, the executive editor of Governing magazine. "There's so many important things going on in Congress, with Medicaid, Medicare and welfare reform. I read the paper, and I think, Where's the noise?" 
 Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, who has been frustrated at his inability to muster opposition to the welfare overhaul bill this fall, wonders the same thing, far more furiously.
"Fifteen years ago, if there was a proposal to take $40 out of some demonstration project here on the Senate floor, there would be 40 representatives of various advocacy groups outside," Mr. Moynihan said. "There are very few advocacy groups outside. You can stand where I stand and look straight out at the Supreme Court -- not a person in between that view. Not one of those flaunted, vaunted advocacy groups forever protecting the interest of the children and the helpless and the homeless and the what-you-will.
"Are they increasingly subsidized and therefore increasingly co-opted? Are they silent because the White House is silent?"
What is happening to advocacy? As the Government lurches toward its Dec. 15 budget deadline for resolving how much to spend on Medicare, education, the welfare system, and other social programs, the landscape seems dramatically altered.
In part, momentum has shifted from the liberal advocacy groups, which are reeling in the face of the Republican agenda, to the conservative ones, which have gained tremendously in strength and power.
For conservative groups like the Heritage Foundation, the Christian Coalition and the National Right to Life Committee, these are heady days, replete with respectful attention in the news and the chance, for the first time in decades, to work with a Congressional majority to change the role of the Federal Government.
At the same time, the nature of advocacy has changed, becoming less a matter of mass protests and grass-roots coalitions than an expensive amalgam of focus groups, paid television advertisements, E-mail and faxes put together by highly paid Washington lawyers. Indeed, the only large march in Washington in the last year, the Million Man March in October, was not based on an advocacy agenda or political demands, but was pure identity politics, bringing black men together.
 
Liberal Groups AskIf Anyone's Listening
The sheer breadth of the battles to be fought has stunned many liberal advocacy groups: welfare, legal services, Medicare and Medicaid are all under attack. Some advocates say they have felt compelled to cooperate with the Republicans rather than lose all by fighting. Contributing to the silence is the difficulty of mobilizing their own members at a time when so many Americans have lost faith in Government.
And some Republicans in Congress are attacking the advocacy groups themselves. Representative Ernest Jim Istook Jr. of Oklahoma and others are seeking to make nonprofit groups ineligible for Federal grants if they engage in significant advocacy. The Istook amendment, which delayed the budget resolution for 10 weeks and galvanized opposition from liberal advocacy groups, is dead for now, but is likely to be reintroduced as part of a lobbying disclosure bill.
Liberal advocacy groups say Senator Moynihan's tirade in Congress, during this fall's welfare debate, was unfair. They say they have lobbied desperately to get the White House and Congress to reject the Republican spending cuts, and have won some important concessions. And as to mobilizing mass support, they say, it is not that they are keeping quiet, but that no one much is listening -- and that outside Washington, there is little understanding of the profound social changes the Republicans propose.
"If there's a silence, it's the silence of trees falling in the forest unheard," said James Weill, general counsel of the Children's Defense Fund. "Like all the trees cut down to print our excellent report on the state of America's children, which passed unnoticed across many, many desks. Between March and September, we did all kinds of reports, press releases, and events on welfare, but they just didn't get the attention they did in the past. Part of it is that people in this country don't have the foggiest idea of what's coming at them. When the Congressional cuts begin to bite, we'll start seeing reaction."
Meanwhile, though, liberal advocacy groups are spending most of their time defending old ground.
"Most of the advocacy work these days is trying to defend the hard-won victories of 10 or 20 years ago, or even back in the New Deal," said David Cohen, co-director of the Advocacy Institute, a Washington group that teaches citizen groups how to influence policy. "We had to fight the Istook amendment. There's no choice about that. It had to be done. But it's not a substitute for a vision. There isn't a vision right now."
 
In Centers of Power, Fewer Voices on Left
As liberal advocacy groups run to stay in place, conservative groups march ahead with a clear agenda.
"What we're saying is that on fundamental issues like welfare, Medicare and the budget, government has not been working," said Stuart M. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at the conservative Heritage Foundation. "This is something we've been crystallizing over many years, and it strikes a chord for average Americans, who agree that we need structural changes. So of course it's very difficult for the left to mount mass opposition to those changes."
Certainly, there are fewer liberal voices heard in centers of power these days. What was once an extensive network of welfare rights organizations largely withered under the Reagan Administration. And the bloc of liberal mayors and governors who could be counted on to protest any attempt to cut back social spending in the years that the Republicans held the White House -- among them Mario M. Cuomo, David N. Dinkins, Michael S. Dukakis, Henry G. Cisneros and Ann Richards -- have been replaced by more conservative politicians.
"The larger story is that this is a time when Americans doubt the ability of the government to do anything, so it's hard to rally public support," said John Rother, the legislative director of the American Association of Retired Persons.
If liberal advocacy is less visible than it once was, he and others said, it is in part because many groups have decided that in light of the political realities in Congress, their energies are better used on the inside, negotiating with legislators, than on the outside, organizing mass protests or letter-writing campaigns.
"Any group like A.A.R.P. that represents a broad spectrum of people has a responsibility to get the best possible deal for its members," Mr. Rother said. "We had to go in there and negotiate. Even if what we end up with is still unacceptable, it's clear to me that without us in there, the bill would've been worse in quite specific ways."
Some longtime Washington watchers, though, say that the liberal advocacy groups were slow to develop their tactics for fighting a Republican Congress and that they were stranded by a President who did not stand his ground.
"We had a fundamental transfer of power, and in the opening months, people were just sitting there shell-shocked, and the President was essentially sitting on the sidelines," said Fred Wertheimer, the former president of the public-interest group Common Cause. "Meanwhile, the Republicans were rushing to do everything at once."
 
New Technology Replaces Grass Roots
At the same time, Mr. Wertheimer said, the nature of advocacy has changed since the mass protests of the 1960's and 1970's.
"Marches aren't the way you fight advocacy battles now," he said. "Technology is becoming more and more a factor in the ability to conduct advocacy campaigns. That plays to those with resources: Welfare mothers don't send faxes, they don't get E-mail, and they can't buy paid television ad campaigns."
Business groups have become sophisticated about using boiler-room telephone operations in Washington to create the semblance of a grass-roots advocacy campaign. One such "Astroturf" campaign was last summer's fight over the telecommunications law, in which long-distance telephone companies flooded Congress with more than half a million telegrams ostensibly sent by citizens urging the House not to rewrite the law.
But an investigation by members of Congress, puzzled to be getting so much public reaction on an issue that was hardly riveting to most Americans, discovered that as many as half the telegrams were bogus, sent by a telemarketing firm without authorization from the people whose names were signed -- some of whom were dead.
"Our vendor messed up, and I feel terrible about the breakdown of the system," said Robert Beckel, chairman of Beckel Cowan, the public relations firm that coordinated the campaign. "But that aside, I don't see anything wrong with this kind of advocacy. If you have the resources, what's wrong with calling people, asking for their support, and telling them you'll send a telegram for them? It's a lot more representative than hiring some well-connected Washington lobbyist."
Perhaps, but neither kind of campaign is available to those without resources. "We're in an era when most political speech is bought, so we heard a lot during the health care debate two years ago from insurers and others whose economic interests were at stake," said Mr. Weill of the Children's Defense Fund. "The reason there isn't much now is that people with lots of money are perfectly happy about what's happening."
Ralph Neas, a Washington lawyer who is counsel to the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, said progressive groups needed to learn to match right-wing prowess in handling electronic media and shaping a clear message.
"Our side has not done as good a job as we should have in framing the issue," he said. "Americans might think we're just talking about the budget deficit, when we're really talking about the role of government. I don't think people have any idea what is going to happen to millions of children and women in poor families if we undo a 60-year Federal social safety net. If the President doesn't stand firm in blocking the conservative agenda, we will probably not see that net put back together in our lifetimes."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Bank Guidelines Prepared For Traders Who Gamble
Responding to trading scandals at Barings and other banks, Federal banking regulators are to propose guidelines to limit pay for traders who take excessive risks, Government officials and traders said.
Bank regulators hope to bring traders' personal financial interests in line with their banks' interests, rather than see employers reward traders who take huge risks to earn large bonuses -- while endangering their employer's viability. While examiners' guidelines do not carry the force of law, banks follow them scrupulously because poor marks from an examiner can lead to a wide range of regulatory problems. [D10.]
 
Leeson Charged in Singapore
Singapore formally charged the former Barings trader Nicholas W. Leeson today with fraud and forgery linked to some $1.4 billion in losses that broke the venerable bank. Mr. Leeson arrived in Singapore on Thursday, after a 13-hour flight from Germany. If convicted, he could be sentenced to 14 years in prison. [D12]
 
English-French Water Merger
A French water company is buying a big British counterpart for the first time. Lyonnaise des Eaux is buying Northumbrian Water Group for $1.28 billion. Shares of Northumbrian surged to almost five times their value at the time the company was privatized. [D12.]
 
Bonanza at a Nickel Mine
Prospectors in Eastern Canada stumbled upon a vast cache of nickel in 1993, making a small company into a giant mining company. The market capitalization of the company, Diamond Fields, has soared from $100 million to $3 billion in less than a year. And within a few years, the mine could be producing 8 percent of the nickel consumed in the world. It is welcome news for the company's founder, who is in trouble with American authorities after the collapse of one of his earlier enterprises. [D10.]

Cartel's Woes Drain Colombia
The Cali drug cartel is facing an economic crisis that appears to be roiling the economy of Colombia. The stock market there has tumbled, and members of the cartel have been selling real estate for cash. At the same time, the peso has lost 7 percent of its dollar value because of the scarcity of dollars. [A7.]
 
Troubles at Privately Run Jails
As the Federal Government puts control of some of its jails in private hands, pitfalls are emerging, including overly generous contracts and the hiring of companies that are difficult for the Government to supervise. [A1.]
 
A Study of Economics of Gambling
Can gambling revive towns? It is a $482 billion industry, but its economic, social and political effects are little understood. Bills in Congress may provide that information. [A1.]
 
Hyundai Car Plant in India
Hyundai of South Korea is to build a $1 billion plant in India in a venture to assemble 200,000 passenger cars annually. [D12.]
 
Roller Coaster for High-Tech Stock
Illinois Superconductor is one of a handful of publicly traded companies striving to exploit the strange physical phenomenon known as superconductivity. But while it is racing to demonstrate the commercial value of its high-efficiency device for filtering radio waves, its stock have been taking a roller coaster ride on the Nasdaq market. [D14.]
 
A Virtual Visit To Antarctica
Mountain Travel Sobek hopes to take one million people on a cruise through Antarctica next month, 38 of them on the research ship Livonia and the remainder on the World Wide Web. "Virtual" travelers will track their progress through live chats with crew members, video from the field and hourly weather updates. Advertising. [D14.]
 
London Stocks Tumble
Stock prices fell from their record levels in London, and were mixed in other overseas markets. The dollar rose against European currencies but fell against the yen. [D10.]
