HEADLINE: Federal Study Would Weigh Costs of Gambling's Spread

BYLINE: By By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: DEADWOOD, S.D.

 BODY:
Betty Whittington and Bill Walsh have come down on opposite sides of the argument over gambling in this gritty Black Hills mining town, which voted to legalize casinos in 1989. Although both fought to pass the legislation, Mrs. Whittington now strongly opposes the casinos, which have all but wiped out the town's retailers, while Mr. Walsh, who owns a casino and a hotel, says gambling has helped revive what had been a dying community.
But the two agree on what is becoming one of the most critical issues for the dozens of communities across the country that have considered proposals for gambling. Mrs. Whittington and Mr. Walsh say that before the vote, they had no idea what the casinos would do to the town and that they would have done things differently if they had. 
 "In many ways, it's been 180 degrees different from what we sold the state when we fought for this," said Mr. Walsh, who runs the Franklin Hotel on Main Street, which is now lined by gaudy gambling parlors. "We had thought it would just be back-room gambling. Obviously, we've lost a lot of retail because of it. I don't think we had any idea how much people wanted to gamble."
Strolling past storefront casinos that have replaced everything from the state social services office to the insurance broker and department store, Mrs. Whittington commented, "I'm homesick all the time, and I never left home. We were completely unrealistic."
The experience of Deadwood -- and many other communities that had once embraced gambling as a shortcut to prosperity, from Atlantic City to New Orleans -- is an important reason why the most significant legislation for the future of the rapidly expanding, $482 billion gambling economy may be two bills in Congress that would provide communities with a commodity often in short supply: information.
The bills would create a national commission that would study the profound, if still poorly understood, economic, social and political effects of gambling and would arm communities with that information before they decided whether to allow casino operators.
The legislation is being fought bitterly by the American Gaming Association, a powerful new industry group that is led by Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., the former chairman of the Republican Party. Mr. Fahrenkopf, who has warned against an assault on the industry by "a greedy Federal Government and moral crusaders," says the bills are Trojan horses whose real intention is to open the way for Federal regulations.
The sponsors insist that the bills are focused only on information.
"If you want it in your community, fine," said Rep. Frank R. Wolf, a Republican from Virginia who is the original sponsor of the House bill and is an admitted opponent of casinos. "But at least you should have information available to make an intelligent choice. People have not had that."
The House bill has more than 100 co-sponsors, and its passage appears likely, perhaps before the end of the year. The Senate version, sponsored by Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, and Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, could be voted on early next year.
"One of the main reasons you've seen this headlong rush to build casinos in the past few years is that there was not much information on the broader economic impact of gambling," said Robert Goodman, a professor at Hampshire College and author of "The Luck Business," a book recently published by Marvin Kessler Books/The Free Press. "You cannibalize the local economy to a large degree when you open a casino. You just transfer money from one area to another. People just have no idea."
Among the issues that would be explored in the study are how much casinos simply transfer spending from local businesses to the slot machines and gambling tables and how much gambling increases crime and the costs of crime prevention. It would also look at the drawing power of gambling advertising, the effects of computerized gambling and gambling on the Internet, and the actual costs of gambling addictions to businesses and communities.
It had once been estimated that slightly less than 1 percent of a population was susceptible to gambling addiction, but some new studies are putting that figure as high as 5 percent. They find that treating the disorder can cost more than $15,000 for each person.
In fact, corporations are already starting to deliver their own assessments of the impact of gambling by avoiding areas that have casinos.
"It is a very competitive environment among cities seeking corporate relocations," said James Wadley of the Wadley-Donovan Group, corporate relocation consultants in Morristown, N.J. "All things being equal, if you had two opportunities, the one without gambling is going to be more attractive than the one with gambling."
Gambling supporters have tried to amend the legislation. They complain that the bills would be the first step toward Federal regulation of a business that the states are better equipped to control, and they question the fairness of any study financed by Congress.
Mr. Fahrenkopf said, "Our concern is that these two pieces of legislation are predisposed to an unfair and biased look." Since no two communities are alike, the study cannot provide general conclusions about gambling nationwide, he added.
"Each jurisdiction has got to weigh the issue based on their own socioeconomic conditions," Mr. Fahrenkopf said. "It's our view that gaming may not work everywhere. But you can't take that study and apply it to Oregon or Minnesota."
Before the explosive spread of gambling in the past few years, academic experts interested in the topic had little to study, beyond the isolated instances of Las Vegas and Atlantic City. Now the proliferation of casinos is generating a slow trickle of reports.
Clearly, casinos have brought some economic benefits to certain communities, particularly to a few Indian tribes. Perhaps the best example is the enormously prosperous Foxwoods Resort Casino, opened by the Mashantucket Pequot tribe in Ledyard, Conn., in 1992. That gambling revenue has created jobs, bought homes and given many tribe members a good education.
But even the Indian casinos have a great impact on the surrounding areas. A study of the 17 Indian casinos in Wisconsin earlier this year found that they had produced $326.7 million in revenue for the state but that related social costs had reduced those benefits to a maximum of $166 million. Because of those social costs, the state might even have lost money in the long run, the study said.
The study also found that the Wisconsin casinos generally attracted the poor and the elderly. The typical gambler is 50 to 70 years old, the report said, and has a family income of $20,000 to $30,000 a year.
"What we found is that it's a transfer of money, really from the lower-middle-income and poor to the casino operators," said William Thompson, a professor at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas and a co-author of the study.
He estimated that if less than half the gambling at a casino is done by people who live outside the state, the state loses substantial sums of money.
"When the industry studies casinos, they tell you where the money goes to, not where it comes from," said Mr. Thompson, who endorses the national study proposed by Congress.
Other studies have also shown that there can be substantial hidden costs for casinos.
John Warren Kindt, a professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and the author of several gambling studies, has estimated that every dollar in tax revenue brought in by legalized gambling generates about $3 in costs. He has also estimated that a one-cent increase in a local sales tax will raise more net revenue than legalized gambling.
Supporters of the gambling bills say a national study is important because casinos often have an impact on more than one state. Thecasinos draw customers from a broad area.
"The problem is that states are not making these decisions independently," said Peter Reuter, a professor of public policy at the University of Maryland and a researcher on a study being done in his state. "The decision to put casinos in Massachusetts is based on what's happening in Connecticut, for instance."
The Parish of Grant, a rural district in Louisiana, does not have gambling, but it is within 50 miles of a number of riverboats and other casinos. Edward L. Tarpley Jr., the local prosecutor, said the area had suffered a big increase in the number of cases of worthless checks, embezzlement and forgeries, most of them related to gambling.
"We do not have a casino in our parish, but we have all the problems," Mr. Tarpley said. "We simply did not know what this was about. What the gambling people are doing is picking off states and communities one at a time, using the studies they have paid for. People don't have the real information about the costs. We sure didn't."
Jeffry Bloomberg, the former prosecutor in Deadwood and now head of South Dakota's prison system, said that another side effect of gambling was its tendency to dominate local politics. The local government becomes so dependent on the success of gambling to raise revenue that it has to rethink positions on numerous issues, he added.
"It changed the whole character of the community and the government," Mr. Bloomberg said. "Almost any decision at City Hall is based on what's good for gambling now. I'm not sure that is what the government should be focused on."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Congress is working on legislation requiring that information be given to communities considering proposals for casino gambling. Meanwhile, Bill Walsh, owner of the Franklin Hotel and Casino, said a 1989 vote on gambling in Deadwood, S.D., would probably have come out differently had he and others known more about how gambling would change the character of their town. (Michael Lewis for The New York Times) (pg. B16)

HEADLINE: John Collins, 76, Boston Mayor During City's Renewal in the 60's

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
John F. Collins, one of three strong postwar mayors who rebuilt Boston with a formula emulated around the country, died of pneumonia today at Vencor Hospital here, where he had been under treatment since July. He was 76.
During his two terms as Mayor, from 1960 to 1968, Mr. Collins oversaw a wave of rebuilding and renovation begun in the late 1950's by his predecessor, John Hynes. 
 "What Collins has left us is the greatest legacy any mayor can, which is an investment in the city for the long term," Marisa Lago, director of the Boston Redevelopment Authority, said today. "He had the vision to insure that Boston wouldn't recede into a backwater city."
During Mr. Collins's tenure, the redevelopment authority, created by Mr. Hynes, channeled $2 billion of Federal money into renewal projects. Government Center arose from the rubble of seedy Scollay Square during the Collins administration, the Prudential Center became an anchor of the city's economic and commercial revival, and the city's dying waterfront began a new life as a business and tourist center.
Mr. Collins also envisioned the conversion of run-down warehouses around Faneuil Hall into a bright mix of restaurants and stores. That project, Quincy Market, was begun under his successor, Kevin White.
Not that Boston's urban renewal was regarded as universally successful. The wholesale razing of the working-class, vibrant West End to make way for high-rise apartments became its most widely criticized feature.
Mr. Collins, a native of Boston's Roxbury section, attended city schools before enrolling in Suffolk University, where he studied law and, in 1941, graduated at the top of his class.
Mr. Collins, a Democrat, practiced law in Roxbury before serving for several years in the Massachusetts Legislature. Then, during a 1955 epidemic, he and his four children were all stricken with polio. The children recovered fully, but he spent 10 years in a wheelchair and later was able to walk only with the help of crutches.
Mr. Collins is survived by his wife, Mary Patricia Cunniff; their four children, and five grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Parade Leader Can Never Show Deflation

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Greeting yesterday's blustery dawn with a general's determination, Jean McFaddin drove out to inspect her troops. She powered her golf cart past human bowling pins, assorted clowns and two cross-eyed dragons, before stopping to speak in code with a lieutenant.
"I hear there's a little Big Apple problem," she said to the aide. "If it falls through, we'll move to Mother Goose." 
 She had not slept in more than 24 hours, but this was no time for rest. Not on the D-Day of pageantry, the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. And certainly not for Jean McFaddin, its producer, director and grande dame for the last 18 years.
Having addressed the Big Apple float problem -- the engine was acting up -- Ms. McFaddin continued north on Central Park West. She wore a uniform of red and black, Macy's colors. In her pocketbook was a walkie-talkie: on this day, communication was almost as important as the weather.
Almost. There was no way for Ms. McFaddin to anticipate the mischievous winds that would soon toss her 18 balloons around like -- well, like balloons. Two would meet their demise, and two more would limp to the finish line, bleeding helium.
At that moment, however, she was determined to conquer the elements. As a breeze ruffled her gray hair, she squinted south toward the wind tunnel known as Broadway. "It's going to be a great parade," she said.
Ms. McFaddin is a Macy's vice president in charge of public relations, promotions and events. She oversees events throughout the year, from the annual flower show to the Fourth of July fireworks. But the Thanksgiving parade looms over the rest like a huge dollar-sign balloon.
The event is thought of as the kickoff to the Christmas shopping season. The advertising potential prompts toy and candy manufacturers to promote their products through floats and balloons. For example, this year marked the maiden voyage of a balloon modeled on the Sky Dancer action doll.
But the parade also reflects American society's changing interests. In 1934, Walt Disney provided balloons of Horace Horsecollar, a long-forgotten cartoon character, and the Big Bad Wolf, then the symbol of Great Depression fear. That same year a balloon bearing the likeness of Eddie Cantor was buffeted by midtown winds; he is remembered now, vaguely, for once having made whoopee.
It has even mirrored the country's tragedies and triumphs. Parades were canceled during some of the World War II years, with the balloon rubber donated to the war effort. And in 1963, less than a week after President Kennedy's assassination, parade flags bore black bunting, signaling that people were marching more out of duty than celebration.
Given the event's rich history, a lot depended yesterday on Ms. McFaddin. Macy's was counting on her. So was NBC, which televises the parade. And so were the bundled-up children, tens of thousands of them.
But she seemed well-suited to handle the pressure -- more so than her celluloid equivalent, played by Maureen O'Hara in "Miracle on 34th Street." Once a director who specialized in avant-garde productions and the plays of Shaw, Ms. McFaddin switched to pageantry, caught the eye of Macy's executives and was hired to revive its annual parade.
The job has clearly grown on her. Yesterday, she greeted people with "Happy Parade!" and seemed oddly at home amid the surreal tableau at Central Park West and West 77th Street, the starting point.
She was surrounded by human fire hydrants, dogs and bumblebees. Up the street was Humpty Dumpty. And around the corner, a gigantic Barney the dinosaur was strapped face-down outside the Museum of Natural History, as though awaiting paleontological inspection.
Suddenly, it was 9 A.M. Months of preparation had come down to this moment. The skies were slate-colored, the temperature was 35 degrees, and a teasing wind was blowing from the south.
Ms. McFaddin cut a red ribbon with a battery-operated carving knife and stepped out to lead the parade. Behind her were 18 balloons, 32 floats, 14 marching bands and thousands of singers, dancers and other entertainers.
The spectators roared their approval, as passing clowns showered them with multicolored confetti. People cheered from the wooded lip of Central Park on one side and from the windows of apartment buildings on the other. Ms. McFaddin, marching a block a minute, returned their smiles and waves.
But soon the queen of the parade began to march backward. She saw trouble: Some balloons were teetering dangerously close to deadly tree limbs and street lamps.
At Columbus Circle, Chelsea Farley, age 10, and her 6-year-old cousin Dana sat under a police barricade with eyes and mouths wide. Chelsea said she liked the Garfield balloon the best; Dana's favorite was Dudley the Dragon, a cheerful television character with 20-foot sneakers who was added to the parade this year.
Alas, Dudley was doomed. A stiff wind sent the 65-foot balloon into something sharp, leaving a gaping wound in its belly.
Dudley was discreetly removed from the parade route and quickly deflated just a few feet from young Chelsea, who didn't seem to mind. But Meridian Worldwide, the character's licensing agent, probably did; according to New York magazine, the company paid Macy's $350,000 to have the balloon created and highlighted during the nationally broadcast event.
Ms. McFaddin and her entourage pressed on down the 2 1/2-mile route, cheered along by people who stood five deep on the sidewalks. Once she reached the end, in front of Macy's at Herald Square, she clambered onto a reviewing stand to watch, and to receive reports from the field.
Just before noon, Santa Claus's sleigh arrived at Herald Square, officially ending the 69th parade. Then came the casualty count, with Ms. McFaddin grimly acknowledging, "We had a lot of balloon damage."
Like Dudley, Sonic the Hedgehog of video-game fame was so banged up that it couldn't finish. A deflated Pink Panther finished, but barely. Betty Boop lost the half-crescent moon on which she sits. And Sky Dancer's first parade appearance was marred by facial damage.
Still, Ms. McFaddin said she was very pleased. She said she was also tired, and expected to be sound asleep in her Upper West Side apartment by mid-afternoon.
Sometime after midnight, she said, she will get out of bed. She will make some popcorn and rewind a videotape. Then, protected from cold winds and far from teetering balloons, the general will watch her parade in private.

HEADLINE: IN REVERSAL, SERBS OF BOSNIA ACCEPT PEACE AGREEMENT

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Nov. 23

 BODY:
The Bosnian Serbs agreed this evening to abide by the peace accord reached in Dayton, Ohio, removing an obstacle to sending American troops to help enforce the peace.
The Bosnian Serbs had refused to initial the agreement on Tuesday in Dayton, where they had been represented by Slobodan Milosevic, the President of Serbia, on whom they have relied for military and political support. The Clinton Administration had said that no American troops would be deployed unless the Bosnian Serbs accepted the accord, which has been signed by the two other parties in the Bosnian conflict, the Muslim-led Bosnian Government and the Bosnian Croats. 
 The Bosnian Serb leaders initialed the very accords that they they had refused to sign on Tuesday, said Lawrence Butler, the ranking American diplomat in Belgrade. Mr. Butler said he faxed the signed documents to Washington late tonight.
In announcing the reversal, the official Belgrade television said the Bosnian Serbs had "fully accepted" the accord, even though they found provisions "painful."
Nikola Koljevic, a vice president of the self-declared Bosnian Serb republic, confirmed that the Bosnian Serbs had agreed to the accords. He said, however, that they were hoping for "some improvements" in the agreement. "I can not be more specific," he said in a brief telephone interview tonight.
The Bosnian Serb capitulation came after a meeting here today of their top leaders with President Milosevic, who may have lost his dream of a Greater Serbia but has taken another step in his drive to be seen in the West not as the man who started the war but as the moderate leader who brought it to an end.
A Western diplomat speaking on condition of anonymity said he had thought it would take longer for President Milosevic to bring the Bosnian Serbs around. "It was a complete humiliation of the Bosnian Serb leadership," he said. "I didn't expect it to happen so soon."
In Washington, Administration officials greeted the Bosnian Serb announcement with relief, but cautioned that they still needed to review what the Serbs had agreed to.
"Milosevic assured us before leaving Dayton that he'd get the Bosnian Serbs on board, but that he'd need a couple of days to calm these guys down," said a State Department official. "It sounds like he's been able to pull this off."
Defense Department officials, in particular, had expressed concern that winning Congressional approval for the accord would be even more difficult without the Bosnian Serbs' consent.
The acceptance suggests that moderates within the Bosnian Serb leadership, who are supported by Mr. Milosevic, have prevailed over the hard-liners, led by Mr. Milosevic's political rival, Radovan Karadzic, political leader of the self-proclaimed Bosnian Serb republic.
The Bosnian Serbs' capitulation would appear to spell the political end for Dr. Karadzic and for Gen. Ratko Mladic, commander of the Bosnian Serb army. The agreement says that individuals who have been indicted by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague may not hold political office. Both Dr. Karadzic, a former psychiatrist, and General Mladic have been indicted on several counts.
The hard-liners had been angry with Mr. Milosevic, who was negotiating in Dayton on behalf of the Bosnian Serbs, for having agreed that Sarajevo would be a unified city, which would require the return of Serb-controlled suburbs to the Bosnian Government. They also felt that he had given away too much other territory that the Bosnian Serbs had gained on the battlefield.
Dr. Karadzic was present at the meeting with Mr. Milosevic, Belgrade state television reported. General Mladic, who has been reported to be suffering from kidney stones, was represented by his deputy. Also attending, the state television said, were Mr. Koljevic, the vice president; Biljana Plavsic, another vice president of the self-proclaimed Bosnian Serb republic, and Momcilo Krajisnik, speaker of its parliament.
That Mr. Milosevic won over Ms. Plavsic and Mr. Krajisnik was considered of particular importance. While Mr. Koljevic is viewed as a moderate in the Bosnian Serb context, the others were considered hard-liners.
Mr. Krajisnik, who was present in Dayton, had denounced the agreement; two years ago, Ms. Plavsic had rejected the peace proposal put together by the former American Secretary of State Cyrus Vance and Lord Owen of Britain, saying that six million Serbian casualties was not too high a price for the Bosnian Serbs to pay for their goals. Mr. Milosevic retorted that she should probably be committed to a mental hospital.
Reached by telephone at their headquarters in Pale, Bosnia, outside Sarajevo, the Bosnian Serbs said they would have no official comment on today's events.
Details of the meeting between Mr. Milosevic and the Bosnian Serb leaders, including which person actually initialed the document, were not made public, but Western diplomats and Belgrade political analysts say they are certain Mr. Milosevic used some of the same strong-arm tactics on the Bosnian Serbs that the American negotiators had used in Dayton.
"You can just about bet that they had their arms twisted far up their backs," said a Western diplomat. "They succumbed to his blandishments, and believe me, they can be pretty unattractive."
Mr. Milosevic's position was as strong as that of the Bosnian Serb leaders was weak.
To begin with, the United Nations Security Council had lifted economic and military sanctions, but if the Bosnian Serbs' intransigence upset the Dayton agreement, the sanctions might have been imposed again. "You can bet that Mr. Milosevic was telling them that they would have the wrath of all the Serbs on them," a Western diplomat said.
In Belgrade today, an extended broadcast was devoted almost exclusively to the lifting of sanctions, with interviews of people on the street who welcomed the day and praised their leader. "This is the happiest day of my life," said one woman.
Then there is the Bosnian Serb army, which has been dependent on support from Belgrade. It has been badly routed in recent weeks by the Bosnian and Croatian armies, and was thus in no position to argue that it should fight on.
While rogue elements of the Bosnian Serb military could still engage in guerrilla warfare, the army cannot be expected to achieve any significant military gains if Mr. Milosevic this time lives up to his promise not to support it. It is a promise he has made before, and then broken.
As for Dr. Karadzic, "it is too early to know what he will do," said a Western diplomat. "He might try to hang on, but it will be very difficult, if not impossible, without the loyalty of the army, which he does not command."
And the last 48 hours have accentuated a power struggle within the Bosnian Serb leadership, which had been remarkably united until recently. The hard-liners, principally Dr. Karadzic and General Mladic, have their base in Pale, but little remains there beyond their bodyguards and local residents who once catered to skiers in the winter resort village. The moderate leadership, led by Mr. Koljevic, operates out of Banja Luka.

HEADLINE: The Wounded Giants of Japan;
Its Bank System Is Reeling, but How Serious Is the Pain?

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Japanese banks are the titans of the international financial system, towering over Citicorp and BankAmerica like sumo wrestlers over a kindergarten class. But now, to hear some people talk, the titans are about to topple with a crash that would devastate financial markets around the world.
Some analysts, regulators and business executives worry that a financial meltdown in Japan, home to the world's 10 biggest banks, could be set off by a ballooning burden of bad debts and a loss of confidence abroad. Even American officials have tried to avoid actions that would further endanger the Japanese institutions. 
 Are the pessimists right?
Those who know the Japanese banks the best, the bankers and the analysts in Tokyo, seem almost unanimous in their contention that the biggest banks will survive on their own or be rescued through mergers. They say the banking system, saddled with bad debts amounting to at least 8 percent of national economic output, will not collapse, though anything short of that could happen.
"They're not going to suddenly step back and watch the whole thing burn down," David Threadgold, a financial analyst at BZW Securities (Japan) Ltd., said of the Japanese authorities. "Ultimately, the second most important thing for any government to do, after securing their borders, is securing their credit system. If you haven't got a credit system, you haven't got a country. So they'll do what they have to do."
To be sure, financial experts in Tokyo have been surprised before, and some Japanese bankers who express confidence now did not exactly show great acumen a few years ago when they were piling up all those bad loans.
Moreover, while many experts say a collapse is not imminent, some have grave concerns that in the long run the banks will stumble out of their ordeal as much weaker, second-rate financial institutions. To escape that fate, they will have to change their old ways, which have left managers overcompensated and the banks complacent, overprotected and secretive, the experts say. And there are few signs of that happening.
For now, the bankers and analysts base their guarded optimism in part on capital ratios and other financial data, but mainly on their understanding of Japanese politics -- especially the role of the Ministry of Finance. Here in Japan, where the term "free markets" is rarely heard and regulators and bankers often seem to be on the same side, the ministry, with the wave of a hand, can rush more than $180 billion in dollar reserves and hundreds of billions more in yen to the banks to prevent them from crashing in a liquidity crisis.
So when Masayoshi Takemura, the Finance Minister, says the nation's largest banks will not fail, people in Tokyo tend to believe it. If the ministry keeps the biggest banks afloat -- even if some are absorbed by others -- any other banking problems look manageable.
Some analysts say that up to three dozen of the nation's 1,000 main financial institutions may become technically insolvent as bad loans erode their capital bases. Yet, they add, even if the Government allows some of the smaller institutions to fail, such bankruptcies are unlikely to cause severe repercussions abroad.
In fact, the United States suffered a similar debacle that began in the 1980's -- a widespread crisis in the savings and loan industry, costing several hundred billion dollars. The cleanup of bad debt, which equaled about 2.5 percent of economic output, according to Morgan Stanley Japan, hastened a big consolidation of the banking business -- but it did not impair America's financial system.
While Japan's debt crisis is of a larger magnitude, analysts here say that it, too, is unlikely to bring down the house.
Still, the financial community has felt a few sharp jolts, like the failures of five institutions in the last year and the expulsion of Daiwa Bank from the United States a few weeks ago. The industry's borrowings from the Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, are more intensive this year, and the seasonal crunch has not yet come.
But the central bank has mapped out the system's liquidity flows, with an eye on cash needs for each day through the end of the year. Dec. 4, for instance, is corporate tax payment day, requiring a $70 billion injection; Dec. 10 is bonus day for employees across the country, and then comes the rush toward the new year, as companies scramble to dress up their year-end accounts.
A credit squeeze seems to have abated somewhat, and, as many big Japanese banks plan to announce on Friday a near doubling in operating profits for the half-year ended Sept. 30, foreign bankers and investors are showing new interest in doing business with them.
For the long term, though, there is still enormous anxiety because it will be expensive to mop up the mess.
"A bank can go on operating -- even if it's insolvent -- for eternity if people don't start yanking their money out and if the Government starts pumping in money," said Alicia Ogawa, a financial analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd. here. "But the Bank of Japan needs its money back eventually, and where's it going to come from? Who pays for the losses?"
The Finance Ministry has floated the idea of using taxpayers' money to bail out financial institutions that lent recklessly for real estate projects during the 1980's. That strategy would mirror the United States Government's approach to the savings and loan debacle. But with operating profits rolling into the Japanese banks, the idea is unpopular with the public.
As a result, politicians probably will delay a public bailout as long as possible, raising the ultimate cost -- just as was done in the United States.
That final amount remains unclear. The Government recently said bad debts amounted to 37.4 trillion yen, or about $370 billion, with half unrecoverable. But some analysts say the number could top $735 billion.
At the banks, meanwhile, the new surge in profits has forestalled any sense of crisis. Indeed, the average annual income for male employees at money-center banks is $96,000, among the highest of any industry.
When a hijacker commandeered a plane in northern Japan this summer, what shocked some people most was that he turned out to be a banker drawing about $80,000 a year on long-term sick leave from Toyo Trust and Banking, an institution with a sizable portfolio of bad debt.
"His income is better than mine!" Hiromu Nonaka, the Home Affairs Minister, said at the time. "Unless the banks give up their own fortunes before they ask for public funds, they will not get any understanding from the people."
Despite modest efforts to cut costs, Japanese bankers say they still entertain clients often, typically spending $100 to $200 a person.
"There are very few financial systems around the world that have this big a problem and then go off to spend lots of money," said David Atkinson, a financial analyst at Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd.
While bonuses on Wall Street fluctuate with profits, the only consequence of Japan's crisis on bankers here is that this year, their annual bonuses, typically equal to six months' pay, will be cut to less than five and a half months' pay. And the banks had to be pressured to do that much.
"They are cutting the bonuses because everyone out there is criticizing the banks," a Japanese banker said. "Morale is still high, but we are worried about the future."
So are many investors and bankers abroad. Specifically, they are worried that there is no standard mechanism by which a bank can fail, and so the recent failures have been handled in quirky fashion.
When the Finance Ministry in August closed Kizu Credit Cooperative, the nation's largest credit union, it wanted to display its financial muscle to limit a chaotic bank run -- more than 10,000 people had swarmed into Kizu branches to withdraw deposits. The Bank of Japan trucked in sacks of money, piling them on the counters and into rooms in the buildings.
Not everyone was convinced. Some customers refused to leave the lobby at one branch and spent the night there. Managers also neglected security, even with so much money lying around, and two months later they discovered that about $1 million in yen had been stolen during all the shuffling.
Nor is there a way for an insolvent bank to raise money in the markets to bolster its capital base to international standards of adequacy. Traditionally, the Finance Ministry simply arranged for a troubled institution to be absorbed by a healthy one, and the public never knew the extent of the ailing bank's problems.
Such methods, however, no longer comfort the foreign community, which became increasingly anxious after United States authorities expelled Daiwa Bank following disclosures of $1.1 billion in secret losses in bond trading in the bank's New York office. What angered the Americans most was that the Finance Ministry knew of the scandal for six weeks before informing them.
The Japanese public is getting jittery, too. Many savers are transferring some of their money from private institutions to the postal savings system run by the Government.
There are other warning signs, some experts say. The current high profits are a dividend from lucrative bond trading and low costs of funds, not from their bread-and-butter lending business. The Bank of Japan has lowered its discount rate, the rate at which it lends money to commercial banks, to five-tenths of 1 percent, giving the banks a cheap source of funds and a virtual subsidy that helps them write off bad debt.
But even with that help, profits are low by international standards. Return on assets for the top 150 banks is an average of two-hundredths of 1 percent, compared with 1.3 percent, for example, at Citicorp.
So while there may be little risk of a sudden collapse, some experts fear for the future. Even with an economic recovery, they say, the financial system faces long-term decline that may turn the banking titans into mere shadows of themselves.
"The Japanese authorities can handle an abrupt liquidity crisis," said Kazuhito Ikeo, an economics professor at Keio University. "But I doubt they are capable of handling basic solvency problems. So there could be a gradual meltdown of the Japanese financial system."

HEADLINE: Foreign Stocks And the Dollar Finish Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
With markets closed in the United States, stocks were mixed overseas yesterday, while the dollar gained strength against leading European currencies but fell against the Japanese yen. Gold was lower.
In London, the broad-based Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 stocks tumbled eight-tenths of 1 percent. The selloff was led by electricity stocks, which fell after news that the British Government would begin antitrust investigations of proposed takeovers of regional electric companies by two British power companies, Powergen P.L.C. and National Power P.L.C. 
 In Frankfurt, the DAX stock index was unchanged from Wednesday, and in Paris, the CAC-40 index fell four-tenths of 1 percent.
Markets in Japan were closed for Labor Thanksgiving Day.
On the Toronto Stock Exchange, the 300-stock composite index rose 13.45 points, to 4,672.3. In Mexico City, the IPC index was up about 1.4 percent from Wednesday's close.
The dollar strengthened against the German mark, helped by speculation about a cut in German interest rates, which would make the dollar more attractive to investors. The monetary policy committee of Germany's central bank will meet next Thursday.
In London, the dollar fetched 1.4135 marks, up from 1.4057 late Wednesday. The dollar bought 100.66 Japanese yen, down from 101.62.
Other late dollar rates in London, compared with Wednesday: 1.1410 Swiss francs, up from 1.1350; 4.8674 French francs, up from 4.8500; 1,593.50 Italian lire, up from 1,589.50, and 1.3541 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3532.
The British pound was quoted at $1.5635, down from $1.5645 late Wednesday.
The Mexican peso strengthened against the dollar. In Mexico City trading, 7.6150 pesos fetched a dollar. Late Wednesday, the rate was 7.6650 pesos to the dollar.
Gold closed in London at $382.70 an ounce, down $1.70. In Zurich, gold fell $1.90 to end at $382.60. In Hong Kong, it fell $2.74, to $382.02.

HEADLINE: A Canadian Diamond in the Rough

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Prospectors for a small company in Vancouver, British Columbia, did not find the diamonds they were searching for in Labrador in September 1993, but they did stumble on something else: a vast cache of nickel. And almost overnight, this serendipitous discovery vaulted the company, Diamond Fields Resources Inc., into the ranks of the world's major mining companies.
The discovery, of course, has vastly increased the wealth of the company's founder, a penny-stock promoter named Robert M. Friedland. And it may also help his reputation, for he is in trouble with American authorities after the collapse of one of his earlier enterprises. He faces a possible civil suit from the Environmental Protection Agency over toxic waste that was left behind. 
 For Diamond Fields, growth has been swift. In less than a year, on the strength of what is expected to become one of the world's biggest and lowest-cost nickel mines, its market capitalization has soared from $100 million to $3 billion.
By the end of the decade, the mine near Voisey Bay in Labrador could be producing at least 133 million pounds of nickel a year, or 8 percent of the world's consumption. At current prices, that is worth more than $500 million. "A field of dreams," exulted the normally reserved Canadian investment house, Nesbitt Burns, projecting that the mine may hold as much as 150 million tons of nickel, which is used mainly for stainless steel.
Added Douglas Leishman, a geologist and senior mining analyst of Yorkton Securities of Vancouver: "This is the ultimate discovery. Only in my wildest imagination did I think the story would develop as it has."
No doubt Mr. Friedland never imagined such a turn of events, either. The boyish-faced 45-year-old promoter, who started Diamond Fields in 1993, moved from Vancouver to Singapore last year to expand the Asian operations of his personal holding company, the Ivanhoe Capital Corporation. He came into the sights of American authorities after the 1992 collapse of one of his earlier ventures, Galactic Resources Inc.
Mr. Friedland had been chairman and president of that beleaguered gold company, which from 1986 to 1992 operated a mine at Summitville in the mountains of southwestern Colorado.
When the E.P.A. came on the scene in the winter of 1992, it said it found an environmental disaster. Cyanide and copper waste had seeped into streams that feed the Alamosa River, which nourishes the rich San Luis farming valley near the New Mexico border.
Eleanor Dwight, a spokeswoman at the E.P.A.'s Denver office, said the agency had already spent $70 million to try to restore the land and decontaminate the water and expected the total bill to hit $120 million.
The E.P.A. is collecting data for a possible civil suit against Mr. Friedland as part of its cost-recovery efforts. Nancy Mangone, an enforcement attorney at the Denver office, said, "My hope is the Voisey Bay discovery will improve our chances of getting some money because it may be a source of funds for Friedland of any judgment we get against him."
A Federal grand jury in Denver has just handed up an indictment against Galactic and two of its executives who stand accused of multiple violations of the Clean Water Act.
The indictment did not name Mr. Friedland, but the grand jury investigation is continuing "concerning the Summitville mine in all its aspects," said Ken Fimberg, an assistant United States attorney in Denver.
Mr. Friedland, who holds both American and Canadian citizenship and is a graduate of Reed College in Portland, Ore., with a degree in political science, said the charges against the two Galactic executives -- Samye Buckner, the general manager, and Thomas Chisholm, the environmental manager -- "remain to be proven."
"I have seen no evidence that these violations took place," he said.
In any case, he added in an interview, the accusations "recite a chain of events that took place after I ceased all association with the company." He also stressed he had "no operating role in the company whatsoever."
Galactic ceased operations in late 1992. Mr. Friedland, who had been controlling shareholder, resigned as president in February 1990 and as chairman that June.
Rolling the dice has always been part of the international minerals business. According to a brochure of his Ivanhoe holding company, Mr. Friedland has raised more than $500 million of venture capital for enterprises with mining, oil and gas, real estate and other interests in more than a dozen countries in Asia, Africa, and North and South America.
But elsewhere, the dice have been less than generous. Vengold Inc., another of his enterprises, plunged from a 1994 high of $16.25 to less than $2 on the Toronto Stock Exchange after exploration prospects in Venezuela were reported below expectations.
No one expected the new Klondike at Voisey Bay, halfway up Labrador's east coast, which has catapulted Diamond Field shares from less than $1 a year ago -- adjusted for a four-for-one split in September -- to its current $25.875.
The discovery, which has made Diamond Fields the best-performing equity this year on the Toronto Stock Exchange, is also pumping nearly $100 million a year into one of Canada's most economically depressed regions. "We are seeing increased employment and spinoffs to hotel, aircraft and other service companies," said Dr. Rex Gibbons, Minister of Natural Resources in Newfoundland, which includes Labrador.
Much more money could be on the way. Diamond Fields and its partners contemplate an investment of up to $1 billion in a new mining mill complex and associated smelting and refining plants.
Government environmental and other regulators would have to approve the projects. Also needed is consent of the native Inuit and Innu people who are concerned about maintaining traditional ways of life and the ecology of the region -- a place where the bears and the caribou roam.
The Teck Corporation, a $550 million (Canadian) a year Vancouver-based mining company, bought 10 percent of Diamond Fields shares last April for $108 million (Canadian). The International Nickel Company, or Inco, made a deal in June.
Inco is spending $700 million (Canadian) to acquire 30 percent of Diamond Fields' Voisey Bay deposit. Inco gets 25 percent directly through the issuance to Diamond Fields of $525 million of 6.5 percent preferred shares, convertible into 13.3 million Inco shares. Conversion would give Diamond Fields an 11 percent equity interest in Inco, making it the largest single stockholder.
Inco, based in Toronto, also agreed to acquire 7 percent of Diamond Fields shares, which works out to a 5 percent stake in the deposit, making it the fifth-largest Diamond Fields shareholder. Mr. Friedland, with 13 percent, is the largest.
The Vengold and Galactic experiences delayed institutional acceptance of the breadth of the Voisey Bay discovery.
"There was such a bad taste in people's mouths that some firms still won't even write a recommendation for Diamond Fields," noted Dorothy Atkinson, senior mining analyst at Pacific International Securities of Vancouver.
But she added: "I personally think Friedland has rehabilitated his reputation. He has a world-class deposit which will have terrific cash flows."
Bob Purcell, manager of Inco's corporate public relations, commented: "We consider Bob Friedland a really smart cookie. That's apparent from his track record. He's told everyone he wants environmental perfection on this project, and that's what we want too."

HEADLINE: Investments Abroad Reach Record Pace

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

 BODY:
American corporations, flush with record profits, are investing far more abroad than ever before -- buying companies, building factories and opening offices and stores.
Direct investment abroad reached $33 billion for the first six months of 1995, according to the Commerce Department. This $66 billion annual pace represents a 47 percent jump from last year and a 27 percent increase from the record year, 1993. 
 The resurgence in American spending overseas has reversed a long imbalance. Throughout the 1980's, foreign direct investment in the United States, especially in real estate and corporations, vastly outpaced American investment abroad. But the tide turned in 1991, and American spending has been greater every year since.
Some of these investments have resulted in the shutting of American factories. But economists and the companies making the investments hail the foreign expansion as a testament to American efficiency.
American companies are leading a global investment boom fueled by worldwide economic growth, especially in developing nations. Formerly protected markets have opened, and state-owned enterprises have been put up for sale. Countries that until recently regarded multinational corporations as pirates coming ashore now let American companies drill their oil wells, grill their hamburgers and even bury their dead.
While Western Europe still gets most of the money, the flow is increasing most rapidly into Asia and Latin America and has more than doubled to the developing world's four leading recipients -- Brazil, Mexico, Singapore and Indonesia -- from just three years ago.
Even regional telephone companies and electric utilities, once the local yokels of American business, have joined the corporate jet set to scour the world for new markets.
Since the late 1980's, U S West has gone from handling local calls in 14 states to providing cellular telephone service, cable television, international call switching, telephone directories, standard telephone service and advanced wireless communications in Hungary, Malaysia, the Czech Republic, Britain, Lithuania, France, Norway, Russia, Sweden, Slovakia, Poland, Japan, Brazil, Spain, the Netherlands and India.
"American telecommunications companies are some of the best in the world," said Charles M. Lillis, chief executive of the U S West Media Group, which includes foreign operations. In other countries, he said, "one of the big benefits is enormous growth opportunities in businesses we know very well."
Japan, despite its economic slowdown, is also attracting billions in new American investment, reflecting some success in efforts to pry open that nation's markets. But investment in China, with its uncertain political outlook and its frequent flouting of American intellectual-property rights, has slowed.
Although United States companies have been investing abroad since America itself was an emerging market in the early 19th century, economists say that even adjusting for inflation, the latest surge has been unmatched.
American companies have already transformed themselves into some of the world's most efficient, lowest-cost producers of goods and services, regaining their lead in many high-technology fields. They have also bolstered profits at home by cutting jobs and installing the latest technology, said Michael E. Porter, a Harvard Business School professor and consultant.
"Now, the hot topic around board rooms is, 'How can we grow?' Many companies are seeing foreign expansion as the best avenue," Mr. Porter said.
While corporate mergers and acquisitions within the United States are often merely transfers of control, he said, American companies can use foreign acquisitions as bridgeheads for larger market invasions.
Though the United States is leading the charge, investments are rising around the world. Total direct foreign investment by all countries -- excluding portfolio investment, which brings no direct management or control -- rose 9 percent last year, to a record $226 billion, from $208 billion in 1993, according to United Nations figures.
One of the favorite targets is the United States. Direct investment in this country totaled $28 billion in the first half of this year, a $56 billion annual pace that would be the strongest in this decade. But adjusted for inflation, investments in the late 1980's exceeded today's pace. Still, although economists caution that investment figures can be distorted by shifting exchange rates and the timing of major transactions, most believe the latest surge is part of a long-term trend. "Everybody's into a less protectionist, more deregulatory mode," said Jagdish Bhagwati, a trade economist at Columbia University. "Our firms are in a position to move in."
Most of the factories American companies are building abroad are meant to capture foreign customers, who account for an increasing share of the companies' sales and profits. "The single most prominent reason for people investing in a market is as a base for selling into that market," said Lewis Alexander, the Commerce Department's chief economist.
Many companies that were shorebound just a few years ago are now, in the face of saturated markets and increasing competition at home, looking abroad. This month, the Central and South West Corporation, an electric utility based in Dallas, agreed to pay $2.6 billion for Seeboard P.L.C., a British utility. Also this month, Texas Utilities completed a $1.6 billion agreement to buy Eastern Energy from the Australian Government.
Other service providers, having jammed practically every available shopping strip and highway exit in the United States with their fast-food restaurants, video stores and fashion shops, now want to share Big Macs, blue jeans and American movies with more foreigners. In September, Gap Inc., the clothing retailer, opened its first two stores in Japan. Blockbuster, the movie-video chain owned by Viacom Inc., announced plans recently to nearly triple the number of its foreign outlets by the year 2000, to 4,000 from 1,400 today. The expansion is expected to double the foreign share of its total sales to 30 percent from 15 percent today and to bolster revenues for Hollywood studios.
McDonald's is also counting on foreign demand for most of its growth this year, cracking markets in Malta and Jamaica and in the former Soviet bloc countries of Slovakia and Estonia. It plans to open 2,300 restaurants this year, 30 percent more than last year, with two-thirds of them overseas.
Several major oil companies have been concentrating their investment in new rigs, refineries and gas stations abroad, although there is some evidence that this is beginning to slow.
As American oil supplies play out and environmental restrictions curb drilling, Exxon executives like to say that their prospects at home are limited by acts of God and acts of Congress. Instead, the company looks for oil under the remote Tarim Basin of China and beneath the seas off Malaysia. As foreign energy demand grows more rapidly than domestic need, Exxon is also speeding investments to sell gas and refined oil in emerging markets like Thailand, Singapore and Eastern Europe.
While Exxon's domestic capital and exploration spending fell 7.5 percent, to $1.3 billion, over the first nine months of this year, foreign spending rose 18 percent, to $4.8 billion. "It only makes sense for Exxon to select its investments from among the most attractive available on a worldwide basis," said Lee R. Raymond, Exxon's chairman, at the company's annual meeting this year.
Direct foreign investments do put Americans out of work when companies take advantage of low wages abroad to build factories and then ship goods back into the United States. Reduced trade barriers, especially with Mexico, have helped companies like Allied Signal, Farah and General Electric shift jobs to Mexico this year.
American companies, which invested $3.3 billion in Mexico last year, backed off after the peso crisis started in December, and they spent only $142 million in the first quarter of this year. But with the cost of Mexican labor and plants suddenly much cheaper because of the Mexican currency's crash, American investment bounced back to $885 million in the second quarter, equal to last year's rate.
Economists say the current American investment drive is especially impressive because it coincides with a relatively weak dollar, which would be expected to increase the cost of doing business overseas.
"There is no question that relative competitiveness of international firms is what drives foreign investment," said Edward Montgomery Graham, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research center. "A few years ago it became downright fashionable to talk about the declining competitiveness of U.S. industry and how we were being annihilated by the Japanese. But there has been a resurgence of U.S. competitive strength."
American makers of computer chips, seemingly on the verge of succumbing to the Japanese a few years ago, find few barriers to their global ambitions. Motorola, with 60 percent of its sales abroad, up from 56 percent last year, announced in September a $720 million plant expansion, primarily to make semiconductors, in Tianjin, China. In October, Intel announced plans to build a $1.6 billion plant to make flash memory devices in Israel, a $1.5 billion plant to make microprocessors in Ireland and a plant to make computer components in Malaysia.
American companies' quest for foreign customers does not even stop at the cemetery gates. Service Corporation International, the world's largest chain of funeral homes and cemeteries, announced in July that it was buying Europe's largest funeral business from Lyonnaise des Eaux of France for $423 million. The year before, Service Corporation bought two chains in Britain, becoming the largest owner of funeral homes there. The European funeral business, the company explained both times, had never seen the sort of efficiencies and competitive zeal that Service Corporation brought to the United States.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, the Inflow of Mexicans Seems to Slow

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: CIUDAD JUAREZ, Mexico, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Victor Covarrubias knows Mexico's northern border well. He has waded the Rio Grande here many times, slipping past the Border Patrol as he heads north to America's pepper harvests or construction sites where $6 an hour is 15 times what he can earn back home.
But this week Mr. Covarrubias, who has crossed the border at many different points, found that it has changed. For several days, he tried to cross the river from Juarez into El Paso, only to have American agents block his advance again and again. Finally he hired a coyote, a people-smuggler who promised to lead him across the river along a secret route and put him on a plane to Dallas for $400. But that was a swindle, and although Mr. Covarrubias did finally make it to the United States, agents detained him before he got close to his plane. 
Although thousands of illegal migrants still cross parts of America's 2,000-mile southwest border virtually unhindered, others are finding that since enforcement has been tightened along some key stretches, it is no longer an easy matter. It has become so difficult to breach the border south of Juarez or San Diego, which until recently accounted for 60 percent of illegal crossings, that after repeated failures, some migrants, like Mr. Covarrubias, have exhausted their resources. And thousands of other Mexicans are now weighing a complex equation of transportation costs, wages and logistical risks before trying to migrate north.
A recent study by Jorge A. Bustamante, a prominent Mexican demographer, concluded that despite Mexico's wrenching depression, illegal immigration to the United States decreased somewhat this year because tightened enforcement greatly increased the costs.
The study appears to support an assumption underlying a crackdown by the Immigration and Naturalization Service: If the authorities make illegal border crossings sufficiently difficult and costly, some people will quit trying.
"As long as there are huge wage disparities between Mexico and the United States, you'll have a continuing flow," said Robert Bach, an executive associate commissioner at the I.N.S. "But what Bustamante is showing, and what we believe, is that our increased enforcement has begun to tip the economic balance. For many workers, it's become too expensive to come north."
Several respected researchers dispute Dr. Bustamante's conclusions. Frank D. Bean, a demographer at the University of Texas at Austin, for instance, has concluded that in the last year not only Mexico's economic crisis but also strong job growth in the United States have helped increase illegal border crossings, though he adds, "It's not the mammoth phenomenon that some people are saying it is."
About 40 percent of the illegal Mexican migrants apprehended each year have tried to cross from Tijuana, south of San Diego; 20 percent have come from Juarez. Until recently, these borders were out of control, with thousands of migrants racing across the line each day and American agents pursuing them through railroad sidings and suburban patios.
Two years ago, however, the Border Patrol put 400 agents at 100-yard intervals for 22 miles along the border in the area of El Paso, forming a virtual human barricade.
One year ago, along the border running east from Imperial Beach, Calif., the authorities built a 14-mile steel fence, installing searchlights and motion detectors and fielding hundreds of new agents.
This year, new agents have also been deployed south of Tucson. With $236 million in additional funds in the fiscal year that ended on Oct. 1, the Border Patrol increased the number of agents along the 2,000-mile line from Brownsville, Tex., to Imperial Beach to about 5,000 from under 4,000.
But even as the Border Patrol has offered new deterrents, the Mexican and American economies have provided powerful incentives for migrants to go north. Last December's peso devaluation cut Mexican wages in half and threw millions of Mexicans out of work, and 1995 has seen a surge in American job growth.
In the wake of these factors, the number of illegal migrants apprehended by the Border Patrol surged by 30 percent, from 979,101 in the fiscal year 1994 to 1,271,390 in 1995. But how to interpret the increase?
For nearly two decades, the relationship between the number of illegal migrants apprehended and the number seeking to cross appeared straightforward, because the Border Patrol's size and tactics were consistent. Now, however, demographers are divided about whether the increase in migrants apprehended should be interpreted as a swell in illegal migration, or in the beefed-up Border Patrol. Further complicating the analysis, agents seize and count thousands of the same illegal immigrants many times.
Dr. Bustamante's study is not based on I.N.S. statistics. For eight years, he and other demographers at Mexico's Colegio de la Frontera Norte, a Tijuana-based research group, have carried out weekly interviews with migrants at crossing sites in Tijuana, Mexicali, Ciudad Juarez, Nuevo Laredo and Matamoros, and in 1993, they began a parallel survey at several northern cities.
Using the random-sample techniques of a household survey, Dr. Bustamante estimates the flow of undocumented migrants crossing the border. In the first three months of this year, he concluded in a recent study, the northward flow declined by about 9 percent, compared with the same period in 1994. The reason, he said, was that migration costs, including bus and airplane tickets to northern cities, have increased, and breaching the border has become so difficult that many migrants now pay hundreds of dollars to coyotes.
"It's overwhelmingly clear that the number of undocumented migrants has declined," Dr. Bustamante said. "Costs have risen, and that's largely due to the increase in the numbers of border agents."
Another factor dampening the flow may be the political climate in the United States as it is portrayed in Mexico; lately it has seemed openly hostile to immigrants.
"Five-Year Prison Terms for Illegals!" screamed the Diario de Juarez's headline on Sunday for an article about a proposal by Republican legislators to increase prison terms for recidivist illegal immigrants who are using false documents.
Thomas J. Espenshade, a Princeton University demographer, expressed skepticism that stepped-up enforcement has had any significant impact. "A short-term decline is not out of the question, but my guess is that it wouldn't be a permanent reduction," he said. "It's a pretty porous border."
Neverthless, many potential migrants are weighing the risks carefully. In Mr. Covarrubias's case, he and his wife were barely supporting their four daughters when in September he was laid off from his job in a tire factory 375 miles south of the border. When an old friend called from Dallas with news of a job in an auto-body shop and wired him $500 for travel costs, Mr. Covarrubias boarded a bus to Juarez.
After the coyote took his money, Mr. Covarrubias waded the river into the United States southeast of Juarez, but he was detained hours later. He looked a bit dazed when he was deported back across the bridge into Juarez last week.
"Put in your story that of every five who try to cross, only one gets through!" Mr. Covarrubias said.

HEADLINE: Watches That Time Hasn't Forgotten

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
Imagine a new car powered by a steam engine -- a superb steam engine built from modern materials, but still a variation on a 19th-century design. Imagine that the car is a delight to the eye, but hardly up to modern performance standards. Now imagine that it is manufactured in limited numbers, priced at $10 million and heavily advertised with the hope of attracting conspicuous consumers, speculative investors and collectors with nostalgia for a time when they understood how machines worked.
Hardly a viable marketing strategy, you say? A nearly identical one is working nicely for the dozen or so Swiss companies that are using computerized design systems and space-age materials to create outrageously expensive mechanical timepieces in an age of cheap, accurate quartz watches. Indeed, while most high-end watchmakers, including Audemars Piguet, Breguet, Patek Philippe, Rolex and Vacheron Constantin, do not make their earnings public, all are apparently doing very, very well after near-death experiences in the early 1980's. 
 Sales of the watches are expected to be strong enough, in fact, to qualify as one of the few bright spots for retailers in what seems to be shaping up as a dreary holiday season. Many shoppers, concerned about new rounds of job cuts and other economic problems, appear to be watching their purchases more closely than usual. But the sharp rise in the stock market has added to a feeling of good cheer among the affluent, leading to bullish projections for expensive goodies, including the old-style watches.
The sales of 11 members of Montres et Bijoux Geneve, the trade association for the high-end mechanical watchmakers, represent just 7 percent of the watch production of Switzerland. But in 1994, they generated 40 percent of the country's $7 billion in earnings from watch exports, which have tripled since 1981. Indeed, the market for expensive mechanical watches is so hot that Blancpain, a defunct brand until its trademark was purchased for just $15,000 in 1982, was sold only 10 years later to SMH, the conglomerate that makes Swatches, for $65 million.
"This is an extremely profitable industry," confirms Roland Schild, a consultant to Montres et Bijoux Geneve.
It was not always so for the industry, now a fabulous anachronism built on craft, snobbery and the expectation that anything rare and beautiful will become more valuable.
Quartz watches, introduced in the 1970's by two Japanese manufacturers, the Seiko Corporation and the Citizen Watch Company, rapidly made inroads into the near-monopoly of Swiss watchmakers. Swiss brands that had dominated the middle and upper-middle portions of the world market -- notably Tissot and Omega -- reacted late and never recaptured the initiative.
Eventually, most high-end Swiss manufacturers offered their own quartz movements to supplement their lines of mechanical watches. And in 1979, the Swiss impressed the world with the Concord Delirium, an expensive quartz watch less than one-tenth of an inch thick that was widely seen as the industry's means of reinventing itself.
"By 1980, people thought the mechanical watch was dead," said Joe Thompson, editor of Modern Jeweler, an American trade publication.
But a number of factors kept the upper end of the mechanical market alive.
One was stubbornness. Rolex, a large Geneva-based watchmaker owned by a charitable foundation, chose to continue depending primarily on mechanical movements. In effect, the company was forced to move to the high end of the market, as the middle became the exclusive domain of quartz. However, canny marketing emphasizing quality and ruggedness -- not to mention the idea that anyone who could afford a Rolex had arrived -- gave the company an identity that no other men's watch had provided since the Omega in the 1950's. "Sticking with mechanical watches was a risk for Rolex, but a very good risk," Mr. Schild concluded.
Another factor was technology. The innards of any mechanical watch made in 1995 would have been understood by a watchmaker in 1895. But some of the materials, notably light, super-strong titanium, would have been foreign. So would the machine tools capable of forming minuscule parts with far greater precision. And the computer programs used to design watches with more functions that fit into smaller spaces would have seemed miraculous. Thus, once the decision was made to stick with mechanical designs, technology made it possible to sustain the "dazzle" factor at acceptable costs.
But neither technology nor marketing genius probably would have saved the mechanical watch without a third phenomenon in play: collectibility. While there had long been a market for antique pocket watches and clocks, the wristwatch was viewed as too new and too common to rate as a collectible. Indeed, in Sotheby's first auction, in 1980, six fine watches fetched a measly total of $16,000.
But perceptions changed rapidly in the mid-1980's. This was due in part to a scarcity of new mechanical watches at a time when all manner of nostalgia items were finding their way into auctions. Daryn Schnipper, a senior vice president at Sotheby's and the house's expert on watches, thinks the boom was prompted by a rumor that Patek Philippe, the high end of the high end, was dropping out of the business.
The boom, however, was no fluke. In 1985, a Patek Philippe watch made in 1955 sold for $159,000 at Christie's in Geneva. And once the idea was firmly planted that mechanical watches were collectible, the companies with grand old names began emphasizing the inherent scarcity of hand-finished watches.
"The luxury watchmakers took a second look and asked, 'What can we do to catch up with the secondhand market?' " Ms. Schnipper recalled. The answer was a revival of the tradition of making mechanical watches with extra features -- perpetual calendars, stopwatch mechanisms, moon phase indicators, hour-and-minute chimes and the like, which watchmakers call "complications." In 1989, Patek Philippe produced the Calibre '89, a softball-sized "watch" with 900 parts and 33 complications that sold for $2.7 million and sent collectors into a frenzy.
Mechanical watches with multiple complications -- and prices of $50,000 to $100,000 -- are now the rage, in part because they effectively guarantee to collectors that the models will be made in small numbers, in part because they are fabulous toys for the rich. So are so-called skeleton watches -- the back and front of which are made from clear crystal, with the design of the movement permitting light to pass through. "We had high tech," Mr. Thompson of Modern Jeweler suggested. "Now we have high mech."
While the simplest versions of the high-end mechanical watches can be purchased for $5,000 to $20,000 directly from the jewelry shop display, watches with multiple complications generally must be ordered months or years in advance. "With some models, we simply buy as many as we can get," explained Anthony D'Ambrosio, executive vice president of Tourneau Inc., the biggest retailer of high-end mechanical watches in the United States.
Rodolphe Schulthess, the director of marketing for Breguet, said that making the watches only after they had been ordered was good business practice in part because it kept inventory costs to a minimum. In part, too, the scarcity is linked to a dearth of watchmakers.
But mostly, scarcity is a marketing device to validate collectors' speculation that unique watches will appreciate rapidly.
From a distance, the high end of the watch market looks like a single business. Close up, it is plain that the companies have strikingly different strategies.
Rolex, which will make 750,000 watches this year -- 50 times as many as Audemars Piguet -- sells what Mr. Thompson calls "mass class." Most of the watches have relatively simple movements housed in superbly finished steel or gold cases. However, if you insist on paying more than $20,000 for a Rolex, the company will oblige: clad in platinum and studded with diamonds and sapphires, the watches can have retail prices of well over $100,000.
Patek Philippe, which dominates the collectors' market, is known for conservative -- even austere -- designs. Its simplest watches are still available for less than $10,000. But the company has moved rapidly to exploit its identity, offering an array of skeleton watches and models with multiple complications for up to $900,000.
Vacheron Constantin, which dates from 1755 but was purchased by Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani of Saudi Arabia in 1987, boasts the most impressive enameling, a process known to only a few dozen Swiss workers. The enameling can add months to manufacturing time and tens of thousands of dollars to the price. Breguet, founded by the acknowledged genius of 19th-century watch design, Abraham-Louis Breguet, and now owned by Investcorp, a group of Arab investors, is the master of complications.
One company, Chopard, in contrast to all the others, aims its products specifically at women. Its watches are meant to be jewelry as much as timepieces. Indeed, the company is known for "happy diamonds" -- watches with loose precious stones between the crystal and the face.
Perhaps the most striking marketing story, though, is Blancpain, which, in Ms. Schnipper's words, "rose from the ashes." Advertised as Switzerland's oldest brand, but not seen in stores for decades, the watches reappeared in jewelry stores only in the mid-1980's. The resurrected company caught the wave perfectly with the slogan "since 1735 there has never been a Blancpain quartz watch and never will be." And it has exploited new technology to specialize in celebrations of old technology: Blancpain has sold nine of its "1735" models -- big, 800-part watches that do everything but brew coffee. The current price is $800,000.
Can expensive mechanical watches keep flying high? While skeptics wonder how many people will pay more for a watch than for a Mercedes-Benz, the champions of the high end say the potential market has barely been scratched.
"Men who wear $1,000 suits and $200 shoes are just beginning to see watches as fashion statements," Mr. D'Ambrosio suggested.

HEADLINE: Drug Crackdown Is Believed to Sap Colombia's Economy

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 22

 BODY:
As the authorities arrest leaders of the Cali drug cartel, seize their properties, close their bank accounts and destroy cocaine-processing laboratories, the organization is facing an economic crisis that many say has affected sectors of the national economy.
In recent weeks, investigations into donations by drug traffickers to President Ernesto Samper's 1994 campaign, have caused nervousness among investors and sharp declines in the stock market. While the trends have been attributed by some to Mr. Samper's difficulties, others say the weakening of the cartel cannot be ignored as a factor. In any event, drug power and drug money seem to be the root of the uncertainty. 
 Calculating the impact of the drug trade on the economy is difficult, economists and officials say.
Salomon Kalmanovitz, co-director of Colombia's Central Bank and the author of a study on the effects of drug trafficking on Colombia's economy, estimates that before the Government crackdown, drug trafficking brought in $3.5 billion a year or 5 percent of the gross domestic product of almost $70 billion.
Doug Wankel, chief of operations at the Drug Enforcement Administration, says that $4.5 billion to $7 billion is a conservative estimate of drug money in the Colombian economy. He said 80 to 90 percent of that comes from the Cali cartel.
Over the years, drug traffickers have become the country's largest land owners, with more than seven million acres of farmland, giving them control of entire regions.
But crackdowns have created a shortage of dollars within the cartel, and since August, cartel members have been selling real estate in areas including Cali for cash. At the same time, the peso has lost more than 7 percent of its dollar value because of the scarcity of dollars.
"One of the real factors that have pressured the devaluation of the peso has been the suspension of part of the drug traffickers' income," Mr. Kalmanovitz said.
As demand and prices have fallen, the construction industry, especially in Cali, has entered a recession. An estimated 20 percent of investment in construction in Cali is said to come from drug traffickers.
The selling off of land came a month after several drug lords were arrested and allegations about illegal campaign financing gained strength.
President Clinton last month announced sanctions against more than 40 Colombian companies that have been identified as front organizations for the Cali cartel and measures to prevent United States companies from trading with them.
"It was a strong political message, but there are teeth attached to it," Mr. Wankel said. "A number of American companies and banks have called us concerned about the effects of this law."
Since Mr. Clinton's announcement, both Government and private statements and actions to combat the financial side of the cartels have increased. Recently, the Government won Congressional approval for a law that, for the first time, makes money laundering a felony.
Private banks have closed the accounts of Drogas La Rabaja, one of the country's largest drug store chains and distributors of medical products, which is owned by the children of the Cali cartel's leaders, Miguel and Gilberto Rodriguez.
However, opposition to the crackdown is high. Earlier this year, lawmakers nearly succeeded in approving legislation that would protect undeclared income and inhibit prosecution on charges of illicit enrichment.
