HEADLINE: Ruthless Ex-Dictator Getting Credit for South Korea's Rise

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea

 BODY:
If there is a villain in South Korean history, it might at first seem to be Park Chung Hee, who overthrew a democratic Government and ruled for nearly two decades as a ruthless dictator.
Yet Mr. Park's image these days is improving. While few people deny that he was sometimes brutal, Mr. Park is also increasingly remembered as the architect of the South Korean economic miracle. 
 "We give some credit to Park for economic development, even though politically he had problems," said Lee Shin Bom, a spokesman for the governing Democratic Liberal Party.
One of those political problems was a proclivity for torture, as Mr. Lee discovered first-hand in the 1970's when he was detained and tortured several times. The worst was electric shock treatment, recalled Mr. Lee, who was once arrested for nothing more than possessing an article about Korea clipped from an American newspaper.
Yet Mr. Park, who was assassinated in 1979, today is buried in the national cemetery. A range of political parties send flowers to his grave, and even his old nemesis, Kim Dae Jung, has visited his tomb.
Mr. Kim's tribute is particularly striking because Mr. Park tried to kill him. Mr. Kim, a dissident who ran against Mr. Park for President in 1971, was kidnapped while in Tokyo and apparently would have been executed if it had not been for American intervention.
One of the lessons of Mr. Park's renaissance in public opinion seems to be that the public is willing to forgive a good deal of a leader who presides over an economic boom.
Mr. Park took power when South Korea was barely more prosperous than India, and he oversaw the economic takeoff that has transformed it into a modern industrializing country. Some scholars say he paradoxically contributed enormously to Korean democracy, despite his repression of democracy movements, for he nurtured an economic boom that created the middle class that is the backbone of Korean pluralism today.
To be sure, Mr. Park is hardly hailed as a national hero. There are no statues of him, no schools named for him. The cruelty of his rule is widely acknowledged.
Part of the reassessment of Mr. Park seems to reflect disenchantment with two of his successors as President, Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, both of whom have been disgraced for corruption.
"I wouldn't say that there's a broad nostalgia for Park," said Lee Chul, a National Assembly member who as a student democracy leader was sentenced to death by the Park administration. "It's just that the public sees Chun and Roh, and they think that Park was better."
Mr. Park was a brilliant Japanese-trained major general when, in 1961, he overthrew the democratic -- but chaotic -- administration of Prime Minister Chang Myon. That precipitated more than three decades of rule by military leaders.
In 1979, in a dispute over how to handle demonstrations, Mr. Park insisted on using paratroopers to crush the protests. His intelligence director favored a softer line and tried to settle the disagreement by shooting Mr. Park dead.
"We criticized Park Chung Hee because we saw things through the prism of American democracy and human rights," said Lee Young Duk, an editor of the Chosun Ilbo, a major Seoul newspaper. "But if we had had American democracy in the 1960's, would we have achieved this much? Perhaps Park Chung Hee's approach was better suited to the public consciousness of the time."

HEADLINE: BASKETBALL;
At Nebraska, a Reunion of Sorts

BYLINE: By DOUG SCANCARELLA 

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, N.J.

 BODY:
Damian Peter is expecting a happier holiday season this year as he visits his older brothers, Christian and Jason, at the University of Nebraska this week.
Nebraska, college football's No. 1 team, will play Oklahoma at Lincoln today and Damian, who attends Notre Dame, will be watching his brothers play on the defensive line for the unbeaten Cornhuskers. 
 "All three of them, especially Damian, have been looking forward to this week for a very long time," their mother, Mary Peter, said recently. "They're very close, but it's very rare that all three of them are together. It seems like there is always a game."
The Peter family, from Middletown in Monmouth County, didn't think today's reunion would ever take place after what happened last year. Damian, at age 20 the youngest of the brothers, had hoped to follow Christian, who is a senior, and Jason, a sophomore, into major college football. He signed with Notre Dame in the spring of 1994, but his dream was cut short three months later after a swimming pool accident nearly left him paralyzed.
A month before reporting to South Bend, Ind., he stopped by a friend's house in New Jersey to go for a swim. Diving into the pool, he hit his head at the bottom where the shallow end meets the deep end. The initial diagnosis was paralysis from the neck down.
"The first thing that came to my mind was football," Damian said. "I worked all of my life to get a chance to play major college football and then I had some doctor that I didn't even know telling me I could never play again. I was crushed.
"I dove in that pool a million times. This time I just dove out too far. I just blacked out. The next thing I knew, I was in my hospital room."
With his football dreams shattered, Damian spent that season watching Notre Dame and Nebraska play on television. Now, after more than a year of rigorous rehabilitation, Damian is not only on his feet, but back at Notre Dame, which honored his scholarship, attending classes and preparing to play football again.
"Notre Dame has been great," Mary Peter said. "There was never any question that they'd honor the scholarship."
Before the accident, the Peter brothers, all of them about 6 feet 6 inches and 300 pounds, seemed to have it all. Damian graduated from Middletown South High School, a New Jersey power, with honors and was named an all-state offensive lineman as a senior.
Christian, however, has had troubles off the football field while at Nebraska. In 1993, he was charged with sexual assault in Lincoln, the first of three such incidents. He was accused of twice improperly touching a young woman. Blaming an alcohol problem, he pleaded no contest and served 18 months probation. He was also sentenced to 100 hours of community service and instructed to complete an alcohol-treatment program.
Less than six months later he was accused -- but never charged -- with sexually assaulting a nightclub dancer. The authorities said that there was not enough evidence to prosecute.
This past summer a Nebraska student said she had been raped by Christian in 1991. The woman said she did not report the incident for almost four years because she feared retribution. Christian, through a family lawyer, has vehemently denied the accusation.
In 1994, Christian led the Cornhuskers in sacks. This season, with Nebraska looking toward a second consecutive national title, he is second on the team in sacks, fourth in tackles and projected as an early-round National Football League draft choice. Jason is ninth on the team in tackles.
Christian refused to address his problems off the field, saying he has been instructed by the university not to discuss the case.
Meanwhile, Damian has vowed to prove the doctors wrong who said his football career was over.
"The thing that I'll always remember," Christian said, "is that the first thing Damian said when he saw me after the accident was, 'I'm going to play football again.' If any of us can do it, he can. He's the strongest of the three of us."
When Damian wiggled his toes 48 hours after the accident, the prognosis was upgraded from being paralyzed from the neck down to partly paralyzed above the waist. Doctors determined at that point that Damian had suffered a severe bruise to the spine and temporary paralysis.
Although it is doubtful that a person can return to the football field after sustaining such an injury, one can regain mobility in the legs and arms and carry on a normal life.
While Damian knows the odds are high, he has vowed to play for the Fighting Irish.
"The progress he's made has been incredible," his mother said. "From where he was, to where he is today, is world's apart. In the end, though, it'll be the doctors' decision."
Damian is taking a full load of classes, majoring in economics. He lifts weights daily, runs, does neck exercises and works out on the football field, hoping to return for spring workouts.
"Next spring is the most realistic goal," he said. "Every day I keep working out with the hope of suiting up. Some people have told me to be thankful that I've recovered to where I am and not try to push it by playing football. But that's not me. I have to be out on the field doing what I love.
"I try not to look back and monitor my day-to-day progress. My goal is to play football. I just work day today to reach that goal. I'm getting encouragement from my family and my teammates."

GRAPHIC: Photo: From left, Christian, Damian and Jason Peter enjoying a light moment at Nebraska Stadium this week. (Gail Folda for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Oil and Wildlife Just Don't Mix

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Open Alaska's Wildlife Refuge" (Op-Ed, Nov. 20): Alaska's Governor, Tony Knowles, is living in a fantasy land created by the big oil companies and their puppets in Alaska's Congressional delegation. 
 When considering oil drilling in a great untouched wilderness, there is no such thing as doing it right. Wilderness and an industrial zone cannot by definition exist together; any intrusion can be felt for many miles.
To say it has been done right at Prudhoe Bay is disingenuous: Grizzly bears and wolves have been killed, driven away or become addicted to garbage. Removal of predators and a hunting ban allowed a growth spurt in the caribou herd, but its birth rate is now declining. The oil fields spew as much of some air pollutants as the District of Columbia. The pipeline is in such shoddy condition that it is too dangerous to inspect.
As for reducing the deficit, to reach the dream revenues Governor Knowles quoted, leases would have to sell for as much as 40 times the price of adjacent, far-lower-risk offshore leases.
As for the United States Treasury's receiving half of any revenues -- which are highly unlikely considering the low odds that economically recoverable oil is present -- you reported Nov. 11 that Representative Don Young and Senator Ted Stevens have said the state will get the refuge opened with a 50-50 revenue split and sue later for its full 90 percent share.
This is one small example of the dishonesty of this whole drilling campaign.
Though the area to be drilled is a small percentage of the refuge, even the Reagan Interior Department called it the "biological heart" and "center of wildlife activity" for the entire refuge. Don't let the Alaskan marauders destroy this last great wilderness.
 
SUSAN ALEXANDER
V.P., Environment Communications
Public Media Center
San Francisco, Nov. 20, 1995

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN;
A Plain-Speaking Conservative

 BODY:
This 60-second commercial is one of nine that Steve Forbes is broadcasting in Iowa, New Hampshire and other states.
ON THE SCREEN -- Close-up photographs of Mr. Forbes with Ronald Reagan, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and his family, and then Mr. Forbes speaks to the camera. 
 PRODUCER -- Our Town Films, Paul Sanderson.
SCRIPT -- Announcer: "He's been called a champion of economic growth and a visionary. He is Steve Forbes, and under his leadership Forbes magazine has become the most successful business magazine in the world. A conservative leader, he devised the bold tax cut plan for New Jersey that is creating new jobs and economic growth. He was appointed by Ronald Reagan to lead Radio Free Europe, which played a crucial role in the fall of Communism. He and Sabina, his wife of 24 years, are raising five daughters."
Mr. Forbes: "I'm Steve Forbes. America has the potential for the greatest economic boom and spiritual renewal in our history. But we're being held back by Washington politics as usual. It's time we move forward. Start with a low flat tax, put term limits on politicians and restore control of our schools to parents. Let's return opportunity to all Americans. Do that and our best days are ahead."
Announcer: "Steve Forbes for President. A true vision, an honest voice."
ACCURACY -- This commercial includes some hyperbole. While Mr. Forbes runs a successful magazine, it grew mostly under his father, the late Malcolm Forbes. Mr. Forbes did help devise the Whitman tax cut, but it is not solely responsible for the state's growth. Scholars debate whether Radio Free Europe played a major role in the fall of Communism.
SCORECARD -- The commercial introduces Mr. Forbes as a plain-speaking conservative who has accomplished more than running a magazine, and it succeeds in connecting him to issues that are popular among primary voters.

HEADLINE: Making Volunteerism Easier For Busy Workers of Today

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 24

 BODY:
From Atlanta and Miami to San Diego and Seattle, a new brand of youthful volunteerism is flourishing, nurtured largely by a network of organizations devoted to providing varied and flexible opportunities for busy young professionals to serve their communities.
The movement began in 1986 in a living room on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where six friends gathered to discuss their frustrations with established volunteer agencies in New York City. Their meeting led to the formation of New York Cares, a clearinghouse designed to connect service-minded New Yorkers with dozens of projects around the city. 
 Nine years later, New York Cares has a mailing list of 13,000 volunteers, and its model has been replicated in 26 cities. The groups report a total membership of more than 75,000 people, most of them 25 to 45 years old, and they have created a national umbrella organization, known as City Cares of America, to help form new groups and spread successful ideas.
Experts on philanthropy credit the network with countering a declining interest in volunteerism among young working Americans who seem to have neither the time nor the inclination to serve their communities.
The groups make charity work attractive to such people by simplifying the process of volunteering and removing the concept of guilt. If someone wakes up on a Saturday morning in a mood to help paint an elementary school, all he or she has to do is show up. If he has to head into the office, or chooses to play tennis instead, no one calls to harangue him.
"We don't put the kind of restraints on people that other places do by saying you have to volunteer two hours a week," said Kathy Behrens, executive director of New York Cares. "We want you to volunteer when you're able."
That is what lured Sarah L. Zimmerman, 34, to Hands On Atlanta five years ago, when she moved here to take a job as the associate director of news and information for the Southern Baptist Home Mission Board.
"I travel a lot for work, and I don't want to make a commitment to be someplace the third Friday of every month," Ms. Zimmerman said while sorting cans of creamed corn and tomato soup at a food bank on a recent evening. "If I don't show up for a month, no one's going to think that I let them down."
With such flexibility, the charity network is tapping the energies of an age group that began to turn away from volunteerism in the late 1970's and early 80's, as women joined the work force and young people delayed marriage and family life, said Virginia A. Hodgkinson, vice president for research at Independent Sector, a Washington group that encourages philanthropy and volunteerism.
"Usually, if you're a parent, you have schools and churches and other organizations that start you volunteering," Ms. Hodgkinson said. "But there really weren't enough vehicles for these young professionals until these groups brought them into the community. If we hadn't had them, we may really have seen a decline."
Instead, adults between 25 and 44 are the most active volunteers, according to Independent Sector. In 1993, for instance, 48 percent of American adults 18 or older said they had volunteered at least once in the past year, while 55 percent of those from the ages of 35 to 44 had volunteered. While volunteerism among all adults has fallen since its peak around 1990, when the recession gave charity work more urgency, volunteerism is at higher levels now than it was in 1988, when Independent Sector began monitoring it.
The emergence of the City Cares network reflects deep changes in society and the world of charity work.
"The person who volunteered in the past doesn't exist anymore," said Philip L. Collyer, executive director of Greater D. C. Cares. "That was an individual who worked in the home and had some extra time. Everybody is working now outside the home and has far less discretionary time. Yet they still have a need and a want to support the community."
Most of the groups are growing rapidly, usually with only word-of-mouth advertising. In the smallest city involved, Greenville, S.C., membership is growing 10 percent per month. Hands On Greenville, which began only 20 months ago, now has 400 members.
At Hands On Atlanta, this month's calendar includes 187 projects, including park cleanups, tutoring programs and soup kitchens. The projects are available on every day of the month -- there were several traditional Thanksgiving dinners for the homeless -- with most scheduled for evenings and weekends for the convenience of working people.
Started in 1989 by a group of 12 friends, Hands On Atlanta now has a $1 million budget, 17 paid staff members and a mailing list of 11,000 volunteers.
They include people like Jill A. Barker, 30, an accountant who spends her Thursday nights running a mentoring program for sixth graders at Paul D. West Middle School in East Point, just south of Atlanta. Last week, her seven charges raced around the library pulling books and magazines off shelves to research articles for a magazine they were producing.
"It's amazing what a little individual attention will do," Ms. Barker said. "Last year, I had a kid who was constantly being suspended from school but would show up for every single Hands On Atlanta meeting."
Kelly Williams, a 12-year-old who was writing an article about computers, explained her interest. "In Atlanta public schools, they need to calm those kids down because it seems like they're not getting an education," Kelly said. "Here you get more help. My mom didn't want to bring me to Hands On Atlanta at first, but I told her it was very important."
The key to the success of the groups is simple. They make volunteering easy, meaningful and fun. Because the groups insist on direct involvement in the community, as opposed to stuffing envelopes or selling raffle tickets, they provide instant gratification for volunteers. The projects also double as singles clubs for the socially conscious and have led to a number of marriages.
"People look forward to it," said Nicole M. Kelly, the founder and executive director of Hands On Greenville, "because they know they're going to see their friends at the Read to Me program this week or they think, 'Maybe I'll see that cute guy at the park cleanup again.' "
To those who contend that such a casual approach diminishes the impact of volunteerism, Ms. Kelly replies that occasional volunteerism is better than none at all.
"There are 400 people at least in Greenville who simply would not volunteer if they did not have this organization," Ms. Kelly said.
The groups provide bridges to community service by designing volunteer projects and advertising them to members in monthly newsletters, or in some cases, by sending volunteers to events conducted by established charities. Many City Cares projects are traditional -- things like soup kitchens, literacy tutoring and housing rehabilitation -- but others fill a void.
San Diego Cares provides moving crews for people with AIDS who have to relocate frequently as their assets diminish. Volunteers at Hands On Miami read bedtime stories to children in shelters. In an annual campaign, New York Cares collects winter coats every December -- 71,000 last year -- for the poor.
The groups raise money from corporations, foundations and individuals, and most now collect about half of their budgets from a single day of mass volunteerism when participants collect pledges for the number of hours they work. About 7,500 people participated in the Hands On Atlanta Day on Oct. 7, raising more than $400,000, said Michelle Nunn, the group's executive director.
Leaders of several of the groups said they had occasionally been treated warily by more established charities, which might view them as competitors for both donations and volunteers. "Ultimately, for the community's good, people will learn to collaborate," said Cori L. Snyder, acting executive director of City Cares of America. "But a little competition is good for everyone."
As the groups continue to grow in size and sophistication, their focus may also broaden, with projects designed more for permanent improvements than short-term relief.
"We're a lot more interested now in systemic change," said Ms. Nunn, 29, the daughter of Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who is a longtime proponent of national service for young adults. "Before, it was enough to bring some children to a picnic. Now we want to know whether we can really change people's lives."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

DRUG RING TENSIONS SPAWN VIOLENCE
Tensions among some of New York's most powerful Colombian drug rings have spawned a series of murders and kidnappings in Queens, even as violent crime is dropping almost everywhere else in the city, the police and Federal agents say. Coming after the arrests of six of the top seven kingpins of the Cali drug cartel in Colombia, the surge in violence suggests that discipline is eroding in the upper levels of the Colombian cocaine distribution system that supplies New York, New Jersey and much of the Eastern Seaboard. [Page 1.] 

THE LIFE AND DEATH OF AN ABUSED CHILD
 The police said the bruises and scars that covered Alisa Izquierdo's body made clear that she had been physically and sexually abused for some time before she was found dead on Wednesday in her family's apartment on the Lower East Side. Even those who have dealt with many cases of child abuse said the horrific details of her torture had left them shaken and outraged. As her mother, Awilda Lopez, was arraigned on second-degree murder charges, details of Alisa's life and history of abuse began to come into sharper focus. [1.]
 
NEW YORK CITY
 
RICH AND POOR FEEL BUDGET CUTS
 New Yorkers speak in many voices when asked how the city governments' retrenchment has affected them. But interviews with three dozen of them from a variety of economic and social backgrounds produced some significant common threads. Many poor and working-class people said they had seen a sharp decline in services. While many middle-class residents said their lives had changed little because they use few city services, those with children in the public schools shared the concerns of less-affluent New Yorkers. And there were bitter complaints about the subway system. [27.]
 
KICKING THE HABIT OF NEGLECTED HOUSING
 Before she moved to 281 St. Ann's Avenue in the Bronx, Mary Mays led a life in relentless quest for the fleeting nirvana of countless crack dens. But since May she has lived with other recovering addicts in Mott Haven who rely on themselves and each other for the strength to stay sober. But they might have to return to their old ways of living until their landlord fixes the damage from two recent fires and responds to their repeated complaints about crumbling walls, smoky boilers and shoddy repairs. Their landlord is the City of New York. About New York by David Gonzalez. [27.]
 
PURPORTED APHRODISIAC TAKES FOUR LIVES
 Four men in New York City died between January 1993 and this spring and a 17-year-old required hospitalization for an erratic heartbeat when they ate a purported aphrodisiac sold at city grocery stores and tobacco shops, Federal officials said. The substance was supposed to be applied to the genitals but was not labeled, and when the victims ate it, they began vomiting and their hearts beat erratically, the officials said. [26.]
 
REGION
 
BIG CROWDS, LITTLE CASH
 As the holiday shopping season got its official send-off, store managers in the region and around the country were already slashing prices, dressing their employees in animal costumes and generally pulling out all the promotional stops in what is shaping up as the most difficult retailing environment in years. And while the gimmicks may have drawn crowds, they did not seem to draw out much cash. [Business Day, page 37.]

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

E.P.A. Cuts Inspections As Its Budget Is Reduced
The E.P.A. has canceled hundreds of inspections for pollution because of budget cuts imposed by Congress. Agency officials say the reduction in inspections is likely to intensify if Congress imposes even deeper reductions. A Republican-backed bill would cut spending on environmental enforcement by more than 20 percent. 
 The Republicans say there is not enough money to fix every environmental problem. The argument will be a prominent part of the budget talks between the White House and the Republicans in Congress. [Page 1.]
 
The Dow Sets a Record, Yet Again
Blue-chip stocks advanced to a record high for a third consecutive session, in light trading. The gain was fueled, analysts said, by strong overseas markets and a surge of money into mutual funds. Stocks jumped at the opening and remained in plus territory the whole day. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.23 points, to 5,048.84. For the week, the Dow rose 178.47 points. [41.]
 
Better Japanese Bank Earnings
Japan's 11 major commercial banks reported strong increases in earnings for the six months ended Sept. 30, aided by a low cost of funds and lucrative bond trading. But they warned that results would worsen in the second fiscal half, with some banks reporting losses. [38.]
 
Clinton Lists Budget Priorities
The White House readied for next week's budget talks by sending Congress a "set of priniciples" that the President would demand in a balanced-budget agreement. [1.]
 
The Federal deficit fell 27.4 percent in October, the start of the Government's fiscal year, from October 1994. [47.]
 
Treasury Prices Rise
Treasury prices ended higher in a quiet session. Traders took their cue from strong buying in Asia and Europe. The 30-year Treasury bond yielded 6.24 percent, down from 6.27 percent on Wednesday. [47.]
 
Boeing's Profits Motivate Strikers
The real issue at the center of the Boeing strike appears to be a conflict over the workers' share of the company's large profits. On the same day that workers rejected a contract, senior executives became eligible for stock options, in some cases worth $5 million a person. The machinists say they want their share of Boeing's good fortunes. [6.]
 
KFC's Troubles in India
Indian officials closed the first KFC restaurant in New Delhi, after inspectors found two flies in the kitchen. The flies are really an excuse to crack down on KFC, a unit of Pepsico, which has become a lightning rod for Indian economic nationalism. [4.]
 
New York City Unions Divided
New York City's municipal labor unions are bitterly divided over an agreement that would cover 140,000 non-uniformed city workers, and the leaders of three of the largest union locals vow to fight ratification. [25.]
 
Counting on 100 Million People
The 34th Street Partnership in Manhattan is trying to attract new businesses by establishing that 100 million people do indeed visit Herald Square each year. [25.]

Dollar Ends Week Stronger
The dollar edged higher against leading currencies, settling at 101.41 Japanese yen and 1.4193 German marks. [40.]
 
Corn Prices Surge
Corn prices surged in Chicago after the Government reported larger-than-expected weekly export sales, suggesting that rising prices were not deterring foreign buyers. [40.]

HEADLINE: To Tally Foot Traffic, Study Midriffs;
Counter Clicks for Each One, as New York Swarms Blindly By

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
High noon in Herald Square, and the concrete landscape seethes with people of every size, shape and description. Some stride boldly, some flow in schools like fish, some bubble by in baby carriages. Hundreds rush by each minute.
Lawrence Howard stares straight ahead, his brow furrowed in the intense concentration common to billiard parlors. In his hand, he holds a small clicker. As each person passes, his right thumb snaps down. Click . . . click, click, click . . . click. Babies are counted, dogs aren't. Bicycle messengers are clicked if they are on the sidewalk but not if they're on the street. 
 "I try to look straight ahead and only at the middle of the body," Mr. Howard said as he struggled to cope with a "platoon," a swarm of people sent spilling across an intersection by a green light.
Counting people, not money, might be the ultimate New York phenomenon -- though often they amount to the same thing. Mr. Howard, on the job earlier this month, was counting for the 34th Street Partnership, a business improvement district interested in luring new and more prestigious businesses to Herald Square and the busy shopping area around it.
The initial purpose of the partnership was to establish that 100 million people -- the number that has always been claimed -- do indeed visit Herald Square each year. That task accomplished, counters have been canvassing specific spots, developing data to encourage new businesses to come and existing ones to expand.
Pedestrians are counted for many reasons in New York, a city with more of them than any other in America. Transportation planners count pedestrians when they do safety studies and make roadway improvements, when they decide the size of crosswalks, design new subway stations and position parking lots. Urban planners consider pedestrian activity in zoning and other decisions. Businesses count pedestrian traffic to make location decisions. And business improvement districts -- private organizations made up of businesses in a particular neighborhood -- use the counts to lure others to their districts.
The value of foot traffic is made strikingly obvious by average annual rents of $150 per square foot in stores adjacent to key subway entrances and $70 to $80 a half-block away, real estate professionals say. With so much at stake, banks and businesses often require precise, documented counts.
HMV, the record superstore, recently opened in Herald Square to take advantage of the potential for walk-in customers. Kmart is building its first Manhattan store in the Penn Station area. Cambridge Members, a Korean-owned men's clothing superstore, recently almost doubled its space at 33d Street and Broadway, to 15,000 square feet. Conway's, the bare-bones discount retailer, also chose Herald Square for a new store.
"The more people in the area, the greater the likelihood that more people will stop in," said Stephan Bassett, a Conway's executive. "It's as simple as the more the merrier."
Actually, from the people counter's point of view, it's possible to have too much of a good thing. From now till Christmas -- the busiest shopping time of the year -- Mr. Howard and his fellow counters will be off the streets. "It's too crowded to work," he said.
During much of the postwar shift to the suburbs, cars passing potential mall sites were more interesting to counters than were urban walkers. But David Milder, president of Danth Inc., the consultant helping the partnership interpret its numbers, said that the retail potential of suburbia had "maxed out," and that national chains were scrambling back into cities.
"Cities and downtowns are all about people," he said. "That's their competitive advantage."
The counting itself is mind-numbing work that nonetheless requires keen attention. Mr. Howard, who works off and on as one of four counters on each corner of one of the world's busiest intersections -- Avenue of the Americas and 34th Street -- has no time to give directions. But to his own astonishment he remembers faces, even saying hello to one man whom he remembered clicking off several days before. Counters work episodically, returning to the same locations again and again to reduce their margin of error.
Mr. Howard takes three five-minute counts, then adds them together and multiplies by four for the hourly rate. The most crucial rule is to count only people walking in one direction, to avoid counting anybody twice -- even as people dart by at a rate of two a second at peak hours.
Most counters are graduate students making $7 an hour. Mr. Howard, a zoning specialist for the partnership, counts personally to keep a finger on the district's pulse.
Daniel A. Biederman, the partnership's president, first grasped the importance of people-counting when the Rockefeller Brothers Fund asked him to make over Bryant Park in 1980. He sought out William H. Whyte, author of the 1989 book "City: Rediscovering the Center," for advice. Mr. Whyte had already counted people in the decrepit, drug-riddled park, and found that a lot of people used it.
But it was a complicated case. Mr. Whyte's counting revealed that two to two and a half times as many pedestrians walked on the north side of 42d Street, even though the sidewalk is wider on the park side. Some people were clearly put off by the park's woebegone appearance.
Redevelopment of the park went ahead, Mr. Biederman said, because calculations of the masses of people in the immediate area strongly suggested that a green space could draw them in. The park now often draws 5,000 people on a nice day, five times as many as it did 15 years ago.
There are many other uses for pedestrian counts. Earlier this month, the Regional Plan Association released a glowing report on the prospects for downtown Brooklyn, based in part on the 100,000 daily visitors to the Fulton Mall, the area's main shopping district. The Times Square Business Development Association issued a report last year on Eighth Avenue's surprising potential for nonpornographic retail development, based in part on the numbers of pedestrians counted.
Professionals say the most accurate counts are the most expensive: those made by examining aerial photographs under microscopes. Other counting methods include time-lapse photography, used by Mr. Whyte in some locations.
Planners also use estimates based on computerized analyses of census, utility, transportation and other data. But experts insist that only actual counts can be trusted, though "most people don't do it because of the tremendous cost," said Herbert Levinson, a pedestrian consultant based in New Haven.
In particular, there has been no citywide count since the late 1970's, when the Regional Plan Association did one. As a result, officials for city agencies and business groups say, there is no standard reference -- which means some areas' claims are questioned by others. For instance, according to the Times Square Business Improvement District, 1.5 million people visit Times Square daily. That would make it more than four times busier than Herald Square eight blocks south, a degree of magnitude Mr. Biederman questions. "There's a lot of puffery in these numbers," he said.
Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square group, said that the 1.5 million figure, used in the district's brochures, was not the result of an actual count but rather represented estimates derived from adding the hundreds of thousands of people in the neighborhood riding on subways and buses, working in offices and staying in hotels. "It's as close as you can get without actually being out there counting," she said.
But some say that more, and better, counting is exactly what is needed. "The city should commission a traffic engineer to go out and do pedestrian counts," said Lee Phillips, president of the Phillips/Norwalk Company, a retail planning consultant.

HEADLINE: Session Is Short and Quiet, But Treasury Prices Go Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday in a quiet and abbreviated session.
Without fresh economic data, market participants took their cue from strong buying in Asian and European markets early yesterday before the opening of the New York market. Most trading desks were thinly staffed as many participants extended the Thanksgiving holiday to a four-day weekend. 
 Prices held steady throughout the session. Many market investors do not want to buy in any meaningful amounts before seeing additional proof of a weakening economy and some progress between Congress and the Clinton Administration toward an agreement for a Federal budget package and an increase in the debt ceiling.
The market is hoping that after an agreement, the Federal Reserve will lower short-term interest rates.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 13/32 , to 10815/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.24 percent from 6.27 percent on Wednesday.
Trading in the New York cash market halted early, at about 2 P.M., on the recommendation of the Public Securities Association, which represents firms that buy and sell debt securities.
Next week, the market faces added supply as the Treasury sells $30.25 billion of new two-year and five-year notes in addition to its regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, which will total $28 billion. In when-issued trading ahead of next week's auctions, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.48 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.69 percent.
Kim Rupert, an economist with MMS International, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said she did not see supply as a major obstacle because of the market's bullish mood. "We got through the refunding without many major setbacks," she noted, referring to the Treasury's sales of 3-year and 10-year notes this week.
Ms. Rupert said the technicals of the market remained positive, "and besides we usually see month-end buying and we expect to see more of that."
Some traders speculated that yesterday's buying was prompted in part by expectations that a slow start to the holiday shopping season would hinder growth and restrain inflation, giving the Fed an opportunity to cut rates again to stimulate the economy.
"Next week we get housing starts," Ms. Rupert said, "which has been a significant number for the market." Also due next week are a report on durable goods orders for October, a report from the National Purchasing Management Association and auto and truck sales numbers from American auto makers.

HEADLINE: Federal Deficit Fell 27.4% In a Month of Budget Debate

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The Federal deficit in October, the start of a new fiscal year, was 27.4 percent lower than in the corresponding month a year ago.
The amount of the deficit was smaller than analysts had expected, but Cynthia Latta, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill, a forecasting service in Lexington, Mass., said the October decline mainly reflected smaller appropriations approved by Congress during the budget stalemate. 
 "You can't spend much without the appropriation bills," she said. "They'll make up for it."
The Treasury Department said today that spending in October exceeded revenue by $22.8 billion. The deficit in October 1994 was $31.3 billion.
The deficit for the full fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30 was $163.8 billion, the lowest since 1989, when it was $152.5 billion.
The deficit hit a record $290.4 billion in the fiscal year 1992 before it started to decline. It was $255.1 billion the following year and fell to $203.2 billion last year.
The Clinton Administration estimates that the deficit will decline slightly this fiscal year, to $162.8 billion.
Analysts have said the lower deficits in the last few years are a result of a healthy economy that has created jobs -- and more taxpayers -- combined with spending limits.
The Government collected $95.6 billion in October, compared with $89 billion in the month a year ago. It spent $118.4 billion, down from $120.4 billion. The deficit is the difference between receipts and expenditures.
Interest on the national debt amounted to $21.6 billion for the month and is projected to total $349.3 billion for the entire year.

HEADLINE: Rich or Poor, Most Feel Cuts in City Services

SERIES: SHRINKING THE CITY: Citizen's Voices

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
Antoinette Leonard says her high school has become so overcrowded that in some cases 39 students are packed into a class. Alvin Berk worries that a decline in tree-pruning by city crews will lead to the death of handsome old trees in his neighborhood. But Rocio Proano says the city services she cares most about, particularly the public library, have actually improved -- despite a year of extraordinary spending cuts by the city and state.
New Yorkers speak in many voices when asked how the governments' retrenchment has affected them. But interviews with three dozen New Yorkers from a variety of economic and social backgrounds did produce some significant common threads. 
 Many poor and working-class people, who depend heavily on city hospitals and other assistance from the city, said they had seen a sharp decline in services. Many middle-class New Yorkers, on the other hand, said their lives had changed little because they use few city services -- although some did worry about how the cutbacks were affecting people less fortunate than them.
Middle-class New Yorkers with children in the public schools shared the concerns of less-affluent New Yorkers about ballooning class sizes and generally diminished school resources. And many people who commute on the subways and buses bitterly complained that service was declining while the fare had gone up.
The interviews took place in three Brooklyn neighborhoods -- upscale Park Slope, working-class Flatbush and middle-class Mill Basin -- and they revealed a broad range of views, some of them unexpected.
"Mister, you could eat off my sidewalk," said Sonja Henney, describing the Sanitation Department's work on her block in the Midwood section of Brooklyn. "My business is booming, and I believe I couldn't pay for a better education for my two children." Miss Henney is a day-care supervisor and sends her children to city schools. "So I really can't complain," she added.
But another woman, a retired teacher's assistant in the public schools, did. She has taken in six foster children, who range in age from 4 months to 12 years. The city has stopped paying for baby sitters to help foster parents, and the woman, who agreed to be interviewed on the condition that her name be withheld, said it had cost her dearly.
"If I have to take one of the kids out to a doctor, I have to take all six kids," she said. "And they do not pay for the car fare. I get no assistance, and it's not right."
What follows are reactions to city and state budget cuts from eight other New Yorkers.
 
Shrinking the City: Citizen's voices.
 
Antoinette Leonard
 She is a junior at Midwood High School. The math textbook she was given in September has no cover, and some students have been closed out of advanced placement classes. Her math class has 39 students, her Spanish class has 36 and advanced placement biology has 35.
"They were smaller last term," she said. "There were 24, 25 kids in most of my classes." Midwood has about 3,500 students but only 5 guidance counselors -- one for every 700 students, Ms. Leonard noted. "When you go to see a guidance counselor, they ask you for your number, not your name."
"The Mayor and the President say that New York has the lowest graduation rates," she said. "But then they spend all their money on weapons. Why aren't we spending more money on education?"
 
Rocio Proano
 She is pleased that the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library has expanded its hours (though the Brooklyn system is deferring maintenance expenses and making other cuts to maintain its hours). And she is happy that her subway stop, Grand Army Plaza, is being rebuilt. Those are the government services on which she said she most depends.
"Actually, I think city services are better," said Ms. Proano, who talked briefly while hurrying to catch a subway train on a recent afternoon, and who did not say what her occupation was. "I think the stations show a lot of improvement, and crime is down, from what I hear. So that counts for something."
 
Alvin Berk
 A university administrator, he is chairman of Community Board 14, which includes the neighborhoods of Flatbush and Midwood and parts of Kensington.
"There's been a lot of nibbling around the edges," he said. "One thing that you see is tire carcasses all over the streets because the Sanitation Department stopped picking up discarded tires with the garbage. Now you have to bring them to a central place in each borough, and no one knows where those are."
"Trees aren't being pruned," he added. "The limbs break during storms, sometimes damaging property. Certainly, it is going to make the city a less attractive place to live."
"The community boards' budgets have been hurt seriously," he continued. "They were cut 19 percent last year, and for many boards that has been carried over to this year. A lot of boards have lost staffing. We reduced our staff from three to two. The complaint-taking capability of community boards is being jeopardized, and that means that community boards are less able to track agency performance."
 
Norman Henkin
A retired lawyer, he said he had noticed no changes in the services on which he depends, like the police, sanitation and subways. But he worries that the city and state cutbacks have hurt the poor.
"I think it stinks," he said. "I'm a rich man, so it doesn't affect me. But poor people are starving." Asked what the city should do to remedy this problem, Mr. Henkin quickly volunteered to do his part.
"I think they should increase taxes," he said, "especially on people like me."
 
 Barbara Byrd-Bennett
She is superintendent of Community School District 17, which includes parts of Flatbush and Crown Heights. The district has 27,000 students in 27 schools.
"I can see firsthand the effect in the schools," she said. "Larger class sizes, less money for resources. The number of students that guidance counselors serve has increased. I have fewer security guards and security aides. I have fewer dollars to purchase updated hardware for computers for our students."
"I have kindergarten classes with 28 to 30 students," she said. "I have fourth-grade classes with 34, 35 students. When you have increased bodies, you need new furniture, new desks. You have to buy furniture for kids, but there is no money for that. When we talk about equity in education, we just don't have it."
 
Francois Jacqueline
 A Flatbush resident, he works as a teacher's assistant at Westinghouse High School in downtown Brooklyn. He was particularly dissatisfied with the care his pregnant wife received at Kings County Hospital Center, a city hospital. When she was hospitalized there a few months ago, he said, she had to spend 12 hours in the emergency room before she was assigned a bed.
"The services there are not proper," he said. "They don't respect the patient." The cutbacks, he said, are "very bitter medicine. The rich get richer and the poor, like me, get poorer."
 
Clive Rose
He is a hospital nurse from Flatbush, and he said the service cutbacks have had no effect on his life. Though his children's public school classes are somewhat larger, they do not seem bothered by it -- and so neither is he. Because he drives to work, Mr. Rose said he was unaware of any changes in subway and bus service.
"I never really use the services," he said, "so it hasn't really affected me yet."
 
Edward Martin
He lives on Manhattan's Upper West Side near Columbia University and teaches English and history at the Berkeley Carroll School, a private school in Park Slope.
"I haven't seen much change in my neighborhood, around Columbia, because we didn't have much in the way of services to begin with," he said. But then he noted one big exception: the subways.
"There's no doubt that the trains are more crowded, they run less often and they definitely seem dirtier," he said. "The fare is going up and the service is going down."
 
Shrinking the City
 Future articles in this series will continue to detail the effects of budget cuts on a number of city agencies.

HEADLINE: Haitian President Is Hinting That He Might Not Step Down

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 24

 BODY:
In an ambiguous speech delivered in Port-au-Prince to some of his most loyal supporters, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide appeared today to endorse their longstanding demands that he ignore a pledge he made to the United States and remain in office for three more years.
"If you want three years, I will not turn my back on you," Mr. Aristide said in an address at the end of a weeklong conference on national unity. 
 But the Haitian leader hedged his comments, adding, "If you want elections, I will not turn my back on you." Elections to choose his successor are scheduled in three weeks.
He also told the several hundred delegates at the meeting that he wanted to consult with leaders of opposition parties and business groups before making a final decision. "Neither myself or you make a whole," he told his supporters.
"My mission is a fragile one," he also said. "I try to weigh every word I say."
Making their own position clear, the delegates, who had earlier passed a nonbinding resolution calling on the President not to step down, erupted into cheers and began to chant "Three more years! three more years!" according to people who attended the conference, held at the National Palace.
Under the Haitian Constitution, Mr. Aristide cannot succeed himself in office, and is scheduled to step down on Feb. 7. Last week, Rene Preval, a former Prime Minister under Mr. Aristide and close friend of his, registered as the candidate of the governing Lavalas Movement, which immediately made him the front-runner and appeared to end growing speculation that an election might not be held. Thirteen other candidates are in the running.
Mr. Aristide, who spent three years in exile in Venezuela and the United States after being ousted in a military coup in September 1991, has served only two years of the five-year term to which he was elected in December 1990. As a result, many Lavalas members have argued that he should be allowed to remain in office to make up for the time he lost.
That position, however, conflicts with guarantees Mr. Aristide made to the Clinton Administration in Washington shortly before 20,000 American troops entered Haiti in September 1994 to restore him to power. Standing with Mr. Clinton at his side, Mr. Aristide promised publicly to leave office in February 1996, a pledge he has repeated, under American pressure, many times since his return.
In recent weeks, though, the once-cordial relations between Mr. Aristide and his benefactors in Washington have cooled somewhat. More than $4.5 million in American aid to Haiti, for instance, has been put on hold because the Aristide Government has failed to make progress on a program to privatize state-owned companies, and an additional $100 million may also be in jeopardy.
Mr. Aristide's remarks today followed almost two weeks of intermittent street violence, which erupted after he delivered a fiery eulogy at the funeral of a close relative slain by gunmen. In that earlier speech, Mr. Aristide called on his supporters to "go to the neighborhoods where there are big houses and heavy weapons," and criticized the American-led United Nations peacekeeping force operating here for not disarming what he called "the big men with the heavy weapons."
Since then, at least 10 people have died and more than a score have been wounded or injured in street clashes.
Mr. Aristide's remarks came one day after he met with President Clinton's national security adviser, Anthony Lake, in Port-au-Prince. A spokesman for the American Embassy, Stanley Schrager, said that Mr. Lake's visit "was not related to the recent disturbances" but that he assumed "they talked about the presidential election and everything else."
Evans Paul, a former Aristide ally and Mayor of Port-au-Prince who broke with the President after parliamentary elections this summer, has charged that the Lavalas Movement is trying to make the presidential election meaningless by creating a climate of insecurity in which voting and campaigning are impossible.
But in an indication of the confused state of Haitian politics, Mr. Paul has also joined those who have suggested that Mr. Aristide remain in office for three more years. In an interview last month, he said that was the best way for Haiti to preserve stability and guarantee economic and political development.

HEADLINE: New Delhi Journal;
Fowl Fight Over Flies Sends India Into a Stew

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Since health inspectors arrived two weeks ago at Kentucky Fried Chicken's first restaurant in the Indian capital and filed a report that was used to justify closing the outlet, wags here have had a name for the episode: the Tale of Two Flies.
Other Indians are not sure whether to laugh or cry. 
 Either way, the travails of Colonel Sanders' beachhead in the land of tandoori chicken have been the occasion for a thoroughgoing tamasha, the Indian equivalent of a brouhaha.
The flies -- two flies, precisely, in the part of the kitchen used to thaw frozen chicken -- were cited by the city's Health Commissioner in ordering the restaurant's license canceled for "unsanitary conditions."
Unlike in China, where Mao Zedong's directive "Away with all pests!" once set millions to swatting flies, the fly has never been hard pressed in India. The Indian restaurant has been something of a home-away-from-home for flies, a fact cited by many Indian newspapers in their coverage of the controversy. M. D. Nalapat, a columnist writing in The Sunday Times of India, even suggested that Kentucky Fried Chicken should have been "given an award," not shut down, "because only two flies were found."
But flies, as many Indians have said from the start of the controversy, have been more in the way of an excuse than a cause of Kentucky Fried Chicken's problems. Like Coca-Cola when it was driven out of India by Government order 20 years ago, KFC, as it is called, by friend and foe alike, has become the latest lightning rod for a form of Indian economic nationalism.
The "Chicken War," as it is often called in Indian newspapers, began three months ago, when Pepsico Restaurants International, the Dallas-based parent company of Kentucky Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut, opened the first of 60 fast-food outlets it plans for India in the next seven years. The first fried chicken outlet, in the southern city of Bangalore, drew immediate fire from the economic nationalists, who persuaded the Bangalore city government to withdraw the restaurant's license.
In Bangalore, the reason given was that chicken samples taken from the restaurant contained dangerously high levels of monosodium glutamate, said by Indian opponents of Kentucky Fried Chicken to be carcinogenic. The Indian executives who manage Pepsico's restaurants obtained a court injunction staying the city's action, reopened in five hours, and won a high court ruling this month reinstating the restaurant's license. But by then the Bangalore dispute had been overshadowed by the dispute in New Delhi.
By opening the chain's second outlet in the capital, KFC executives were effectively challenging the lion in his den, since the Delhi regional government is controlled by the Bharatiya Janata Party, principal standard-bearer in Indian politics for Hindu nationalism and its economic component. In the period leading up to a general election across India next spring, the party's national leaders have staked out their opposition to foreign investment in consumer industries. Their mantra has been suitably catchy: "What India needs is computer chips, not potato chips."
Even party leaders seem unsure whether they can fire public passions sufficiently to unseat the governing Congress Party, which broke the tablets of Indian socialism when it ushered in a new era of market economics in 1991. The Hindu middle class from which the nationalist party draws its support flocked to the Bangalore and the New Delhi restaurants, with lines curling into the street. In a Times of India survey, 67 percent of the respondents said that Kentucky Fried Chicken had been "unfairly singled out" when far worse conditions are tolerated in many Indian restaurants.
Perhaps most surprising, considering India's own spicy cuisine, Colonel Sanders's recipes have come in for enthusiastic reviews. Khushwant Singh, one of the country's best-known novelists and critics, wrote a piece in The Hindustan Times recalling how he came across Kentucky Fried Chicken during a university teaching stint in Hawaii 20 years ago and found it as tasty as tandoori chicken -- the heavily spiced, spit-roasted chicken brought to India in the Middle Ages by invading Mogul conquerors.
"Why they call it junk food, I had no idea," Mr. Singh said.
For now, KFC executives say they will press ahead with their $80 million investment program, starting with a court challenge in which the company will seek restitution of its New Delhi license. Sandeep Kohli, the 38-year-old managing director of Pepsico Restaurants in India, said the company will argue that standards in the New Delhi restaurant are superior to virtually all of New Delhi's 20,000 other restaurants, at least half of which operate without licenses or inspections of any kind.
"Ours is by far the cleanest kitchen in this part of the world," he said.
Other commentators have suggested that this is no year, and New Delhi no place, to be trumpeting the superior virtues of tandoori restaurants, at least from the standpoint of hygiene. In July, the city was shaken when a prominent young politician, Sushil Sharma, a former leader of the Congress Party's youth wing in the capital, was arrested and charged with shooting his wife and attempting to burn her body in the tandoor oven of a Government-owned restaurant. For several months after the episode, tandoori restaurants in the city reported a sharp falloff in trade.

HEADLINE: Lots of Cash Pays Off, a G.O.P. Candidate Finds

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: BEDFORD, N.H., Nov. 21

 BODY:
If George Herbert Walker Bush was born with a silver spoon in his mouth, Malcolm Stevenson Forbes Jr. was born with a complete place setting.
Money -- by the bucketful -- is at the core of Mr. Forbes's candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination. It may not buy him love from the voters, but it is certainly buying him attention, to say nothing of a respectable standing in the polls. 
 In the nine weeks since he announced his candidacy, Mr. Forbes has spent $7 million of his personal fortune to bombard New Hampshire and Iowa and other pivotal states with a television and radio advertising campaign months ahead of the states' Presidential nominating contests. It is more intense than the blizzards of advertising that most candidates run on the eve of the actual voting.
Because he rejected Government money to help finance his campaign, Mr. Forbes is free of Federal spending limits, and he is well on his way to far exceeding the total amount most of his rivals have budgeted for advertising in those early states.
Such saturation, so early, by a single candidate is unheard of in Presidential politics. But it seems to be paying off for Mr. Forbes. Though he is still in single digits in most polls, he has pulled even with or ahead of every candidate except the front-runner, Senator Bob Dole, in New Hampshire or Iowa -- sites of the first two important contests. He is drawing attention away from Mr. Dole's rivals during the crucial run-up to the primaries, as they all are vying to break from the pack. He is not helping Mr. Dole either: his commercials relentlessly attack the Senator on issues like term limits.
"I think I'm getting real value for my money," Mr. Forbes, who is known among friends as a penny pincher, said with satisfaction here at a breakfast meeting with Republicans.
Three influential Governors who are backing Mr. Dole agreed that Mr. Forbes, long a behind-the-scenes player in Republican politics, should not be underestimated. "Who's got the most momentum in this state right now? Forbes," Gov. Stephen Merrill of New Hampshire said before he endorsed Mr. Dole. "He's talking in specifics much more than conventional wisdom, and people like that."
Gov. Pete Wilson of California, who withdrew from the Presidential race in late September, said, "Why is he doing better than the also-rans? He is a new face. And he is the only one who can legitimately claim to be an outsider."
And Gov. Terry E. Branstad of Iowa, marveling at how Mr. Forbes' advertisements have saturated his state, said, "I've been through four campaigns for Governor, and I used to have a hard time seeing my ads. With Forbes, I see six in one day. And I almost never watch TV."
Indeed, it is impossible to turn on a television here without seeing the 48-year-old Mr. Forbes, in his matter-of-fact, plodding delivery, describing his proposals on the flat tax, term limits or health care in a mix of nine commercials thus far. On WMUR, the leading television station in New Hampshire, for instance, the Forbes campaign is paying for about 80 commercials this week at a cost of about $50,000. In addition, the campaign is spending nearly as much in other broadcast and cable stations in the state -- and even more in Iowa and for some national commercials.
By contrast, candidates who abide by spending limits have a cap of just over $600,000 for the entire New Hampshire primary. Mr. Dole has yet to broadcast a television commercial in New Hampshire this year, but others have had far more modest advertising campaigns than Mr. Forbes: Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Morry Taylor, a tire-wheel manufacturer.
The Forbes commercials are not flashy affairs: they are meat-and-potatoes, full of facts and figures. They were produced by Our Town Films of New York, which has done work for Forbes magazine but is not known for political advertising. But the scripts are by a coterie of campaign veterans that includes Carter Wrenn and Tom Ellis, longtime confidants of Senator Jesse Helms, R. Marc Nuttle, who ran Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign in 1988, and John McLaughlin, a pollster.
Mr. Forbes plays down his wealth by noting that other candidates have spent more than he has. But he neglects to say that the others started months, if not years, earlier than he did. He insists that people are responding to his message.
"When people come up to me they don't talk about 'Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous,' " Mr. Forbes said in an interview as his van rolled from here to Concord. "Ideas -- that's what they identify with you."
In fact, Mr. Forbes has been hammering so hard on his signature flat-tax proposal that it has given voters an issue with which to connect him. With a flat tax, taxpayers would fork over 17 percent their earnings.
Advocates say the flat tax would be simpler to administer and would distort business decisions less than the current, complicated tax code does. But opponents say it would be hard on the poor and on middle-class people who rely on deductions such as for home mortgage interest.
Mr. Forbes concedes that if he were not a millionaire, his ideas would not be heard. Though he has a sparse organization and is pouring almost all his money into advertising, Mr. Forbes' cash gives him other advantages: He plans to spend $1 million for an intense effort to gather enough signatures to get on the primary ballot in New York.
Dismissing critics who note that Mr. Forbes' poll numbers are not as strong nationally as they are in Iowa and New Hampshire, William A. Dal Col, Mr. Forbes' campaign manager, said that all he would have to do is buy more commercials on the networks, "If I bought some time on the three majors, I'd take care of that in a week."
Mr. McLaughlin, Mr. Forbes' pollster, is also delighted to have a client who is not encumbered by spending limits. "For 20 years, we've had these Watergate laws that have stifled the issue discussion," he said. "Forbes is rewriting the rules -- it's revolutionary."
The ultimate question is whether a blank check can buy a candidate more than a short-lived blip in the polls. Former Gov. John B. Connally of Texas spent $12 million in the Republican primaries in 1980: he got only one delegate. But unlike Mr. Forbes, Mr. Connally did not concentrate his spending on commercials.
Then there is former Representative Michael Huffington, who spent $29 million last year, mostly in advertising, to try to win a Senate seat in California. He lost to Senator Dianne Feinstein, but by a margin of less than two percentage points.
Mr. Forbes runs even more of a risk than Ross Perot in using his own money to finance his campaign for President because Mr. Perot scored points with voters as a self-made billionaire.
Perhaps that is why Mr. Forbes -- who prefers to be called "Steve" -- is doing his best to portray himself as a commoner despite the estimated $400 million he inherited from his family's publishing empire.
But he tripped over his patrician roots in an interview when he remarked that he liked Big Macs and Whoppers. "The nice thing about Whoppers is you can at least console yourself that some of that is on the recommended list: the lettuce, the tomato," he said. But he pronounced it toe-MAAAH-toe.
Michael Murphy, Mr. Alexander's chief adviser, dismissed Mr. Forbes as having "reached his ceiling -- he's never been above the margin of error." That may be true, but there is little evidence that Mr. Alexander is doing any better.
It might also be that Mr. Forbes' advisers are right -- and that people do like his message. Tom Horgan, a college administrator in Amherst, N.H., said he was torn between Mr. Alexander and Mr. Forbes, but was intrigued enough by the Forbes commercials to go hear him speak this week. "He was much more dimensional than his advertising would indicate," said Mr. Horgan, who is 42. "Some people might think he's a Johnny-one-note. He talks a lot about economics. But it is a message that gets through. Lamar Alexander doesn't have a message that gets through."
Mr. Forbes said that to prove that there is grass-roots support for his candidacy, he has begun soliciting contributions, and plans a big fund-raising bash at the Waldorf Astoria on Dec. 13. He insists that his own spending on the race "won't be higher" than $25 million.
But his campaign manager, Mr. Dal Col, is confident he can squeeze more out of Mr. Forbes if need be. "Let's put it this way," he said. "If we're second in New Hampshire and I need more money, do you think there will be any doubt?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steve Forbes signed his name for a supporter at the Deka Research Corporation in Manchester, N.H. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Banks Post Big Rises In Earnings

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 24

 BODY:
Japan's 11 major commercial banks, aided by a low cost of funds and lucrative bond trading, today reported strong increases in earnings for the six months ended Sept. 30 but warned that results would slow in the second fiscal half, with some of the institutions likely to fall into the red.
The banks made little progress in reducing their big supply of bad loans in their first half but were expected to take big write-offs at the end of the current fiscal year. Nine of the 11 plan to write off all their loans to Japan's seven troubled housing lenders, and some said they would do so even if it meant reporting a loss or skipping a dividend payment -- steps the banks have been loath to take. 
 "Even including loans to housing loan companies, we will be able to dispose of problem loans by the end of this fiscal year," said Takeshi Yano, senior managing director of the Mitsubishi Bank.
By the Government's estimate, the nation's banks are saddled with bad debts amounting to 37.4 trillion yen, or about $370 billion, with half that amount unrecoverable. Some analysts, however, have said the bad debts could be twice that.
The 11 big commercial banks are Dai-Ichi Kangyo, Sumitomo, Sanwa, Sakura Mitsubishi, Fuji, Tokai, Asahi Bank of Tokyo, Daiwa and Hokkaido Takushoku. Their operating profits soared in the first half because they were able to obtain inexpensive funds in the short-term money market -- interest rates were as low as four-tenths of 1 percent -- and buy long-term Japanese Government bonds paying as much as 3 percent in interest.
Compared with the corresponding period in 1994, operating profit more than doubled at Daiwa and Hokkaido Takushoku, rose about 75 percent at Sakura and Fuji and increased about 50 percent at Tokai, Asahi and Sumitomo.
The rate at which the banks wrote off bad loans slowed from the half a year earlier, causing pretax profit to rise even more than operating profit at several of the institutions. The 11 banks wrote off 1.24 trillion yen in bad loans in the latest half, down from 3.39 trillion yen a year earlier.
For the full fiscal year, many banks expect earnings to fall sharply, and in some cases expect to report losses, as they write off larger portions of their bad loan portfolios.
The Bank of Tokyo and Fuji said they expected earnings to decline. Daiwa -- already reeling from a scandal in which a trader lost $1.1 billion through unauthorized bond trades in New York -- said it might post a loss, depending on the amount of bad loans it decided to write off.
Hokkaido Takushoku said it expected to report a pretax loss of 190 billion yen for the fiscal year after writing off 250 billion yen in bad loans. The loss would come despite a cost-cutting plan that will close 30 branches, cut as many as 300 jobs and employ capital reserves to dispose of the bad loans.
In contrast, Sanwa, which wrote off 251 billion yen in bad loans during the first half, said it expected pretax profit to rise 32 percent in the full year. And Dai-Ichi Kangyo said it expected a 66 percent gain in pretax profit.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Asia and Europe; Many U.S. Traders Off for Day

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher against most leading currencies yesterday in Asia and Europe. Many American currency traders were taking a long Thanksgiving holiday weekend.
 Without their American counterparts, even European and Asian dealers struggled to find reasons to trade. 
 "Everyone is in a holiday mode," said John Nasti, director of foreign exchange at Barclays Group. "It just seems to be the same thing: London opens in a narrow range and the U.S. follows suit."
In New York trading yesterday, the dollar settled at 101.41 Japanese yen, up from 100.76 yen on Wednesday. The dollar also rose to 1.4193 German marks from 1.4090 marks and to 1.1437 Swiss francs from 1.1369 Swiss francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5595 from $1.5625.
Many financial markets in the United States and Japan were closed on Thursday for national holidays; Japan celebrated Labor Thanksgiving Day.
Speculation that Germany's central bank could soon cut a key interest rate pushed the mark lower against other European currencies and against the dollar, dealers said.
 Yet some doubted a rate cut would come soon in Germany. "From what I can see, they're saying they'll cut rates, but not imminently," an American trader said. "But the market is not playing the long term."
 The dollar also got a modest lift against the yen as the Japanese currency slipped against the mark and other European currencies.
 The yen was "sold against some of the European currencies," said David Gilmore, a partner with Foreign Exchange Analytics.
He said dealers were betting that Japanese securities houses would buy the French franc, the British pound and other currencies on behalf of some clients looking to invest cash that had just been freed up.
Dealers reported a flurry of dollar buying against the yen as the dollar crossed 101.15 yen. Some market participants who had bet the dollar would not get that high had to buy to minimize their losses.
 But the dollar's rally against the yen stalled near the 101.55 level, where a pile of sell orders from overnight Asian trading sat awaiting completion.
 "There were some sell orders there left over from Tokyo," one trader said.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
LaFontaine Isn't Eager To Rejoin the Islanders

BYLINE: By JASON DIAMOS 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Nov. 24

 BODY:
The way it sounded, Pat LaFontaine, trade rumors swirling about him, would show up if the Islanders were to reacquire him in a trade. But he would probably not be too happy about it.
LaFontaine, who joined the Islanders after playing for the 1984 United States Olympic team and became a fan favorite on Long Island, forced a trade from New York in October 1991, when the owner, John O. Pickett, and Bill Torrey, then the general manager, refused to renegotiate his contract. 
 He likes Buffalo. A lot. He has a huge contract. He has to like that a lot.
"The way I look at it is, you move and you grow and you learn from those experiences," LaFontaine said today about his relationship with the Islanders, who tied the Sabres, 1-1, here tonight. "That's something that was a long time ago. I had said all along that it was the best for both parties. And really, I have no regrets. I feel good about what happened and what transpired.
"I still go back and visit the Island. We have a lot of close friends on the Island. But right now, I'm a Buffalo Sabre. I have an obligation to my teammates. My home is here. And I'm enjoying my time. I haven't asked for a trade."
But LaFontaine also said he realizes that hockey is a business. And he has seen what the Sabres have done this season -- namely, rid themselves of salaries. LaFontaine, who missed almost 16 months of play after injuring his knee in 1993, will make $4.3 million this season, $4.6 million the next and $4.8 million the two after that.
"I think if an organization, because of economic reasons, would like to move on, that's a situation where, hey, if you're needed somewhere else, that's where you go," LaFontaine, 30, said.
But Sabres General Manager John Muckler did not sound as if he were looking to transfer anyone. While conceding that he had talked to General Manager Don Maloney of the Islanders today, Muckler said that local newspaper reports of a trade involving LaFontaine had been "blown out of proportion."
LaFontaine's agent, Don Meehan, said he would be surprised by a trade with the Islanders.
"You can never say never," he said. "But there are a combination of factors why I don't think it's going to happen. No. 1, Pat's happy in Buffalo. No. 2, I don't know that Buffalo wants to trade Pat. No. 3, Pat had no intention of playing for John Pickett earlier and I see no reason why he would want to play for him now. And No. 4, he's got a contract that is very substantial."
But the Islanders desperately need a marquee name -- almost as badly as they need a center. And LaFontaine fits both bills.
 
SLAP SHOTS
 Count out the Calgary Flames' holdout center, JOE NIEUWENDYK, as far as a trade for KIRK MULLER goes. A person familiar with the situation said that Nieuwendyk, 29, wants no part of playing for a rebuilding team. Nieuwendyk's agent, HERB PINDER, said as much on Friday.

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action Levels Playing Field

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I am concerned that a quotation attributed to me in "Not Just a White Man's Game: Blacks in Business Master the Art of Networking" (Business Day, Nov. 9) may have been misinterpreted. 
 The quotation was: "The African-American mind-set reflected a need to say, 'I did it myself.' . . . It may be one of the fallout aspects of affirmative action, feeling guilty that we have been handed things, so we want to do it ourselves."
I strongly support affirmative action and believe it is necessary to help level the playing field of economic opportunity. However, the assault on affirmative action by the conservative right has reframed the debate. Affirmative action, instead of being viewed as a partial remedy to past and present discrimination, is itself attacked as discriminatory.
Under this logic, it has been suggested that affirmative action is a disservice to African-Americans because it taints our accomplishments as "handouts." In the business circles that Black Enterprise magazine covers, this is understood by both black and white businesspeople to be the racially polarizing political rhetoric that it is.
The importance we place on access to equal opportunity is most notably reflected in our decision to pull the Black Enterprise-Pepsi Golf and Tennis Challenge out of California because of its governor's repeated attacks on affirmative action and minority set-asides. As executive director of this event, I moved it to the Doral Golf Resort and Spa in Miami.
During an economic boycott a couple of years ago the city of Miami learned of the influence and economic power of the African-American business community. This same community will work to preserve affirmative action as long as access to economic opportunity continues to be denied to so many.
 
JOHN C. GRAVES
New York, Nov. 22, 1995
