HEADLINE: MAKING MICROSOFT SAFE FOR CAPITALISM

 BODY:
James Gleick's "Making Microsoft Safe for Capitalism" (Nov. 5) makes it sound as if Microsoft were doing something wrong by being a strong competitor and by creating innovative software that customers decide to buy.
The PC software business is incredibly competitive. Prices decline even as products improve dramatically. The Internet is creating even more opportunities for competition. Microsoft must continue to innovate or we will be history. This is not paranoia; it is simple fact. 
 Gleick asserts that the quality of Microsoft's products has been "incidental to" our success. This is outrageous. Excel and Word have received industry awards because they are great products. No company in our business can sell products that don't excite users and receive positive reviews.
Contrary to Gleick's assertion, there was never any deliberate attempt to sabotage any competitor's software application. Windows's success depends on making a very broad range of applications compatible. Windows is a great and open platform. In fact, we spend a huge amount of our resources working with other software companies to make sure their products run well on Windows.
Perhaps most troubling is Gleick's uncritical acceptance of our competitors' self-serving claims about business practices and ethics. There is nothing illegal -- or unethical -- about being relentless in improving existing products or creating new ones.
Lastly, Gleick's call for Federal action would be bad news for everyone. The notion that any new work we do should be controlled by a Government agency and given away free for others to copy makes no sense from either a legal or economic perspective. The personal computer marketplace is one of the great American success stories precisely because it has developed on its own, indeed flourished. It is the envy of countries around the world and should not be subjected to burdensome Government regulations.
 
BILL GATES
Chairman and C.E.O.
Microsoft
Redmond, Wash.

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
Republican Socialism

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS 

 BODY:
IF THERE IS ONE proposition upon which all Republican politicians can agree, it is that the Government should butt out of the market. The budget bills passed by the Republican-controlled House and Senate earlier this month testify to the G.O.P.'s faith in the invisible hand. Explicit industrial policies, like tax incentives for small businesses in poor neighborhoods, are as unfashionable as they have ever been; implicit ones like affirmative action are beyond the pale. People who want money must go out and get it for themselves.
There is one important exception, however. The reduction in capital-gains taxes for individuals and businesses that Congress agreed to recently -- widely viewed as a rest stop on the way to no capital-gains taxes at all -- is a textbook case of the Government intervening in the economy. That's not how Republican politicians have packaged it, of course. Lower the capital-gains-tax rate, runs the party line, and you take the Government out of the market, allowing it to work its magic. 
 But is this really true? If you believe in the free market you want to minimize the effect of Government policy on economic decisions. And in this respect the capital-gains-tax cut makes a bad situation worse.
 MOST AMERICANS DO NOT enjoy taxable capital gains, and so are not directly influenced by capital-gains-tax rates. But those who do enjoy them -- and they are, by and large, America's affluent -- make an important economic decision. They choose where to invest their capital. Steve Forbes, the candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination who is now leading the charge to eliminate capital-gains taxes, illustrates the nature of this decision nicely. According to disclosure forms recently filed with the Federal Election Commission, Forbes was paid $1,350,000 in 1994 as president of Forbes Inc. While that may seem like a lot, it is chump change when compared with Forbes's large, well-diversified portfolio of stocks and bonds. Some of Forbes's investments, like his holding of Missouri Pacific Railroad bonds, were clearly chosen because they paid handsome income and dividends. Others, like his shares in the Templeton Growth Fund, which makes risky plays mainly in foreign countries, were chosen because they offered the possibility of big capital gains. The important question now is: how does Steve Forbes decide to invest his next dollar? Does he pursue interest and dividends or capital gains? Does he buy a few more Missouri Pacific Railroad bonds or a few more shares in the Templeton Growth Fund?
As it now stands, Steve Forbes pays a tax rate of 39.6 percent on his returns from his Missouri Pacific Railroad bonds but only 28 percent on his returns from the Templeton Growth Fund. There already exists an 11 percent difference between the highest income-tax rate and capital-gains-tax rates. Should the capital-gains-tax cut for individuals now proposed by Congress become law, the 28 percent rate will drop to 19.8, and Forbes will hand over to the I.R.S. fully twice as much of his returns from the bonds as from the international growth fund. In effect, the United States Government will be saying to Forbes: we prefer more strongly than ever that you roll the dice on those foreign equities, and here's our inducement.
Isn't this exactly the sort of Government interference believers in the free market seek to avoid? Free-marketeers want Forbes to use his ample talents to ferret out investments that are smart on their own terms -- the sort that lead to the economic growth that enriches us all. Lowering the capital-gains tax transforms his every investment decision into a quest not for real growth but for the sharpest tax angle.
In general, the greater the disparity between the upper income-tax bracket and the capital-gains rate the more the Government directly interferes in the investment decisions of the well-to-do, and causes them to make investments that they would not make in a truly free market. Never mind questions of fairness or equity. Anyone seriously interested in minimizing the Government's effect on the economy should push not for lowering the capital-gains tax but for raising it to match the highest marginal income tax rate. The capital-gains-tax rate that least distorts investment decisions is 39 percent. On the other hand, if you believe that the Government can make magic in the market by cutting capital-gains taxes, there is no reason to stop at a zero percent capital-gains tax. We might as well go further and pay people for their capital gains. Then we could have even more of whatever benefits the tax cut brings.
 THE COST TO THE TREASURY of the new Republican industrial policy will fall somewhere between $33 billion and $51 billion over seven years, according to the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation. The benefits are vague. Obviously a capital-gains-tax cut will help the rich get richer, though that is not how it is being sold to the electorate. The tax cut is being sold as an engine for economic growth. Its proponents speak freely of the animal spirits in the American ether waiting to be unleashed: lowering capital-gains taxes will create a new incentive for all those potential entrepreneurs who previously couldn't see the point of starting their businesses. ("Just found out about the capital-gains-tax cut. Guess I'll start that microchip company after all.") There are obvious problems with this theory of human behavior. One is that it fails to explain even the behavior of the theorists. The chief effect a tax cut will have on Steve Forbes, for instance, will not be to cause him to search for his inner entrepreneur but to rearrange his portfolio and hire a few more accountants so that he can keep more of his unearned income.
The other argument on behalf of Republican industrial policy is that it is a good thing to divert capital into capital-gains-intensive ventures. The tax cut will certainly achieve this result. Once it becomes law there will be more real-estate and stock-market speculations than before. Expect rich people everywhere to sell their Missouri Pacific Railroad bonds and buy more Bolivian equities. But as anyone knows who has gazed upon the empty skyscrapers thrown up during the mid-1980's construction boom, driven by real-estate tax breaks, all investment is not socially productive investment. There is no reason to believe that the quest for capital gains will be any less wasteful than other Government-induced economic behavior. If the Government pays rich people to take stupid risks with their capital, rich people will oblige.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
Something New Under the Sweltering Sun

BYLINE: By Bernard Holland 

 BODY:
THE CLASSICAL-MUSIC business used to work pretty much like our school systems. People began in the fall, slowed down around holidays and went home at the end of the spring. The school calendar is a remnant of agrarian years, when children were turned loose not to frolic in local shopping malls but to help their parents in the fields.
Music was driven by other concerns. After a hard season of playing and listening, relief was in order. Musicians took summer jobs, taught, played out of town, did nothing. Listeners put their fingers in their ears and went to the beach. The two parties would have had trouble getting together even if they had wanted to. Concert halls weren't air-conditioned, and sweaty suffering in the name of art, while a virtue at Wagner's Bayreuth, had its limits elsewhere. 
 Concert-free summers, I'm afraid, are forgotten idylls. People were talked into finding the outdoors and music amiable companions. Hence the rural festival. Cooling systems have made concert halls into urban refuges from the heat and stench of August. Avery Fisher Hall has many problems, but its air-conditioning gives divine performances: think of a Haydn quartet reconstituted in British thermal units.
Economics have largely caused musical June to bleed into musical July and then into musical August. Players in major orchestras are paid year-round and need something to do. Managements need concert income. Dark theaters cost money. Beverly Sills, the chairwoman of Lincoln Center, reminds us that an inactive New York State Theater in summer can greet the New York City Opera and Ballet companies with a million-dollar deficit before their new seasons have started.
Lincoln Center has approached the summer music business as an applier of balm. Soothe the weary; placate the put-upon; do it quietly -- this has been its mandate. Home on the range may be stingy with discouraging words, but it has nothing on the Mostly Mozart Festival, a venture aware that listeners fresh from the July broil of the subway will brook no further agitation.
The feel-good esthetic has infiltrated the Center's contemporary culture as well. Take Serious Fun. What a repugnant name, a Uriah Heep among festival titles. Serious Fun sheathes music's cutting edge in euphemism. It tells us that what we are going to hear is substantial but that we shouldn't worry about its getting under our skin. Serious Fun is an eloquent microcosm of summers at Lincoln Center, or it has been until now.
Something new is about to happen: Lincoln Center Festival 96, an urban bouillabaisse of the performing arts, a connoisseur's potluck designed to wake the summer palate. Cunningly devised by my former Times colleague John Rockwell and planned to run between July 22 and Aug. 11, this mix of sweet and sour, whole grain and puree, dares New York to wake up and think at a time of year in which it may not want to.
Samuel Beckett's 19 plays done by Dublin's Gate Theater are hardly a lie-down on some Amagansett beach. Morton Feldman is not a Sousa march on the Fourth of July. Japanese gagaku parts radically from barn-theater revivals of "Carousel" upstate. Virgil Thomson's "Four Saints in Three Acts" is not "La Traviata" in the park.
All is not lost for the timid listener. Offered, too, are events calculated to reassure the forces of reaction while surreptitiously teaching them things they don't already know. How many Mostly Mozart-goers have heard the sound of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony and "Missa Solemnis" on period instruments? John Eliot Gardiner, his Orchestre Revolutionnaire et Romantique and the Monteverdi Choir will demonstrate. How many Beethoven lovers know just how obsesssive a composer their hero was? Mr. Gardiner's forces and Kurt Masur's New York Philharmonic will tell them: the first with the nascent opera "Leonore" in concert, the second with the opera "Leonore" finally became: "Fidelio."
 THE ARGUMENT FOR THIS festival, the one that lurks beneath the practicalities, takes the form of a hope: that New York and its visitors are ready for heavy-duty stimulation during the dog days of a New York summer. Yes, Edinburgh does very nicely at such things, but Edinburgh is never 90 degrees in the shade.
Mr. Rockwell and his team have done their job well. The balances are good: common-denominator programming, spice added, to go with an amalgam of freshness, color and abrasiveness. What better metaphors than these for life in this wonderful if exasperating city.
So the courtship has begun. The suitor's pitch sounds persuasive, but the suit is at a disadvantage, not knowing precisely where the object of its affections is. Who is going to come to these events now that they have been gathered with such laborious care and industry? I wonder if Lincoln Center knows much more than I do. It is a grand experiment in any case, and I want to know what the equation will yield.
Deep in my heart, I wish that the whole thing would go away, that music would lock up for the summer and find its own beach to lie on. The information explosion is just that, an explosion. Explosions hurt things, culture included. But the Lincoln Center Festival 96 is upon us, whether I like it or not; and if it has to be, let's be grateful that so much of its thoughtfulness and adventure has survived the weight of bureaucratic pressure. Nonprofit organizations thrive on caution. and this festival takes a few chances. I wish it well.

HEADLINE: ISLAND REPORT;
LOOKING PAST THE STORMS

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS; FRANCES FRANK MARCUS contributes to The Times from New Orleans.

 BODY:
IN September, after Hurricane Luis howled through the island of Dominica, bashing crops, knocking down trees and pushing the Caribbean into a casual seaside inn, the innkeepers went to work cleaning up and repainting.
The 11-room Castle Comfort Lodge -- homey and comfortable but no castle -- came through shiningly. Water had flowed into the lower level but the rooms were soon livable again, the facade fresh white and the porch overlooking the sea as pleasant as ever. 
 But the telephone kept ringing with questions from anxious reservation holders. The owner's wife, Ginette Perryman, could only shake her head.
"People were worried," she said, "about hurricanes in February." The hurricane season ends on Thursday.
The Caribbean is reaping a whirlwind of worries in the wake of September's hurricanes and lesser storms. Though most of the damaged islands are ready for visitors, two weeks before the winter season begins, the storms' effects continue. According to the American Society of Travel Agents, 48 percent of 425 travel agents surveyed in a poll in late October said reports of damage had caused a drop in Caribbean travel.
"It's the worst season we've experienced since the 1930's in terms of the number of storms," said Michael Youngman, the Caribbean Tourism Organization's sales director. "It was an incredibly bad season."
Even islands that escaped major storm damage are having problems, largely because of air-service curtailment. "Nature took good care of us," said Mike Myers, the owner of Saba Deep Dive Center, alluding to the minor damage to his island. "The irony now is, we've been economically devastated because the airport on St. Maarten has been closed to tourism." Saba's air service is dependent upon St. Maarten's international airport, which reopened to tourists on Nov. 1.
With air service to the region still curtailed and wholesalers still somewhat leery of the hardest-hit islands, travelers to the Caribbean will have to work harder to get there.
Some travelers are turning to Caribbean Connection Plus, of Trumbull, Conn., (203) 261-8603, which develops and sells packages to island-hoppers and is urging clients to route trips through San Juan, where connections can be made with inter-island airlines, whose prices are more competitive.
The company president, Carol Banner, is promoting a new package, "In Search of Volcanoes," to add to its other packages like "In Search of Sharks." The volcano package features islands with extinct, dormant and live volcanoes and little or no hurricane damage: St. Eustatius, Martinique, Grenada and either Montserrat or Dominica, depending on seismic events. Montserrat's volcano is bellowing steam, ash and, on occasion, rocks. Scientists advise not to sightsee near the volcano, though the island is open to tourism.
According to travel wholesalers, winter bookings indicate that the beneficiaries of September's disasters include Aruba, which is outside the hurricane zone; Barbados, which was virtually untouched; and Jamaica, St. Lucia and the Bahamas, which were not hit. All are ready with new attractions. Aruba recently opened Tierra del Sol, an 18-hole Robert Trent Jones golf course, the island's first. Aruba also has a new 413-room Marriott Resort and Casino.
Barbados has a new 18-hole Robert Trent Jones golf course at the Royal Westmoreland resort in St. James. Jamaica and the Bahamas have new Superclubs all-inclusive resorts: the 400-room Breezes Bahamas and the 124-room Breezes Montego Bay. In January a Superclubs competitor, Sandals, will open the 196-room Sandals Royal Bahamian on Nassau.
St. Lucia now has nonstop air service from Kennedy International Airport on the recently privatized BWIA International Airways. St. Lucia's popularity was growing even before the storms, with 47,997 American tourists traveling there from January to June, a 13.7 percent increase over the same period last year. BWIA has also started twice-a-week service to Tobago from New York and Miami, and in December and January will fly nonstop once a week from Miami to St. Kitts.
And there is a fresh gambling attraction in the Bahamas. Marriott's Crystal Palace resort on Nassau has installed a sports betting bar called Sports Book. Next door is Phil's Sports Bar and Deli, where gamblers can watch the action on 10 32-inch television screens and snack on kosher pickles -- perfect for sports lovers who loathe the sun.
Following is an island-by-island report:
 
Anguilla
Anguilla Tourist Information Office, 775 Park Avenue, Huntington, N.Y. 11743; (800) 553-4939 and (516) 271-2600
Hurricane Luis pounded Anguilla with winds gusting to 200 miles an hour, but the small island stood fast, thanks to rigorous construction codes introduced after a 1960 hurricane. Hurricane Marilyn's rain, Anguillans say, merely freshened the foliage.
One of the northernmost islands in the Lesser Antilles, some 16 miles long and no more than three and a half miles wide, Anguilla has some of the Caribbean's glossiest hotels and 35 fine beaches.
Popular spots like Johnno's beach bar at Sandy Ground set up generators and were open for business within days after Luis, and Anguillans all over the island have been working to prepare for winter.
Cap Juluca, (800) 323-0139 and (809) 497-6779, fax (809) 497-6617, its 98 rooms in 18 striking, stark white beachside villas on Maundays Bay, has two absurdly romantic seaside restaurants: Chattertons and Pimms. Main dishes at Pimms, reopening early January, include shellfish lasagna ($20), grilled crayfish ($35) and rack of lamb with black olives and rosemary sauce ($33).
Cap Juluca expects to reopen Dec. 15 after renovations and repairs to cosmetic damage and beach erosion caused by Luis. A 790-square-foot luxury double room will be $595, a three-bedroom villa with private pool $2,775 a day, not including the 18 percent tax. All rates include Continental breakfast.
The elegant 53-room Malliouhana Hotel, (800) 835-0796 or (809) 497-6111, fax (809) 497-6011, overlooks the milelong Meads Bay. The hotel's spectacular beach, which was eroded by the storm, is slowly rebuilding itself. Malliouhana's landscaping suffered greatly, but the gardens are being recreated. Double rates are $480 in a garden room. An oceanside double is $575. The hotel reopened Nov. 17.
At La Sirena Hotel and Villas, (800) 331-9358 or (809) 497-6827, on Meads Bay, two-bedroom deluxe villas for four are $410 a day in winter; a standard two-bedroom villa is $295. Doubles in the 20-bedroom hotel start at $230 for two people, plus 18 percent tax. This congenial hotel, on an excellent beach, is a very good value.
Across the island at Shoal Bay East, Uncle Ernie's beach restaurant, (809) 497-3907, has rebuilt and is serving rum punches and grilled fish, chicken and ribs (ribs or chicken with coleslaw and French fries and a beer are less than $10; fresh fish with a drink is $12).
Shoal Bay beach, near the top of any listing of the Caribbean's best, is wider than ever after the storm.
 
Antigua
Antigua Department of Tourism, Suite 311, 610 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 541-4117
By late September, the island's hurricane-whipped hillsides were greening. Most major hotels expect to be repaired and open for the winter season if they are not open already.
Antigua, scalloped with harbors and coves, made its mark as a sailor's heaven. In the 18th century Britain's West Indian fleet caught its breath here.
English Harbour, which sheltered the ships in the hurricane season, is a deep notch on Antigua's southeast coast, the home of Nelson's Dockyard, named for the fleet's premier sailor, Admiral Lord Horatio Nelson. The harbor's old wood and brick dockyard buildings survived the hurricanes with hardly a scratch.
Today scores of sailing ships gather in Antigua each spring for an intense week of racing and partying. The Antigua Race Week, April 28 to May 4 next year, brings together serious and not-so-serious sailors and attracts more than 200 racing yachts. Hotels, rental cars, airlines -- all are booked far ahead for that time.
For sailors without boats, Nicholson Yacht Charters, which has offices in the United States, (800) 662-6066, fax (617) 661-0554, is located in English Harbor and is the agent for a fleet of 80 to 100 yachts. Every boat survived the hurricanes. The vessels range from trim, wooden yachts with teak decks and clipper bows to roomier, more modern boats.
Chartering the 41-foot sloop Lost Horizon with a British captain and a mate-chef costs $3,850 for two people and $4,830 for four, with meals but not drinks. The charter costs cover seven 24-hour periods.
Attractive lodgings are available near the sailing action. Within the dockyard, now part of a national park, are two popular inns. The 14-room Admiral's Inn, (800) 223-5695 and (809) 460-1027, fax (809) 460-1534, with its old brick, hand-hewn beams and wrought-iron chandeliers, weathered the storms. The dining room is in a romantic setting at the water's edge. Rates for a double range from $108 to $132, plus 7 percent tax and 10 percent service. (The island's hotel tax might rise to 8.5 percent in late December).
The Copper and Lumber Store Hotel, (800) 275-0877 or (809) 460-1058, fax (809) 460-1529, in a 1783 building, has 14 suites or studios, each named after one of Lord Nelson's ships. Some are furnished with antiques; each has a kitchen and living room. Winter rates start at $195, plus 7 percent tax and 10 percent service charge.
On 10 acres of the national park, the Inn at English Harbor, (809) 460-1014, fax (809) 460-1603, offers 28 elegant rooms on the beachfront and on a hillside with a panoramic view of the dockyard. Some beachfront rooms were damaged by the hurricanes but have been redone. On the Terrace Restaurant and Bar, there is candlelight dining; breakfast, lunch and afternoon tea are served at the Beach Bar and Restaurants at water's edge. Double rates from Dec. 20 to mid-March start at $270, plus 10 percent service and 7 percent tax. Current rates range from $120 to $190 for two people, double occupancy.
The Falmouth Harbor Beach Apartments, (800) 223-5695, fax (809) 460-1534, which were undamaged, are close to English Harbor on a small private beach with Pigeon Point Beach nearby.
The 23 studio apartments have kitchenettes, ceiling fans and private patios or balconies. Supermarkets, restaurants and bars are within walking distance. The studios start at $120 a day, plus tax and service; room rates include the use of some water-sports equipment.
 
 Aruba
Aruba Tourism Authority, 1000 Harbor Boulevard, Weehawken, N.J. 07087; (201) 330-0800 and (800) 862-7822
Like its neighbors, Bonaire and Curacao, Aruba lies outside the hurricane belt that envelops most of the Caribbean.
Miles of powdery white-sand beaches edge the island, past a sprawl of hotels and casinos -- the casinos, along with its beaches, are Aruba's main attraction. The 11 casinos range from a small, casual gambling house to glittering palaces in the luxury hotels. And its beaches are among the best in the Caribbean. In the clear aquamarine sea windsurfers race ahead of brisk prevailing winds.
In recent years Aruba's tourism has burgeoned, thanks in part to gambling -- blackjack, roulette, craps, baccarat, mini-baccarat, slot machines and Caribbean stud poker, reputedly invented in an Aruban casino. Government surveys show that casinos lure about half the visitors to the small, desert-like island with rocky red hills, less than 20 miles north of Venezuela.
The island's largest gambling house and the newest sit near two of the best beaches, Palm and Eagle, in a seven-mile swath along the west coast.
The new casino, which opened this summer, is the 10,700-square-foot Stellaris in the Aruba Marriott Resort in Palm Beach, some two miles from the capital of Oranjestad, (800) 223-6388, or (29 78) 69000, fax (29 78) 60649. There are 26 gambling tables and 223 slot machines.
The resort faces 600 feet of the Caribbean along Palm Beach. The 413 rooms, with private balconies, are on eight floors. There is a free-form swimming pool with waterfalls, a health club, exercise classes and volleyball. Winter rates for two range from $230 to $380 a night, plus a 11 percent service charge and a 5.5 percent room tax.
The Royal Cabana Casino, Eagle Beach, near Oranjestad, (29 78) 79000, is expanding but already has 320 slot machines and 33 gaming tables with blackjack, baccarat, roulette and craps.
The casino is a companion to La Cabana All Suite Beach Resort, (212) 251-1710 in New York State, (800) 835-7193 outside New York, fax (29 78) 75474. The resort, on Eagle Beach, has 803 suites, a fitness center with squash and racquetball, three swimming pools, five tennis courts and programs for children and teen-agers. All suites have a whirpool, kitchenette, balcony or patio. For most of the winter, double rates will start at $205 a night, not including tax.
Sports betting is done Las Vegas-style at the Grand Holiday Casino, (29 78) 67777, fax (29 78) 65555, 230 L. G. Smith Boulevard, inside the Holiday Inn Aruba on Palm Beach. Bets -- from $2 to $1,000 -- are placed on horse races seen on television and on baseball, basketball, football, golf, tennis and other sports events.
The trade winds that sweep Aruba have also swept in fleets of windsurfers. A favorite place for the boards is to the north of the island at the Fishermen's Huts area, where the water is shallow and calm.
Windsurfing and hotel packages are offered by the California-based Vela Windsurf Resorts (800) 223-5443, fax (415) 525-2086. The weekly rate for the Marriott package starts at $1,450 a person, double occupancy, including equipment, accommodations, tax and service. For beginners, the price is $1,350 and includes one free lesson and use of beginner equipment.
Windsurf Village, 462 L. G. Smith Boulevard, Malmok, about three miles northwest of Oranjestad, is a 40-unit inn across the road from a Fishermen's Huts launching area. The accommodations, in four buildings, range from basic rooms with kitchenettes to two-bedroom apartments. Private windsurfing lessons are $50 an hour. The village's seven-day winter package, booked through Sailboard Vacations, (800) 252-1070, fax (617) 829-8809, starts at $699 a person, double occupancy, with tax, windsurfing gear and Continental breakfast. The rates apply from Dec. 20 to June 16.
 
The Bahamas
Bahamas Tourism Center, 150 East 52d Street, New York, N.Y. 10022; (212) 758-2777
The 700 islands begin 52 miles east of Florida and end about 50 miles north of Haiti. In between there are casinos, golf courses, colorful diving spots, quiet villages, jet skis -- and long stretches of empty beaches.
New Providence, home of the capital, Nassau, has the brightest lights. Recently, most major hotels on the island have changed hands and are undergoing or have had face lifts.
On Paradise Island, connected to Nassau by a bridge, more than 800 slot machines blink around the clock in the casino at the new 1,147-room Atlantis Paradise Island, (800) 321-3000, fax (305) 893-2866. For children and aquatic types, a kitschy water theme is carried out through mock caves, grottos, a quarter-mile Lazy River Ride and a 3.2-million-gallon aquarium with 132 species of tropical fish.
Doubles start at $185 a night midweek, $265 weekends, plus 10 percent tax and a $10 surcharge.
The 30,000-square-foot casino has 44 blackjack tables, among other games.
Greens fees at the hotel's 18-hole golf course, with five holes seaside, are $60 for guests, $100 for non-guests.
On New Providence, the newly renovated Radisson Cable Beach Casino and Golf Resort (809) 327-6000, fax (809) 327-6987, has an 18-hole golf course and 700 rooms, some decorated in bright pinks, yellows and greens. The hotel offers an all-inclusive plan through its Splash program: the nightly rate range from $390 to $410 for two people, with meals, wine and greens fees.
The largest casino in the Bahamas -- 35,000 square feet and 750 slot machines -- belongs to the Nassau Marriott Resort and Crystal Palace Casino, which is next to the Radisson.
The country's first sports betting bar, Sports Book, is a new attraction at the hotel, (800) 222-7466 or (809) 327-6200 for reservations, fax (809) 327-6735, where a $30 million renovation is muting its screeching purples and reds to softer tropical colors. There are 743 rooms and 94 corner suites, all with balconies.
The hotel's midweek winter room rates start at $119 for a double; the rate Thursday to Saturday starts at $139. Tax is an extra 10 percent.
At the more secluded South Ocean Golf and Beach Resort, (800) 241-6615, fax (809) 362-4728, the 250 rooms have balconies or patios. Its own dive shop, a P.G.A.-rated golf course, tennis courts and a good beach on the other side of the island from busier Cable Beach are other attractions. Winter double rates start at $165, plus 8 percent tax and $2.35 a day a person for maid service.
On clear nights, Florida's lights beam to Grand Bahama, home of the city of Freeport, a golfing center and port with a Floridian air.
The 956-room Bahamas Princess Resort and Casino, Freeport, Grand Bahama Island, (800) 223-1818, fax (809) 352-4485, has domes, arches, pools, waterfalls, a 20,000-square-foot casino and two 18-hole golf courses. Winter doubles start at $120 a night, plus 8 percent tax and a nightly $7.50 service charge. Greens fees are $56 for guests and non-guests. Five-night golf packages start at $510 a person, double occupancy, with a daily round of golf, cart, tax and gratuities.
In the Abacos islands in the northern Bahamas, there are villages, long stretches of quiet beaches and convenient snorkeling.
The upscale Green Turtle Club and Marina, (800) 688-4752 or (809) 365-4271, fax (809) 365-4272, is on Green Turtle Cay, three and a half miles long and a half-mile wide. The resort has 25 rooms, three suites, seven efficiency units and seven villas. The marina can accommodate yachts up to 150 feet long. Winter double rates, effective Jan. 2 to April 14, start at $149 a room, plus a 15 percent tax and service charge. The rate from Dec. 22 to Jan. 1 is $184 a room.
High cliffs on one side and curved beaches on the other characterize breezy Long Island in the south. The Stella Maris Inn, (800) 426-0466 or (809) 338-2050, fax (954) 359-8238, offers access to scuba diving, snorkeling, bone, reef and deep-sea fishing. At Conception Island, one of the dive spots, a wall descends 6,000 feet.
The inn -- 60 units in an assortment of buildings, villas and cottages -- sprawls on a hill with views of the Atlantic and Caribbean. Winter doubles start at $130, plus $18 tax, which includes sailing, boat cruises, daily excursions, bicycles and light entertainment. A five-night all-inclusive scuba package, $2,078 for a couple, includes a flight from Nassau or Fort Lauderdale.
 
Barbados
Barbados Tourism Authority, 800 Second Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 986-6516 and (800) 221-9831
The British arrived in the early 1600's and set about turning the jungle into lucrative sugar plantations. Barbados belonged to Britain until 1966 and is still British in tone, especially in its attention to old houses and gardens.
The symbols of sugar's glory days are the island's great houses, where the plantation owners or their agents lived. Some remain today with the original design more or less intact. One of the island's important historic houses, 300-year-old Sunbury, was lost this year to fire, not to hurricane winds, which mostly bypassed Barbados.
The Barbados National Trust stars the most notable structures in its annual Open House program, a highlight of the winter season. The houses are different every year, and range from 17th-century great houses to opulent modern villas built by expatriates, most not ordinarily open to the public.
The tours will run next year from Jan. 10 to April 3, on Wednesdays from 2:30 P.M. to 5:30 P.M., with one house open each Wednesday. Reservations: (809) 426-2421, fax (809) 429-9055. Admission to each costs $6, including a drink and a tour of the gardens.
One of the island's most important historic houses, St. Nicholas Abbey, (809) 422-8725, a Jacobean house built in the mid-1600's, is open year-round. The abbey, in St. Peter Parish, has Dutch gables and a herb garden, and a displayed inventory of the old plantation's assets, including a list of slaves by name with their values. Open weekdays 10 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Entry fee: $2.50.
A short drive away is the shell of Farley Hill House, recently gutted by fire. The site is now a national park, (809) 422-3555, with a splendid view of the island's entire northeastern rim. There is no entrance fee for pedestrians, but those arriving by car are charged $3.
The National Trust recently opened Tyrol Cot Heritage Village, (809) 424-2074, Codrington Hill, St. Michael, built around an 1854 Palladian-style house, made of coral stone. Tyrol Cot was most recently the home of Sir Grantley Adams, who led Barbados' struggle for independence. His wife, Lady Adams, lived in the house until her death in 1990. The village is a museum of the folk architecture seen in small traditional Bajan dwellings, the moveable chattel houses, early wooden versions of mobile homes. Each is a copy of a traditional design, perfected in 1930. Visitors can see artists and potters at work in the village, open week-days 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Entry fee: $5.
The National Trust is also caretaker of several gardens, including the tropical Andromeda Gardens, (809) 433-9384, spread across a slope near the scenic Atlantic east coast. Verdant with hibiscus, orchids, cactuses, palms and ferns, and an indigenous tree, the Bearded Fig, the gardens overlook a fishing village, Tent Bay. Entrance fee: $5, children $2.50.
Welchman Hall Gully, (809) 426-2421, was a series of caves until the roofs fell in. On the grounds, once part of a plantation of citrus and spice trees, visitors can take a relaxing walkon shady paths. Open daily 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Entrance fee: $5, children $2.50.
The National Trust sells a package of tickets to 16 historic sites and other attractions through its Heritage Passport Program; $35 for 16 attractions or $18 for five.
The island can also be toured on free organized Sunday hikes: 6 A.M., 3 P.M. or 3:30 P.M, full moon walks, 5:30 P.M. For information, call the National Trust.
 
 Bonaire
Bonaire Government Tourist Office, 10 Rockefeller Plaza, Suite 900, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 956-5911 and (800) 826-6247
Small, quiet Bonaire, near Aruba and Curacao in the Netherlands Antilles, is among a handful of the world's best diving spots. Diving, snorkeling and windsurfing are the lures for most visitors. Bird-watching, especially flamingo watching, is a bonus.
 A few things set Bonaire apart. A well-regulated Marine Park protects its entire coastline, ringed by reefs. Divers find spectacular, pristine coral gardens, walls and sponges teeming with parrotfish, trumpetfish, reef squid and angelfish.
 Many of the best sites are accessible to snorkelers in extremely clear water. Spearfishing is banned and permanent moorings are set up for yachts. Certified divers pay a fee of $10 for a one-year Marine Park permit, which allows access to the 80 dive sites, all marked by buoys.
 Bonaire is unusual in its wealth of shore dives. One spot, Windsock, also excellent for snorkeling, lies virtually at the foot of the airport runway. Another, Alice in Wonderland with its Garden Eel colony, is just steps off the main road. The obvious attraction is practically unlimited diving at minimal cost, since boat charters aren't required.
 The Salt City dive trip can be combined with bird-watching. Flocks of flamingos wade through the briny shallows of the solar salt works' ponds, where striking pyramids of salt rise from a lunar landscape. Bonaire's flamingos number nearly 10,000 in breeding season, almost as much as the human population. Some flamingos can be seen from the road.
 flamingos and wild parrots can also be seen in Washington-Slagbaai Park on the dry, hilly northern end of the 100-square-mile island. The park is open from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily but not holidays; $3, $1 for children.
Klein Bonaire, an uninhabited cay less than a mile off Bonaire's west coast, is ringed with dive sites -- 24 in all, starting at depths of only 20 feet, including Knife, notable for snorkeling, and the lush Carl's Hill.
 Windsurfing is most popular at Lac Bay's shallow, protected waters on the southeast coast. Windsurfing and kayaking rentals are available through Windsurfing Bonaire, (800) 748-8733. Board rentals are $20 an hour, $50 a day, $225 a week, rising to $240 on Jan. 1. A two-person kayak is $35 a day.
 Most divers going to Bonaire buy packages through their hotels.
 Captain Don's Habitat, 103 Kaya Gobernador De Brop, (800) 327-6709, fax (305) 371-2337, offers diving 24 hours a day and accommodations in 72 units: suites, cottages and oceanfront villas with kitchens, living rooms and decks or patios. There is a pool and open air restaurant. Night shore diving is available from a flood-lighted pier. Two snorkeling reefs run parallel to the beach. Five-day/four-night dive packages begin at $455 a person, double occupancy, including three boat dives and unlimited shore diving.
The Sand Dollar Beach Club, (800) 288-4773, fax (407) 774-9322, 79 Gobernador North Debrot, has 84 condominiums ranging from studios to three bedrooms done in pastels, wicker and rattan. There is a dive and photo center, a pool with bar, a minuscule sand beach and baby-sitting services, and the Green Parrot Restaurant on the waterfront. A children's program includes snorkeling. A studio rents for $160 a night.
 At the tiny Sunset Inn, (800) 344-4439, fax (305) 225-0527, with a terrace overlooking the Bay of Kralendijk, there are two suites and five rooms; some have kitchenettes. Within walking distance of town, the inn is next door to a dive center. Rates start at $55 a night.
 
 Cayman Islands
Cayman Islands Department of Tourism, 420 Lexington Avenue, Suite 2733, New York, N.Y. 10170; (212) 682-5582
The three islands, Grand Cayman, Cayman Brac and Little Cayman, have magnificent underwater scenery in a pellucid sea, unroiled by this year's hurricanes.
Among the many compelling sights, at Stingray City in the North Sound, divers consort with Southern Stingrays that swim in daily to feed and play.
As recently as the early 1960's, visitors ploughed through swarms of mosquitoes and unpaved roads to reach the underwater views. Divers today have no need to rough it. More than 40 dive operators cater to every skill level.
Accommodations range from plush hotels to simple guesthouses.
The new 340-room Westin Casuarina Resort, (800) 228-3000, fax (809) 949-5825, on Grand Cayman's Seven Mile Beach has a dive shop, gardens, fountains and waterfalls. Guest rooms have French doors and balconies overlooking the sea. Winter double room rates vary from month to month; February starts at $275, plus 20 percent tax and service.
The 236-room Hyatt Regency (800) 233-1234, fax (809) 949-8528, on West Bay Road in Grand Cayman has a dive shop, water sports and one of the island's two golf courses. The resort is a short walk from Seven Mile Beach. Double room rates start at $300. Dive packages are offered in conjunction with Red Sail Sports, a fully equipped water-sports operator, (800) 255-6425 or (809) 949-8745, fax (809) 947-5808. A three-night package for certified divers is $579, the Scuba School three-night package is $679.
For the real dive nut, Sunset House, (800) 854-4767, fax (809) 949-7101, lies on Grand Cayman's shore, near a reef, a mile south of Georgetown, the capital. A casual seaside spot, it has 59 rooms, some with sea views. Three-night double occupancy dive packages start at $362.50 a person, plus $40.50 tax and service. Room-only rates start at $125 a night, plus 20 percent tax and service.
Guesthouses offer basic but comfortable rooms. Adam's Guest House, (809) 949-2512, fax (809) 949-0919, on Melmac Avenue less than a mile south of Georgetown, has three air-conditioned bedrooms and a two-bedroom apartment at the back. Double room rates are $61, plus 10 percent tax.
On Little Cayman, dirt roads meander through the mangroves. The island is home to iguanas, the 202-acre Booby Pond Nature Reserve, thousands of red-footed boobies and 100 pairs of magnificent frigate birds.
Offshore, Bloody Bay Wall starts in 20 feet of water and drops deep into the oceanic blue of the Cayman trench. Snorkeling is possible over the dropoff. Divers can venture through tunnels and rifts, starting in the shallows, and move down and out to spectacular stretches of wall diving.
At the casual Little Cayman Beach Resort, (800) 327-3835 or (809) 948-1033, fax (809) 948-1040, at Blossom Village, there are 32 rooms, a dive shop and photo center. Rooms have air-conditioning, ceiling fans, satellite television but no phones. Molly the Manta is a frequent visitor during night dives. A five-night all-inclusive double occupancy dive package covers four days of diving, meals, drinks and three boat dives a day: $1,159.
On Cayman Brac, a bluff stretches the length of the island. There is a 180-acre parrot reserve and below the waves, sheer walls and plentiful marine life. The Divi Tiara Beach Resort, (800) 367-3484, fax (809) 948-7316, has 59 rooms, a pool and a Peter Hughes Dive and Photo Center. The all-inclusive four-night dive packages for a couple, including three days of diving, meals, drinks, taxes and transfers, start at $1,084.
 
 Curacao
Curacao Tourist Board, 475 Park Avenue, Suite 2000, New York, N.Y. 10016; (212) 683-7660 or (800) 270-3350
At first glance, Curacao -- which lies outside the hurricane zone -- appears to have been misplaced. So much pastel Dutch colonial architecture should not exist on a dry island 40 miles north of Venezuela.
Curacao's architecture is unique in the Caribbean. From the narrow streets of Willemstad, the capital city, to the cactus-studded countryside, the former mansions and plantation houses of Dutch colonists evoke the past.
In offshore waters, snorkelers and divers find action along a coral reef.
The seat of government for the Netherlands Antilles, the island is part worldly-Europe, part small-town Caribbean.
Willemstad is split by the narrow Santa Anna Bay and has long had a split personality as well. Upscale Punda, "the point," was once the city's commercial center and home to the island's Dutch Protestant elite. The island's significant Jewish population built their elegant neo-classical homes in neighboring Sharloo, now an up-and-coming business district.
The two sides are joined by a floating bridge. After several decades of neglect, Otrobanda has been making a comeback. Old waterfront buildings have been turned into small shops and restaurants.
In Punda, the pastel merchants' buildings, gracefully gabled, have always housed shops on their ground floors. Today they sell everything from expensive jewelry and linens to budget clothing and electronics, tax-free. Along the waterfront, Venezuelan merchants sell fresh fish and vegetables at the floating market.
Among the architectural treasures, the graceful Mikve Israel-Emanuel synagogue, 29 Hanchi Snoa, (5999) 611067, in Punda, dedicated in 1732, is said to be the oldest continuously operating synagogue in the western world. It's home to the Jewish Historical Museum and both are open weekdays, 9 A.M. to 11:45 A.M., 2:30 P.M. to 4:45 P.M. Museum entry fee: $2. Services start at 6:30 P.M. Fridays and 10 A.M. Saturdays.
Old City Tours, (5999) 613554, offers walking tours of Otrobanda and Scharloo conducted by a knowledgeable architect. Tickets are $5, including a drink.
The Curacao Tourism Development Bureau, (5999) 616000, in a renovated old mansion at 19 Pietermaai, (5999) 616000, offers information and maps for self-guided tours. Open weekdays 8 A.M. to 5 P.M.
Outside Willemstad, more than a dozen former plantation houses (landhuis) have been restored and given new life as guesthouses, restaurants and government offices.
Northeast of town, Landhuis Brievengat, (5999) 378344, a popular night spot, is a place to linger over early evening drinks and, on Wednesday, Friday and Sunday, dance until late. You can sample the local Amstel beer, $2.25, brewed from distilled seawater, or a cocktail made from Curacao liqueur, flavored with orange peel, $3. A museum exhibits antiques and household artifacts; open 9:15 A.M. to 12:15 P.M. and 3 P.M. to 6 P.M. Monday to Saturday, entry $1.
In the western countryside, near popular beaches, Landhuis Kenepa, (5999) 640244, also known as Knip, is a promotion center for Afro-Curacaoan culture. The house was built in 1700 and a century later was the scene of an important slave uprising. Open 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. weekdays and Sundays. Entry fee: $2.
Off the protected southern beaches, there is good snorkeling along the rocky ledges that define the coves. Among the better spots are Kas Abao, the calm waters of sheltered Lagun, rustic Port St. Marie and Vaersenbaai.
Curacao's dive reputation is growing. The eastern third of the sheltered southern coast lies in a protected Underwater Park, which offers a variety of dive levels.
Peter Hughes Diving, (800) 932-6237, fax (305) 669-9475, based at the Princess Beach Hotel, 8 Martin Luther King Boulevard, has daily boat dives. A two-tank dive is $55, including tanks, weights and belts; unlimited shore diving is $33 for three days, two night dives a week are $35 each.
 
 Dominica
 Consulate of the Commonweath of Dominica, 820 Second Avenue, Suite 900, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 599-8478
 Rising from a sapphire sea, rugged green mountains define the landscape of Dominica, an island carpeted by virgin rain forest and crisscrossed by mountain streams with waterfalls. Such scenic splendors have attracted increasing numbers of hikers, divers and bird-watchers in recent years.
 The 290-square-mile island lies between Guadeloupe and Martinique; its 71,000 residents live mostly in the capital city of Roseau on the west coast. Hurricane damage was mainly to crops. Much of the mountainous interior is reachable only on foot and most hikes require a guide. The hike to the spectacular 150-foot Trafalgar Falls, in the south central part of the island, begins with an effortless 10-minute walk from the road, which becomes more difficult as the path disintegrates into a trail of man-size boulders, swirling streams and moss-covered rocks. A recent rock slide has blocked part of the waterfall from hikers.
 A trip to the Syndicate Nature Trail offers an unusual walk through virgin rain forest, where visitors often spot the endangered Jaco and Sisserou parrots.
 Volcanic action created Dominica, and beneath the surface the island still bubbles and gurgles in fumaroles and steaming springs. Boiling Lake, one of the world's largest, is a 200-foot-wide cauldron of milky liquid simmering in a volcanic crater in the southern section of the island. The hike to the lake is an eight-hour bone-crunching trek nearly straight up and over ridges that drop 200 feet on both sides, then into the Valley of Desolation, a landscape of bubbling mud and sulfurous vapor, and finally, up to the edge of the lake.
 Guided trips to Trafalgar Falls, Boiling Lake and the Syndicate Nature Trail are offered by Ken's Hinterland Adventure Tours, (809) 448-4850, fax (809) 448-8486. The price for a trip to the Syndicate Nature Trail and Trafalgar Falls is $100 for one to four people. The trip to the falls usually includes a stop at Titou Gorge, a rushing river nearly enclosed by stone walls overhead. The hike to Boiling Lake costs $120 for one to four people.
 Most scuba diving is done off Scotts Head on the southern coast. The tops of the reefs, where the coral was weakest, were damaged by Hurricane Luis, according to Billy Lawrence, an instructor for Dive Dominica, but deeper down the coral is intact. Dive Dominica, affiliated with Castle Comfort Lodge, (809) 448-2188, fax (809)448-6088, just south of Roseau, runs two-tank boat dives for $70, usually leaving at 9 A.M. and returning about 1 P.M. Night dives are $45.
 The Castle Comfort, next to the dive shop, is a friendly 11-room lodge with island-style cooking. Hurricane winds and water pounded the inn and blew the leaves off trees but did no structural damage. Rooms have been repainted and are back in order. A seven-night hotel-and-dive package, including 10 dives, breakfast and dinner, airport transfers and taxes, costs $799 a person, double occupancy.
 A new attraction for nature lovers is expected to open sometime next month at the base of Morne Anglais, a mountain southeast of Roseau. The family-run Exotica Resort (809) 448-7895, fax (809) 448-3855, has eight cottages built of hardwood trees that grow on the island. River bathing is nearby, along with rain forest hiking trails. An elfin woodland grows at the top of Morne Anglais, 3,683 feet up. Double rates will start at $172, including tax and service. Children under 12 will not be charged. For a week's stay there will be a 10 percent discount, two weeks 15 percent. The resort plans to operate a shuttle into Roseau, about a 10-minute drive away.
 
Dominican Republic
 Dominican Republic Tourist Office, 1501 Broadway, Suite 410, New York, N.Y. 10036; (212) 575-4966 and (800) 752-1151
 Entire villages could fit with ease into some of the Dominican Republic's immense resorts, which sprawl over nearly 1,000 miles of coastline and 250 miles of beaches. On the north coast, smaller hotels emphasize two of the country's favorite pastimes: whale-watching and windsurfing.
 The Dominican Republic covers two-thirds of the island of Hispaniola; unlike Haiti, which occupies the rest, the country is politically stable. Santo Domingo, the capital, has 11 casino hotels, but the behemoth resorts lie outside the city. Near the town of La Romana east of the capital, guests at Casa de Campo, (800) 877-3643, fax (305) 858-4577, can golf on two 18-hole courses, swim in 14 pools, swing racquets on 13 clay courts, play polo on four fields, lie on a beach half a mile long and a quarter of a mile wide, or visit a mock 16th-century Mediterranean village on a nearby hill, where artists work. Casa de Campo sits on 7,000 acres with nine restaurants and seven bars and open air lounges
 The resort has 300 "casitas," rooms with airy decor and private balconies, and a group of two- to four-bedroom villas with living rooms, kitchens and terraces or family rooms. Casita double-room non-inclusive rates start at $180 a night, plus 23 percent tax and service charge. The all-inclusive casita-and-golf packages are $252 a person, double occupancy.
 In the country's easternmost region, the Punta Cana section has 27 miles of splendid wide white beaches and an offshore reef. The Bavaro Beach Resort, (800) 858-0606, fax (809) 686-5859, is virtually a small city. It includes an 18-hole golf course, a three-mile beach, and almost 2,000 rooms in five hotels. The Bavaro Golf hotel, suitable for families, offers visitors two- and three-bedroom apartments equipped with small refrigerators for $100 a person a night.
 The Bavaro Palace hotel has a casino and 595 deluxe rooms, most with ocean views. The decor is Caribbean bright with wicker and rattan. The Palace's all-inclusive daily double rate: $236 a person. Double rates at the other hotels -- Bavaro Beach, Bavaro Casino and Bavaro Garden -- start at $145, including breakfast and dinner, tax and service. The all-inclusive price is an extra $25 a person a day, covering all meals, drinks, entertainment, non-motorized water sports and golf.
 Although the 350-room Punta Cana Beach Resort, (800) 972-2139, fax (809) 541-2286, is smaller than the Bavaro, it has its own international airport, five restaurants and three bars. It lies on 105 acres near the large National Park of the East, which has remote beaches and caves. Working with the Parks Department, archeologists and environmentalists, the resort recently created a 150-acre nature path around 11 springs.
 The rooms, some in two- and three-bedroom villas, are decorated in soft pastels with wicker and rattan furniture. Double rates start at $144, including breakfast and dinner, tax and service, windsurfing, snorkeling and kayaking.
 On the north coast, in a scenic bay, Cabarete attracts windsurfers from Europe and elsewhere but it has kept its out-of-the-way tone. The morning breezes are gentle and good for novices; experts prefer the afternoon winds, which often build up to 25 knots. The prime windsurf season is May to mid-September. In winter, the wind is less consistent and the waves bigger.
 Cabarete has an assortment of small hotels, condos and guesthouses. The California-based Vela Highwind Centers, (800) 223-5443, fax (415) 525-2086, offers windsurf packages starting at $375 a person a week, double occupancy, including tax.
 The Bay of Samana on the country's northeast corner attracts whale-watchers between January and March, when more than 1,000 humpback whales swim to the bay for breeding. The secluded Hotel Gran Bahia, (809) 538-3111, fax (809) 538-2764, is on a cliff with dramatic views over the bay. Its main building was once a Victorian mansion. The hotel has 108 rooms, 8 suites and 8 villas. Rooms are decked out in wicker with balconies or terraces. Graceful stairs lead to adjacent beaches. Double all-inclusive rates start at $100 a person.
 
Grenada
 Grenada Board of Tourism, 820 Second Avenue, Suite 900 D, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 687-9554
Grenada rises from a coastline of curves and deep notches to green volcanic mountains. The island is known for its white sand beaches and its capital, St. George's, home of the Caribbean's favorite spice market. Sailors are partial to the island because of its good mooring spots and its proximity to the Grenadine islands, stretching north to St. Vincent, which make ideal destinations.
 Sitting on a promontory above three extinct volcanic craters, St. George's is one of the region's prettiest harbor cities, a mix of French colonial with red fish-scale tile roofs and graceful English Georgian.
 Steep hills offer views over the city to the almost landlocked harbor. The best way to see St. George's is on a leisurely two-hour stroll starting at the Carenage, a pedestrian walk around the horseshoe-shaped harbor. The early-18th-century Fort St. George, guarding the harbor's mouth, is now a police station.
 The Market Square, near the harbor, is a social hub and home to the spice market, open Monday through Saturday. Nutmeg, mace, cinnamon, cloves, ginger and tumeric scent the air in covered sheds, where vendors offer spice jars starting at about $2. There is also a profusion of fresh produce, bananas, oranges, lemons, limes, mangoes, sorrel, eddoes, cassavas and coconuts.
 Grenada's best beaches are in the southwest, on the leeward side, where the sea is calm. Grande Anse stretches two miles. Scuba World, (809) 444-4371, fax (809) 444-4800, based at the Grenada Renaissance Resort, rents equipment for water sports, including windsurfing boards or Sunfishes for $16 an hour.
 On a hillside overlooking Grand Anse at its south end, the Flamboyant Hotel, (800) 742-4276 or (809) 444-4247, fax (809) 444-1234, has one-bedroom suites and two-bedroom cottages in addition to hotel rooms; each of the 39 units has a veranda. The hotel has a beachside cabana, bar and restaurant. Winter double rate in a one-bedroom suite: $135.
 Sailing is the focus at the Secret Harbour Resort, (800) 437-7880, fax (813) 530-9747, overlooking Hartman Bay on Grenada's south coast. The 20 air-conditioned suites have verandas, Italian-tiled bathrooms and refrigerators. The beach is small, but the winter rate for a double -- $225, plus 18 percent -- includes the use of Sunfish and windsurfing equipment.
 The hotel is owned by the Moorings, (800) 535-7289, fax (813) 530-9747, a large charter company with a full-service marina on the bay and a fleet of sailboats available with or without crew. Its "Yachting Get-a-Way" package includes three nights on a 50-foot crewed yacht and four nights at the resort. The double rate is $1,595 a person, including all meals on the yacht, breakfast and dinner on the days spent at the resort, a scuba lesson, an island tour, the use of water sports equipment and taxes. Tips for the crew are extra.
 
Guadeloupe
 French West Indies Tourist Board, 444 Madison Avenue, 16th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10022; (900) 990-0040 (50 cents a minute)
 On Guadeloupe, storm winds and water uprooted trees and set off mudslides but did no significant damage to hotels and restaurants or to the offshore islands, Les Saintes and Marie-Galante. So it is still possible to sample what is said to be the Caribbean's best cooking, a combination of French and zesty Creole stroked with flavors from East India.
 Guadeloupe is a department of France, and on the two islands that form it -- the mountainous Basse-Terre and Grande-Terre, with its rolling hills and white sand beaches -- the food is rich and tropical and the wines are French.
 Food specialties include boudin Creole (spicy blood sausage); pate en pot (a thick, Creole soup); accras (crispy, herb-seasoned codfish fritters flavored with the tiny titris fish); colombo (a piquant chicken curry); stuffed land crabs with garlic and spices; a hearty red bean and rice casserole; and fresh mango, papaya, bananas, and guava. The restaurants' wine selections may not rank at the top of Parker's list, but the choices work with the food. Ask the restaurant staff to help you choose. You can't go wrong with moderately priced Beaujolais or Maconnais table wines.
 In Pointe-a-Pitre, Guadeloupe's business center, the atmosphere is welcoming at Cote Jardin, (590) 90.91.28, fax (590) 90.79.57, a restaurant at the Marina, furnished with wicker and tropical plants. The dishes include foie gras, salmon marinated in lime juice, lobster tails, sweetbreads, assorted Caribbean fish, beef filet with truffles, and a large selection of dessert pastries made with fresh fruit. Dinners for two with wine range from $75 to $115 and up. Open noon to 2:30 P.M.; 7 P.M. to midnight.
 Le Chateau de Feuilles, a house with a patio overlooking a pool at Anse Bertrand, Campeche, (590) 22.30.30, fax (590) 22.30.46, has a tranquil air and dishes that include hot sea urchin pates, passion fruit and mango desserts. A meal for two costs $68 to $105. Open noon to 3 P.M and evenings by reservation for a minimum of 10 people. Closed Mondays.
 At Les Oiseaux, (590) 88.56.92, fax (590) 83.74.08, at Anse des Rochers, in the countryside outside St. Francois, the specialties are clams Provencale, chicken with lobster and crepes. Diners are welcome to enjoy the pool. $32 to $82 for two. Open Sunday noon to 3 P.M., other days 7:30 P.M. to 11:30 P.M.
 La Sucrerie du Comte, Comte de Loheac, 97115 in Ste. Rose, (590) 28.60.17, fax (590) 28.65.63, is on the site of a former sugar-rum factory, with a lush garden. Specialties include local fish with coconut milk, fish stew, fresh fruit crepes. $50 to $70 for two. Open from 12:30 to 2:30 P.M., 7:30 P.M. to 9:30 P.M.
 In a tropical garden with a view of the sea, Le Rocher de Malendure, in Pigeon Malendure, Bouillante, (590) 98.70.84, fax (590) 98.89.92, serves smoked swordfish, fresh lobster, local shrimp, conch, coconut flan, orange-flavored banana flambee. $29 to $80 for two. Open 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., 6 to 11 P.M. Closed Sunday evening.
 La Fregate, (590) 90.80.03, fax 85.87.18, a popular brasserie and ice cream parlor, is opposite the Pointe-a-Pitre Marina, a meeting place for the boating crowd. Snacks and full breakfasts are served in a relaxed atmosphere. The menu offers stuffed conch tartare, mussels and French fries, ice cream. $25 to $80 for two. Open daily from 5:30 A.M. to midnight.
 Considering the island specialties, it's fortunate that visitors can work up an appetite hiking in Guadeloupe's magnificent National Park, a tropical forest in the heart of Basse-Terre where trails lead through lush foliage to high peaks overlooking extraordinary vistas and cascading falls. More than 300 species of tree can be seen. While making the 40-minute drive from Pointe-a-Pitre, on Grande-Terre, to Basse-Terre along the modern Transcoastal Highway, Route D23 (La Traversee), stop at the Cascade aux Excrevisses, a waterfall with an inviting cool pond at its base. The National Park has no gates and no entrance fee. Call (900) 990-0040 for free maps and brochures in English.
 
Jamaica
 Jamaica Tourist Board, 801 Second Avenue, 20th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 856-9727
In Jamaica, scenery seems to have run amok. Hundreds of miles of coastline alternate between beach, wetland and limestone cliffs. In the Blue Mountain/ John Crow Mountain National Park, Blue Mountain Peak soars to 7,402 feet.
 The central mountain range is the source of hundreds of rivers, streams and waterfalls. Custom-designed hiking, canoeing, birding or botany tours can be arranged with Sense Adventures, telephone and fax (809) 927-2097. The cost of a tour is from $50 to $100 a person a day.
 Day outings from Ocho Rios include a trip to Port Antonio's Blue Lagoon and rafting on the Rio Grande with Tropical Tours, (809) 952-0400. The air-conditioned bus travels along the scenic north coast to Portland's Blue Lagoon for snorkeling, boat rides and lunch, then into the Rio Grande Valley and a two-and-a-half-hour rafting trip to St. Margaret's Bay. Fruit and drinks are served on the bus. The all-inclusive cost is $70 a person.
 The terrain creates many variations of micro-climate and flora, a diversity echoed in the culture and accommodations -- from small eco-lodges to opulent hotels, including the growing all-inclusive resorts. Almost half the hotel rooms are in all-inclusives or hotels that offer inclusive deals. Even budget-priced resorts have now upgraded the basic room-meals-drinks-tips package to include water sports, gyms and saunas, among other extras. Two international chains, Superclubs and Sandals, offer a glut of sports and frills for one all-inclusive price.
 Superclubs' premium hotel, for couples and singles older than 15, is the Grand Lido, (800) 859-78737 or (809) 957-4013, fax (809) 957-4317. It has 200 one-bedroom suites with sunken sitting rooms and private patios or balconies and is on a two-mile white sand beach and 22 acres of grounds in Negril, an area noted for its live reggae shows in the open air. Double occupancy rates: $1,295 a person for three nights in a one-bedroom suite. Offshore in Bloody Bay, the resort's 147-foot yacht offers evening cruises. Frills include weddings, marriage licenses, champagne and wedding cake.
 Superclubs' family resort is the 207-room Boscobel Beach, (800) 859-7877 or (809) 975-7331-8, fax (809) 975-7370, near Ocho Rios, with nannies, bicycles, a computer lab, tennis lessons and a petting zoo. The food includes Continental cuisine, barbecue and hot dogs. For two parents and two children under 14 in the same room, the rate starts at $3,150 a week. The price for an extra child under 14 is $50 a night.
 The six Sandals resorts on the north coast, (800) 726-3257, fax (305) 667-8996, are for couples only, and guests at one can eat, drink and play at the others at no extra cost. The flagship Sandals Montego Bay, with 26 acres and 244 rooms and suites, lies on a large private beach. There are four restaurants and tropical gardens. The double-occupancy weekly rate starts at $3,420 for two people in a junior suite with an ocean view.
 Nearby is the 52-room Sandals Inn, on five acres with a public beach across the road. About half the rooms have balconies and face the sea. The weekly double-occupancy rate for two people starts at $2,200.
 The 180-room Braco Village Resort, (800) 654-1337, fax (516) 223-4815, midway between Montego Bay and Ocho Rios, is the newest -- thus the most inclusive -- resort on Jamaica. It has an Olympic-size pool, a private beach 2,000 feet long, a choice of restaurants, and a simulated Jamaican village complete with courthouse, soccer field, rum shop and Peanut Man. The double-occupancy rates are from $175 to $225 a person a night. Minimum age, 16.
 Near Port Antonio in eastern Jamaica between the coast and the hills is the 10-room Hotel Mocking Bird Hill, (809) 993-3370, fax (809) 993-7133, a Caribbean-style villa with bungalows, views of the Blue Mountains and the sea. It is a five-minute drive from the beach at Frenchmen's Cove. Double-occupancy rates range from $120 to $140, including tax and service charges. Valley Hikes, run from the hotel, offers tours through the countryside. Rates start at $10.
 
Martinique
 Martinique Promotion Bureau, 444 Madison Avenue, 16th floor, New York, N.Y. 10022; (800) 391-4909
 Hurricanes Luis and Marilyn inflicted minor damage on the hotels and restaurants of Martinique, a part of the French Antilles with a predictable passion for excellent food and wine. And although the heavy rain hurt the banana and pineapple crops, it did not harm Martinique's reputation as the flower island.
 Martinique's flowers are showcased in the serene Balata Tropical Botanical Park, (596) 64.48.73, with 195 species of tropical plant, an orchid arbor and 60 varieties of palm. Hummingbirds flit in and out of the hibiscus, bougainvillea and frangipani scent the air, and white and red anthuriums, the trademark flower of Martinique, abound. The park is a 20-minute ride north of the capital, Fort-de-France. You will want to have your taxi wait, so plan to pay $60 round trip. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission is $7, $3 for children.
 Les Ombrages, (596) 53.31.90 and (596) 53.32.87, is a botanical and floral trail in the northern tropical rain forest, a half-hour's drive north of St.-Pierre. Across the Falaise Bridge outside the town of Ajoupa Bouillon, the trail borders a ravine where springs and cascading streams flow past towering trees. Lush vegetation, fig trees and flowers are seen on an easy one-hour hike. Admission is $4, children $2. Open daily 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Round-trip taxi fare, including waiting time, is $40. Admission is $4, children $2. Open 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.
 Martinique's chefs specialize in French and French Creole dishes. While sampling the food, try the petit punch, a concoction of white wine and brown sugar, and the fresh-fruit sorbets, available everywhere. The meal prices below include wine and tip.
 La Fontane, a top restaurant, (596) 64.28.70, fax (596) 64.65.01, on Route de Balata, Fort-de-France, offers French and Creole cuisine in a hillside colonial house furnished with antiques. Specialties are lobster basilique and lamb and mushrooms in a mango sauce. Dinners for two range from $80 to $106. Open noon to 2:30 P.M. and 7 to 10 P.M. Closed Sunday and Monday.
 La Villa Creole, Anse Mitan, Trois-Ilets, (596) 66.05.53, fax (596) 66.08.56, has tables topped with linen cloths in a garden with a waterfall, kerosene lamps and live music. The menu, traditional French with a Caribbean spin, includes salmon steak with foie gras atop a crayfish puree. Meals for two range from $60 to $96. Open noon to 2 P.M. and 7 to 10 P.M.; closed Sunday until Monday evening.
 Overlooking the bay of St.-Pierre is Le Fromager Creole restaurant, Quartier St.-James, Route de Fonds St.-Denis, 97250 St.-Pierre, (596) 78.19.07. The atmosphere is relaxing, the prices moderate, from $40 to $72 for a meal for two. Open daily, noon to 3 P.M. and on Thursday, Friday and Saturday from 7 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. The menu includes curried crayfish, grilled lobster, duck with pineapple, coconut flan.
 Poi et Virginie, Place de l'Eglise, Ste.-Anne, (596) 76.72.22, fax (596) 76.73.69, is a Creole French seafood restaurant. Its seafood platter is a mix of lobster, spider crab, turtle, crayfish, shrimp, squid, clams, oysters. There is live local music or jazz on Friday nights. Reservations are suggested. Ask for a table on the waterfront terrace. Closed until the end of this month, after which its prices, from $50 to $95 for two, will go up.
 Traditional Creole breakfasts are served from 8 A.M. to 11 A.M. at the popular Marie-Sainte, 160 Rue Victor Hugo, (596) 70.00.30, in the center of Fort-de-France. The restaurant is open from 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday. The morning dishes include fish stew, codfish, local vegetables, plantains, fried fish, steak and salad; some lunch choices are codfish fritters, crayfish with piquant sauce, chicken fricassee, banana beignets. Meals for two, $26 to $31.
 Sea urchin tartes and codfish fritters flavored with the tiny titris fish are served on pink tablecloths at the friendly Tante Arlette Creole restaurant, Rue de Lucy de Fossarieu, 97218 Grand Riviere, (596) 55.75.75. Other specialties are grilled fresh fish, lobster and crayfish and gratin of squash, banana and lemon tarts. Meals range from $34 to $67 for two; open from 9:30 A.M. to 9 P.M.
 
Montserrat
 Montserrat Tourist Information Office, c/o Medhurst & Associates, Inc., 775 Park Avenue, Huntington, N.Y. 11743, (800)-646-2002
 Small, green Montserrat, a British Dependent Territory in the eastern Caribbean, has always specialized in tranquillity. But that changed last summer when the island's southern volcanic hills became active. Clouds of white steam rose from hot volcanic vents along with showers of ash, which blackened the sky and fell on the town of Plymouth. South Montserrat is at Orange Alert One, the halfway mark on the alert scale, and more ash explosions are expected. Scientists are keeping watch. Hurricanes Luis and Marilyn swept past the island, washing over beaches and blowing away some of the lush vegetation but causing relatively little structural damage.
 Volcanic explosions over thousands of years have sculptured the 12-by-7-mile island into green-forested hills and mountains above black and gray sand beaches. Many luxurious villas -- vacation houses and investment ventures for Americans and others attracted by the island's quiet charm -- have sprouted in the highlands.
 Most of the villas are in the northwest, scattered on hillsides at the opposite end of the island from the volcano, in what is considered a safe zone. Their patios overlook the green mountains or the calm Caribbean. Most have swimming pools, well-kept lush gardens and modern appliances. Rental agents can arrange for cooks. Tradewinds Real Estate, (809) 491-2004, fax (809) 491-6229, has weekly rentals from $1,050 to $2,500; Neville Bradshaw Agencies, (809) 491-5270, fax (809) 491-5069, from $1,000 to $3,000, and West Indies Real Estate Ltd., (809) 491-8666, fax (809) 491-8668, from $1,250 to $6,500. Prices go down drastically in low season, between April 15 and Dec. 15. For example, a two-bedroom villa offered by Tradewinds costs $1,400 in high season, $750 in low season.
 For enjoying the peaceful mountain trails, one of the appealing options is cycling. Island Bikes, (809) 491-5552, fax (809) 491-8752, rents 18-speed mountain bicycles and offers guided tours along scenic routes for less confident as well as experienced riders. A guide is not essential but novices who bike without a guide should stick to the road.
 The trails go through forested mountain terrain; one drops 1,200 feet, starting at Windy Hill. The routes vary from black-topped roads to goat trails. Some are old footpaths and some are stone-bedded plantation roads overgrown with plants. The terrain ranges from semi-desert to rain forest. The rarest routes are flat. Rentals start at $12.50 for two hours. A day's rental is $25, four bikes for one day is $68. Price for a guide is $35 for a half day, $50 for a day for up to four people.
 
 Puerto Rico
 Puerto Rico Tourism Company, 575 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 599-6262 and (800) 223-6530
 Puerto Rico is famous for sun and sand but word of its fine golf courses has spread more slowly. Golfers can play in the shade of mango, palm, and guava trees at nine courses less than an hour from San Juan. And when they tire of the greens, the beaches and sun, they can head for a casino. There are 15 on the island.
 The more adventurous may prefer to head west, to Rincon, where the island's most elegant small hotel, the Horned Dorset Primavera, (809) 823-4030, fax (809) 823-5580, on the coast road, has added the eight-bedroom Casa Escondida, which it calls "a quiet retreat within a quiet hotel," to its original 22 rooms.
 The inn is a two-and-a-half-hour drive or a 25-minute flight from San Juan. The attentive service, enveloping tranquillity and delicious food have inspired some better-heeled golfers to stay there and fly daily to the Dorado and Cerromar Beach courses. Others choose to play 18 holes for $10 weekdays or $12 weekends at the Punta Borinquen course, (809) 890-2987, in the Ramey area, a favorite of President Eisenhower, about a half-hour away. The Horned Dorset Primavera's double rates start at $340, excluding 10 percent tax and service.
 About a 45-minute drive west of San Juan, in Dorado on the north coast, the Hyatt Regency Dorado Beach Resort, (800) 233-1234 or (809) 796-1234, fax (809) 796-6560, Highway 693, and the neighboring Hyatt Regency Cerromar Beach Resort, (800) 233-1234, fax (809) 796-6560, have four of Puerto Rico's best golf courses. Each was designed by the course architect Robert Trent Jones. Much of the challenge in playing all four courses comes from avoiding ponds and palm trees -- and factoring in the vigorous sea breezes.
 The Dorado Beach's low seaside buildings and extensive landscaping make it the most congenial of Puerto Rico's large resort hotels, although an increased emphasis on attracting conventions and recent room renovations suggest the Dorado is losing its distinctive 1950's island character.
 During high season, guests pay $80 at the Dorado's West Course and $100 at the East Course for 18 holes; nonguests pay $120 and $130. Cart rental is an extra $20. The double rates at the 298-room Dorado start at $489 with breakfast and dinner, plus 9 percent room tax and 15 percent on meals. The meal plan is mandatory.
 The recently renovated 506-room Cerromar is connected to the Dorado by paths and a shuttle. Guests can play tennis on 14 courts. Families with children will be interested in the Cerromar's 1,776-foot River Pool with waterfalls and slides, which is also a popular day-trip destination for San Juan families.
 Cerromar offers three-night winter golf packages, starting at $779 a person, double occupancy, including 18 holes a day on a choice of four courses. Double rates start at $310, plus 9 percent tax. The price for 18 holes at Cerromar's two courses: $80 for guests, $100 for nonguests, plus $20 for cart rental.
 The Palmas del Mar Resort, (800) 468-3331 or (809) 852-6000, fax (809) 852-6320, with a casino, sits on the Caribbean coast at Humacao, southeast of San Juan on 2,750 acres with 3,000 palm trees. The golf course was designed by Gary Player, and has a fiendish 14th hole, with a 200-foot drop. The resort's 230 rooms and suites are in the hotel, the inn and in villas. From Jan. 3 to Feb. 9, the three-night golf package, with four days of golf, starts at $1,244 for two.
 Even the most devoted golfer eventually leaves the course, which is probably why most Puerto Rican hotels with golf courses also have casinos. The Dorado recently renovated its casino; the casino at the Cerromar is being more than doubled.
 At the 672-room Caribe Hilton, (800) 445-8667 or (809) 721-0303, fax (809) 722-6750, Los Rosales Street, San Juan's oldest luxury hotel, double rooms that usually go for $365 to $449 in high season may go for $100, including free meals and booze, for anyone willing to play four hours a day, betting $100 or more per hand. For special gamblers' rates, rooms must be reserved through the casino, (809) 724-0912. The Caribe Hilton's beach, pools and excellent location near the heart of Old San Juan make it the best casino hotel for travelers who don't plan to spend all their time gambling.
 In Isla Verde, the 389-room El San Juan Hotel and Casino, (800) 468-2818, or (809) 791-1000, fax (809) 253-0178, (800) 468-6659, has an opulent lobby, several large pools, a sand beach, bathrooms with television sets -- and lots of intent, high-rolling players. The rates vary according to availability of rooms, but expect to pay from $320 to $475 for a double. Serious gamblers seeking special rates should call the director of marketing, Elaine Siegel, at the casino.
 
 Saba
Saba Tourist Office, Post Office Box 6322, Boca Raton, Fla. 33427-6322; (407) 394-8580, (800)722-2394
At first glance, Saba seems unimpressive, a five-square-mile volcanic scrap rising 2,851 feet, with 1,200 residents and one beach, which disappears in winter. But below the sea, the island is clearly in the big leagues.
Since 1987, the crystalline waters of the entire coast down to 200 feet plus several underwater pinnacles offshore have been protected by the Saba Marine Park. Marine scientists say the structure of the park is unusual: There are few large, shallow reefs fringing the island but rather a narrow shelf of coral-encrusted volcanic boulders and areas of reef separated by volcanic sand channels and ridges.
Underwater, as well as on land, Saba survived September's hurricanes with minimal damage. A Marine Park spokesman said some of the abundant soft corals and sponges were torn from the reefs, which would be noticeable to divers familiar with Saba's waters but probably not to first-time visitors.
