In the Marine Park, erosion and past volcanic activity have formed overhangs, tunnels, alleys and caves. In the complex array of holes and gaps, divers find a multitude of reef fish, moray eels, lobsters and the odd nurse shark.
The gradual slope of Tent Reef, in the Marine Park off the southern part of Saba, is a forest of sea fans, boulder corals and barrel and tube sponges. It is not unusual to encounter eagle rays and large groupers. In shallower parts of the reef, a large overhang plays host to numerous squirrelfish, hinds and snappers. The roof of the overhang is a patchwork of colorful sponges where tiny blue neon damselfish take shelter.
Depths of more than 1,500 feet are found between the island and some of the shallower dive sites. Two-thirds of a mile offshore, underwater pinnacles reach up to within 90 feet of the surface. Divers see assemblages of hard and soft corals on pinnacles, which are a rest stop for many large open-ocean fish and numerous reef fish. Often a large hawksbill turtle will paddle by and disappear behind the large coral heads.
The Marine Park has 36 permanent mooring buoys within the protected area, giving access to the dive sites and preventing anchor damage. The park office is at Fort Bay, the island's main harbor area. Open 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekdays, 8 A.M. to noon Saturday, 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. Sunday.
Saba Deep Dive Center, (599) 46-3347 and fax (599) 46-3397, leads dives each day at 9 A.M., 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. The rate for a single-tank dive is $45, double tank $80 and triple tank $110, including all equipment except wet suit. The price does not include the Marine Park's fee of $2 a dive.
Two other dive shops have similar prices: Sea Saba Dive Center, (599) 46-2246, fax (599) 46-2362, and Wilson's Dive Shop, telephone and fax (599) 46-2541.
The park's snorkel trail, for experienced swimmers only, can be reached from a beach at Well's Bay from May to October. In other months, ground swells pull the sand from the beach.
 
 St. Barthelemy
French West Indies Tourist Board, 444 Madison Avenue, 16th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10022; (900) 990-0040 (50 cents a minute)
Soon after Hurricane Luis roared through small, trendy St. Barthelemy, the island began repairing, replanting and rebudding. St. Barts is more or less ready for winter, cachet (though not every hotel and restaurant) intact.
St. Barts lies between Antigua and Virgin Gorda, two major sailing centers. The capital, Gustavia, has a harbor with mooring and docking facilities for yachts.
The island is known for its upscale accommodations in small hotels, inns and villas. Rooms in the places that are mentioned below can be reserved through their United States agent, West Indies Management Company (Wimco), (800) 932-3222, fax (401) 847-6290. The prices, which include tax and service, are for the 1996 high season (but not around Christmas, when rates are higher).
Francois Plantation, built on the Colombier hillside, has spectacular views from the pool at the hotel's highest point. The 12 colorful, Caribbean-style bungalows, each with a small patio, are in a garden with pergolas, trellises, earthenware pots and winding paths. The complex has one of the island's best French restaurants. The wine cellar is stocked with French bottles selected by the owner. Each room has queen-sized four-poster mahogany beds. There is a four-night minimum stay. Double room rates start at $300, including an American breakfast.
La Banane sits in a garden 100 yards from Lorient Beach. The nine-room inn, with two small pools, is known for its nightly cabaret. The rooms have plantation-style furniture and terraces. The restaurant is open for dinner. Double room rates start at $340 a night, including airport transfers and full breakfast.
The newly painted and landscaped Carl Gustaf, a luxury suites hotel, overlooks Gustavia harbor. Each of the 14 suites has a terrace and most have a private plunge pool. Beds are king-sized. Suites have a minibar, kitchen, two phone lines, fax and 24-hour room service. The fitness center has a sauna. There is a swimming pool, a shuttle to the beach, a restaurant and a piano bar. The two-bedroom suites cost $1,000 a night for four people, the one-bedroom suite $750, including airport transfers and Continental breakfast served in the suite.
Rental villas range from unassuming one-bedroom beach or hillside retreats to luxury estates awash in frills.
The one-bedroom villa called Villa Ven, cooled by fans, has a view of the Grand Cul de Sac area and the ocean. A marble-floored veranda leads to the living room via arched French doors with white wooden shutters. The kitchen is at one end of the living room. The bedroom has French doors leading out to the terrace. Tennis, beaches and windsurfing are a short drive away; Gustavia is a 15-minute drive. Children are not accepted. The cost: $1,750 a week, plus 7.5 percent service charge.
On the hillside above St. Jean, the Villa Rel has been newly redecorated in white. A housekeeper tends the three bedrooms, two baths, living room and dining room. There is a pool. Monogrammed bathrobes and matching towels are included in the cost, $3,900 a week plus 7.5 percent service. Children are welcome.
 
St. Croix
United States Virgin Islands Department of Tourism, 1270 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 332-2222
After Hurricane Hugo in 1989, the people who live here recall, the island was so devastated it looked burned or bombed. In contrast, hurricanes Luis and Marilyn merely toppled large trees, thinned the foliage and damaged buildings. St. Croix's attractions -- good beaches and a wealth of sports, golf included -- are ready for visitors. Virtually all hotels are open, tourism officials say. Some of the best beaches are at Sandy Point in the southwest and at Buck Island, a National Monument that is part of the National Park system, 1.6 miles off northeast St. Croix.
The Carambola Golf Club, (809) 778-5638, at the Westin Carambola Resort in the island's northeast, lost almost 300 trees on its 18-hole course to the hurricanes but there was little damage to the fairways. Hotel guests pay $57.50 a person for an 18-hole round, cart included, nonguests $72.50.
The Westin Carambola Beach and Golf Resort, (800) 228-3000, fax (809) 778-1682, situated on 28 acres along Davis Bay, opened the first of this month after repairs. The hotel has 151 rooms in 25 two-story villas. The rooms have large louvered windows, mahogany furniture, terra cotta floors, air-conditioning and ceiling fans. There are nine tennis courts, a pool, three restaurants and a free shuttle to the 18-hole golf course, (809) 778-5638. For one or two people in a room, rates are $235 to $330, plus 18 percent for tax and service.
Of the 154 rooms at the Buccaneer Hotel, (800) 255-3881, fax (809) 778-8215, built on 300 acres east of Christiansted near Gallows Bay, 50 are on the beach; the three beaches enlarged by the hurricane. The hotel has two swimming pools and eight tennis courts. Double rates start at $210, plus 8 percent tax. The price includes breakfast and snorkel gear. For the 18-hole course, guests pay $44 a person in greens fees, including cart, or $300 for a week of unlimited golf.
Among St. Croix's winter golf packages is one at the pink stucco two-story Hibiscus Beach Hotel, (800) 442-0121, fax (809) 773-7668, on Pelican Cove. The hotel has a seaside open-air restaurant and bar. Its 37 beachfront rooms in six buildings have patios or balconies. A four-night package costs $599 a person, double occupancy, including a rental car, daily greens fees and cart, and two rounds of golf at Carambola.
Sailing options include trips out of Christiansted Wharf and Green Cay Marina near Christiansted. The usual objective of an outing is snorkeling among the parrotfish, French angelfish and other marine life at Buck Island National Monument, (809) 773-1460. In addition to a sheltered sandy beach, Buck Island has a hiking trail and a snorkeling trail in a lagoon along a coral reef.
A Christiansted Wharf cruise captain, John Macy, phone and fax (809) 773-4482, offers a daily Buck Island tour, 9:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., on a 42-foot catamaran for $55 a person, including lunch and rum punch. A two-hour sunset sail around the harbor costs $20 a person, including rum punch.
Capt. Heinz Punzenberger, (809) 773-3161, fax (809) 773-4041, pilots his 42-foot trimaran from Green Cay Marina to Buck Island twice daily. The first trip, 9 A.M. to 2 P.M., costs $45 a person, including snorkel equipment, beer and soft drinks; the second trip, 2 P.M. to 5:30 P.M, is $40 a person.
 
 St. Eustatius
St. Eustatius Information Office, Caribbean Connection Plus, Post Office Box 261, Trumbull, Conn. 06611; (203) 261-8603
Once one of the busiest ports in the Western world, St. Eustatius is now known for quietude, diving and a preoccupation with the past. There's a volcano, the Quill, and it too is quiet; a rain forest grows in the crater. The eight-square-mile island lies 38 miles south of St. Maarten, which bore the brunt of Hurricane Luis. St. Eustatius escaped with damage mainly to vegetation and some eroded beaches.
Among the island's more spectacular dive sites, Grand Canyon is a series of volcanic fissures pouring sand into the ocean depths. At Double Wreck, where two old shipwrecks are covered with coral, divers can see hordes of fish, including flying fish, large barracuda, stingrays and grunts.
Oranjestad, the historic capital of St. Eustatius, is situated in two parts: the Lower Town, beside a gray-black sand beach that Luis diminished, and the Upper Town on the cliff above. Most of the Lower Town has been in ruins for nearly 200 years.
Divers and snorkelers may explore the ruins of partly sunken old yellow brick warehouses by the Lower Town. Coastal erosion has exposed more ruins just offshore in clear, shallow water. Pottery shards, broken clay pipes and, on rare occasions, blue glass beads from slave-trading days can be found on the beach or in shallow water. A diver who has recently explored the waters said the force of the hurricane had exposed pottery shards and pieces of bottles long buried in the sand.
Dominating the bay from a commanding site in the Upper Town are the ruins of Fort Oranje with large cannons. The fort returned a salute on Nov. 16, 1776, to the brig Andrew Doria, flying the Grand Union Flag, the precursor to the Stars and Stripes. This is regarded as the first salute to a flag of the new United States by officials of a foreign power. The island was a source of supplies to the colonists during the American Revolution, and this -- as well as the cannon salute -- angered the British, who wreaked destruction during their occupation of St. Eustatius.
The small Museum of the St. Eustatius Historical Foundation, (599) 382288, 3 Wilhelminaweg, at the top of the cobblestone bay path in the Upper Town, is a former merchant's house that was taken over by the British Navy. The museum has displays on the island's shipping era and on the pre-Columbian period. Open weekdays 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., weekends 9 A.M. to noon. Entrance fee $2.
Dive Statia, (599) 382435, fax (599) 382539, in Lower Town, offers a two-and-a-half-hour introductory diving course for $80, which includes a boat dive and use of gear.
Hotel dive packages start at $575 a person double occupancy, including seven nights, six two-tank dives, breakfast and taxes. Among the accommodations, divers like the relaxed atmosphere at the new family-owned Kings Well Resort, phone and fax (599) 382538, on a cliff overlooking Oranje Bay with a beach below. There are only three guest rooms now, but five more are scheduled to open next month. The double room rates range from $50 to $90, including full breakfast; 7 percent tax is extra.
 
St. John
United States Virgin Islands Department of Tourism, 1270 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 332-2222
Of the three United States Virgin Islands, St. John had the least damage from this fall's hurricanes. St. John is sought out mostly for the scenic wonders of the Virgin Islands National Park, which covers almost two-thirds of the island.
Visitors can arrive only by sea; the nearest airport is on St. Thomas, which lies a few miles to the west of St. John. The island's main town, Cruz Bay, at its western end, has regular ferry service to the Red Hook Wharf on St. Thomas, a 20-minute ride.
Before beginning an island trek, you can pick up free trail maps at the National Park visitor's center, (809) 776-6201, at the park entrance on the north side of Cruz Bay. Open daily from 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. There are 22 hiking trails within the park covering 20 miles in all. The most popular guided hike is the 2.2 miles to Reef Bay, on the south of the island, starting from the side of a hill and descending 800 feet to the bay and exploring sugar plantation ruins in the valley. Reef Bay has a pleasant but rocky beach. The hike is led two or three times weekly, leaving the visitors' center around 9:45 A.M. and returning by boat about 3:30 P.M. The cost is $14 from Cruz Bay, which is the price of the taxi ride (which will vary by starting point) and the boat ride back.
The most popular beach is probably Trunk Bay in the northwest, but snorkelers who know the island prefer the less-crowded beach at Salt Pond Bay, near the Ram Head hiking trail. The coral reefs lie just offshore.
St. John's most luxurious landmark, Caneel Bay, is closed for extensive post-hurricane renovations, including installation of custom-made furniture. The resort is scheduled to reopen June 1.
The National Park Service estimates a million people visit the park yearly; the great push comes in winter, when prices are higher. The lodging prices listed here, for two people, do not include the 8 percent tax.
Scheduled to reopen Feb. 1, after repairs, Cinnamon Bay, (800) 539-9998, fax (214) 871-5444, a concession along a beach on parkland, offers 26 bare campsites at $15 a night all year, 60 tents for $70 in winter, and 40 one-room cottages 15 by 15 feet, $90 in winter. Guests are issued a portable propane stove and the tents and cottages have charcoal grills on the patio. There is an open-air restaurant that serves three meals daily, plus a general store.
Stanley Selengut's popular eco-lodgings, (800) 392-9004, fax (212) 861-6210, offer several options. The 114 canvas cottages at Maho Bay Camps start at the beach and climb the hill. The cottages, which sleep up to five, have cooking equipment, linens and electricity. The price: $95 a night. Just above the Maho Bay cottages, Harmony Resort sits on a hill with views of the beaches. Built of recycled materials and solar powered, the 12 studio apartments have kitchenettes, microwaves and decks. The rates: $150 to $180 a night. At Estate Concordia, a Selengut apartment complex on the island's southeast shore, five new eco-tents, overlooking Salt Pond Bay, sleep five or six people on twin beds and sofa beds. The tents have lofts, kitchen equipment, private baths, screened windows and access to a resort's swimming pool. The double rate is $95.
Nature lovers who prefer a full-service hotel can stay at the 285-room Hyatt Regency St. John, (800) 233-1234 or (809) 693-8888, on Great Cruz Bay, just south of the town of Cruz Bay. The hotel plans to reopen Jan. 2 after repairs. The resort has a quarter-acre swimming pool, a 1,200-foot beach, six lighted tennis courts and three restaurants. High-season rates start at $340 for a double.
 
St. Kitts and Nevis
St. Kitts and Nevis Department of Tourism, 414 East 75th Street, New York, N.Y. 10021; (212) 535-1234 or (800) 582-6208
Graceful old plantation homes called great houses,built for sugar moguls, dot St. Kitts's countryside. Today, some are attractive inns in a setting of hibiscus, bougainvillea and African green monkeys.
Two miles from St. Kitts by sea, on smaller, quieter Nevis, clouds mist the top of 3,596-high Nevis Peak, a companion to St. Kitt's 3,711-foot Mount Liamuga. Nevis has its own assortment of historic inns.
Hurricane winds and water swept both islands, raking sand from beaches and shredding greenery, but the historic inns stood firm. Most are on wind-cooled hillsides; some are closer to beaches. To the prices listed, add 17 percent for tax and service.
The stylish Golden Lemon Inn, (800) 633-7411, fax (809) 465-4019, at Dieppe Bay, St. Kitts's northwest corner, has 32 rooms, some in the great house, others in two-story villas each with its own small swimming pool. There is a large pool as well. An easy path leads to the black sand beach. Hurricane winds stripped Golden Lemon's beachfront foliage but new greenery began growing soon afterward. Double rooms in the great house start at $290, including full breakfast. Villas start at $365. A package including breakfast and dinner is $335 for a room in the great house, with a four-night minimum.
The 18th-century Rawlins Plantation, (800) 346-5358, fax (703) 548-5825, sits on a hill at St. Kitts's western end with a view of Saba and St. Eustatius. There are 10 guest rooms furnished with English antiques in 10 cottages, including the honeymoon suite in the old sugar mill. The dozen acres contain a swimming pool and grass tennis court. The co-owner, Claire Rawson, a trained chef, cooks French and island-style for the restaurant. Rooms have no television, phones or air-conditioning. Double rooms with breakfast and dinner, plus afternoon tea and laundry: $390. Storm damage was minor here.
Ottley's Plantation Inn, (800) 772-3039, fax (809) 465-4760, above the village of Ottley on the Atlantic side of St. Kitts, reopened last month, repaired and repainted after Hurricane Luis. The 15 air-conditioned rooms are mostly in the great house with colonial decor, attractive prints and paintings, the others in cottages. The inn has a spring-fed swimming pool, ocean and mountain views and first-rate multicultural cooking. Double room rates from $310 to $420 a night, including breakfast and dinner. The inn will send a video to prospective guests.
On Nevis, the Nisbet Plantation Beach Club, (800) 742-6008 or (809) 469-9325, fax (809) 469-9864, sits on a beach at the island's northern end, with 38 rooms and a handsome beach pavilion for breakfast and lunch. The 1778 great house was the home of Fanny Nisbet, the wife of Admiral Horatio Nelson. The decor is colonial. Double rates, including breakfast, dinner, tea and laundry, start at $355. Tax and service is 19 percent. Hurricane Luis stripped Nisbet of a few dozen coconut palm trees (since replanted).
In the Gingerland area in Nevis's east, African green monkeys roam the grounds at the 96-acre Golden Rock Retreat, (809) 469-3346, fax (809) 469-2113, where the 16 rooms are in seven cottages and a 19th-century sugar mill. The grounds lie at an altitude of 1,000 feet with a swimming pool, tennis court and nature trail. Doubles with breakfast and dinner start at $255; without meals $195. Dinners are $40, plus tax and service.
The family-run Hermitage, (809) 469-3477, fax (809) 469-2481, dating to 1740, has 14 rooms in 12 cottages furnished with canopied beds. Hammocks swing on the porches. The inn's eight acres lie 800 feet above sea level with a stable, swimming pool and tennis court. Double rates start at $325, including breakfast, tea and dinner.
The deluxe Nevis Four Seasons Resort, (800) 322-3442, fax (809) 469-1112, reopened Nov. 9 after repairs to its pool deck, pier and ballroom; the beach should be rebuilt by the end of November. Double rates start at $550.
 
 St. Lucia
St. Lucia Tourist Board, 820 Second Avenue, Suite 900 E, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212)867-2950
St. Lucia is known for magnificent mountains, a rain forest and inclusive resorts, which were introduced only a few years ago and now include most of the hotels. This year the island was among the lucky number that escaped the hurricanes.
St. Lucia's rugged cone-shaped mountains rise abruptly from the sea. Gros Piton is 2,619 feet high, Petit Piton 2,461 feet. Lying at the foot of the mountains, the town of Soufriere is the staging point for what is touted as the world's only drive-in volcano and the bubbling Sulphur Springs. The steaming springs are part of a volcano that last erupted thousands of years ago. Nearby are the Diamond Botanical Gardens and Mineral Baths, offering a close look at St. Lucia's beautiful flora.
The rain forest covers 19,000 acres of lush mountains and valleys. Tours were resumed recently, having stopped last year after the trail was wrecked by a tropical storm.
Barefoot Holidays, (809) 450-0507, fax (809) 450-0661, offers a rain forest tour for $40, a trip of about four and a half hours, including a three-hour hike.
A daylong bus and boat trip, including a visit to Soufriere, the volcano, Sulphur Springs, Diamond Falls, banana plantations and fishing villages, is $70, including lunch on the boat.
Independent touring is easier this year. Reconstruction of St. Lucia's scenic west coast road, underway for three and a half years, ended in July; Soufriere and the Pitons are now more accessible.
The hotel room prices listed here include food, drink, sports, tax, service, and airport transfers.
The Jalousie Plantation Resort, (800) 392-2007, fax (809) 459-5366, sits between the two Pitons, with 114 rooms, four restaurants and three bars and lounges. There is a pool with swim-up bar, four tennis courts, a squash court and a new par-three golf course. The health club includes an aerobics studio and gym. Water sports include sailing. Room prices start at $600 for two people.
The pink Sandals St. Lucia, (800) 726-3257, fax (305) 667-8996, with a crescent-shaped beach on the west coast, is on 155 acres. The 273 rooms are in the main hotel and hillside villas. The resort, for couples only, has five restaurants, a fitness center, a nine-hole golf course and a pool with a waterfall, swim-up bar and bridges. Activities include tennis, volleyball, horseshoes, snorkeling, kayaking, water-skiing, windsurfing and scuba. Weekly rates for two people start at $3,670.
On a cove at St. Lucia's northernmost tip, the 100-room Le Sport, (800) 544-2883, fax (305) 672-5861, was designed for health and beauty devotees. Saunas, loofa rubs and hydro massages are among the options, and archery and fencing are among the sports. Rooms for two start at $500.
The recently redone East Winds Inn, (800) 223-9832, fax (212) 599-1755, sits on eight tropical acres and a palmy beach along La Brelotte Bay on the northeast coast. The inn has 26 rooms in 13 cottages, a pool, a beachfront bar and restaurant, a French chef, snorkeling, canoes and a library. Double room rates start at $490.
The 238-room Wyndham Morgan Bay, (800) 822-4200, fax (809) 450-1050, is on Choc Bay just north of the capital. The resort offers waterskiing, snorkeling, sailing, tennis and a fitness center. The guest rooms have private balconies and terraces and most have sea views. Double-occupancy rates start at $430, for a room with a garden view.
 
 St. Maarten
St. Maarten Tourist Office, 675 Third Avenue, 18th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10017; (800) 786-2278
On the island split between Dutch St. Maarten and French St. Martin, the Dutch side was especially hard hit, partly because of its more intense development.
Repairs are continuing. Many shops and restaurants are open; the island Government expects 60 percent of hotel rooms to be ready for guests by the end of this month. The harbor is open to cruise ships.
As on the French side, St. Maarten has scenic beaches, turquoise water and volcanic mountains.
In Philipsburg, the capital, American culture dominates, the dollar is accepted and nearly everyone speaks English. Front Street, the southernmost of the city's three main east-west streets, is full of jewelry stores specializing in gold and gemstones. As in New York's Diamond District, shoppers should compare prices. (On a visit in August, nearly all stores advertised 50 percent off gold, but the prices were higher than in New York.) The Front Street shops weathered the storm, and most are open.
The anchor store, Little Switzerland, on Front Street, (599) 5-23530, which is expected to reopen by the end of the month, sells an impressive range of European designer jewelry as well as china, crystal, watches and other luxury items, from Hummel figurines to Chanel and Fendi fragrances.
The vendors will bargain, and prices will vary. In August, a pair of small earrings of opals mounted in 14-karat gold cost $138 at one store; at another, Gurlink, 33 Front Street, (599) 5-30356, a similar set with similarly fiery opals was $68.
Take precautions to verify the authenticity of diamonds by asking for a receipt and written money-back guarantee. It may be a good idea to charge the gem rather than pay cash so that you have recourse through your credit card. Most shops are open from 8 or 9 A.M. to noon and from 1 P.M. to 6 P.M.
One open hotel is the 600-room Maho Beach Hotel and Casino, (800) 223-0757, fax (212) 969-9227, where 400 rooms are available and the others are expected to open mid-December. Double room rates start at $225 plus 20 percent tax and service. The hotel is near the airport.
In Philipsburg at 35 Front Street, the 54-room Holland House, (599) 5-22572, fax (599) 5-24673, is near shopping and casinos. Winter double room rates start at $145 for two people, plus 20 percent tax and service.
A smaller resort that expects to be open for winter is the secluded Oyster Pond Beach Hotel, (800) 777-1700, fax (599) 5-76585, with 20 rooms and 20 suites near Dawn Beach. Double rates start at $170, plus 20 percent tax and service.
Holland House and Maho Beach are among four offering a Stay Seven, Pay Five rate Dec. 20 through April 15, 1966. The rate, available through travel agents, allows guests to stay seven nights for the price of five.
 
 
St. Martin
French West Indies Tourist Board, 444 Madison Avenue, 16th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10022; (900) 990-0040 (50 cents a minute)
Unlike Dutch St. Maarten, which has been Americanized, the sensibility on French St. Martin is Gallic. With strong support from France, St. Martin responded quickly and effectively to the damage left by Hurricane Luis. At least 76 percent of the 2,554 hotel rooms are expected to be ready for winter, tourism officials say. Rental villas sustained relatively little damage.
St. Martin's specialties are beaches and restaurants. In the community of Grand Case, which is noted for good dining spots, the storm washed away several seaside places and damaged some terraces, but other restaurants fared well.
The survivors include Bistro Caraibe, at 81 Grand Case, phone and fax (590) 29.08.29, which has fish specialties, including salmon with herb sauce, for $19, and breast of duck on toasted goat cheese and a salad bed for $10. There is a selection of French wines by the glass for $3. Dinner for four with wine costs $100.
Down the street, La Creperie le Soleil, (590) 87.92.32, offers a ham, cheese and tomato luncheon crepe for $7.
Other restaurants that are open include Cha Cha Cha, 61 Grand Case, (590) 87.53.63; Pizzeria la Californie, 134 Grand Case, (590) 87.55.57; Hoa Mai, Belvedere Hotel, Cul de Sac, (590) 87.32.52; Le Porto Fino, Grand Case, (590) 29.08.28, and a new one, Sunny, 151 Grand Case, (590) 29.23.75.
Among the storm casualties, the beachside food shacks, called lolos, were washed away and are being rebuilt for the winter season. The shacks sell grilled chicken, sausage and shrimp. Cost of a meal: about $8.
In Marigot, a pleasant place for lunch, La Vie en Rose, (590) 87.54.42, fax (590) 87.58.26, on the corner of Rue de la Republique and Boulevard de France, fronts on the harbor. Bistro fare is the rule, with plenty of seafood. About $20 a person with wine.
Beaches that are officially open for swimming include Plum Bay, Baie Rouge, Petite Plage, Friars Bay, Galion Beach, Pinel Island and Orient.
The reopening date for the island's most stylish resort, the 80-room La Samanna, had not been set as of early November by its management, Rosewood Hotels and Resorts. A spokeswoman for Rosewood said the hotel would be closed at least through the end of 1995. For an update on the opening, call (800) 854-2252.
 
 St. Thomas
United States Virgin Islands Division of Tourism, 1270 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10020; (212) 332-2222
In mid-September Hurricane Marilyn left St. Thomas, the commercial center of the United States Virgin Islands, in shambles. But just six weeks later, after heroic efforts by emergency workers, Charlotte Amalie's deep harbor was once again ready for cruise ships. The inauguration was celebrated on Oct. 31 by 1,150 passengers arriving on the Celebrity liner Zenith.
The visitors listened to steel bands, drank free rum punch, shopped, took sightseeing tours, attended a fair hosted by the Committee to Revive Our Culture and swam at Magens Bay, one of the island's best beaches, a glorious U-shaped bay on the island's north side.
Afterward, according to an island public relations representative, the cruise ship passengers gave St. Thomas high marks. Luckily, the passengers didn't have to check into a hotel; the island's habitable hotel rooms will be housing relief workers until Dec. 15, said Beverly Nicholson, director of the St. Thomas/St. John Hotel Association.
Among many hotels, there is uncertainty about reopening dates. Originally, island officials had announced that 60 percent of hotel rooms would be open by Dec. 15. By early November, the percentage had dipped to 40 to 50 percent because of a shortage of repair supplies.
The hotels that have announced they will be fully open by Dec. 20, said Mrs. Nicholson, include Secret Harbour Beach Hotel, (800) 524-2250; Emerald Beach, (800) 528-1234; Island Beachcomber, (800) 982-9898, and Sapphire Beach Resort, (800) 524-2090. Elysian Beach Resort, (800) 524-4746, says it will also open on that date. The 171-room Bluebeard's Castle, (800) 524-6599, will open Jan. 18. The renovated 290-room Stouffer Renaissance Grand Beach Resort, (809) 775-1510, will reopen early next summer with a shortened name, Renaissance Grand Beach Resort; it suffered major damage to its beachside rooms, lobby and landscaping.
As for the island's natural assets, all the beaches are open, said Mrs. Nicholson. "Nature has a wonderful way of taking over," she said.
 
St. Vincent
St. Vincent and the Grenadines Tourist Office, 801 Second Avenue, 21st Floor, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 687-4981
A 4,000-foot volcano, La Soufriere, caps the landscape on St. Vincent, but the chain of the Grenadines is best known for excellent sailing. The 32 islands and cays stretch 75 miles, with beautiful deserted beaches, coves and offshore reefs.
The lush 35-acre Young Island, 200 yards off St. Vincent's southern coast, is home to Young Island Resort, (800) 223-1108, fax (310) 440-4220, with 29 cottages and yacht charter packages. The cottages have adjustable louvered walls, ceiling fans, rattan furnishings and refrigerators. Winter double rates start at $430, including breakfast and dinner but not the 17 percent tax and service charge. Guests can also combine two nights on a yacht and five nights at the resort. From Dec. 18 to Feb. 28, the weekly rate begins at $3,300 for two. The yachts sleep two couples plus crew.
Young Island Resort's sailing destinations include Bequia, nine miles south of St. Vincent, with clear blue-green water and a protected bay. From Bequia, it's seven miles to picturesque hilly and clubby Mustique, with good snorkeling.
Eleven miles south of Mustique, there is a new yacht anchorage on Canouan Island at the Tamarind Beach Hotel and Yacht Club, (800) 223-1108, (809) 458-8044, fax (809) 458-8851, which opened in January. Facing the sea, the rooms have ceiling fans and balconies. Double rates are $300 a day, plus 17 percent tax and service, and include meals, airport transfers and the use of small sailboats and other water-sports gear.
Among St. Vincent's yacht renters, Barefoot Charters, (809) 456-9526, fax (809) 456-9238, on Blue Lagoon offers weekly charters on bare boats -- yachts rented without a crew -- starting at $2,660 a week for a 41-foot boat with two cabins and two heads; $2,380 from Jan. 7 to 31. A captain costs $100 a day; a cook, $75 a day.
The Lagoon Marina and Hotel, (800) 742-4276, phone and fax (809) 458-4308, has two 44-foot sailboats for charter; winter prices are $400 a day or $2,800 a week for a skippered boat. The price does not include a cook, which is $40 a day extra, plus $20 a person a day for provisions.
The hotel has an open-air bar and restaurant and 19 simply furnished rooms with balconies. The double rates are $95, plus 17 percent tax and service.
The 32-room Sunset Shores Beach Hotel, (800) 223-6510, (809) 458-4411, fax (809) 457-4800, sits on three acres with gardens, a pool and a view of Young Island. The rooms have private patios. Double rates start at $140, plus 17 percent tax and service. An extra $38 a person buys breakfast and dinner.
 
Tortola
British Virgin Islands Tourist Board, 370 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10017; (212) 696-0400
Calm waters, steady winds and many anchorages give Tortola some of the world's best sailing. Storm winds swept the island but left little damage. The smooth waters make the British Virgin Islands ideal for novice sailors -- and nervous passengers. Secluded coves and deserted beaches all around are idyllic destinations. More than 50 other islands in the British Virgin archipelago are scattered nearby in crystalline waters. Tortola is the largest island, 30 square miles topped by 1,780-foot Mount Sage. The capital, Road Town, is the hub of activity, which is mostly low-key.
Tortola is a base for crewed charter boats and bare boats. Cruising between islands normally takes only a couple of hours. Among destinations, charter captains recommend White Bay, with its fine white sand, on the island of Jost Van Dyke. Other pleasant day stops: Great Harbor on Peter Island and The Caves on Norman Island, which offer snorkeling through beachside sea caves accessible right off the boat.
Some of the best overnight anchorages are Soper's Hole and Cane Garden Bay on Tortola and Great Harbor on Jost Van Dyke. While in Great Harbor many people head for Foxy's, (809) 495-9743, an open-air beachside restaurant and bar, where the owner, Foxy Callwood, often sings calypso and local bands perform. The specialty is grilled fish, and there are beach barbecues on Fridays and Saturdays. Dinner for two is about $40, drinks about $3.50 each.
Among smaller boats, the 40-foot sloop Cheers can sleep four. During winter, a seven-day sail for two costs $3,850, including meals prepared by a chef, and drinks. For six nights aboard the 65-foot trimaran Promenade, 10 people pay $13,500, including on-board meals and drinks. Scuba is $25 a dive. The rate drops by about $1,300 for each couple fewer. The 105-foot Cuan Law, a trimaran, sleeps 20. Cabins are often rented on an individual basis. Double rates for an air-conditioned stateroom with private bath and meals: $2,860 for six nights. The boats can be booked through Virgin Island Sailing Limited, (800) 233-7936, fax (809) 494-6774. At least three months' advance booking is recommended.
A large yacht-charter operation, The Moorings, (800) 535-7289 or (809) 494-2331, with its flagship base on Tortola, has 180 sailing yachts, ranging from 32 feet to 76 feet. In winter, a 50-foot boat will cost $940 a day; a 32-foot boat, $330 a day.
Sailing courses are given by the Offshore Sailing School, (800) 221-4326, fax (941) 454-1191, at The Moorings' 43-room Treasure Isle Hotel in Road Town, on a hillside overlooking the harbor. The sailing course, which includes seven nights at the hotel, one dinner, lessons in a classroom and aboard a boat, is $1,495 a person, double occupancy.
 
Trinidad and Tobago
Trinidad and Tobago Tourist Board, 7000 Boulevard East, Guttenberg, N.J. 07093; (800) 748-4224 and (201) 662-3403
It is said that Trinidad has more of just about everything -- more roots, culture, festivals, music, birds and butterflies -- than other islands in the Caribbean. The roots come from around the world, and the birdlife is rich -- 433 species or so -- because Trinidad skirts South America. On less-developed Tobago, diving is accessible and good.
Trinidad's most famous festival is its big, boisterous Carnival, which peaks on Fat Tuesday, Feb. 20 next year, with an explosion of music and dancing in the streets. But pre-Carnival events and other festivals erupt year round -- some in the capital, Port of Spain, some in villages and smaller towns. Many festivals have no fixed dates, others are rescheduled at the last minute. The one relatively quiet time is the six weeks of Lent.
Much of the music is steel pan, played on a carefully tuned steel drum. A band of five or more players beats out a calypso, jazz or classical tune. Beating a pan means moving the whole body, making it a form of dance as well as music.
Port of Spain's lively Carnival-like air intensified last year when its central plaza was landscaped with trees, grass, walkways and built-in chess tables and renamed the Brian Lara Promenade after a young cricket star. (Cricket is an island passion.) On some Friday evenings there's a performance here on an open-air stage -- steel pan bands, stand-up comedians, performing dogs. In the nightclubs, musicians perform virtually until dawn, validating Port of Spain's image as a city that doesn't sleep.
Among the most popular spots, the smoky Mas Camp, phone and fax (809) 623-3745, at 19-23 French Street in Woodbrook, west of Port of Spain, usually has live entertainment with a Trinidadian flavor. Calypso singers perform on Wednesdays. The types of music include soca, a livelier version of calypso. Go in late evening; the music ends around 4 A.M. Entry fee is $2 to $3. A Carib beer, brewed on the island, costs $1.
For Creole food, try an old favorite, Veni Mange, (809) 622-7533, in a small house in the St. James district decorated with batik and paintings by Trinidad artists. The dishes, which vary with the season, include pumpkin fritters, callaloo soup, red snapper and coconut mousse. Lunch is served Monday to Friday, dinner only on Wednesdays. Lunches average $10, plus $1.20 for a rum punch or $1 for a Carib beer. Dinner has a set price of $10, plus 15 percent tax.
When bird-watchers go to Trinidad, they head for the veranda and mountain trails at Asa Wright Nature Center and Lodge, 1,200 feet high, about seven miles north of Arima and a 90-minute drive from Port of Spain. Turquoise-billed toucans and bearded bellbirds are among the species seen at the nature center, along with tufted coquette hummingbirds. A day visit to Asa Wright, phone and fax (809) 667-4655, is $6, including a tour of the reserve. Reservations are needed. The double rate for an overnight stay in one of the 24 rooms is $210, including tax, meals and afternoon tea.
On Tobago, the reefs off the village of Speyside on the island's eastern tip, a straggle of small houses between the mountains and the sea, seem almost untouched. But the famous Buccoo Reef, at the island's western end, is now sadly degraded. The offshore water is one of the few places in the world where manta rays are common close to shore.
Two Speyside inns have their own dive shops. The more dive-focused of the two is the casual, new 22-room Manta Lodge, (800) 544-7631, fax (809) 660-5030, owned and run by a professional diver. The beach is across the road. Double rates start at $90, plus 20 percent tax and service. Seven-night packages with 10 dives start at $767 a person, double occupancy, including tax and airport transportation. The charming 38-room Blue Waters Inn, (800) 742-4276, (809) 660-4341, fax (809) 660-5195, is built on 46 wooded acres. Swimming is along a beach on a private cove. Double rates start at $121, including tax and service.
 
 Turks and Caicos
Turks and Caicos Tourist Board, Post Office Box 594023, Miami, Fla. 33159; (800) 241-0824
More than 200 miles of barrier reefs surround the Turks and Caicos, prime spots for scuba diving and snorkeling. Eight islands and more than 40 small cays lie in the archipelago, graced with sandy beaches, secluded coves and shallow reefs. The waters are clear, the reefs pristine, the marine life healthy and abundant.
The archipelago lies 30 miles southeast of the Bahamas. The most developed of the islands is Providenciales, known as Provo, which has a variety of lodging, dining and entertainment choices.
The same barrier reef that attracts divers also breaks the surf, creating calm turquoise bays along miles of virtually vacant white sand beaches. On Provo, 14 miles of beach run the length of the northern coastline. Beaches are public from the low-tide line to the dune line. There are no public restrooms, but most beachside hotels don't mind visitors stopping by for a few minutes of shade and a drink.
Provo's most popular beach is the two-and-a-half-mile stretch in front of the resorts on Grace Bay. The most crowded area, good for strolling, jogging and people-watching, is near Club Med Turkoise. Seclusion can be found nearby at Grace Bay's eastern end. Leeward Beach on the east end of Provo is peaceful, deserted and offers powder-white sand, coconut palms, small rocky cliffs and stone jetties.
The major diving areas lie at the western sides of Provo, West Caicos and Grand Turk and the eastern side of South Caicos. Walls richly blanketed with soft corals and vibrant sponges start at 35 to 60 feet below the surface and plunge as much as 7,000 feet into an abyss.
On Provo at Turtle Cove Landing, Flamingo Divers, (809) 946-4193 or (800) 204-9282, specializes in small groups, no more than 12 divers on a 30-foot boat. They schedule regular trips to the popular dive sites, including the plunging walls at North West Point, a 45-minute boat ride from Provo. Here, plumes of black coral trees and dark strands of deep-sea gorgonian decorate the Black Coral Forest. Colorful fish life abounds, especially at the Amphitheater. Shark Hotel is a good place to spot reef and black tip sharks and view a stand of pillar coral. The price is $60 for a two-tank dive, including weights, soft drinks and snacks. There are discounts for three or more days of diving.
Dive packages are also available at Provo's major hotels. Dive Provo, at the Turquoise Reef Resort and Casino, (800) 234-7768 or (809) 946-5040, has a new program that teaches divers how to identify fish. Divers attend a fish-watching seminar and later -- equipped with a reference book, chart, slate and waterproof notes -- search the reef. Their findings are sent to the Reef Environmental Education Foundation. The price is $50 a person. The progam is included in the resort's dive packages, which cost $484 a person for three nights and two days of diving. The resort's three-story hotel has 228 rooms, a few suites, an open-air lobby, a large pool and a small casino.
At the deluxe new Royal Bay Resort and Villas, (800) 822-3900, fax (305) 670-4948, on Provo, the dive/ water sports program includes help for beginners. The dive operator, Provo Aquatic Adventures, (800) 967-3483, fax (305) 351-9740, offers a $90 diving course that includes pool instruction and a guided open-water dive. The resort's 200 rooms, some in villa suites, have ocean views from private balconies, coffee makers and telephones with fax capability. Double room rates start at $210. Dive packages start at $709 a person, double occupancy, for four nights, with three diving days.
One of Turks and Caicos's marine species is being successfully farmed. After 10 years of research, the unusual Caicos Conch Farm last spring harvested its first crop: 70,000 pink-lipped shellfish. Situated on Provo's Leeward Channel, the farm, telephone and fax (809) 946-5849, raises the conch, which have been overfished, in tanks, pens and a pasture. Guides lead tours Monday to Saturday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tickets are $6.
 
 Virgin Gorda
British Virgin Islands Tourist Board, 370 Lexington Avenue, N.Y., New York 10017; (212) 696-0400
Like its neighbor Tortola, Virgin Gorda is a sailor's delight. Lying in clear, tranquil waters, the island has deluxe cruising grounds for people who prefer sailing with eyes glued to land.
The Baths in Devil's Bay National Park is the island's most popular attraction, though not the first choice of people who crave seclusion. Its shallow pools, caves and grottoes, formed by giant volcanic boulders, make it a fine place to swim and snorkel.
Most boat charter companies are based on Tortola, the most populated of the British Virgin Islands. But Virgin Gorda has a selection of bare boats -- yachts rented without a crew -- and an assortment of sea-oriented resorts.
Some resorts offer land-sea packages, such as the upscale Biras Creek with 32 suites and a two-bedroom villa, (800) 223-1108 or (809) 494-3555, fax (310) 440-4220. Built on a 140-acre peninsula, which can be reached only by boat, Biras Creek overlooks North Sound, a popular anchorage, protected by reefs and islands. The resort expects to reopen Jan. 19 after renovations and post-hurricane repairs by its new owner, who grew so fond of vacationing here he bought the place. Biras Creek's suites will have a new design, and Italian tiles will decorate the oceanfront pool; a new building will house an activities center with a conference room and library. Suites have furnished patios and private open-air garden showers. Hurricane Luis slowed the renovations by a month.
Little Dix Bay, the island's premier resort, also suffered some water damage during the hurricane. It has taken advantage of the need to close temporarily by undertaking a complete renovation, which will include new furniture. It will reopen on March 1.
The eight-day Sailaway package at Biras Creek includes a five-night hotel stay and two nights on a 45-foot crewed yacht sailing to other islands. The double rate starts at $3,775, with meals and the use of Boston Whalers, small sailboats and bicycles. A 17 percent tax and service charge is extra.
For people who like dropping anchor near a hotel, the Bitter End Yacht Club and Resort, (800) 872-2392, fax (312) 944-2860, with 100 rooms in 50 villas along a mile of waterfront at the north tip of Virgin Gorda, charters bare boats to experienced sailors. The resort's villas, built of natural wood, have thatched roofs and wrap-around porches. All rooms look out on the water. For a recently refurbished 30-foot Freedom, the weekly price for two is $3,360, including cleaning service, meals at the hotel and the use of a dock or one of 65 moorings in calm North Sound near the resort. The price is the same for seven nights in a hillside villa. The Bitter End adds a daily $12 service charge a person and the 7 percent tax. The price also includes unlimited use of a fleet of small sailboats, kayaks and Boston Whalers. Before sailing away, guests must pass an hour-and-a-half check-out sail with an expert. The seven-night room package includes an introductory sailing course or, for an extra $150 a person, a more intensive three-and-a-half-day course through the Nick Trotter Sailing School. The Bitter End rents its moorings to nonguests for $15 a night, including garbage pickup and a pre-dinner launch service.
Misty Isle Yacht Charters, (809) 495-5643, fax (809) 495-5300, charters four yachts and two power boats. Bare-boaters should make reservations three months in advance for the peak season. The weekly price for a 35-foot sailboat that sleeps four is $2,190; a 50-foot yacht that sleeps 10, $4,290. Additional charges include daily boat insurance of $20 plus a refundable security deposit. A British Virgin Islands cruising permit is $2 a person a day. A National Parks Trust fee for use of moorings is $10 a week for five people or fewer; $15 for eight or fewer. The company will provide a captain for $90 a day extra, plus provisions. A cook is $70 a day.
Among the sailing excursions, the Dogs is a group of islets and rocks with fine snorkeling northwest of Virgin Gorda. Because of possible swells, it's not a place to anchor overnight.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In: Black Rock;
A Bit of New England In a Troubled City

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
NINE days ago Bridgeport lost the battle to jump-start its economy when the Connecticut Senate refused to approve a gambling casino for the city. But in the process, its need for job development was vividly exposed.
The city's resilience in the face of some 40 years of economic and social decay, signaled by municipal recovery from the brink of bankruptcy in 1991 to a $4 million surplus in fiscal '95, as well as the state's resolve to assist in its future, continue to be reassuring to owners of the fine old homes in desirable neighborhoods that come as a surprise to those who only know the city because of its well-documented problems. 
 "It's a common misconception that Bridgeport is not on its feet now," said Charles Brilvitch, the city historian. "The turnpike goes through the worst part of the city, giving people the wrong impression. They don't see neighborhoods like Black Rock."
Black Rock is the city's wealthiest section, a peninsula bordering the Town of Fairfield. Named for the stony shore that some residents liken to Maine, Black Rock is physically separated from the rest of the city by the Connecticut Turnpike. Largely hilly and wooded, Black Rock is dense with venerable, spacious houses, dozens of them in historic districts and priced at little more than half the cost of similar homes on Fairfield County's Gold Coast.
Other positives include magnificent water views, convenient shopping in Fairfield, and a strong sense of community. But because it is a part of Bridgeport, many home buyers say no when real estate agents suggest Black Rock.
Negatives include Bridgeport's image, which some Black Rock residents sidestep by using Black Rock, not Bridgeport, as a home address; a public school system whose grade-school pupilsbarely reach the Connecticut Mastery Test's competency level and property taxes that are among the highest in the state. At the rate of $67.80 per thousand dollars of assessment, taxes on a house selling for $375,000 are $8,618.
None of that stopped David E. A. Carson, president and chief executive officer of the Bridgeport-based People's Bank, from moving to Black Rock from West Hartford 12 years ago. He chose a white colonial house in Black Rock even though he had his pick of any Gold Coast community. "We had just become empty-nesters, looking for not too big a house," Mr. Carson said. "This one met all our requirements, and it has a million-dollar view of the water." Weather permitting, he takes his racing shell out for morning rows in the harbor.
"Black Rock is the friendliest community we have ever lived in," he said.
Houses descend in size and price as they get closer to the turnpike and Bridgeport proper. "They are ideal for young families," said Joseph Formato, president of Century 21 Coastal Realty in Fairfield. While houses can be found for under $100,000, "there are no slums in Black Rock as in the rest of the city," Mr. Formato said.
T HE neighborhood does have the more than 400-unit P. T. Barnum subsidized low-income housing project on Wordin Avenue, which is now being completely renovated. The development is next to the Longfellow Elementary School. Black Rock children who do not attend Fairfield Country Day in Fairfield, Greens Farms Academy in Westport or other private schools outside Bridgeport go to Black Rock School for kindergarten through second grade, Longfellow for grades 3 through 8, and Bassick High School. Bridgeport has 44 public schools, almost 21,000 students and no junior highs.
"Our enrollment grew by 600 kids this year," said James A. Connelly, Superintendent of Schools, "which is typical of the past five years. A lot of them are immigrants."
S.A.T. scores are significantly below both state and national averages, but Mr. Connelly said that "we have three magnet schools in the elementary grades for literature, languages, math and science, and three more for the high school -- academic for advanced college placement, marine science and business."
St. Anne's, a pre-K through grade 8 parochial school in Black Rock, charges $1,750 a year. Citywide there are six Roman Catholic elementary schools and one high school.
"Black Rock buyers are not usually from outside the region," said Barbara Franzen, an agent with Prudential Connecticut Realty in Fairfield. "They come from Fairfield and Westport, want the water and are familiar with Black Rock as a uniquely beautiful waterfront enclave. There's very little for sale because people love it and don't move."
Love, however, is not the only reason for staying put. "Where would they go?" asked Mr. Brilvitch. "They might sell a fantastic house in Black Rock for $200,000, but what will that buy elsewhere?" The typical Black Rocker is childless or able to afford private schools, immune to Bridgeport-bashing, and in for the long haul.
David Grimshaw is one of a number of writers and artists who have been attracted to the neighborhood. Mr. Grimshaw, who moved in seven years ago, is president of the Black Rock Community Council, a group of about 600 families and businesses that, among other things, has upgraded the facades and sidewalks on Fairfield Avenue's commercial strip and converted a former residence for elderly women into the Burroughs Community Center. It also conducts ongoing discussions about seceding from Bridgeport.
"We pay very high taxes, commensurate with the higher prices of our homes compared with the rest of Bridgeport," said Mr. Grimshaw, "and we feel that our tax dollars are spent in other parts of the city more than here."
Black Rock could attempt to become an independent community, or rejoin the Town of Fairfield, from which it was annexed to Bridgeport in 1870. "We would need state and city approval," said Mr. Grimshaw, indicating that it would be a highly adversarial procedure. Connecticut has no mechanism for dealing with secession.
Black Rock's relationship with Fairfield began in 1681, when the Unquowa Indians of Black Rock sold their land to the Town of Fairfield. For the next 140 years Black Rock flourished as a port, but the hurricane of 1821 blew away a protective island land mass and sent shippers scurrying to safety in Bridgeport Harbor -- the second deepest in the state after New London.
In 1836 Bridgeport incorporated as a city, and by 1870 it was a thriving industrial hub looking to annex Black Rock to develop it residentially for Bridgeport's industrial tycoons. Black Rock's landowners gladly accepted the annexation, sold off parcels at prime prices and got the city to build them some new roads.
An aura of wealth and good times expanded when, in 1874, George Wells built the George Hotel, a 400-room waterfront resort on Grover Hill. The Bridgeport Yacht Club opened in 1895, and Black Rock Harbor blossomed as a boating center.
"By the beginning of the 20th century Victorian hotels were going out of style," said Mr. Brilvitch, "and the George Hotel land was more valuable as house lots, so it was torn down in 1902. Redeveloped residentially through the 1920's, the area was typical of so-called high class developments -- there were restrictive covenants against Jews" -- which could explain why there are several denominations of churches in Black Rock reflecting waves of Swedish, Hungarian, Irish and Italian immigration, but no synagogues, although they exist elsewhere in the city.
THE Black Rock Yacht Club, opened in 1926, took in 30 members this year, according to Dr. Arthur Samuelson, admissions chairman. Limited in number to 250, members pay initiation fees of $3,500 and annual dues of around $1,350. The club has two tennis courts, a pool, restaurant, and about 80 moorings. There are no slips, because "we are wide open to southwest seas and wind," said Dr. Samuelson.
The Fayerweather Yacht Club, formed in 1919, has almost 1,000 members, 125 moorings, a restaurant, and only a two-month waiting list. Initiation costs $500 and dues are $175 a year.
One of Connecticut's major seasonal tourist attractions, Captain's Cove Seaport, is on Black Rock Harbor. It offers full marina services, a 500-seat dining room, craft shops, entertainment, a fish market, and tours of the H.M.S. Rose, a replica of an 18th century British frigate.
Bridgeport residents need only a $5 parking sticker to be admitted to several public recreation areas, including the beach at Seaside Park, tennis at Glenwood Park, and Beardsley Park, which was designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and contains a zoo and carousel. The municipal 36-hole Fairchild-Wheeler Golf Course charges $5 a day in addition to the sticker. Black Rock's sole public park is St. Mary's by the Sea Wildlife Refuge.
A sampling of restaurants includes Black Rock Castle, an Irish pub filled with Celtic music and the aroma of shepherd's pie. The Blood Root Restaurant and Feminist Bookstore is vegetarian, sells books, and caters mostly to women, "but a certain kind of man feels comfortable here," said Selma Miriam, an owner. Home on the Range serves breakfast and lunch, but at 6 P.M. switches to dinners to go. Grilled lamb with roasted vegetables and couscous costs $9.
Cultural attractions in downtown Bridgeport include the Greater Bridgeport Symphony Orchestra, the Barnum Museum -- dedicated to Bridgeport's circus impresario and onetime Mayor -- and the Discovery Museum for children.
"Black Rock's socio-economic life has remained stable in spite of Bridgeport's ups and downs," observed Jack Collins, third-generation owner of the Collins Pharmacy on Fairfield Avenue. "It's one of the few places in Fairfield County where young adults can afford to live where they were born."

FOR THE BIRDS: In the late 1960's a large fir tree in Black Rock provided shelter for four South American parakeets that escaped from a crate at Kennedy International Airport. Before it blew down in a storm a few years later the tree housed 25 nests harboring up to 300 birds that eventually ranged up and down the East Coast. Today, hundreds of the bright green birds remain in Black Rock, nesting each year to the delight of visiting bird-watchers and picture-takers. Residents, often upset by the birds' raucous screeching, say they have not had the heart to implement a program devised to eradicate the birds.

HEADLINE: Women Recovering From Compulsive Gambling, Step by Step

BYLINE: By MARY REINHOLZ 

 BODY:
ON a recent Friday evening five women gathered at a wooded psychiatric complex not far from the bright signs off Sunrise Highway and Route 110 in Amityville. After a ritual reading of a 12-step program's goals and purposes, they began speaking quietly of their compulsion.
One by one they described how gambling in its myriad forms became a habit at church-sponsored bingo parlors; at bars with the state's new video keno game, Quick Draw, or at candy stores and supermarkets, where they bought instant lottery tickets. 
 "Gambling was in my family, whether it was bingo or horses or numbers," said Alice M., 54, of Selden, a one-time compulsive blackjack player who organized the first "women's room" of Long Island Gamblers Anonymous with Pat J. of Farmingdale.
Pat J., also 54, calls herself "a compulsive bingo player" who dabbled in horses and played the slot machines in Atlantic City and Las Vegas. She has not gambled "for two and half years."
The group, which began meeting on Oct. 13, meets on Fridays at 7 P.M. in Robbins Hall on the 83-acre grounds of South Oaks Hospital, a center for treating addictions. The hospital donated space for the group because it is a host for recovery programs, said Dr. Sheila B. Blume, a psychiatrist who is medical director of the alcoholism, chemical-dependency and compulsive-gambling programs.
Dr. Blume added that women in Gamblers Anonymous across the country have had difficult times in establishing "permanent core groups," largely because men who are identified as compulsive gamblers outnumber women 2 to 1.
"Men are mostly addicted to gambling," Alice said. "But more women are getting into it now, because it's become the thing to do and is so easily accessible. All you have to do is look at the buses going to Atlantic City."
She and Pat J. decided that the time was right to start a group because women had complained that they would be "intimidated" in meetings that men dominated, they said.
"Gamblers Anonymous was started 38 years ago, but it is still geared toward middle-aged married men," except in areas like Las Vegas, said Judy L., 35, an unemployed legal secretary who took a train from Brooklyn for the third meeting in Amityville, on Oct. 27.
Judy is single and has tried unsuccessfully to start Gamblers Anonymous groups for women in New York City, she said, adding that last year she spent $35,000 on gambling from the sale of her late parents' house to play mostly "card games" in her neighborhood, in Atlantic City and aboard cruise ships. "It was the excitement, the glamour, the feeling of being a big shot," Judy said. "I'd get a rush being at a table surrounded by men and sometimes beating them at their own game."
Judy said after the meeting that she has been in debt to loansharks and had started gambling as a teenager, "because I was unhappy at home." She has been alternating between periods of abstinence and binges since joining Gamblers Anonymous 12 years ago and sporadically attending meetings. Lately, she said, she has been going to meetings in Rockville Centre and Bohemia.
"I haven't gambled for 47 days," she told the group.
Micki, in her 60's, pronounced herself "abstinent since Oct. 12," after years of compulsively playing Lotto and, more recently, Quick Draw.
"I was still playing it when keno came out," Micki said. "It's in the bowling alley where I go in Suffolk. Now I see girls going into bars to play, and guys' pushing and promoting Quick Draw and keno, which I now call electronic crack. And I want to tell them, 'Stop, don't get into it.' "
Dr. Blume said she strongly supported the group, noting that one-tenth of the compulsive gamblers receiving help are women. "Most of the people in G.A. are high rollers who have incurred debts in the hundreds of thousands of dollars," she said. "Most women don't have that kind of money. Most are bingo players. They may play six nights a week, using up their retirement funds and pensions, not buying new clothes and eating minimally. But they are not usually reached by G.A., although they fit the diagnostic criteria for compulsive gambling."
The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of the American Psychiatric Association lists compulsive gambling as an impulse-control disorder. In advanced stages, it includes returning to gamble after a loss to "get even" or to "chase losses," and committing crimes like forgery, theft and embezzlement. Exact figures are hard to come by, Dr. Blume said, but she estimated the percentage of compulsive gamblers at 1.5 to 3.0 percent of adults, "with an unknown number of teen-agers."
Rachel Volberg, a sociologist and president of Gemini Research in Roaring Spring, Pa., specializes in studying gambling. Ms. Volberg said it would "overstate the issue" to picture all pathological gamblers as white-collar criminals.
She said gambling more commonly affected gamblers' families and workplaces.
Ms. Volberg also disputed the idea that female compulsive gamblers were mainly bingo players. She said gambling patterns had changed in the 1990's. In some regions, she added, the ratio of compulsive gamblers ranges from "10 men to 6 women."
An even greater number of problem gamblers do not meet the "clinical diagnosis for pathological gambling," Ms. Volberg said, adding:
"Women are involved in many forms of gambling, slot machines, some of the table games. Women are often more comfortable playing blackjack than poker. And they are definitely into what's been euphemistically called gaming videos, or video-lottery terminals, video poker, video keno and blackjack. The gaming machines appear to be more dangerous in terms of the number of people who get into trouble with them."
Dr. Blume said two general groups become addicted to gambling, "the action seekers, often men, and the escape seekers, who are more often women."
"Men are more likely to start as winners," she said, "while women are more likely to start gambling at a time of difficulty in their lives such as an abusive relationship, and gamble as an escape.
Compulsive gambling will increase "until our policy makers admit there's a problem, even though that gets in the way of their looking to gambling to generate revenues without taxation," Dr. Blume said.
Alice, a former bookkeeper who suffers from chronic depression and alcoholism, said she began gambling in hopes of making extra money after her marriage broke up in 1978. She played bingo five nights a week and went to play the slot machines in Atlantic City, she said, adding:
"Toward the end I got into blackjack. I would stay at the tables for 28 hours and go to work in the morning. It got to the point where I would lose my paycheck and couldn't pay my bills. But I lost most of my money on the Cash 3 and Pick 4 numbers games of the New York State Lottery. I kept figuring the next time I'd win. You look at the idea that your luck is going to change."
In 1993, Alice, who now receives welfare, spent 28 days at South Oaks. She had therapy and attended Gamblers Anonymous meetings.
Lloyd A., chairman of the Long Island Intergroup of Gamblers Anonymous, a business group, welcomed the women's group. "Only six or seven women" attended the 30 or so mixed meetings a week that the organization sponsors in Nassau and Suffolk for 600 members, he said.
"I don't know why," Lloyd said. "Maybe they're not admitting it. It's an easy disease to hide. But more women across the country are coming into the program, and a lot more today are becoming trustees."
Modeled after Alcoholics Anonymous, Gamblers Anonymous was founded in Los Angeles in 1957 and now has 12,000 members worldwide, said Karen H.
Karen, an international executive secretary, was "one of two women" when she attended her first meeting in Los Angeles 10 years ago, she said, and she is now the "only woman" in her regular support group there. "But I don't see that as a problem," Karen said. "People will use any excuse to go back to gambling such as there are too many guys and not enough women."
Others contend that female gamblers' groups, like women's groups in Alcoholics Anonymous, address special needs. "It's been difficult for women to feel comfortable or accepted, especially in rooms where there are high rollers and businessmen who spend thousands of dollars with a throw of the dice," said Valerie Lorenz, executive director of the Compulsive Gambling Center in Baltimore. It is host to residential 12-step programs where women sometimes outnumber men.
Ms. Lorenz said she often became involved in court cases to obtain reduced sentences for compulsive gamblers charged with crimes like forgery and embezzlement. She said female gamblers generally tended to commit lesser offenses like passing bad checks, although one woman from New York for whom she helped to obtain a reduced sentence, a 41-year-old former bookkeeper, embezzled $265,000 from her former employer over two years to support her gambling. She tried to commit suicide three times while facing Federal charges in 1993, Ms. Lorenz said.
The woman, Susan F., was released on probation last month, after having served an 18-month sentence, with 6 in prison and 12 in treatment.
"It was at the joker poker machines in my neighborhood where I went over the edge," Susan said. "You can lose anywhere from $600 to $1,000 in the blink of an eye. Most of the time I gambled knowing I wasn't going to win. Most people gamble out of boredom or because of problems at home. They're looking for a dream world. Gambling doesn't do the physical damage of alcoholism. But the psychological effects are devastating. What you're doing basically is playing Russian roulette with your life."
Information on the new group is available from Alice M. at 698-6936.

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Volkswagen Golf GL;
Born in Mexico of German Stock

BYLINE: By LEONARD M. APCAR 

 BODY:
STOPPED at an intersection the other day, I came face to face with an immaculate little Volkswagen Beetle, the kind you used to see everywhere and hardly ever see now. I pointed it out to my children as if it were a museum piece on wheels.
It is hard to believe it has been 25 years since Volkswagen's heyday in America. In its prime, the Beetle outsold the best-selling cars of today, like the Ford Taurus and the Honda Accord. 
 VW likes to brag that it is still the best-selling European make in the United States, but its sales are about a fifth of what they once were. There are so many more competitors now. But even when Volkswagen had the market at its fender and demand for small cars soared, the company lost ground. The Japanese simply offered more stylish, more sturdy and better-equipped small cars -- and sold them for less.
One often-forgotten fact is that VW was the first foreign auto maker to build cars in this country in recent years. In a bid to prove that it was serious about the United States car market, and fighting the effects of a rising German mark, it moved into a building in Pennsylvania that Chrysler had never used.
But by 1987, the factory was closed. Customers had whispered about differences in the quality of German-made models compared with those assembled in America. Sales continued to sink.
Then, three years ago, just as VW was ushering in restyled 1993-model Golfs and Jettas, labor and manufacturing troubles struck its assembly plant in Mexico, by then its chief source of cars for North America. The problems cut off shipments to the United States for months, and the industry all but wrote off Volkswagen in America.
I, too, hadn't thought much about VW until a group of us rented a dark blue, sparsely equipped Golf in Europe this year and drove it more than 1,400 miles in a week on both the country roads and high-speed routes of France and Italy. The company considers the car's 1.8-liter engine, with 75 horsepower, too anemic for America, but it delivered solid performance with a five-speed manual gearbox. The car was responsive in shifting, steering, braking and acceleration.
Inside, wind noise was remarkably moderate for a small car, the seats were surprisingly comfortable and leg room was more than adequate for adults. The hatchback's cargo bay -- which is larger than some full-sized trunks -- swallowed everything the three of us had. I cannot recall hearing even a rattle. (And this from a rental car.)
Could a Volkswagen built in Mexico for Americans be this smooth?
After driving a nearly identical 1995 Golf GL, the answer is yes. There are noticeable differences between the German-made Golf and its North American cousin -- mostly for the benefit of Americans' tastes. But Mexican labor did not come up short in the quality of assembly. Doors and trim fitted nicely on the pearl red metallic test car, which felt solid and handled smoothly. Compared with Japanese makes, however, like the Toyota Corolla and the Honda Civic, VW's quality is still lagging, according to surveys of owners by J. D. Power & Associates.
In this price bracket, the Japanese make supremely competent cars, of course. What VW offers is, at its heart, a quintessentially German car: chracteristically Teutonic in its decor and a bit rowdy under the hood. At $13,575, the base-model GL is pretty complete. Anti-lock brakes are a $775 option; a sunroof costs $590 and an automatic transmission is $875. The Golf GL is now sold in America only as a four-door hatchback; the popular Jetta is essentially a Golf with a trunk.
In the past, VW was criticized for designing one car and selling it virtually unchanged around the world. But for American tastes, the Golf sold here had cup holders (Ach du Liebe! These Americans actually drink in their cars?), a fancier audio system with more speakers and a throaty bass, a larger four-cylinder engine, a center console with a lockable storage bin and a convenient button to pop open the hatch.
There are also three significant touches on the American car that are not found on most of VW's rivals. One is a standard-equipment security system that sets off an alarm and disables the engine if anyone tampers with the ignition, doors, hood, hatch or radio. One reason for the system is to help reduce the cost of owning a VW. For years, certain models were costly to insure because they were so frequently stolen.
There is also a standard power lock system that allows you to lock or unlock one door or all four doors and the hatch from either of the two front doors. With the turn of a key, the system also sets the car alarm and a tiny red light flashes -- accompanied by a toot of the horn -- to indicate that the car is buttoned up and the alarm is on.
And finally there were daytime running lights, a safety feature that is spreading to more and more cars in an effort to make them more visible and reduce collisions. Anytime the ignition is on, both front and rear lights are lit. One drawback is that the device is so new that well-meaning folks will stop to tell you that your lights are on. One benefit is that as of January, New York law requires auto insurance companies to provide premium discounts for all vehicles equipped with the feature.
The Golf's 1995 instrument panel was well laid out except for two goofs. With a passenger-side air bag there was no room for a glove box, even though the European version had dual air bags, a glove box and storage shelfs under the dash. The cup holders on the version sold here, clearly a grudging concession by German stylists who wouldn't think of sipping coffee in a car, blocked access to a small storage cubby. The center console and the wide side pockets in the front doors, with thoughtful removable liners, only partly compensated for the missing glove compartment. (On 1996 models, VW found a way keep all the other features and carve out a glove box.)
To serious German car designers who value performance and simplicity, the bows to American taste must seem like pandering. But Volkswagen is trying mightily to mount a comeback in America and there are results: its sales are up smartly; its products are appealing, and the quality is improving. The company is even preparing to bring back a successor to the Beetle, the Concept 1, restyled with 90's flare. That should arrive by the year 2000, about 50 years after the first Volkswagen came to America. By then, the Beetle may truly be an antique.

INSIDE TRACK: A feisty German alternative to cool Japanese efficiency.
