HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By DAVID RAMPE 

 BODY:

PLEASANT SURPRISE
 
Exports Whittle the Deficit
Exports spurted ahead in September, cutting the trade deficit to the lowest level of the year. The deficit with Japan narrowed for the sixth month in a row, and the one with China, which was getting worrisome, also contracted. The strong exports suggest that third-quarter economic growth will come in well above expectations. If the export trend continues next year, it could drive the economy into its fifth year of expansion. Exports rose by $1 billion in September; a rule of thumb is that $1 billion of exports keeps nearly 20,000 Americans at work.
 
BUDGET SHOWDOWN
 
The Government Reopens
Government workers streamed back to work after a six-day shutdown, but they may stream out again next month. Congress and the White House reopened the Government by patching up their differences and agreeing on spending only through Dec. 15. But that merely delayed an all-out debate on taxes and spending. Meanwhile, the shutdown cost the Government $700 million or more, largely to pay Government workers for lost work, the White House said. Tourists at least were pleased that national landmarks reopened.
 
GAMBLING
 
Casinos Lose, Too
Gambling has exploded into a $482 billion economy, but casinos sometimes find themselves on a bumpy ride. Harrah's Jazz Company, which was seen as something of an economic angel in New Orleans, abruptly suspended construction of what would have been one of the biggest casinos in the world and filed for bankruptcy protection. Far from creating jobs, the company laid off 2,500 casino employees. And Hilton Hotels, which planned to split up its hotel and casino operations into separate companies, waffled about its intentions after its president, who had been a lawyer in Nevada, quit. Barron Hilton, the chairman of the company, was quoted as saying that in thinking about a spinoff, he had "an open mind" and saw several "pros and cons."
 
EASTERN EUROPE
 
Ex-Communist Ruler in Poland
Poland is getting a new president, an ex-Communist, but economic policy is not likely to veer much. Aleksander Kwasniewski, a Communist-turned-social democrat, won the election over Lech Walesa, gathering 52 percent of the vote. That would have disturbed investors once, but a former Communist has served as Prime Minister, and the economy is headed for its fourth year of robust growth. Foreign investment is flowing in unabated. Mr. Kwasniewski promises to continue market-oriented policies.
 
CHRYSLER'S DRAMATICS
 
An Opening for Kerkorian
The friction continues at Chrysler, at which Kirk Kerkorian appears to be in a good position to put an ally on the board. An opportunity opened up when Joseph E. Antonini, the former head of Kmart, quit the auto maker's board, saying he was influenced by the controversy between Mr. Kerkorian, Chrysler's second-largest shareholder and leading critic, and the board. The resignation sent up Chrysler's stock.
 
AIRCRAFT
 
Down Time at Boeing
Striking workers at Boeing dug in their heels and voted to continue their walkout, now in its eighth week. They decisively rejected a contract offer that union leadership had unanimously recommended. The longer the strike goes on in the fourth quarter, the worse Boeing earnings will be hit. So analysts are busy cutting earnings estimates, and even preparing for a loss. But the strike only delays production, so Boeing should make up the ground later. When the 32,000 striking workers do return, there will be plenty of work to do. Earlier this month, Boeing got $12.7 billion in orders for 77 planes from Singapore Airlines.
 
MULTIMEDIA
 
From the Desk of Bill Gates
Another month, another media blitz for Bill Gates. This time it's for his book, "The Road Ahead," which comes complete with a CD-ROM. Viking is spending $1 million to promote the book, its lead title this fall. "We don't take anything for granted," says a Microsoft executive who is involved in the project. Mr. Gates received a $2.5 million advance for the book and money from subsidiary rights sales. Proceeds from the sale of the $29.95 book are to be donated to help finance technology in classrooms.
 
MOVIES
 
'Toy Story,' Chapter One
Mr. Potato Head is one of the familiar old faces in Disney's "Toy Story," but otherwise the computer-animated film shows off the best in up-to-the-minute Hollywood technology. The film, which opened this week, also inaugurated what is sure to be a mind-boggling marketing blitz. Disney itself is spending an estimated $20 million on promotion, and enlisted advertiser partners like Frito-Lay and Burger King to spend additional $125 million on their own promotional ploys. That marketing force, plus deliriously favorable reviews, could make "Toy Story" the hit of the holiday season. Burger King alone plans to distribute 35 million figurines and 15 million puppets based on Woody, Buzz and other stars of the show.
 
LAW
 
The Plaintiffs Wins -$89.14
It used to be that class-action suits often would end with plaintiffs winning small awards, and their lawyers walking away with millions of dollars in fees. But homeowners who took out mortgages from the Bank of Boston discovered a new twist. In the case of Dexter J. Kamilewicz, he spotted a $91.33 charge from his escrow account for lawyers, and got $2.19 in back interest. And to boot, he never knew he was part of class action represented by lawyers. Now the matter is back in court, and Congress is noticing. One bill to be introduced would protect plaintiffs, rather than defendants, against the excesses of lawyers.
 
ACADEMIA
 
Move Over, Cliff's Notes
Computers have obviously made a big mark on campus. One of the latest inroads lets students buy ready-made term papers, in the few minutes it takes to thumb through a catalogue, pick up a phone and read off their credit-card and fax numbers. A typical eight-page paper already on file costs about $50, while custom research goes for $200. There is even a CD-ROM available with abstracts of paper for sale. Companies in the budding industry profess that the papers are meant strictly for research, and certainly not for plagiarism. "That's absolutely, positively forbidden," says the head of one term-paper service. One student says the service responds to that well-known "worried feeling, when you'd have a 10-page paper due, and you haven't done anything for it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: THE MARKETS -- The Dow Vaults Higher and Makes It All Look Easy -- The Dow surpassed 5,000, only nine months after passing 4,000 for the first time. The average has soared 31 percent so far this year, thriving in a climate of falling interest rates, quiet inflation, rising profits and a flood of money going into stock mutual funds. (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section 4; Page 10; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 387 words

HEADLINE: Safer Streets? We'll See

 BODY:
New York City is embarking on a new era of traffic control. Police officers are replacing civilian agents at busy intersections. Helicopters prowl the skies in search of the dreaded gridlock. Soon, the Department of Transportation will unveil a plan to clean up "high-fatality" areas like Columbus Circle and Queens Boulevard. Most of these ideas have been tried before, which does not mean they are not worth revisiting.
The police surrendered the job of directing traffic to civilian agents in the 1970's as an economy move. Now many civilian jobs have been eliminated, also as an economy move, and the police are back. The battle against gridlock has actually been a long guerrilla war, in which the city alternately threatens, punishes and bribes motorists to keep them from blocking intersections between lights. 
 The city has been promising to target "high-fatality areas" since 1899, when a realtor named Henry Bliss became the first person ever to be run over by a horseless carriage. New Yorkers will not be surprised to hear that the car was a cab.
The latest traffic reform initiative will depend on what Transportation Commissioner Elliot Sander calls a "marriage" between his department and the police. The divorce rate in these ventures tends to be astronomical. But Mr. Sander says the two bureaucracies have been cooperating well on everything from improving traffic flow to enforcing anti-dumping regulations.
Critics on the New York City Council claim the new traffic control plan does not pay enough attention to pedestrian misbehavior. The Brooklyn Democrat Noach Dear, head of the Council's transportation committee, is calling for an anti-jaywalk initiative. This is not the first, or even the 20th time that a politician has demanded that officials do something about the local citizenry's tendency to walk wherever they feel like walking.
But after a century of complaints, the city has not yet managed even to make most jaywalking illegal. In New York City, crossing at the corner on a red light is indeed a crime. But crossing in the middle of the block is simply a colorful local custom. Even Mr. Dear does not want the police ticketing every pedestrian-voter who walks on red, no matter how far it might go toward balancing the city budget. He prefers an education campaign.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING;
No Centennial Hoopla in This Sport

BYLINE: By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
A century ago this Thanksgiving Day, the molecules that produced motorsports' amoebic event -- six cars, a race course and a sponsor -- came together along the lake front in Chicago.
The first automobile race in the United States was won by Frank Duryea in a car that he and his brother, Charles, had built. That contest -- 54 miles from Jackson Park to Evanston, Ill., and back again in snow and freezing temperatures -- took more than 10 hours to complete. 
 Pace laps run faster than that nowadays, but even a century ago, racing had its sales-pitch component up to speed. Everyone involved was hawking something. The Duryeas were promoting their horseless carriages; R. H. Macy, which also sold cars back then, entered a German-made Benz and would have won had its driver not hit a trolley and a sleigh. And The Chicago Times-Herald, the race sponsor, wanted to create an event to sell newspapers -- the forerunner of made-for-TV sports.
The National Football League and Major League Baseball are great at throwing birthday parties. Auto racing is not so great at it, which in itself can tell you something about its history.
You probably could have guessed that Americans have been racing automobiles for 100 years or so. It's a sport that didn't need a Dr. Naismith, just two cars -- at which point it was as inevitable as the first traffic accident.
Besides, centennials of this sort too often turn self-important or gassy or both (see Ken Burns, parts I through IX). And in dealing with an activity that has compiled a human casualty count at least into four figures, maybe too much retrospection is not to be encouraged.
No peril of that with auto racing, though, because few running it seem in much of a commemorative mood. The ruling powers celebrated this 100th milestone in their own fashion -- speeding past it like a blown pit stop signal. They were so good at ignoring it, they even passed up a chance to make money off of it.
Leo Levine, whose excellent 1968 tome, "Ford: the Dust and the Glory," currently brings $500 for a first printing, a few years back decided that this centennial thing was a sure-fire marketing missile. So he drew up a logo and went looking for partners to join him in licensing ventures.
Levine is now batting .500 as a for-profit historian. The city of Chicago expressed some interest, he said, and one foreign automaker chipped in a few dollars. But the sanctioning bodies? Levine couldn't get a nibble.
While other sports have de facto caretakers for their history and tradition -- football has the N.F.L. and the National Collegiate Athletic Association; golf, the United States Golf Association -- auto racing has always been so loosely confederated that none of its several sanctioning bodies (most of which came into being after World War II) can claim the role. Not that any of them seem eager to claim it, of course.
The group that comes closest is Nascar, one of the most successful sanctioning organization in the United States. But racing's version of George Halas, Bill France Sr., did not arrive until the late 1940's. France, in forming Nascar, brought order to the chaos of stock car racing, where previously all you needed to collect the winner's share of a race promoter's purse was a faster car and a small firearm.
From organizing the races along the sands of Daytona Beach, Fla., France's group has grown into an empire that reaches all the way down to dozens of local short-track racing programs. Now, it turns out they are too busy to celebrate.
"With all the racing series we're running nowadays, there really isn't a lot of time left over to set up something like that," Kevin Triplett, a Nascar spokesman, said apologetically when asked why Nascar failed to note the centennial.
Nascar's newest creation, the SuperTrucks, symbolize another factor tending to blur racing's view of its past. No other sport save yachting is so sharply defined by technology, and the wheel (competitively speaking) must be constantly reinvented for reasons relating to safety, economics and popularity.
The SuperTrucks drew sellout crowds almost everywhere this year in their inaugural season, and CBS has already doubled the number of truck races it will televise next year, from two to four. The SuperTruck, Nascar's child prodigy, is the offspring of demographics (more and more Americans own utility vehicles) and television (truck events rarely exceed 90 minutes, and are split by that old racing tradition, a "halftime").
But as soon as they become too expensive or not popular enough, the SuperTrucks will be put into the crusher and recast. In just 100 years, economic Darwinism has seen Duryea's carriage evolve into dozens of subspecies -- dragsters, monster trucks, off-road racers, midgets, sprinters, Indy racers -- while dozens more have become extinct.
It has kept the sport thriving, but it also dulls one's sense of history when the equipment and the playing fields keep changing.
Only CART, literally the adolescent among major sanctioning groups in the United States, bothered to come up with a centennial logo and dedicate a page in its press guide to The Chicago Times-Herald race.
Speaking of that newspaper, that's probably why this centennial thing never got out of the garage: no sponsor. A real symbolic one would do. How about calling the first century the Hooters 100?

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bill France Sr., the man who brought organization to stock car racing by forming Nascar, at one of his early beach races in Daytona Beach, Fla. (ISC/Nascar)

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1520 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: 570 Lexington Avenue;
The Aura Is of Another Era -- But So Is the Space

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IT is said so often, it is practically a mantra: There are not enough large blocks of contiguous space available in good midtown buildings. It is why some developers are ready to put up new buildings, why landlords are tightening up on concession packages, why would-be subletters are ratcheting up rents on big chunks of excess space.
But landlords with a plethora of small spaces are in no such catbird seat. According to ReLocate, which tracks vacancies, there are 488 spaces of 5,000 to 20,000 square feet available in Class A buildings between 50th and 59th Street alone. Add in available sublets, and there are 604 spaces looking for tenants. 
 On the surface, that should spell glum news for 570 Lexington Avenue, that 50-story landmarked bastion of tiny spaces that has just come back on the market. Although the 51st Street building served for decades as headquarters of the mammoth General Electric Company, by today's standards its small floors -- about 17,000 square feet in the base and 3,000 square feet in the tower -- are unlikely to lure any major corporation.
"Our floor plates are below even the bare minumum for a big company," said David R. Greenbaum, president of the Mendik Company, the building's managing partner.
And yet, Mr. Greenbaum and his colleagues exude optimism. Mendik and Quantum Realty Partners, which together own half of the building (Columbia University owns the other half), are pumping $40 million into renovating and marketing it. And they have been spurning drugstores, apparel stores and other would-be tenants for the building's retail space, in hopes of landing, say, a white-tablecloth restaurant.
"We could have rented the retail space six times over, but we are holding out for the right use," said Mr. Greenbaum. And what, exactly, would that use be? "An elegant store that would fit in with the types of office tenants that don't want to be in a plain vanilla, glass curtain-wall building." And what are the chances of snagging such tenants? "We expect to be fully leased in less than 15 months."
The jazzy Art Deco building does have many things going for it. It has visiblity -- indeed, the Landmarks Preservation Commission once called it "one of the most expressive skyscrapers of its era." It is right by the 51st Street subway station and a few blocks from what will soon be the northern entrance to Grand Central Terminal.
ITS tight security system, based on magnetic-stripe cards that allow only authorized people to use the elevators, is a plus, as are the individual air-conditioning controls on each floor. And, Mendik is asking annual rents in the $30's-per-square-foot for the lower floors, and in the mid-$40's for the towers -- rents that, many brokers say, are barely market rate for the area.
Still, the building has formidable drawbacks. It is ridden with columns, and its floor-to-ceiling heights could never support the dropped ceilings or raised floors that high-technology users need. And, convenient as it may be, Lexington Avenue and 51st Street is simply not as prestigious an address as, say, 712 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street, or Carnegie Hall Tower, at 152 West 57th Street, both known for small spaces and high-profile tenants.
"The street is a problem," said Robert L. Billingsley, an executive vice president of the Colliers ABR brokerage. "It is noisy, it is congested, and it simply does not have the cachet of Park or Fifth."
Apparently, some tenants do not care. Mr. Greenbaum says he has nine deals, covering about a quarter of the building's 435,000 square feet, ready for signing. The first tenant, the law firm of Seiden, Stempel & Bennett, will move into about 6,000 square feet on the 14th floor in December.
"The ownership is stable, the building is convenient to the courts, our view is great, and we're not stuck with all that windowless interior space that you get on a big floor," said Jay Gordon Seiden, a partner.
The building also may have timing on its side. The recovering economy has meant more new small companies, more big companies looking to open small branches in midtown, and more law and accounting firms looking for elegant homes.
"This building is hitting a seam in the market," said Peter R. Friedman, who heads his own brokerage. "Once it gains momentum, it will easily fill up."
Indeed, Mendik is hoping that, if just a few prestige tenants sign on, the deluge will come. For now, its marketing program stresses the appeal of occupying an entire floor in a restored landmark, and of tower floors where elevators open directly into the space, much as in an elegant penthouse.
But once the leasing ball starts rolling, Mendik plans to rely heavily on ads that simply superimpose the names of new tenants on a silhouette of the building. The expectation is that those tenants will have even more drawing power than the building.
Brokers say the approach could work. "People with big egos, who don't want to be a tiny tenant on someone else's large floor, and people who want views, they're going to love this building," said Jeffrey A. Lichtenberg, executive managing director of the Edward S. Gordon Company.
IT seems a rosy prospect for a building that, but two years ago, seemed to have a quite different destiny. Built in the early 30's as a headquarters for the Radio Corporation of America, the building quickly became the main New York home for G.E., one of RCA's owners. But in 1974 G.E. moved its headquarters to Fairfield, Conn., and the building began emptying out.
G.E. did not abandon the building. In the mid-80's it spent $20 million to restore the building's lavish marble and metal fixtures and orange-brick facade. And in 1985 the building, with its signature crown of lacy radio-wave figures, got landmark status.
Still, G.E. continued to move its people out. By the 90's, two-thirds of the building was vacant. So in 1993, preferring a tax deduction to the deed on empty space, G.E. donated the building, then valued at $40 million, to Columbia University.
At first, Columbia, whose Morningside Heights campus was reaching saturation, talked about holding classes, seminars and cultural programs in the building. It even talked of turning part of it into a Columbia Club, complete with overnight rooms, squash courts and dining facilities.
Instead, scarcely a year after taking title, Columbia negotiated a deal with the Mendik/Quantum partnership to renovate and market the building. Columbia executives remain mum about their reasons, but Mr. Greenbaum theorizes that they were responding to the nascent economic recovery.
"They decided this was an asset whose potential should be maximized," he said.
Mendik and Quantum, which is operated by the financier George Soros, are similarly mum about the division of duties and equity involvement. But it is clear that Quantum has supplied most of the capital, Mendik is providing the sweat equity and Columbia, which retains 50 percent of the building, remains a passive investor.
The partnership has done some mid-course strategic corrections of its own. For a time, it talked of turning the tower floors into condominiums, and building an entrance on 51st Street for the residential tenants. It scotched that plan because "the upfront investment seemed too steep," said Bernard H. Mendik, Mendik's chairman.
So the partnership is spending its money on restoring the building to its former gleam. It has stripped away metallic paint and dropped ceilings, thus uncovering original aluminum fixtures and a vaulted ceiling vestibule. It has commissioned look-alike floor tiles and marble pieces to replace old ones that had worn down or cracked, and it is buffing up the metal G.E. clock on the 51st Street corner wall.
It has even added a few things that the original architects, Cross & Cross, had designed but that were never installed. "The chandeliers in the lobby, the metal grillwork in the back wall, it's all new, but it follows the first building plans," said Mr. Mendik. "In the height of the Depression, people just ran out of money, I guess."
And, of course, there are some added fillips as well. There are sconces on the facade now, and back lighting behind old fixtures in the elevator cabs. An old reception area south of the Lexington Avenue entrance is now a 2,300-square-foot store looking for a tenant. Mendik even redesigned the subway entrance on the corner.
THE partnership is in a good position to pay for all the work. The building is debt-free, and both Mendik and Quantum are in sound fiscal health. And G.E. continues to pay rent on about 40 percent of the building's space through the end of 1996.
Now all that remains is getting a good buzz circulating about the building. On Oct. 17 the partnership held a cocktail party in the lobby. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Jennifer Rabb, chairwoman of the Landmarks Preservation Commission, came, and so did several hundred brokers.
"For the last 20 years, unless you were doing business with G.E., you had no reason to ever visit this building," Mr. Greenbaum said. "Now we're ready to reintroduce it to the community."

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Artistry and Invention Seamlessly Joined

BYLINE: By RITA REIF 

 BODY:
IN THE WORLD OF WEAVERS, Lenore Tawney is almost legendary. During the 1950's and 60's, she invented techniques that transformed the craft and made weavings that looked like airy sculptures. Then four years ago, at the age of 84, Mrs. Tawney developed serious vision problems. She also made a discovery: a cache of her best early work, which had been missing for 15 years, had turned up in a friend's attic in New Jersey.
That work, appropriately called the Attic Collection, is one reason for the renewed interest in her work. In fact, she is busier now than ever with her own exhibitions. Two solo shows opened this year in Pittsburgh and in Chicago. Five others, from Honolulu to Amsterdam, are planned for the next 18 months. 
 "I've always liked to travel," said Mrs. Tawney, who plans to attend all the openings.
For the moment, it's the show at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam, which opens in May, that's consuming most of her attention. It will exhibit for the first time most of the 48 pieces in the Attic Collection. "I've been working intensely to finish the knots and braids and other details on these works so they can now be exhibited," she said.
These pieces were misplaced in 1976, after she was evicted from her studio in lower Manhattan and sent them to be stored at the Quakertown, N.J., home of the ceramist Toshiko Takaezu. They were found only in 1991, in Ms. Takaezu's attic.
The collection covers Mrs. Tawney's entire career at the loom, from 1955 to 1976, and includes pieces that demonstrate how she used the techniques she invented, called the open warp and the open reed, to change the texture and shape of weaving in the 1950's and 1960's. There are also examples of her Surrealist collages and constructions in boxes from the 60's and 70's.
Mrs. Tawney is probably the only one who knows exactly which works are going where, and she is supervising the packing and shipping of everything. Greeting a visitor to her all-white studio in the Chelsea section of Manhattan recently, she was dressed all in white -- shirt, pants and a beret, which covered most of her reddish hair. She exudes energy and seems taller than her five feet and decades younger than her years. Only occasionally is it apparent that she sees dimly now.
Her most familiar pieces are gossamer in texture, as delicate as a spider web. In the 1950's, however, her weaving was anything but fragile: the colors were often gaudy and the textures robust as she experimented with color and fibers. By 1961, in her first solo show, at the Staten Island Museum, the colors were neutral -- black, white, straw -- and the new elongated pieces were as airy as fish nets.
"It was the beginning of the art fiber movement," said Jack Lenor Larsen, a New York textile producer. One of Mrs. Tawney's finest works from this period is "Dark River," a subtly curved, narrow weaving of parallel vertical threads. In it, she transformed an abstract image into that of a figure of a cloaked woman, crowned with a wig of braids. At 14 feet, the weaving is so tall that its owner, the Museum of Modern Art, has never exhibited it.
 THE ATTIC COLLECTION CONTAINS A similar work, "Murmuring River," which is only nine feet tall. Among the other pieces is a 1974 weaving depicting an American flag in reverse as a protest to the Watergate scandal.
Leonora Agnes Gallagher, one of five children born and raised on the shores of Lake Erie and the Black River in Lorain, Ohio, knew her own mind from early childhood. Asked recently when she changed her first name, she said: "About the first grade. Why? Too many letters."
At 20 she left home for Chicago, where she became a proofreader for a legal publisher and took courses at night at the Art Institute of Chicago. In 1941, she married George Tawney, a psychologist, who became ill and died 18 months later.
She moved to New York in 1957 and continued weaving until she was evicted from her studio. She then went to India and spent six months at an ashram. While there, she received a commission from the General Services Administration for a work for the Federal Building in Santa Rosa, Calif.
Rather than a weaving, she created a blue fiber work of 2,500 threads, each of which was tied to a canvas canopy near the ceiling. The 16-foot linen strands are knotted at the end to drop like threads of rain over the enormous lobby. " 'Cloud' took me right off the loom," Mrs. Tawney said, "and there I was hanging from the ceiling."
While her work has taken many forms, thread remains at its core. "Every one of my boxes is full of thread, and there is thread in my collages too," she said. "We wear fiber and are closer to fiber than almost anything else. It's our diapers -- and our shrouds."
 Personal and literary explorations of the less visible (and therefore more conjectural) half of life by a gifted critic and acutely intuitive memoirist.
SUSPENDED ANIMATION: Six Essays on the Preservation of Bodily Parts. By F. Gonzalez-Crussi. (Harvest/Harcourt Brace, paper, $16.) Elegant meditations in a sort of formal rococo style by a pathologist who knows that death is more fun when you thoroughly understand it.
 
Poetry
THE ANNALS OF CHILE. By Paul Muldoon. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $21.) Easier of access and more emotionally direct than his previous work, these poems are also more arcane and allusive -- especially the long autobiographical sequence "Yarrow," an account of the birth of the poet's imagination.
ATLANTIS: Poems. By Mark Doty. (Harper Perennial, cloth, $22; paper, $11.) These new poems are the best yet by Mr. Doty; together they form a fierce meditation on the death of a lover as they look at the world "in a state of grief so pure it is a kind of ecstasy."
THE COLLECTED POEMS OF LANGSTON HUGHES. Edited by Arnold Rampersad and David Roessel. (Knopf, $30.) Except for juvenilia, all the poems, including hundreds Hughes himself did not include in collections. Altogether they remind us that he had perhaps the greatest affinity for popular speech and song of any American poet in this century.
THE HUSBANDS: An Account of Books 3 and 4 of Homer's "Iliad." By Christopher Logue. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $19.) A heroic, often brilliant, portion of the author's long-term project of bringing this distant, uncomfortable, alien poem closer to readers of contemporary poetry.
THE INFERNO OF DANTE: A New Verse Translation. By Robert Pinsky. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) A near-symphonic rendition of the tour through hell attains a truly Dantean velocity without missing a jot or a tittle.
A SCATTERING OF SALTS: Poems. By James Merrill. (Knopf, $20.) Merrill's last collection, published just weeks after his death. These poems have the unfailing style and varied brilliance one expects, but also a sense of summing up -- a wealth of poetry reaching its final form.
SELECTED POEMS, 1965-1990. By Marilyn Hacker. (Norton, $22.) Supple, and colloquial, formalism gives an inviting elegance to poems of often astonishing directness, heated passion and a vision of the human family that calls into question virtually all of what are called traditional values.
 
Politics & Current Affairs
THE ALL-AMERICAN SKIN GAME: Or, The Decoy of Race. The Long and the Short of It, 1990-1994. By Stanley Crouch. (Pantheon, $24.) Tough, sharp-witted essays, speeches and reviews from an omnivorous and optimistic black (he says Negro) humanist and student of jazz and blues.
ALL GOD'S CHILDREN: The Bosket Family and the American Tradition of Violence. By Fox Butterfield. (Knopf, $27.50.) A Times correspondent's painful examination of social pathology from generation to generation, always getting worse, told with a novelist's determination to see it whole.
AMAZING GRACE: The Lives of Children and the Conscience of a Nation. By Jonathan Kozol. (Crown, $23.) In an impoverished neighborhood in the Bronx, Mr. Kozol details, with his customary sensitivity, the devastation wreaked upon children.
AUTOPSY ON AN EMPIRE: The American Ambassador's Account of the Collapse of the Soviet Union. By Jack F. Matlock Jr. (Random House, $35.) A scrupulously sober, fair-minded and intelligent analysis of the Soviet collapse by a diplomat on the scene from 1987 to 1991.
BETRAYAL: The Story of Aldrich Ames, an American Spy. By Tim Weiner, David Johnston and Neil A. Lewis. (Random House, $25.) How a turncoat C.I.A. officer sold his agency to the Soviets and got away with it for nine years without even being careful; lucid narration by three correspondents of The New York Times.
BROKEN COVENANT: American Foreign Policy and the Crisis Between the U.S. and Israel. By Moshe Arens. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A senior Israeli politician indicts Bush Administration policy as meddlesome and duplicitous.
BURY ME STANDING: The Gypsies and Their Journey. By Isabel Fonseca. (Knopf, $25.) A diligent account of a spirited but hapless minority whose aversion to history is such that many do not recall the half million slaughtered in World War II, or indeed that such a war took place.
CALL THE BRIEFING! Bush and Reagan, Sam and Helen: A Decade With Presidents and the Press. By Marlin Fitzwater. (Times Books/Random House, $25.) The press secretary to Presidents Ronald Reagan and $25.) The press secretary to Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush includes a few gems in his discreet recollections.
CASINO: Love and Honor in Las Vegas. By Nicholas Pileggi. (Simon & Schuster, $24.) The unease and aimlessness of the gangster life, captured fly-on-the-wall fashion and conveyed in the perceptions of the crooks themselves.
THE CENTER HOLDS: The Power Struggle Inside the Rehnquist Court. By James F. Simon. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A professor at New York Law School provides a lively and accessible narrative about how the current Supreme Court reaches its judgments.
CITY LIFE: Urban Expectations in a New World. By Witold Rybczynski. (Scribner, $23.) Why our cities aren't like Paris, explained by a witty and subtle architect; mainly, their democratic vistas give no special focus to kings or bishops.
A CIVIL ACTION. By Jonathan Harr. (Random House, $25.) This tale of a lawsuit (Massachusetts householders vs. industrial polluters) is most disquieting when it suggests that legal quirks and personalities determine who, if anyone, is compensated.
COMRADE CRIMINAL: Russia's New Mafiya. By Stephen Handelman. (Yale University, $27.50.) A reporter's account of post-cold-war Russia, now a lawless land at the mercy of organized crime.
DAVID BRINKLEY: 11 Presidents, 4 Wars, 22 Political Conventions, 1 Moon Landing, 3 Assasinations, 2,000 Weeks of News and Other Stuff on Television and Growing Up in North Carolina. By David Brinkley. (Knopf, $25.) The veteran broadcast journalist rambles somewhat haphazardly but frequently with great charm over the momentous events he has witnessed and the forces that shaped him -- told in the cadences of that distinctive voice.
THE DEATH OF COMMON SENSE: How Law Is Suffocating America. By Philip K. Howard. (Random House, $18.) A lawyer argues that this would be a better country if we had less law.
DEFENDING PORNOGRAPHY: Free Speech, Sex and the Fight for Women's Rights. By Nadine Strossen. (Scribner, $22.) The president of the American Civil Liberties Union polemicizes againt the branch of the feminist movement that advocates censorship of sexually explicit materials.
THE DE-MORALIZATION OF SOCIETY: From Victorian Virtues to Modern Values. By Gertrude Himmelfarb. (Knopf, $24.) The distinguished historian argues that the West has lost its moral compass over the course of the 20th century.
DRIVE-BY. By Gary Rivlin. (Holt, $25.) A meticulous journalistic re-creation of that too-ubiquitous urban horror, the drive-by killing of teen-agers by teen-agers.
THE END OF AFFLUENCE: The Causes and Consequences of America's Economic Dilemma. By Jeffrey Madrick. (Random House, $22.) A journalist turned economic historian argues that historical changes have killed the prosperity many Americans remember, and that no economic or political nostrum can bring it back.
THE END OF REFORM: New Deal Liberalism in Recession and War. By Alan Brinkley. (Knopf, $27.50.) In the late 1930's, a distinguished historian argues, liberal interventionism lost its nerve and settled for underwriting consumer demand, with the results we now see around us.
FIRST IN HIS CLASS: A Biography of Bill Clinton. By David Maraniss. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) An account, written by a Washington Post reporter, of Mr. Clinton's life up to his announcement that he was running for President; rich in detail and reticent in interpretation.
FRIENDS IN HIGH PLACES: The Rise and Fall of Clark Clifford. By Douglas Frantz and David McKean. (Little, Brown, $24.95.) The authors, a reporter and a lawyer, see Mr. Clifford's crash -- a criminal indictment after 50 years of smooth cruising at altitude in Washington -- as the inevitable end of such a career.
A GOOD LIFE: Newspapering and Other Adventures. By Ben Bradlee. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) A memoir by the former editor of The Washington Post, who was, during Watergate, the world's most famous editor; his comfortable prose makes his accomplishments look easy.
HAPPY DAYS: My Mother, My Father, My Sister & Me. by Shana Alexander. (Doubleday, $27.50.) The journalist attempts to solve the psychological puzzles of her upbringing with an emotionally frigid mother, a passive father and a bizarre disruption of family life.
HEART: A Memoir. By Lance Morrow. (Warner, $22.95.) A moving work of literal introspection: in the wake of his second heart attack and second bypass operation, Mr. Morrow tries to find out what's really wrong with his life and himself.
AN INTIMATE HISTORY OF HUMANITY. By Theodore Zeldin. (HarperCollins, $25.) Not history so much as informed rumination by an Oxford social historian who talks to many people (mostly Frenchwomen) about the fundamentals of human experience -- hope, despair, love, etc. -- and thinks that hope still has a chance.
LOSING GROUND: American Environmentalism at the Close of the 20th Century. By Mark Dowie. (MIT, $25.) A courageous critique of the environmental movement that contends its leadership has ceded the moral high ground to become just another special interest in Washington.
MOVING VIOLATIONS: War Zones, Wheelchairs, and Declarations of Independence. By John Hockenberry. (Hyperion, $24.95.) Swaggering in a wheelchair isn't easy, but this candidly aggressive National Public Radio correspondent is up to the job (or any other).
MY AMERICAN JOURNEY. By Colin L. Powell with Joseph E. Persico. (Random House, $25.95.) The autobiography of the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff shows the making of the man who decided not to run for President.
NEOCONSERVATISM: The Autobiography of an Idea. By Irving Kristol. (Free Press, $25.) In this collection of essays, Mr. Kristol shows that his temperament has remained constant even as his politics have shifted.
THE NEXT AMERICAN NATION: The New Nationalism and the Fourth American Revolution. By Michael Lind. (Free Press, $25.) An intelligent, industrious, not very cheerful look at possible futures. Balkanization through identity politics? Stratification, Brazilian style?
THE NIGHTINGALE'S SONG. By Robert Timberg. (Simon & Schuster, $27.50.) Mr. Timberg, a graduate of the United States Naval Academy, examines some of his fellow alumni in Government service (overrepresented in the Iran-contra affair) and finds that their conduct was influenced by fear of a second Vietnam.
NIGHTMOVER: How Aldrich Ames Sold the CIA to the KGB for $4.6 Million. By David Wise. (HarperCollins, $25.) Same Ames, same story, somewhat gentler on the agency; enhanced by the authority of a veteran espionage writer.
THE POLITICS OF DIPLOMACY: Revolution, War and Peace, 1989-1992. By James A. Baker 3d with Thomas M. DeFrank. (Putnam, $32.50.) The former White House chief of staff, Secretary of the Treasury and Secretary of State in the Reagan and Bush Administrations gives his accounting of American diplomacy during those years and tries to distance himself from Mr. Bush's disastrous re-election camapaign.
RACIAL HEALING: Confronting the Fear Between Blacks and Whites. By Harlon L. Dalton. (Doubleday, $22.50.) A black law professor at Yale University offers refreshingly straight talk about the need to confront racial problems without evasion or euphemism.
REASON TO BELIEVE. By Mario Cuomo. (Simon & Schuster, $21.) The former Governor delivers a polemic against the Republican revolution and urges a renewal of community ties.
RETHINKING AMERICA. By Hedrick Smith. (Random House, $25.) An examination of America's economy and prescriptions for repairing it to accord with a changed world order, by a journalist who does not fear big subjects.
THE REVOLT OF THE ELITES AND THE BETRAYAL OF DEMOCRACY. By Christopher Lasch. (Norton, $22.) The ills of democracy, Lasch passionately contends, arise from such defaults as the abdication of responsibility for the community by economic elites and the propagation by academics of a skeptical relativism.
SIMPLE RULES FOR A COMPLEX WORLD. By Richard A. Epstein. (Harvard University, $35.) The brilliantly contrarian law professor at the University of Chicago offers a prescription for a more productive and efficient -- and libertarian -- society.
TEMPTATIONS OF A SUPERPOWER. By Ronald Steel. (Harvard University, $18.95.) The author, who teaches international relations at the University of Southern California, criticizes American foreign policy as muddled and wasteful and offers suggestions in keeping with contemporary conditions.
TRUST: The Social Virtues and the Creation of Prosperity. By Francis Fukuyama. (Free Press, $25.) A fascinating argument -- that institutions between the family and the state (like Rotary or the Boy Scouts) are good for civility and good for capitalism too -- and dazzling case studies of industrial nations that have such groups or don't.
THE TWILIGHT OF COMMON DREAMS: Why America is Wracked by Culture Wars. By Todd Gitlin. (Metropolitan Books/Holt, $25.) A former president of Students for a Democratic Society, now a sociology professor at New York University, eloquently sounds an alarm over the degeneration of left-wing activism into self-absorbed identity politics.
VIRTUALLY NORMAL: An Argument About Homosexuality. By Andrew Sullivan. (Knopf, $22.) The author, who is the editor of The New Republic, reflects reasonably on society's dealings with the minority of which he is a member; he thinks society could do a lot better.
WHERE THE SUCKERS MOON: An Advertising Story. By Randall Rothenberg. (Knopf, $25.) A lively rendition, by a former advertising columnist for The Times, of real life at an agency that tried to sell cars by ridiculing ads for cars.
WHY WACO?: Cults and the Battle for Religious Freedom in America. By James D. Tabor and Eugene V. Gallagher. (University of California, $24.95.) A carefully documented and engaging study by two scholars of religious conversion, arguing that intolerance of unconventional religions underlay the disastrous confrontation between the Government and the Branch Davidians in 1993.
THE WINNER-TAKE-ALL SOCIETY: How More and More Americans Compete for Ever Fewer and Bigger Prizes, Encouraging Economic Waste, Income Inequality, and an Impoverished Cultural Life. By Robert H. Frank and Philip J. Cook. (Martin Kessler/Free Press, $25.) An economist and a professor of public policy contend that the star system -- in which a very few monopolize pay and prestige, while the many suffer -- is permeating the economy to the detriment of the social fabric.
 
Religion & Philosophy
THE DEATH OF SATAN: How Americans Have Lost the Sense of Evil. By Andrew Delbanco. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) Passionate and erudite, Mr. Delbanco explores the ethical problems of secular rationality; when Satan was real he lived within us, but now evil is externally located, in capitalism, Communism, neurosis or any other convenient scapegoat.
GOD: A Biography. By Jack Miles. (Knopf, $27.50.) Not a joke but a scholarly, entertaining literary inquiry into the character called God as His multiple personalities have been rendered through the ages in the Hebrew Bible.
JOHN DEWEY: And the High Tide of American Liberalism. By Alan Ryan. (Norton, $30.) In his study of Dewey's philosophy, the author finds it a model for "middle-of-the-road radicalism."
THE ORIGIN OF SATAN. By Elaine Pagels. (Random House, $23.) The author, a professor of religion at Princeton, looks at how changing conceptions of the diabolic offer insight into Western history.
POPE JOHN PAUL II: The Biography. By Tad Szulc. (Lisa Drew/Scribner, $27.50.) Mr. Szulc, a seasoned reporter of Polish birth, inquires into the special circumstances of Polish Catholicism and the special stresses of fascist and Communist domination that formed the present Pope.
 
Science
AFTER THE FACT: Two Countries, Four Decades, One Anthropologist. By Clifford Geertz. (Harvard University, $22.95.) The leading anthropologist of his generation looks back on his career and finds himself with more questions than answers.
ANCESTRAL PASSIONS: The Leakey Family and the Quest for Humankind's Beginnings. By Virginia Morrell. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) In a model of science writing, the author, a correspondent for Science magazine, traces the history of the family that has dominated paleoanthropology.
THE BEAUTY OF THE BEASTLY: New Views on the Nature of Life. By Natalie Angier. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $21.95.) Essays and excursions by a New York Times science reporter who deals gracefully with current ideas about the innerest workings of us organisms.
EDWIN HUBBLE: Mariner of the Nebulae. By Gale E. Christianson. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) A readable, entertaining life of the brilliant astronomer whose work, fundamental to modern theories of the universe, never interfered with his self-promotion, pretension and vanity.
ENGINEERS OF DREAMS: Great Bridge Builders and the Spanning of America. By Henry Petroski. (Knopf, $30.) The author, a civil engineer and historian of science, shows in his history of American bridges that hubris can be as fatal to engineers as to generals.
THE ENGINE OF REASON, THE SEAT OF THE SOUL: A Philosophical Journey Into the Brain. By Paul M. Churchland. (Bradford/MIT, $29.95.) A philosopher's argument, clear, witty and scientifically up-to-date, that all of human mental life, however subjective it feels, is reducible to material activity taking place in the brain.
FIRE IN THE MIND: Science, Faith and the Search for Order. By George Johnson. (Knopf, $27.50.) Careful, balanced explorations of the places where scientific understanding of this extremely strange universe and religious and philosophical perceptions of it may illuminate each other.
MEMORY'S GHOST: The Strange Tale of Mr. M. and the Nature of Memory. By Philip J. Hilts. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A look at research on memory, centered on the story of Henry M., a 69-year-old man whose memory was destroyed by an operation in 1953; written by a New York Times science reporter.
A MOMENT ON THE EARTH: The Coming Age of Environmental Optimism. By Gregg Easterbrook. (Viking, $27.95.) Essays on the most complex of modern subjects, treating our considerable environmental accomplishments and our puzzling neglect of threats (diseases, for instance) in other people's backyards.
MR. WILSON'S CABINET OF WONDER. By Lawrence Weschler. (Pantheon, $21.) A many-minded journalist views and views again David Wilson's storefront Museum of Jurassic Technology in Culver City, Calif., where some things are what they seem to be.
NANO. The Emerging Science of Nanotechnology: Remaking the World -- Molecule by Molecule. By Ed Regis. (Little, Brown, $23.95.) Crisp science journalism about a possible world of endless bounty, produced by incredibly tiny machines.
NOAH'S CHOICE: The Future of Endangered Species. By Charles C. Mann and Mark L. Plummer. (Knopf, $24.) The authors persuasively contend that humans will decide, by default or by intention, who goes extinct, and at present have not a clue how to do so wisely.
PALE BLUE DOT: A Vision of the Human Future in Space. By Carl Sagan. (Random House, $35.) A scientist predicts that when the solar system meets its end, our species will survive by colonizing other worlds.
 
Science Fiction
BLOODCHILD: Novellas and Stories. By Octavia E. Butler. (Four Walls Eight Windows, $17.) This volume comprises the entire output of short fiction by Ms. Butler. Readers of her moving novel "Parable of the Sower" will especially appreciate the title story, which explores the role of human beings in a symbiotic relationship with powerful aliens.
EVOLUTION'S SHORE. By Ian McDonald. (Bantam/Spectra, paper, $12.95.) The protagonist of this powerfully understated allegory is an ambitious electronic journalist who turns out to be the ideal guide to an enigmatic alien entity that threatens the continuation of civilization-as-we-know-it.
FEERSUM ENDJINN. By Iain M. Banks. (Bantam/Spectra, paper, $12.95.) The plot of this puzzle story of almost excessive invention explains how a high-tech but stagnant civilization on a far-future earth is roused to save itself. The novel constantly challenges the reader's patience but amply rewards those who stay the course.
FOUR WAYS TO FORGIVENESS. By Ursula K. Le Guin. (Harper Prism, $20.) Another of Ms. Le Guin's solidly written and densely imagined fictions whose sociological and anthropological resonances never obscure the concerns of individuals caught up in the great events of history.
THE GOLDEN NINETIES. By Lisa Mason. (Bantam/Spectra, paper, $12.95.) A novel that thrusts the reader, through the legerdemain of time travel, into a lusty, brawling 19th-century San Francisco that Ms. Mason brings to life with a winning mixture of intelligence and passion.
LEGACY. By Greg Bear. (Tor, $22.95.) On a planet named Lamarckia, evolution has taken a different turn from the Darwinian competition among individuals that has filled Earth with armies of tough survivors. When human settlers intervene, the outcome is nothing less than tragedy on a global scale.
RESURRECTION MAN. By Sean Stewart. (Ace, cloth, $22.95; paper, $11.) A tightly focused, emotionally intense novel that tracks the coming of age of a likable young man named Dante in a world where magic, bred of anger in the inner cities, has returned to claim a place in our streets and our psyches.
 
Spies & Thrillers
CHINA WHITE. By Peter Maas. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) An investigative reporter, in his first thriller, explores heroin trafficking, with its interconnections between Chinese gangs, the mob and American intelligence agencies.
THE CODICIL. By Tom Topor. (Hyperion, $21.95.) When a wealthy industrialist leaves half his estate to the child he fathered in Vietnam, a private investigator must uncover secrets about the dead man's past in order to deliver the legacy.
A CROOKED MAN. By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) An attentive thriller by a daily reviewer for The Times debates the decriminalization of drugs in an up-to-date Washington environment.
ENIGMA. By Robert Harris. (Random House, $23.) A thriller based on the actual code-breaking activities carried on in Bletchley Park in England during World War II.
KOLYMSKY HEIGHTS. By Lionel Davidson. (St. Martin's, $22.95.) An American agent braves Siberia to uncover the secret of a Soviet doomsday machine.
THE LAST HIGH GROUND. By Robin A. White. (Crown, $23.) Cultures clash but eventually collaborate as an American investigator and a Japanese accountant pursue a Japanese mafioso who is sabotaging Boeing airplanes.
OUR GAME. By John le Carre. (Knopf, $24.) In a British adventure novel redolent of John Buchan and Eric Ambler, a retired Treasury official and secret spymaster sets off in search of a vanished friend -- a onetime double agent.
SHELLEY'S HEART. By Charles McCarry. (Random House, $23.) A really smart thriller about the Presidency, by a journalist who well understands how the gears of power are shifted.
SLEEPER SPY. By William Safire. (Random House, $24.) This newspaper's one-man diversified literary industry offers a cerebral thriller about a Russian agent everybody's looking for and whose real identity has become lost to the Russians themselves.

Sports
THE COURTS OF BABYLON: Tales of Greed and Glory in a Harsh New World of Professional Tennis. By Peter Bodo. (Scribner, $25.) A senior writer at Tennis magazine looks at changes in the professional tour that have reduced players from "gentlemen to jerks."
MY USUAL GAME: Adventures in Golf. By David Owen. (Villard, $23.) Mr. Owen, a journalist, had a handicap numbering in the dozens when he set out to devote every waking moment to improving his golf game; he recounts his obsessive odyssey in hilarious detail here.
ONE PITCH AWAY: The Players' Stories of the 1986 League Championships and World Series. By Mike Sowell. (Macmillan, $27.95.) Recollections of the dramatic series of baseball games that decided the pennants, then the World Series, of 1986.
ONLY IN AMERICA: The Life and Crime of Don King. By Jack Newfield. (Morrow, $23.) An indictment of the flamboyant boxing promoter, written by a veteran investigative reporter who is currently a columnist at The New York Post.

Travel, Nature & Adventure
THE CITY OF FLORENCE: Historical Vistas and Personal Sightings. By R. W. B. Lewis. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.50.) An autobiographical, anecdotal, historical memoir, filled with love and learning, about a distinguished scholar's affair with a miraculous city.
MY OLD MAN AND THE SEA: A Father and Son Sail Around Cape Horn. By David Hays and Daniel Hays. (Algonquin, $19.95.) And so they do, round trip from New London, Conn., becoming better, wiser and more loving people en route but never overloading a marvelous sailing yarn.
THE PILLARS OF HERCULES: A Grand Tour of the Mediterranean. By Paul Theroux. (Putnam, $27.50.) A horrible tourist but a grand interlocutor, Mr. Theroux, indifferent to ruins and cathedrals, talks to whomever he meets, yielding slice after slice of the strangeness of everyday life around the great inland sea.
SAVAGES. By Joe Kane. (Knopf, $25.) A superb report on life among the Huaorani, a virtually intact Amazonian tribe whose resolve to stay as and where they are confronts the resolve of governments and energy companies to pump the earth from under their feet.
THE SIGN OF THE CROSS: Travels in Catholic Europe. By Colm Toibin. (Pantheon, $24.) An Irish novelist ponders his relationship with Roman Catholicism and his Irishness, augmented by his reports of Holy Week visits to Eastern Europe, Spain, the Balkans and Rome.
VENICE REDISCOVERED. By John Pemble. (Oxford University, $25.) A historian's fresh, fascinating account of the potent symbolic resurrection of Venice in the European imagination after its political death in 1815.
 WALT WHITMAN'S AMERICA: A Cultural Biography. By David S. Reynolds. (Knopf, $35.) An extensive historical excavation, aiming to show how Whitman, an enthusiast for almost everything, transmuted into his poetry images from all aspects of American culture.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: November 26, 1995

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1626 words

HEADLINE: Present at the Cremation

BYLINE: By Anatol Lieven; Anatol Lieven, a Moscow correspondent for The Times of London, is the author of "The Baltic Revolution: Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and the Path to Independence."

 BODY:

AUTOPSY ON AN EMPIRE
The American Ambassador's Account of the Collapse of the Soviet Union.
By Jack F. Matlock Jr.
Illustrated. 836 pp. New York:
Random House. $35. 
 IN 1992, after the collapse of the Soviet Union, Jack F. Matlock Jr., the former United States Ambassador in Moscow, asked Mikhail S. Gorbachev if he now felt that he had moved too slowly in granting the Soviet republics real autonomy, the implication being that if he had moved faster he might have been able to save the Soviet Union.
Mr. Gorbachev replied: "Jack, I can see you are a professor now, because your question is academic. In some abstract sense, it is probably right that I moved too slowly, but I did not have the luxury of living in the abstract. I lived in a harsh world of political reality. . . . Even as it was, when I began to talk of a federation in early 1990, most of the Central Committee was in opposition. I had to fight them all the way. I simply did not have a free hand and should not be judged as if I had."
Mr. Gorbachev's words should be engraved above the desk of every Westerner who presumes to give advice to other countries. All too often, those of us -- journalists in particular -- who are acutely sensitive to the tight constraints under which our own governments operate assume other leaders can do whatever they please.
This is a mistake that Mr. Matlock is careful not to make. "Autopsy on an Empire" is one of the most scrupulously sober, intelligent and fair-minded analyses of the Soviet collapse yet to appear; and coming from a man who from 1987 to 1991 was closer than any other Westerner to the heart of the events he describes, it also has enduring value as a historical document. Mr. Matlock's personal reputation is probably the highest among recent American ambassadors to Moscow, and his book will deservedly enhance it.
On the Bush Administration's Moscow policy, Mr. Matlock echoes criticism made elsewhere, but since his views are those of a Soviet expert and foreign service professional, they have more weight than most. He faults George Bush for excessive caution, a caution stemming less from ideology than from personal character.
Mr. Matlock says, first of all, that Mr. Bush did not respond with sufficient sympathy to Mr. Gorbachev in 1989-91, despite the immense changes he was trying to bring about and the immense difficulties he was facing. And while failing to give any real help to Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Bush also failed to react in time to the rise of Boris N. Yeltsin and to the demands of the non-Russian republics.
In Mr. Matlock's words, Mr. Bush "was uncomfortable with change. Even when it was for the better, he had difficulty recognizing the improvement at first. He always seemed just a step behind -- not so much that he endangered anything vital but enough to miss opportunities Reagan would probably have seized." However, as Mr. Matlock adds when discussing Mr. Bush's failure immediately to condemn the August 1991 coup: "This time President Bush was lucky. The self-styled emergency committee in Moscow began to disintegrate on the second day of its existence, not because of foreign pressure but because of its own fragility and incompetence."
Actually, it might be said that luck has helped both the Bush and Clinton Administrations in their dealings with Russia. Their policies have often been contradictory, alternately timid and overbold, obsessed with personalities (Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Yeltsin) and, above all, responsive to short-term American domestic political pressures rather than long-term American interests. Luckily, Russia has been so weak internally and externally that so far there have been no really serious consequences for the West.
Mr. Matlock's principal intention is not to analyze American policy. Instead, he asks a question that must haunt many experts on the Soviet Union: "How could I make sense of my own life, devoted as it was to understanding the Soviet Union, if I could not understand the Soviet collapse?"
His "autopsy" on the Soviet Union is persuasive: "The deceased was a being of vicious habits that his physicians set out to cure. They managed to alleviate the patient's paranoia and curb his aggressive behavior, but the drugs administered undermined his immune system, and he eventually died from the spread of infections that would not be life-threatening to a healthy body. . . . The fact that the patient failed to survive the treatment should be regarded as a consequence of the patient's self-induced morbidity rather than the treatment administered."
Mr. Matlock shows great sympathy for Mr. Gorbachev in his efforts to keep the Soviet Union together. His portrait of the last Soviet leader is psychologically acute, even moving, but Mr. Matlock is also well aware of Mr. Gorbachev's shortcomings: his inability to tolerate strong figures around him; his reliance on the K.G.B., which eventually betrayed him; his longstanding failure to grasp the realities of economic reform.
Mr. Matlock does not believe that anything could have saved the Soviet Union. At best, he suggests, the Kremlin leaders might have preserved some kind of loose federation -- if they had accepted Baltic independence at an early stage, tried harder to maintain an alliance with the Russian democrats and kept a tighter grip on the K.G.B. But such a state would have been inherently unstable and, in my view, could not have long survived in any case.
While he condemns the brutality of the Soviet military intervention in the Baltic states in January 1991, Mr. Matlock wisely avoids the cold war hyperbole of some Western commentators. As he points out, the amount of blood shed in Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia on Mr. Gorbachev's orders was remarkably slight. (He might have added that it was slight not just by the bloodstained standards of Russian history but also by comparison with the records of some West European democracies in defense of their colonial empires.)
My only real criticisms of Mr. Matlock's views center on his extensive epilogue, which deals with developments in the former Soviet Union since 1991. These are not his main subject, of course, but they are obviously on everyone's mind at the present time. There is every chance that the next Russian Presidential election, scheduled for June, will either lead to a more overtly nationalist presidency or be canceled, ushering in a decrepit Yeltsinite semi-dictatorship -- if Mr. Yeltsin can physically survive that long.
Mr. Matlock accurately portrays the combination of imperial nostalgia and practical weakness in Russia today. Yet he sometimes goes too far in blaming imperial ambition for Moscow's concern about Russians living outside Russia, minimizing legitimate national sentiments and the worries of the Russians in other countries. As the Yugoslav case shows, manipulation from above is effective only if it has genuine fears and hatreds to work on.
Fortunately, such feelings are at present very limited among the main Russian communities outside Russia. But should those feelings intensify, the West will have to address them, not simply dismiss them out of hand. This applies, to take one important example, to the Ukrainian-Russian dispute over the Russian naval base at Sevastopol, which the overwhelming majority of Russians regard not as an imperial outpost in Ukraine but as a Russian city -- San Diego, one might say, rather than Guantanamo Bay.
A connected point concerns Estonian and Latvian legal discrimination against the Russian minorities in those republics. To be sure, there are powerful justifications for the Baltic laws, but their negative impact on relations with Russia cannot be denied, nor should Russia's hostility be attributed simply to imperialism.
Although Mr. Matlock correctly observes that Latvia's legal barrier to most Russians' rapidly obtaining Latvian citizenship has "infuriated many Russian democrats who had defended Latvia's right to seek independence," he may not fully realize the enormous damage this and similar laws have done to those democrats, as well as to Western prestige in Russia. Discreet Western pressure on Estonia and Latvia has, in fact, been very effective in getting them to moderate their laws, but this accomplishment has been completely lost on most Russians. As far as they can see, Western governments have been almost entirely silent about the civic rights of the Baltic Russians, while exerting intense public pressure on Russia to remove its troops from the Baltic states. More than any other question, the Baltic policy of the West has strengthened the Russian impression that the Western powers are hypocrites, using the language of universal values to trick Russia into strategic concessions.
Another issue pushing the Russians in an anti-Western direction is that of NATO expansion to Eastern Europe. Curiously, Mr. Matlock does not mention this in his book, but in May, in a joint letter to Warren Christopher signed by him and a group of other senior former United States officials, Mr. Matlock and his colleagues wrote that "in our view, this policy risks endangering the long-term viability of NATO . . . and convincing most Russians that the United States and the West are attempting to isolate, encircle and subordinate them, rather than integrating them into a new European system of collective security." It is a great pity that in formulating policy in this and other fields, United States administrations do not bend more to the advice of professionals like Mr. Matlock and less to the pressure of a variety of ignorant and partisan domestic lobbies. But then, such criticism is decades old at least, and all the indications are that things are getting worse, not better.

HEADLINE: A Gospel Session Honors Beethoven

BYLINE: By VALERIE CRUICE 

 BODY:
THE Prayer Tabernacle Choir of Bridgeport will perform a swinging gospel rendition of the final movement of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony, "Joyful, Joyful We Adore Thee" with the Greater Bridgeport Symphony on Saturday at the Klein Memorial Auditorium.
"We love singing it -- we sing it every Christmas. And with an orchestra, oh my, it's just something. The trumpets! It brings a lot of joy," said Bishop Kenneth H. Moales Sr., founder of the Prayer Tabernacle Church of Love and its choirs in the city's East End. "It's a new sound of gospel with the full orchestra live," he continued, "rather than with all the technology of producing gospel artists; very few of them have sung with a live orchestra." 
 How did a gospel choir and a symphony orchestra connect?
The executive director of the orchestra, Jena Maric, said that her organization "realized over the years where we've had concerts with jazz and ragtime, that it was a natural progression to another form of American music."
"I actually heard them perform in the late 1980's with an orchestra; I was very impressed," Ms. Maric continued. "The next time I heard them was with Judy Collins at Fairfield University. They were very effective. The audience loved them. They have a genuine impact."
The Prayer Tabernacle Choir will be featured in the concert's second half, the first half being devoted to the glittering "Scheherazade" by Rimsky-Korsakov.
The Prayer Tabernacle Choir is one of several that have evolved from the original youth choir started by Bishop Moales in 1968 when he founded the church.
"We started out just as a choir of the community for the young people to have something to do Saturday afternoons," he said. "It's been a vehicle for those who did not have an alternative to the streets. Many have learned to play instruments. We also involve the arts, creative arts and dance. We go sing in the prisons. Every Saturday our young people's choir feeds 200 to 300 people. We have approximately 170 young people. We even have a gospel nightclub called High Voltage where we serve non-alcoholic drinks. And we see that everyone gets home."
Bishop Moales's current project is starting a school in the East End. "It's going to be a regular academic Christian school that gives special emphasis to the arts," he said. "We are committed to turning this community around spiritually, socially and even economically." The school -- pre-kindergarten through sixth grade -- is expected to open in the fall of 1998. The Bishop, who is 50 years old and the father of three grown children, was born and raised in Father Panik Village, which he described as being "the highest-crime community in the city at one time."
Bishop Moales's work in Bridgeport has not gone unnoticed. In September he was made a bishop of the Pentecostal Church of our Lord and Savior Jesus Christ. His church in Bridgeport is headquarters for a region overseen by him which encompasses North Carolina, Ohio, New York and Connecticut.
In addition, he was recently elected president of the 60-year-old National Convention of Gospel Choirs and Choruses.
The number for tickets and more information about the Greater Bridgeport Symphony Concert is 576-0263.

HEADLINE: After Yonkers Blast, Heartache And Shifting Blame for Evacuees

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: YONKERS

 BODY:
BEHIND the cordoned-off streets, the flashing lights and a steady stream of officialdom were 2,000 personal stories of residents -- many poor and elderly -- who were put out of their homes for 10 days this month in what is believed to be the largest evacuation effort ever in Westchester County.
"We've seen a lot of hardship, a lot of heartache right at the beginning of the holiday season," said Roger Denman, a 20-year resident of Buena Vista Apartments, where an explosion in the electrical service room of the sprawling complex set off a series of power failures, which left residents unhurt but without shelter. 
 "People who can ill afford it have lost so much," Mr. Denman said.
In addition to taking a personal toll, the explosion has raised questions about whether building codes and oversight responsiblities for Government-subsidized structures like this one are strict enough.
Commissioner Vincent J. Masucci of the Yonker Bureau of Housing and Buildings, said that as an engineer he "never would have designed a complex of this size with a power supply only in one room."
"Maybe the Government was trying to save money, but in the long run they did not," the Commissioner said. "I'm just thankful that no one was hurt and there wasn't a more serious spread of fire."
The apartments were constructed in the early 1970's in part with Federal funds. The state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal now oversees the 18-story, 450-unit complex, which is managed by a private firm, Buena Vista Associates, a limited partnership. Since the explosion, questions have arisen over whose responsibility it is to inspect utilities at the site.
The power failure occurred on Nov. 9 after most of the families that live here had settled in for the night. Gladys Smith, 72, a retired nurse's aide, said she was watching television when the lights in the 450 apartments flickered and the complex went dark.
At the time, Mrs. Smith and neighbors like Sharen Branch and her two young children were not aware that the electricity had surged through the building's water mains and melted seals, causing a flood and forcing utility workers to shut off gas, heat and water.
Nor did residents know that it would be a week and a half before they could return to their homes -- and probably at least a month until the gas would be turned on again.
For Mrs. Smith, who immigrated to the United States from Liberia 37 years years ago, the wait to return home would be even longer. In the confusion, she lost her blood-pressure medicine, and visits back to an emergency office set up in a school close to the complex only frustrated and weakened her. In tears a week after the evacuation, she left the emergency office by cab for her son's home, resolved to wait until after Thanksgiving to return.
"There's no heat, no stove even to make myself a cup of tea," she said. "There may be no place like home but not under these conditions."
For Ms. Branch, who did return, the homecoming was not as she expected. The apartment was cold, and she sat in the living room the first morning back dressed in a coat and boots.
She said the turkey dinner she promised her two sons would have to wait because while she was away she used up what little savings she had traveling back and forth from her mother's apartment in the Bronx to Yonkers each morning to put her children on the school bus. Besides, she said, the stove no longer worked.
Meanwhile, Yonkers officials sorted through the explosion's aftermath, shipping the electric switching gear to a private investigative firm to determine the cause of the explosion and whether there had been foul play.
But Commissioner Thomas J. Lorio of the Yonkers Fire Department said his department did not suspect arson. Other tests to determine whether firefighters at the complex had been exposed to polychlorinated biphenyls -- the toxic substances known as PCB's previously used in the manufacture of electrical equipment, which are believed to cause cancer -- came back negative. The main switch gear for the complex, which was grounded to the water pipes, apparently shorted out, sending current 65 feet along the main and into the street.
James Lafferty, a senior housing inspector for the city, reported that except for investigating run-of-the-mill tenant complaints, the city had never inspected the power supply room.
"No local inspections were required, or for that matter allowed," Mr. Lafferty said, explaining that it was the job of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
But a spokesman for the state said that the division only has oversight responsibilities and that inspections were up to the locality.
"The city is looking for a scapegoat, and it's not us," said Harry G. Ryttenberg, the spokesman.
Other city officials and Consolidated Edison said it was up to the private management company to maintain the building.
They explained that public utility and municipal inspections are made only when buildings are constructed.
But Councilwoman Symra D. Brandon said the responsibility for ongoing maintenance should never rest with a private company, especially when state and Federal financing was involved.
"How can a management firm properly oversee itself?" she said. Ms. Brandon represents the First District, which includes Buena Vista Apartments.
Kenneth Davis, property manager for Buena Vista Associates, would not say when the electrical supply room was last inspected. And Devorah Fong, a spokeswoman for the company, could also not confirm when a routine inspection was last made. "In normal daily operations, I suspect," she said.
Richard Tyrrell, Yonkers' chief electrical inspector, said that special infrared scanners, which are usually owned only by electricians, are used to inspect electrical equipment and detect loose wires or what is known as "fatigue" in electrical connections.
But Mr. Tyrrell said that an inspection would not have necessarily prevented the explosion. "A rat could have gotten in there," he said.
It was the second power blackout at the complex in six months, said Denise Payne, a tenants' association leader.
The first one lasted about 12 hours, the second 10 days, she said.
"What if there is a third?" she continued. "And will we survive that one?"
City officials said last week that they were also asking themselves "what if" questions.
"We saw major damage, a catastrophe," said Commissioner Albert R. McEvoy of the Yonkers Police. "We need to plan ahead in case this happens again."
Although city agencies, the Red Cross and the Salvation Army worked together throughout the 10 days to help return people to their homes, the disaster has prompted officials here and in other municipalities to review procedures for such emergencies in the future.
Commissioner McEvoy and other city officials plan to critique the evacuation proceedings and will prepare a manual on handling future emergencies.
In White Plains, the Deputy Commissioner of Public Safety, Daniel Hickey, said emergencies often prompted municipalities to review procedures.
"We have plans in place, and we've seen several large apartment fires here where we had to evacuate people, but never of the magnitude of the one in Yonkers," he said. In White Plains, a propane truck exploded on Interstate 287 last year, sending a fireball onto neighboring property and forcing the evacuation of families nearby.
In Mount Vernon, Ray DeRizzio, Director of Emergency Services, said that even though that city had detailed plans for emergencies, most municipalities had limited resources and would be forced to call in the county or even the state a large-scale disaster.

HEADLINE: Downsizing Portends Coming Discontents

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As one of the 77,800 A.T.& T. managers who received a voluntary separation package, I urge Russell Baker to relax (column, Nov. 18). Many business units whose employees received their "packages" have been informed that the employees cannot be spared. Some who accept the offer will have their acceptances overridden by higher management, which is their prerogative. It is estimated only 10 percent of the managers who received offers will be let go. 
 I agree with Mr. Baker in his assessment of the state of American capitalism. Statistics may tell a rosy tale of increased productivity, but much of that arises from a fear of falling behind by workers who are more fearful of losing their jobs now than ever.
Funny Mr. Baker should mention the guillotine, for in the great inequity that all this Republican redistribution of wealth is accomplishing, no doubt there is being sown the seeds of some massive future revolt. The French Revolution, remember, was not so much a revolt of the peasantry as of the disaffected middle class.
Making companies responsible for released workers' unemployment benefits, retraining costs and health care for a full year might make them think before leaping into the downsizing pool next time.
 
KEN HARNISCH
Bayside, Queens, Nov. 21, 1995
