HEADLINE: Texas Replaces Food Stamps With Food Cards

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Nov. 26

 BODY:
While Congress and the White House debate the future of welfare, Texas officials, trying to cut down on fraud and administrative costs, have expanded to the entire state a program that dispenses food-stamp benefits electronically.
The program, known as electronic benefit transfer, has been experimented with in Texas and seven other states as a way to reduce waste and fraud by giving recipients a plastic debit card rather than food stamp coupons. 
 Texas has been testing it since October 1994 and this month the program was expanded statewide, entirely eliminating food stamps printed on paper. About one million Texas households are now using the plastic cards at grocery checkout counters. Maryland is the only other state where the system is in use statewide.
"It's been a tremendous success," said John Sharp, the Texas State Comptroller who proposed the system in 1991. "The little card doesn't work at a downtown street corner that sells crack cocaine. It works in large groceries." Some smaller groceries that accepted stamps under the old system have been removed from the program, he said.
Since the system went into operation, purchases of groceries with food stamps have greatly increased, Mr. Sharp said. In the Dallas and Houston areas, such purchases jumped a total of $10 million in the first month after the system went on line, even though food stamp benefits had seen a slight decline.
Sue Keetch, an administrator with the state's Department of Human Services, said grocers in the Dallas area were happy with the new program because it was bringing in more revenue.
The cards are also being used by the 200,000 people who get benefits under Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the Government's main cash assistance program.
Because the system makes it difficult to trade food stamp benefits on the black market, officials say recipients are buying more food. Each recipient has an electronic account in which the benefits are automatically deposited each month. And no change is given after a purchase, which means that recipients never receive cash.
Mr. Sharp said the electronic records make it easier to detect fraud. Already, he said, the authorities have cracked several food stamp trafficking rings in Texas. These included a meat market that accepted the coupons and gave cash in return.
The state needed Federal waivers to test the system.
About 27 million people in the United States receive food stamps, with Texas distributing about 10 percent of the nation's estimated $24 billion in benefits. In Texas, the average food stamp allotment is $292 a month for a qualifying household.
Officials say the new system will save the state more than $10 million a year in administrative costs and save the Federal Government millions more by eliminating mass mailings, armored car shipments and the cost of shredding food stamps, estimated at $24 million a year.
"If you're going to talk about welfare reform, you ought to first get the hogs out of the creek," said Mr. Sharp, a Democrat. "There are a lot of people scamming the system."
Of the debate in Washington, he added, "Nobody up there is saying, 'Why don't you make the system work the way it ought to work.' "
Officials say the program also makes grocery check-out quicker and more efficient. "The cashiers are thrilled with the electronic process," said Kristy Ozmun, a spokeswoman for H.E.B., a large grocery chain based in San Antonio. "There's no paper to process through the system, so it eliminates all those steps along the way."
Recipients say the program is much safer than the old system and reduces the stigma associated with cumbersome paper coupons.
"It takes the guilt out of dealing with food stamps," said Perry Wise, a 37-year-old unemployed plant worker in Conroe, near Houston. "It's much speedier at the register and unless someone is looking over your shoulder they don't know how you are paying for your groceries."
Ms. Keetch added, "Now they don't have to rip coupons out of their book with everyone giving them the fish-eye."

HEADLINE: Scandal Puts Focus on Lingering Questions About Utah Congresswoman

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 26

 BODY:
As chairwoman of the Young Republicans, Enid Greene was given two minutes to speak at the Republican National Convention in Houston in 1992. Wearing a red power suit, the 33-year-old candidate for Congress from Utah seemed unusually self-possessed. "Should anyone stand between us and our goals," she warned her audience, almost spitting out her words with measured emphasis, "we will move them aside."
As she drew out each word, she held her hands together and then yanked them apart, showing the path this determined young Hannibal would clear over whatever Alps stood in her way. A whoop went up from the Utah delegation, where her future husband, Joe Waldholtz, hung on her every word, nodding in silent communion. 
 Representative Enid Greene Waldholtz's ambition has always been evident. Less clear has been how far she would really go to win elective office.
That is one of several questions being asked as Federal investigators sort out the couple's convoluted financial troubles, hidden by her husband's shuffling of various joint accounts. When Mr. Waldholtz vanished earlier this month for six days, he ignited a media frenzy that has produced a stream of reports of bounced checks, commingling of personal and campaign funds, and dubious campaign reports.
The central question is where Mrs. Waldholtz got the $1.8 million she spent to win her seat in Congress last year. Did she win fair and square, or did she use illegal money to surge ahead at the last minute? Before the election, she tap-danced through her answers, telling a television interviewer: "We're very blessed."
Today, no one describes Enid Greene Waldholtz as blessed. Her marriage is in shambles, and her political career may be, too. Once anointed by Speaker Newt Gingrich as one of the few freshmen with the potential to be a "real leader," Mrs. Waldholtz cowered in her office recently when the House debated important legislation banning gifts for members of Congress, a bill she had originally sponsored. Threatened with eviction from her Georgetown home, once owned by Henry A. Kissinger, for repeated failure to pay the $3,800 monthly rent, she is moving on her own to more modest quarters, her 3-month-old daughter in tow.
Mrs. Waldholtz blames her husband for her troubles, but several associates say they warned her more than a year ago that her finances were a mess. Her supporters say that Mrs. Waldholtz, a savvy, no-nonsense corporate litigator who represented banks when she was in private practice, was nonetheless blinded by love.
There is a sense of urgency in her district in Utah, and on Capitol Hill, for Mrs. Waldholtz to explain herself. Governor Michael O. Leavitt, who performed the Waldholtzes' civil wedding ceremony, said that she had "one shot" to make her case and that she should make it soon, or her political career would be over.
Although Mrs. Waldholtz has been cooperating with Federal authorities, she has so far avoided public disclosure. She skipped a self-imposed deadline to explain discrepancies in her financial reports to the Clerk of the House. Last week, she succeeded in getting her divorce proceedings sealed.
The couple's friends, and even opponents, say that Mrs. Waldholtz may well have been duped, at least initially, by Mr. Waldholtz, who pretended to be a rich political operator when they first met at a Young Republican convention in 1991. They say she probably did not know that when he showed up in Utah in 1992 to work on her first race for Congress, he had left Pittsburgh under a cloud of money problems, with both his employer and his family. He is still wanted in court in Pittsburgh to explain what he did with more than $600,000 he was supposed to have invested for his grandmother.
But after she married him, in August 1993, Mrs. Waldholtz also began having money problems. According to court records, her gardener filed a $3,600 lien on her house in December 1993, and her dentist sued her in February 1994 for an unpaid bill of $73. She accumulated parking tickets, with the city of Salt Lake taking her to court seven times to pay late fines; four of those times, she failed to appear.
 
A Successful Career With Roots in Utah
By this time, Enid Greene, now 37, was a comer in Utah politics. The third of five children of D. Forrest and Gerda Greene, she was the first of three who were adopted. (Her biological mother died in childbirth when Enid was born.)
The Greenes lived in San Francisco, where Mr. Greene, an investor, had a seat on the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange. When Enid was 12, they moved back to Salt Lake City and their Mormon roots.
Enid was smart and energetic, finding early success on the high school debating team and in home economics. "There wasn't a thing she couldn't do," her mother said in an interview. Asked why her daughter had become a lawyer, her mother said: "When she was growing up, we saw a lot of girls losing husbands through divorce or death and, because they didn't have an education, she saw them go into waitressing and low-pay jobs. And Enid said, 'If that would ever happen to me, I would want to be able to hang onto the home my husband had provided for me and our children.' "
Enid Greene joined a top Salt Lake City law firm, but, as a single Mormon woman in her mid-30's, she was something of an outcast.
Some friends say that she lost her 1992 campaign for Congress in part because she was not married, but she had other problems as well. She came across as harsh and humorless. Before her rematch in 1994 against Karen Shepherd, the Democrat who beat her in 1992, she married and underwent a makeover.
"In '92, Enid was a single Mormon woman who was very aggressive, very strident, opinionated, hard-charging, very straightforward and bookish, with wire-rim glasses and curly tight black hair," said Bill Wachob, a Democratic media consultant based in San Diego who worked for Mrs. Shepherd.
"In '94," he said, "she was married, she gained weight, let her hair grow, took off her glasses. Although she was still articulate, she had no resemblance to the candidate of 1992. She would wear a nice pink sweater and pearls, and in her commercials she said, 'Some people say I should attack back, but I won't.' "
 
Bounced Checks And Many Warnings
Mr. Waldholtz, five years her junior, was the treasurer for his wife's 1994 campaign. Her associates say that is when his money problems became apparent.
"She was aware of Joe's financial improprieties by the summer of '94," said Steve Taggart, her former press secretary. "There were 50 or 60 bounced checks by then, and by June, there were 80 that we knew of." He added: "There were a zillion press reports about her problems, and she was obsessed with her press reports. You'd think she'd have had a clue by the 19th story."
By mid-June, Mr. Taggart and Kaylin Loveland, the campaign manager, told Mrs. Waldholtz about irregularities on her reports to the Federal Election Commission. Ms. Loveland said that Mrs. Waldholtz "assured me she understood what I was saying, and she said she and Joe would take care of it." Ms. Loveland wrote a memorandum that day and kept a copy, which she said she was not ready to make public.
When nothing happened, the two campaign workers met with David Hansen, a representative for the Republican National Committee, and David Jordan, the former United States Attorney for Utah, now a lawyer in private practice.
Mr. Jordan had a talk with Mr. and Mrs. Waldholtz. "Joe had lots of explanations for why things hadn't been done," Mr. Jordan said. "There were problems with the books; the records were hard to find or had been misfiled. At the end of the meeting, I told Enid that in my judgment, she needed to get a professional from outside and have them straighten out the books. I told her she shouldn't leave it to be done internally. She agreed."
By the end of the summer, Mr. Taggart and Ms. Loveland had quit, and Mrs. Waldholtz had heard from the state Republican chairman and even Governor Leavitt that her campaign had severe financial problems and that her husband should not be involved in her office. Still, she refused to act.
 
Trying to Explain An Influx of Money
By the end of August, she had raised just $280,000, and she was trailing in the three-way race. Then she startled many in Utah by pumping huge amounts of cash into her sagging campaign. First, she put in $880,000 plus a $15,000 loan; less than two weeks before the election, she put in $650,000 more.
Of the $1.8 million raised in the campaign, she reported furnishing more than $1.5 million of it herself.
The sudden infusion of cash drew questions immediately because she had spent only $313,000 on her 1992 race and still had a debt, and because she refused to say where the new money had come from. After the election, she hinted that it had been family money, then said it had come from her own money-management account.
Mrs. Waldholtz recently told Federal authorities that it had come from her father; she said he had swapped assets with her husband, although her husband apparently had none to swap.
David Owen, a friend and political consultant, said she would never "willfully defraud her father."
But David Magleby, a Democrat and the chairman of the political science department at Brigham Young University, said: "It doesn't add up. Was the father that dumb? How does someone that conservative, who has dealt with securities all his life, give money in that amount without checking it out?"
In the most recent account of the campaign funds, her lawyer said last week that Mrs. Waldholtz had known that her father was lending her and her husband more than $1 million, but she thought that money was to help her husband pay off debts, not for her campaign, which would be illegal. Federal election law says candidates cannot accept contributions of more than $1,000 from any individual. Moreover, they cannot spend more than half of any assets held jointly with a spouse.
The controversial contributions paid for television advertisements and a sophisticated direct-mail campaign. With that help, and a lift from the national surge for Republicans, Mrs. Waldholtz won, with 46 percent of the vote; Mrs. Shepherd won 36 percent, and Merrill Cook, an independent, won 18 percent.
For more than a year, the Utah press has been reporting irregularities in Mrs. Waldholtz's personal and campaign accounts, but Federal agents did not pick up the scent until late last month.
As recently as Nov. 1, Mrs. Waldholtz was defending her husband. "I will tell you most emphatically that there would be no truth to any allegation of wrongdoing by either my husband or me," she told The Hill, a Capitol Hill newspaper.
But when Mr. Waldholtz vanished on Nov. 11, Mrs. Waldholtz moved fast to distance herself from him. She filed a missing-person report immediately and filed for divorce two days later. She attributed her difficulties to what she described as her husband's endless deceits, saying she wanted him "tracked down, arrested and punished."
No one has been charged with any crime. Mr. Waldholtz turned himself in after a warrant was issued for his arrest in connection with a $1.7 million check-kiting scheme, and he is talking to Federal prosecutors in preparation for a court appearance on Dec. 15. The authorities hope that he will testify against his wife.
"He has no credibility, but he has a Rolodex in his brain," Mr. Magleby said. "That's what the Justice Department is bargaining for -- names, dates and phone numbers" of people who know what Mrs. Waldholtz knew and when she knew it.

HEADLINE: A Family Struggle for the Soul of Times Mirror

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26

 BODY:
To understand the deep changes roiling The Los Angeles Times and its parent, the Times Mirror Company, four months after a management turnover that brought wrenching cutbacks to the paper and its staff, it is useful to look much further back, to a different turning point in the paper's history.
On March 5, 1961, the newspaper began a tough five-part series on the far-right-wing John Birch Society. But for those who knew the Chandler family, which controls the newspaper, it was more than an expose on some anti-Communist zealots. 
 The Chandlers had previously used The Times as a mouthpiece for their intensely conservative politics, and so the series was perceived as both a declaration of editorial independence and an attack by one part of the family, led by Otis Chandler, who had succeeded his father as publisher a year earlier, against a faction led by Philip Chandler, Otis's uncle and a stout supporter of the John Birch Society.
Philip Chandler resigned from the company's board eight months later, and Otis Chandler was on his way to a 20-year reign of rising profits, journalistic excellence and what many perceived as a liberal editorial agenda. According to former top editors and executives of the paper, Otis Chandler had mounted what amounted to a subtle kind of coup: he insured that the measure of the newspaper's success in its owners' eyes would be financial returns rather than the number of Republican politicians the paper helped elect.
Whatever understanding there was, however, is as much a part of history as the old series on the John Birch Society. As the newspaper's returns dwindled in the late 1980's, a trend accelerated by the downward spiral of the local economy, the conservative heirs of Philip Chandler have pushed for management changes and more influence over the paper's content. The first wish was granted earlier this year when Robert F. Erburu was replaced as chief executive by Mark H. Willes, the former vice chairman of General Mills; the second wish seems unfulfilled, at least so far.
Prominent in their absence from the fray, at least publicly, are Otis Chandler, now 67, his three sons and his two daughters. Prominent in his desire to appear ascendant is his cousin Jeffrey, Philip's son. Whatever the merits of Jeffrey Chandler's views -- he is a large shareholder but has no role in the company's management -- he is the only Chandler who is talking to all comers about the newspaper that has been the symbol of the family's achievements.
"As long as the paper was doing well financially and as long as the dividends were growing it was just a whole bunch of rich people clipping coupons," Jeffrey Chandler, 53, the owner of two radio stations in San Diego, said in a recent interview. "We were frustrated with the paper's slant, but it was always talk. There was never a plan to do anything about it. If a newspaper is supposed to reflect the opinions of its owners, it hasn't."
Now, he insisted, that is changing.
"We just want the paper brought back to the center, and I think you've seen less extreme positions already," Mr. Chandler said. "The family feelings were made known to both Willes and Erburu, that we simply weren't going to tolerate this stuff any more."
After suffering through five years of costly missteps and weak earnings -- Times Mirror had a $67 million loss in 1992, and its return on equity last year was 9.5 percent, compared with an industry average of 14.5 percent -- the company has undertaken cutbacks, layoffs and the summary closing of some operations, like New York Newsday. The company said the cost-cutting moves would result in $540 million in after-tax charges this year.
The Chandlers still control nearly 60 percent of Times Mirror's voting stock and have 4 family members on the 15-member board, including Bruce Chandler, another of Philip's four children. But no Chandler holds a major executive position. And no Chandler has held a senior executive position since Otis stepped down as publisher of The Times in 1980 and as chairman of Times Mirror in the mid-1980's.
Otis Chandler's only attempt to place a family member in contention for a top job ended 15 years ago when his eldest son, Norman, suffered a brain tumor that ended his career.
Mr. Willes said in a recent interview that his instructions from the board had been general rather than specific. "There wasn't a mandate in the sense of 'We expect you to come in and have this done by this date,' " Mr. Willes said.
He added, though, that "the board and management know substantial change is needed." And Shelby Coffey 3d, the newspaper's editor, said neither the board nor the family had exerted any pressure on him to alter the paper's news coverage or its editorial policies.
It seemed sudden, but in fact Times Mirror's transformation and the rise of the more conservative side of the family had been proceeding quietly for a decade, ever since Otis Chandler was first pushed aside by the more conservative Chandlers, according to former editors and executives at the paper.
Indeed, one of the most conspicuous aspects of the recent changes is that Otis Chandler has all but disappeared from the company and even this city; his creative impulses are now channeled into his museum of vintage cars in Ventura County. In his few public comments he has abandoned the defiant attitude that once drove The Times and has maintained an air of quiet acceptance.
Reached at a new home in Bend, Ore., Mr. Chandler said he was too busy moving furniture to talk. But in a recent interview with The American Journalism Review, Mr. Chandler shocked some former colleagues and supporters by indicating that he had lost some of the fire he had brought to the newspaper years before.
Mr. Chandler has long been known for a note he wrote to Tom Johnson, his successor as publisher of The Los Angeles Times and now the president of CNN, saying, "Together we are going to push The New York Times off its perch."
But Mr. Chandler said in the interview that the vow was merely a tool "to rally the troops," as he put it, rather than a commitment. "Being a competitive person, maybe I got a little too arrogant, not only that we would be the best but that we would challenge the best," he said.
Bill Kovach, curator of the Nieman Foundation at Harvard University, said, "It's almost impossible for me to believe that what he's saying now is what he felt when he was doing the job."
One former top official of The Los Angeles Times who worked closely with Mr. Chandler and who insisted on anonymity, said: "We were astounded. It was totally inconsistent with what we knew and heard. But it tells you something about what is happening in that family."
Under Mr. Willes, the focus has shifted unmistakably to the bottom line. In fact, many believe he has humiliated Mr. Erburu with his criticisms of the company. "Hardly anyone paid much attention to return on capital," Mr. Willes said in a recent interview. "We were sinking like a rock in a number of places in the company."
In fact, Mr. Willes's cutting has raised the stock price, but some analysts are still concerned. Shares of Times Mirror closed at $31.25 on Friday, up sharply from a little more than $17 earlier this year. But now Times Mirror faces a deeper problem: Where is the company's growth going to come from?
"Cutting costs is necessary, but it will not make this an exciting growth company," said Peter P. Appert, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons. "They're going to have to shift toward growth at some point or the stock is going to head back down again."
And some Chandlers still want more change. Jeffrey Chandler would like to see an end to certain kinds of coverage, including product- liability suits by consumers against manufacturers, and assertions that some companies are placing heavily polluting factories in poor neighborhoods.
But there is no evidence that anyone on the editorial side of the newspaper is listening. The only indication of a rightward turn in the paper's policies was the endorsement last year of Gov. Pete Wilson, the Republican gubernatorial candidate. Many members of the editorial board opposed the publisher's decision to do so.
The decisive turns -- which in some ways set the stage for this year's executive changes -- began in the mid-1980's, when Otis Chandler was nudged aside as chairman of Times Mirror, according to former editors and executives at the paper, and persuaded to become chairman of the board's executive committee.
The coup was completed in 1989, when Mr. Erburu and conservative family members demanded that Mr. Johnson, Mr. Chandler's handpicked successor as publisher, fire the liberal head of the editorial page, Anthony Day.
Mr. Johnson refused, which led to his ouster. Shortly after, Mr. Day was replaced.
Otis Chandler and his wing of the family were losing influence. After Otis's son, Norman, suffered his brain tumor, another son, Michael, was left with severe head injuries from an accident while auto racing. He now holds a position in circulation in Orange County. A third son, Harry, 42, holds a midlevel job at The Times, but his mother said his real passion was film production, which he still pursues through an outside production company.
Harry Chandler offered in a brief telephone conversation to explain his views, but he did not return subsequent telephone calls.
Marilyn Chandler, Otis Chandler's former wife, said: "The problem is that Otis retired rather early. It's good to have a family member down there keeping an eye on things. I wish we had more."

HEADLINE: U.S. WILL DEPLOY ITS SPY SATELLITES ON NATURE MISSION

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
With the cold war a fading memory, the nation's spy satellites are beginning to turn some of their attention to nature.
In addition to peering at the usual military targets, they are monitoring such natural phenomena as clouds, glaciers, sea ice, deserts and tropical rain forests to gather clues about long-term global climatic change and ecological threats. 
 At the urging of Vice President Gore, and with the support of Congress, the new program is directing spy satellites to study about two dozen ecologically sensitive sites around the world. Ultimately, it is to monitor about 500 sites. Scientists are programming the satellites to study diverse habitats vulnerable to environmental shifts and damage, including some that are unusually remote and forbidding.
"In terms of turning swords into plowshares, this is about as good of an example as I can think of," said Dr. Jeff Dozier, dean of the school of environmental science at the University of California at Santa Barbara and a member of the program's management team.
The data will be archived for future generations of scientists and will remain secret for now to conceal the abilities of the nation's reconnaissance systems, the scientists said. Intelligence experts always try to hide the exact abilities of their surveillance systems so foes are less likely to know how to evade and counter them. And in any event, the data will be most interesting in future decades because it seeks to reveal trends over time.
The program picks areas of the Earth that are thought to be particularly revealing of changes in the natural world and repeatedly photographs them on a fixed schedule, seasonally in some cases. Data are to be collected for decades, in theory revealing subtle ecological shifts that might otherwise be missed. For example, Mount Kilimanjaro in northeast Tanzania near the Kenya border is to be scrutinized for signs that the Earth's rising levels of carbon dioxide are changing its high forests.
The monitoring effort is led by Medea, a taciturn group of about 60 scientists in academia and industry who advise the nation's intelligence agencies on the use of secret data to study the environment. Medea stands for Measurements of Earth Data for Environmental Analysis. The group was founded after the cold war to aid re-evaluations of the nation's sprawling intelligence enterprise and has championed an environmentalist agenda.
"We want to make sure that the scientist working in 2020 has available a lot of relevant information," Dr. Gordon J. MacDonald, Medea's chairman and a geophysicist at the University of California at San Diego, said in an interview.
The new reconnaissance effort is run for Medea by the National Reconnaissance Office in the Pentagon and is coordinated by the Central Intelligence Agency, which is apparently pleased with the broadening of its responsibilities.
"It's an exciting new issue to engage in," said a senior Federal intelligence official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Modest amounts of resources are producing interesting results. The other thing that makes it interesting is the high-level interest. It makes any producer enthusiastic if you've got eager customers."
The program is very different from the related effort to mine old spy-satellite photos for environmental data, a process the Clinton Administration recently began. That effort, featuring photos originally taken for military reasons, is often hit or miss in terms of ecological relevance. In contrast, the new effort directly targets nature and its subtleties.
So too, the program is different from recent intelligence gathering that studies natural phenomena for clues to the deeper roots of war and focuses on such things as drought, population growth and lack of arable land.
Medea scientists say spy satellites have several advantages over standard environmental studies. Coverage is wider and cheaper than that done by armies of scientists on the ground and can aid in spotting trends. Moreover, spy satellites can often assess faraway areas virtually inaccessible by other means.
The scientists add that spy satellites are better than civilian remote-sensing craft, like Landsat or Spot, which orbit the earth for the United States and France, respectively. Military craft can zoom in on ground targets, letting scientists learn more. Moreover, they say, these spy images can often aid civilian analyses.
"You can use the intelligence assets to make the interpretation of the civilian ones much more accurate," said Dr. Dozier of the University of California at Santa Barbara.
By definition, the vision of spy satellites is far more penetrating than civilian ones, though Medea scientists are barred from discussing such differences. It is well known that spy satellites not only take color and black-and-white photos but readings in hundreds of different parts of the electromagnetic spectrum, using such instruments as space radars to see through forest canopies and desert sands.
Since the cold war's end, policy makers in Washington have heatedly debated how best to use the nation's huge investment in spy satellites, with some encouraging a broadening to include economic intelligence in aid of businesses and trade negotiations.
The Republican-led Congress has been generally supportive of Medea and its environmental efforts, ignoring scattered critics who say the programs are inappropriate and wasteful and should be eliminated. For the fiscal year 1996, the Administration requested $17.6 million for the environmental work, and appropriations conferees allotted $15 million.
Representative Norman D. Dicks, Democrat of Washington, and his colleagues on the House Intelligence Committee wrote in a minority report on the 1996 budget that the initiative "promises to lead to better understanding of long-term environmental change as well as better management of crisis situations involving natural and ecological disasters."
Steven Aftergood, a senior researcher at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington, said the environmental reconnaissance was "potentially a watershed in the reform of intelligence," adding, "It reflects an expanding definition of national security."
"There are people who will paint this as soft-headed environmentalism," Mr. Aftergood said. "But in fact environmental changes can be an important source of regional conflict, so I think it's a perfectly legitimate redirection."
Marc A. Levy, a political scientist at Princeton University who studies ecological politics, said he applauded the change of focus but doubted if it had political staying power.
"I'm worried that it will be vulnerable to the ebbs and flows of security politics," Dr. Levy said. "Like Star Wars and the B-1 bomber, these things come and go."
But scientists involved in the program say its overhead is so low and the potential gains so great that it is likely to exist for the foreseeable future.
Since the nation launched its first spy satellite in 1960, it has spent $100 billion or more to acquire and use spacecraft laden with cameras, telescopes and antennas that spy on the Earth. Today each spy satellite is thought to cost roughly $1 billion and a dozen or so are believed to be constantly at work.
The Medea group is conducting two dozen or so experiments to see how effectively these spy satellites can monitor natural sites. In many cases, the experimental areas are long-term ecological reserves around the country that are financed by the National Science Foundation, which provides money for basic research.
In the near future, the reconnaissance effort is to expand to take on hundreds of other domestic and foreign sites, with Federal civilian agencies helping nominate areas. Dr. Dozier said that Medea had so far selected about 260 candidate sites around the world and that eventually some 500 would be targeted.
These are some of the current candidates:
*Clouds off the California coast between Los Angeles and San Diego;
*The Mojave Desert in California;
*The Luquillo experimental forest in Puerto Rico;
*A mixed coniferous-deciduous forest in Pleshcheyevo, Russia;
*The Konza prairie in Kansas;
*A lowland tropical rain forest at La Selva, Costa Rica;
*The forested slopes of the Sumava Mountains, Czechoslovakia;
*The coastal zone around the Galapagos Islands, off Ecuador;
*Permafrost in Fish Creek, Alaska;
*Glaciers in Griegsletchner, Switzerland;
*The high slopes of Mount Kilimanjaro.
Dr. Herman H. Shugart, an environmental scientist at the University of Virginia, is now working on a Medea project to study Mount Kilimanjaro and other mountains in the tropics. The thesis is that the increases of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere that are under way will first affect vegetation at high altitudes, causing it to become more verdant.
"If you're looking at the first place on Earth that might show a biological change, the place would be the highest vegetation zones you can find, and those puppies are found in tropical high forests," Dr. Shugart said.
"If this archival system works," he added, "then one day people will be able to say, 'By god, all those mountains are changing in the same way.' It gives you a chance to be creative about things that might matter."

HEADLINE: Retailers' Vision Of Full Registers Goes a Bit Awry

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
America went to the mall over the weekend, snooped around for bargains, nibbled on Mrs. Fields cookies and went home.
The post-Thanksgiving shopping traffic was heavy -- but spending was not, retailers and those who study them said yesterday. "We've had a lot of cruisers," said Vinny Castoro, an assistant manager at the Sears Office Center in the Paramus Park mall in Bergen County, N.J. "Time will tell if they'll come back and buy." 
 Apparel stores suffered the most and entertainment and consumer electronics enjoyed the biggest sales, although in nearly every category, shoppers compared prices, and many stores unloaded merchandise by slicing their profit margins.
Mall revenue was up 5.8 percent on Friday, compared with the day after Thanksgiving last year -- well below the 9 percent increase last year over 1993, according to the International Council of Shopping Centers, which polls 24 malls nationwide each year.
Check-writing on Friday declined 4.8 percent in the 10,000 stores monitored by Telecheck Services Inc., a steep loss compared with last year, when it was up 5.7 percent from the previous year.
"This was weaker than I expected," said William F. Ford, the senior economic adviser for the service, which studies check acceptance. "It looks like consumers started out very cautious."
The Friday after Thanksgiving -- known as Black Friday in the retail industry by those who count on the season to turn their books the same color -- has become less significant in recent years because more shoppers are doing buying closer and closer to Christmas, seeking markdowns in a game of chicken with merchants. The retailers acknowledge this and keep their inventories smaller.
Still, retailing executives still pay close attention to Thanksgiving weekend, even though it is no longer their busiest, as a barometer of what the rest of the holiday season may produce. Many do 40 percent of their annual business between Thanksgiving and the end of the year.
Kurt Barnard, president of Barnard's Retail Marketing Report, lowered his forecast on gains in same-store sales to a range of 3 to 4 percent, from 4 to 5 percent. "The most surprising thing is the depths of sales," Mr. Barnard said. "I've never seen 40 percent off before at this time and there are all kinds of additional incentives, like 'open a charge account today and and get an extra 10 percent off.' It's just wild."
While anything with the word "multimedia" on the package moved smartly, department stores were using discounts to get winter coats and dresses off the racks. Apparel made a meager 1 percent gain over last year, the mall survey found, while entertainment products boasted a 9.3 percent gain, energized by a range of products from "The Beatles Anthology" to movie-related items to software.
"The continued slump in apparel is a disappointment," said Mark Schoifet, spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers. "Everyone had their fingers crossed that this would be the year it would pick up, but it continues to be a major concern with mall operators nationwide."
Department store merchants, too, acknowledged that sales did not inspire them to do jigs in the aisles. "It went O.K.," said Philip B. Miller, chairman of Investcorp's Saks Fifth Avenue chain, adding that same-store sales were up 2.5 percent. "We had planned it a couple points higher," Mr. Miller said. "But I'm very sanguine about December because of the calendar." Christmas falls on a Monday, so the shopping season will be one day longer than usual.
Many retailers are counting on late shoppers; some said they hoped to gain because Hanukkah falls closer to Christmas this year than last. But their optimism may be blunted by factors like high consumer debt and shoppers who simply snub merchandise that is not on sale.
Throughout the country, stores ranging from Kay-Bee Toys, a Manville Corporation unit, to the Neiman Marcus unit of Harcourt General put their wares on sale. Even winter coats were discounted as much as 40 percent in many department stores.
Sears, Roebuck stores, however, appeared to be bustling throughout the country. "We had our best Thanksgiving weekend ever," said John Costello, senior executive vice president at Sears, although he declined to support that with hard numbers. "We don't expect same-store increases to approach the 8 percent December gain of last year, but we did hit our forecast," he said. Hot items included computers and accessories, as well as women's clothing, which has been the focus of the company's latest ad campaign.
Mr. Barnard confirmed that his researchers had found Sears stores packed in many areas, cash registers beeping happily. That the Paramus Park store was slow on Saturday seemed only to underscore the mercurial ways of shoppers that make forecasting hard.
"I think it's a very difficult weekend and people are going to have a tough time figuring it out," said Michael Gould, chief executive of Bloomingdale's, a unit of Federated Department Stores. "I'm not a big believer that this is the start of the holiday season. We had a good November so far, but December was not a good month last year after a spectacular November. So we'll wait and see."
As expected, computer and electronics stores like CompUSA and Radio Shack did better. "Friday and Saturday looked very good," said John Roach, chief executive of the Tandy Corporation, which owns Radio Shack. "At Incredible Universe, computer sales ran 30 percent higher than the prior Friday and Saturday," he said, the smile on his face evident even over a telephone line from Texas. "And at Radio Shack we had very strong sales in the toy area, up on the order of 25 to 30 percent over last year."
John Kale, general manager for sales and merchandise at Micro Center, a small computer-department-store chain based in Columbus, Ohio, said a new store in Dallas did $749,000 in sales on Friday, compared with a Houston store that opened on Thanksgiving weekend last year and took in $683,000. "In talking with some of the general managers yesterday, we were running between 8 and 13 percent ahead of last year," he said.
But even in computers, there was comparison shopping. Jeff Buenz, who was shopping at Fry's Electronics in Palo Alto, Calif., on Saturday, said, "I won't buy until some incredible deal comes up."
Wal-Mart discount stores appeared also to be an anomaly. Although executives refused to say anything about how their weekend went, retail experts said Wal-Mart stores were jammed from coast to coast.
Home furnishings, one area that analysts predicted would soar, seemed to flop on Friday -- the survey of mall shoppers found the category was down 2.3 percent from the similar period last year. Many home-specialty shops that were expected to be packed on Friday seemed instead like libraries.
And many shoppers may not just be holding off, but holding out. "If you don't know what your long-term budget is going to look like, you don't buy," said Marleen Ernstberger, a junior high school math teacher who left a Nordstrom store in Costa Mesa, Calif., empty-handed on Saturday. "You can only rob Peter to pay Paul for so long."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Rose 8% in October

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: MCLEAN, Va., Nov. 26

 BODY:
Orders for industrial tools made in the United States rose 8 percent in October from the month before, according to the Association for Manufacturing Technology.
While domestic customers raised their orders by 15.5 percent last month, demand from abroad fell 22.1 percent, the trade group's report showed. 
 Compared with October 1994, total orders rose 34.3 percent. The association said that orders for the first 10 months of the year were running 12 percent ahead of a year ago.
"We are happy to report that order activity in October has been stronger than most analysts were anticipating," Albert W. Moore, the association's president, said.
Economists follow orders and shipments of machine tools -- used to shape and assemble metal in products ranging from diesel engines to dishwashers -- to gauge industrial output, consumer demand and business investment.
More clues to the manufacturing outlook will come this week. The Commerce Department is to issue its report on October's orders for durable goods on Thursday, while the National Association of Purchasing Management is to release its November index of manufacturing activity on Friday.
The tools report showed that machine tool orders increased to $483.15 million in October, after rising 28.9 percent during September. Previously, September orders were reported to have risen 39.4 percent.
Machine tool shipments increased 12.9 percent in October, to $506.95 million. The backlog of orders, which tracks pent-up demand for tools, fell 1 percent, to $2.363 billion.

HEADLINE: Amtrak's Uphill Climb

 BODY:
Rail passenger service is the stepchild of America's transportation policy and the automobile culture Congress serves so slavishly. It took decades for urban transit systems to wrest even a penny of the Federal gasoline tax to help localities rationalize the way people get to and from work. Now Amtrak, the intercity people-mover struggling to gain its financial footing, is at the mercy of the highway lobby and their loyal legislators.
Congress must provide the financial security Amtrak needs. The passenger company, spun off from railroads that were allowed to concentrate on their viable freight business, deserves a sound financial base from a capital trust fund such as highway construction enjoys. So do rail customers, and so for that matter do motorists who seek open, uncluttered roadways. 
 It is a sad political fact that Amtrak -- already forced to reduce passenger service all across the country -- must beg Congress for this funding from the same half-penny of the gas tax that now goes to subways, buses and other forms of mass transit. Highway lobbies are so powerful that further inroads into the gas tax seem politically unachievable. Bud Shuster, chairman of the House Transportation Committee, says he will consider endowing Amtrak, provided the transit and intercity systems do not invade sacred highway funding.
That approach pits the various mass transit and intercity rail alternatives against each other while exempting highways from budgetary competition. Highway interests luxuriate in the myth that motor vehicles pay for their public costs in taxes at the fuel pump while the rail systems unworthily seek public subsidies.
Delaware's Senators, the Republican William Roth and the Democrat Joseph Biden, see the economics and the politics more charitably. They are two of Amtrak's steady commuting customers and have constituents who depend on Amtrak. Mr. Roth, chairman of the Finance Committee, argues that no other nation tries to run its passenger rail system without subsidy. For those who recommend privatizing Amtrak, Mr. Roth argues that a dedicated capital trust fund is still needed.
A Roth-Biden amendment to the highway bill would have let states allocate a little of their highway tax allocations to Amtrak they way they do now for anti-pollution and anti-congestion projects. But as Mr. Biden observed the other day, that flexibility was rejected because "the cement folks and the asphalt folks" were appalled that states might "spend money on something other than laying concrete or laying down asphalt."
The House's rejection of the modest Roth-Biden proposal indicates that Amtrak's road ahead is curvy and uphill. Although outnumbered, legislators who understand the need for transportation balance should press for hearings to demonstrate Amtrak's and the nation's plight. Through sharing of user taxes or some other means, America needs to find a way to save this necessary resource.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Living In A Cocoon

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
If you are heading for college or graduate school and are sensitive about being male, female, black, white, Asian, young, old, married, unmarried, gay, straight, Catholic, Jewish, evangelical Protestant or a veteran, think about going to the University of Massachusetts at Amherst. You will be protected there against offense to your group sensibilities.
That is the purpose of a new code of behavior proposed by the university's administration and its union of graduate student employees. It would punish as "harassment" a wide range of speech by faculty members or students -- including "epithets, slurs and negative stereotyping" -- that may offend groups. 
 Speech codes at universities had seemed to be on the decline. Several were held unconstitutional. So it is of more than parochial interest that an extraordinarily sweeping code should be proposed in this supposedly liberal-minded state.
The proposed code, circulated at the Amherst campus last month, would ban speech that offends "on the basis of race, color, national or ethnic origin, gender, sexual orientation, age, religion, marital status, veteran status or disability." The graduate students' union said it would add to that list "citizenship, culture, H.I.V. status, language, parental status, political affiliation or belief and pregnancy status."
Speech in those categories would be offensive if it "discriminatorily alters the conditions" of people's participation in the university. It would be judged by what a "reasonable" member of the one of the groups would think of the speech.
To enforce all this would be a complex apparatus of boards and panels. The university would train "volunteer advocates" to represent complainants and defendants. Penalties for students and faculty would range up to dismissal. The graduate students' union said there should also be "mandatory harassment education" at the Amherst campus.
Orwell is the name that comes to mind as one reads this proposal. It would create a totalitarian atmosphere in which everyone would have to guard his tongue all the time lest he say something that someone finds offensive. (The code would let anyone who heard a doubtful remark about some group bring a complaint, even if he was not a member of the group.)
Do the drafters have no knowledge of history? One wonders. No understanding that freedom requires, as Justice Holmes said, "freedom for the thought that we hate"? And if not, what are they doing at a university?
Conservatives who are on the look-out for Political Correctness will find the Amherst campus proposals a juicy target. (They might look to their own vulnerability, many of them, on the proposed constitutional amendment to outlaw flag-burning.)
Fortunately, faculty members across the political spectrum are rallying against the code. Daphne Patai, professor of Spanish and Portuguese, said many at the university understand that its job "is not to impose 'comfort' levels, that civility and suasion, not rules and regulations, are the way to shape the tone of a community."
Robert M. Costrell, professor of economics, said a student who was an unmarried mother might be offended by a statement warning that bringing up "large numbers of young men" in single-parent families could lead to "violence, unrest, disorder." The warning was given by Daniel Patrick Moynihan in 1965.
The chancellor at the Amherst campus, David K. Scott, responded to criticism by suggesting that a code was required by Federal Department of Education regulations. They threaten to withhold Federal aid from any university with a "hostile environment" in terms of race -- and similar gender rules are being prepared.
If so, the Federal regulations need revision. It is time to stop letting the elastic concept of a "hostile environment" menace freedom of speech, at universities of all places.

HEADLINE: OPERA REVIEW;
'Mahagonny,' an Apt Metaphor For Political Chaos in Any Era

BYLINE: By BERNARD HOLLAND 

 BODY:
If politics is the systemization of all that is worst in us, then "The Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny" is the most political of operas. Its banners are all-purpose: equally appropriate to social democrats, libertarians or republicans. So basic are its appraisals of human frailty that any party will do. The message of "Mahagonny" is, unfortunately, in no danger of becoming obsolete.
The Metropolitan Opera brought back John Dexter's 1979 production of the Kurt Weill-Bertolt Brecht stage piece on Saturday afternoon. Its mythical evocation of New World free enterprise looks to faraway places but grows out of a specific environment, the economic and spiritual chaos of Germany in the 1920's. It was a time when Communism and Fascism were in the bloom of youth, when capitalism had reached comfortable maturity, when greed was enjoying its ripe old age and hope was on its deathbed. 
 The Weill-Brecht collaboration formulates an America (for though unspecified, this country it surely is) reminiscent of Franz Kafka's in the unfinished novel "Amerika." Both are Middle European fantasies fed by a few facts, a collection of fictional film images and many dreams. Place names like "Mahagonny" and "Pensacola" were chosen more for their euphony than for any geographic relevance. While Kafka's tone is quizzical and bemused, the opera greets the cruelty it confronts with an equally cruel stare.
Mahagonny is a gold-rush town rising almost instantaneously out of an unnamed wasteland and running on avarice and unregulated brutality. It houses no heroes, only victims and victimizers. Jimmy Mahoney, its male protagonist, is executed for the capital crime of having no money. Jenny, the object of Jimmy's attentions, is not one to let passion (or compassion) get in the way of self-interest. Jimmy's well-heeled friends could easily buy his freedom, but don't.
Brecht's socialist passions found a friend in Weill's sophisticated embrace of popular music. In abrasive harmonies and stern counterpoint, one hears vestiges of the composer's once-rigorous modernism, but this is predominantly the Kurt Weill of smoky bars and parades: long, sinuous, deceptively simple melodies that at their best soar with anthemlike power. The brass-heavy orchestrations tootle with paradoxical good humor.
The Dexter setting is appropriately working class, but it has a hard time occupying the Met's big stage. The proscenium is framed in dull-gray panels; a white curtain attached to a simple rod opens and closes on every scene. A bar, a cut-out palm, a platform, a few chairs constitute the prevailing rough-and-ready-ness.
There is too much simplicity and too little spectacle to fill up these vast spaces. One kept admiring the endless zeal of principals like Kenneth Riegel (Fatty), Timothy Noble (Trinity Moses) and Helga Dernesch (Mrs. Begbick) as they labored to ee-nun-cee-ate every English word of the David Drew-Michael Geliot translation. All of the principals seemed to find themselves belting to the limits of their techniques, hoping to reach the audience spaces in front of them. "Mahagonny" is grand opera but not inflated opera. It is happier on a smaller stage than this.
Jenny is not always the center of attention, but she is the center of "Mahagonny," personifying the city's amalgam of frailty, helplessness and moral indifference, all seductively wrapped in sensuality. Teresa Stratas's cancellation because of illness was a big blow to Saturday's performance. Sheri Greenawald took her place and sang with a diligence that was both earnest and devoid of charm. The scenes designed with Jenny's presence in mind sagged; most of the others flew nicely.
Gary Lakes sang Jimmy in his aggressive, tough-sounding tenor. Alan Held's Moneybags Billy filled the house easily and agreeably. Mr. Riegel, Mr. Noble and Miss Dernesch labored honorably and agreeably in their somewhat hostile surroundings. David Kneuss's stage direction remembers and reproduces John Dexter's visual sarcasms well. James Levine conducted an orchestra touched with saxophone, banjo and barroom piano. There was some splendid brass playing.
For one reason or another, Saturday's audience fled the house in a slow but steady trickle. The audience at the end was more than a skeleton crew, but not that much more.
 
THE RISE AND FALL OF THE CITY OF MAHAGONNY
 
Opera in three acts by Kurt Weill; libretto by Bertolt Brecht; English translation by David Drew and Michael Geliot. Conductor, James Levine; director, David Kneuss; sets and costumes by Jocelyn Herbert; lighting by Gil Wechsler; choreography by John Meehan. Performed by the Metropolitan Opera.

WITH: Sheri Greenawald (Jenny), Helga Dernesch (Mrs. Begbick), Gary Lakes (Jimmy), Kenneth Riegel (Fatty), Timothy Noble (Trinity Moses), Jan-Hendrik Rootering (Alaska Wolf Joe), Tony Stevenson (Toby Higgins), Richard Versalle (Jacob Schmidt), Alan Held (Moneybags Billy), and Victoria Litherland, Kathryn Day, Hillary Nicholson, Reveka Mavrovitis, Victoria Livengood and Sandra Walker (Ladies of Mahagonny).

HEADLINE: House Compromised to Pass the Highway Bill;
Billboard Economics

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Senate's Highway Cave-In" (editorial, Nov. 21) omitted important factors about the outdoor advertising provision in the recently passed national highway system bill. 
 The technical clarification surrounding outdoor advertising in the commercial and industrial "nonscenic" portions of scenic byways is a victory for states' rights, rural economic development and scenic conservation.
The bill gives states the decision-making power to boost local economies in rural areas by allowing outdoor advertising in commercial and industrial zones. As many as 20 percent of the total jobs in rural, scenic areas depend on the travel-tourism dollar, and many small travel-related businesses depend on billboards to bring them customers. In these rural areas, small businesses use 90 percent of the billboards, with 70 percent advertising travel and tourism services.
Most scenic byways have breaks in continuity for incorporated towns, business zones and cities. For instance, Minnesota's Great River Road passes through St. Cloud, a city with a population of 51,000. West Virginia's Midland Trail passes by a chemical plant. The highway bill permits states to establish their own criteria for designating scenic byways that can exclude from designation segments that are not truly scenic. It is only in these segments that new billboard construction is permitted, and only if in compliance with state and local controls.
The billboard provision makes partners of business and scenic beauty in an effort to boost the economies of rural areas.
 
NANCY J. FLETCHER
President & Chief Executive Officer
Outdoor Advertising Assn. of America
Washington, Nov. 21, 1995

HEADLINE: A Multimedia Assault Takes Shape

BYLINE: By LAURIE FLYNN 

 BODY:
Maybe it is his penchant for luring big-name talent like Kevin Wendle, a co-founder of the Fox television network and one-time producer of "Beverly Hills 90210." Or perhaps it is the way he boldly strikes deals for exclusivity when it just is not done. Halsey Minor is proof that the once-cozy Internet, with its roots in academia and the military establishment, is today steeped in the no-holds-barred competitive traditions of American capitalism.
With new electronic magazines popping up daily on the World Wide Web, there is a land-rush feel to the place, and Mr. Minor is intent on staking out his audience early. Mr. Minor, the 30-year-old chief executive of the C/net on-line computer magazine, begun in June, offers a telling example of the aggressiveness, energy and seed money that may be required to set down economic roots in God's little cyberacre. 
 What makes C/net different from other computer magazines on the Web is that the Web site is the leading edge of Mr. Minor's multimedia assault, a business strategy that he hopes will outflank rivals whose roots are in the print-and-ink world. Calling his computer information service a "network" (perhaps a bit prematurely), Mr. Minor is also offering a half-hour cable television show, "C/net Central," that runs several times a week on the USA Network and the Sci-Fi Channel.
"Our category, computers, is going to be the most competitive, simply because it's the first to happen," Mr. Minor said.
Mr. Minor would not say just how much money he received from his principal investors, which include Paul G. Allen, the billionaire co-founder of Microsoft, along with the USA Network, a unit of Viacom Inc. Nor will he say how much he has spent so far. But he estimates that it takes roughly $10 million to start a commercial on-line service and take it to profitability, which he hopes to do by the end of next year. Beginning a television network, by far the more expensive of C/net's two propositions, can require as much as $75 million.
The Web site has been the primary focus of C/net's new advertising campaign, which has sought visibility in places like the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where C/net ads have been plastered on 100 buses.
Yet in the end, no amount of hype will keep the audience if, when people find its Web site (http:/ www.cnet.com), there is nothing there to hold their attention. So while Mr. Minor is spending big sums to get people's attention, he is investing even more in a product that will hold their attention long enough to satisfy advertisers like Intel, Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard.
As do its counterparts in print, C/ net includes reviews of new computer products, like the newest hand-held computer; comparisons of the latest Web browsing software, and columnists like John Dvorak, an industry gadfly.
But as do all Web-based publications, C/net offers something print publications cannot: a reader can move quickly from one document to another by clicking on the various links attached to them. Also, the site can be continually updated.
Mr. Minor argues that these advantages will lure many high-technology companies. "We see an enormous opportunity to move revenue out of magazines and into on-line," he said, "particularly in this category: computers."
 Other on-line experts agree that the electronic media are beginning to encroach on the print industry's territory.
"Halsey is shrewdly going after" the traditional media, said Adam Schoenfeld, an analyst at Jupiter Communications, a market research company in New York. He added that traditional media were reluctant to move to digital media "because it diverts resources from their core business."
But the publishers of the nation's large computer magazines counter any notion that they are somehow cannibalizing their own advertising revenues, insisting that their electronic publishing ventures were not hurting ad sales but helping them.
The CMP Corporation of Manhasset, L.I., maintains a popular Web site called Techweb, and Ziff-Davis has ZDNet, both of which depend on ad revenues. A third publisher, the IDG Corporation, has a number of smaller sites associated with single titles, like PC World magazine.
Techweb "has actually helped our print sales," said Mitchell York, managing director for Interactive Media at CMP, which publishes computer magazines like Computer Reseller News, Netguide and Information Week. "Companies want to know we have an on-line service. They're looking for that medium."
While the traditional publishers contend that publishing in two media helps them to sell ads, C/net has its own approach to multiple media programming with "C/net Central," the television show.
"On line is very much like TV," Mr. Minor said. "It includes all the same things -- the talent issues and production elements are all the same, and they're both ratings-based."
C/net executives hope the show will whet people's appetite for more in-depth information, available on the on-line service. While Mr. Minor started out thinking that revenues from television would account for the largest chunk of C/net's total, today he thinks of the television venture as a way to build brand identity for what appears to be a larger cash cow, the Web site, which also makes its money from advertising.
As a result, the company has slowed its original schedule for beginning a 24-hour computer cable network, though at least two new shows are planned for early next year. "On line is eclipsing our expectations, and television is meeting it," Mr. Minor said. Advertisers are attracted to the on-line service's ability to track precisely how many people view an ad and click on it for more information.
But in television, in contrast to the more crowded field of computer magazine publishing, there is less competition for "C/net Central." PCTV of Phoenix, Ariz., for example, produces computer shows, but it lacks the flashiness of "C/net Central," which is a sort of MTV for computer lovers. (The show features Richard Hart, a longtime television personality in the San Francisco area who is known for putting computerese into people terms.)
And competitive shows anticipated from Ziff-Davis and a partnership of Microsoft and Tele-Communications Inc. have never materialized. (Mr. Minor denies recent published reports that Tele-Communications may make an investment in C/net.) The challenge now is to find the right content.
For C/net's on-line venture, the challenge is to sustain its popularity.
To keep his site competitive, Mr. Minor spun off a new site earlier this month on the Web devoted to "shareware," where subscribers can locate and retrieve any of thousands of software programs and install them -- free or for a nominal charge -- on their own computers.
At the same time Mr. Minor signed a deal with Yahoo, a sort of Web yellow pages, that insures that only C/net's advertising is displayed on the Yahoo home page, to the exclusion of principal competitors like Techweb and ZDNet.

HEADLINE: Wisconsin Governor Endorses Dole for President

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, who has been a leader among the country's governors in pressing the Federal Government to transfer more power to the states, endorsed Senator Bob Dole today for the Republican Presidential nomination.
"He has been truly a friend of all of the governors this past year when he was working so hard in the United States Senate to carry the difficult message that we have to balance the budget, we have to reform welfare and we have to keep the economy moving," Mr. Thompson said. Earlier this year, Mr. Thompson had considered seeking the Presidential nomination himself. 
 Mr. Thompson's endorsement gave Mr. Dole, the front-runner for his party's nomination, the backing of 16 of the 30 Republican Governors, far more than any other candidate. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona have endorsed the Presidential bid of Senator Phil Gramm of Texas; Gov. Don Sundquist of Tennessee has endorsed Lamar Alexander, a former Tennessee governor.
Other Republican governors, like Kirk Fordice of Mississippi, have said they are close to endorsing Mr. Dole.
In accepting Mr. Thompson's endorsement, Mr. Dole said that he would be leaning on the Wisconsin Governor for political advice, and he hinted that he might consider Mr. Thompson as a running mate.
Mr. Dole declared that he wanted a Vice-Presidential nominee with a good political record who wanted a limited role for government, lower taxes, less Federal regulation and more responsibility for the states.
"Obviously, Governor Thompson fits most of those, probably all of those, and would probably be on anyone's list for Vice President and would have been an outstanding candidate for President himself," Mr. Dole said.
In recent months, Mr. Dole has floated the names of Gov. Pete Wilson of California; Dan Lungren, California's Attorney General, and Gen. Colin L. Powell, former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, as potential running mates.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2091 words

HEADLINE: Trying to Stem Emissions, U.S. Sees Its Goal Fading

SERIES: THE AIR IN 2000 -- First of two articles.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
For every step the United States takes to cut emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases that scientists say are warming the earth's atmosphere, it seems to be slipping two steps back from its goal.
Across the country, for instance, more than 1,100 companies have signed up to do as the American Express Company is doing at its 51-story headquarters in lower Manhattan. There, under an agreement with the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, the company has installed new energy-efficient lighting that saves it up to 40 percent on electricity bills. 
 Using less electricity means burning less coal and oil, and therefore emitting less carbon dioxide. Through this simple expedient, American Express has cut annual emissions by about 3,300 tons all told in New York and five other cities.
But a few miles away in Montclair, N.J., not long ago, vivid evidence of backsliding sat resplendently on the floor of Montclair-Bloomfield Motors: a red 1996 Ford Explorer, Eddie Bauer model, one of the gasoline-guzzling sport utility vehicles, vans, minivans and pickups made by all American car companies whose surging popularity is reversing longtime advances in fuel efficiency. The carbon dioxide emitted by about 700 Explorers -- less than half a day's production -- more than cancels out all of American Express's gains.
Do customers ever ask about carbon dioxide emissions when shopping for an Explorer? "Not once," said Ed Goldstein, the business manager of the Ford agency. "Environment is probably last on the list."
The net result of this sort of energy-use tug of war across the broader economy is that the United States is faltering in its effort to cut emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000, as this country and other rich nations are pledged to do under a treaty signed at the 1992 United Nations conference on the environment in Rio de Janeiro.
The Clinton Administration attributes the shortfall mainly to higher emissions brought about by unexpectedly strong economic growth and reduced energy prices. The Administration has promised to take stronger action if its initial actions prove insufficient, but the United States could fall even further behind if the Republican-run Congress carries out plans to cut up to 40 percent of the money used mainly to stimulate private investment in energy-saving measures.
The Republicans display "great hostility" to the Administration's plan, Vice President Al Gore, the driving force behind the policy, said in an interview. And indeed, the conservative Republican chairman of a House subcommittee that deals with environmental issues, Representative Dana Rohrabacher of California, says concern about global warming may just be "liberal claptrap."
 
Initial Effort
Even Opening Step Is Falling Short
This political byplay comes at a time when scientists around the world are more convinced than ever that emissions of carbon dioxide, the major contributor to the tons of carbon in the atmosphere, and certain other gases pose a serious threat.
A United Nations panel of scientists advising parties to the climate treaty, in a draft report now undergoing final review, recently concluded for the first time that human influences already have probably caused some warming of the atmosphere.
The 2,500-member group, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, predicts that the warming will increase over the next century and beyond and that the resulting climate changes and rise in sea level are likely to cause widespread economic, social and environmental dislocation if greenhouse gas emissions are not reduced.
Even before these latest findings, the 142 nations that are parties to the 1992 treaty had opened negotiations on stronger emissions-reduction measures. The aim of cutting emissions to 1990 levels by 2000 -- a nonbinding treaty goal to which the United States and other rich countries have voluntarily subscribed -- was never intended as anything more than a first step in a decades-long effort to deal with the risk of climate change.
Going beyond the first step now appears more daunting than ever in view of the stumbling of not just the United States, but most other industrialized countries as well. Britain, Denmark, the Netherlands and Switzerland say they expect to reduce carbon dioxide emissions below 1990 levels by 2000, and Germany expects an 11 percent drop from 1990 levels by 2005. But eight other industrialized countries expect to join the United States, the world's leading emitter of carbon dioxide, in falling short of the treaty goal.
It is a shaky initial example for the developing countries, which are not yet bound to any specific aims but whose emissions are expected to outstrip those of the rich nations in the decades ahead.
The Administration's Climate Change Action Plan, adopted two years ago as an executive branch policy, relies mostly on an array of voluntary measures by business, industry and homeowners to cut energy use and thereby carbon emissions. Its philosophy is exemplified by the program for stimulating investment in more efficient lighting, Green Lights, in which the Federal Government acts as catalyst, provider of reliable technical information and cheerleader.
For instance, the Environmental Protection Agency recruited American Express as a Green Lights participant. Because of the long-term savings in electricity bills, the company agreed. In another wrinkle of a sort encouraged by the Clinton plan, Consolidated Edison, the utility company, provided a one-time incentive rebate to American Express. The resulting energy savings by many such Con Ed customers obviates the need for the utility to build new power plants, saving money and emissions.
Green Lights began in the Bush Administration, and utilities in many parts of the country have been offering energy-saving incentives to businesses and consumers for some time, but both efforts are being expanded and encouraged under the Clinton plan. Companies now participating in or committed to Green Lights are expected to save 14.3 million tons of carbon dioxide a year, and the E.P.A. projects annual savings of 44 million tons by 2000. More than $3 billion in annual electric bill savings are also projected for 2000, along with a substantial reduction in other air pollutants.
There is "really no downside," said Martin T. Warfel, an American Express vice president.
 
Moderate Measures
Indirect Approach To Emissions Cuts
Many experts believe that these sort of "no regrets" measures are the way to go in the near term: reducing carbon dioxide emissions through energy-efficiency measures that make sense for other reasons. The experts do not agree on whether this will be enough to solve the problem in the long term.
In view of scientists' uncertainty about how serious the climate problem is, almost no one is advocating costly, Draconian action just yet, and no country has taken any.
The Administration's plan outlines more than 50 measures, many patterned on the Green Lights approach. They include awarding "Energy Star" labels to energy-efficient office equipment, appliances and computers, planting more trees to absorb carbon dioxide, setting higher efficiency standards for home appliances, though Republican-sponsored legislation would place a moratorium on them and reducing emissions of methane, the second most important greenhouse gas, from farms and leaky natural gas lines.
Together the measures represent a long and varied menu of ways to reduce emissions. The plan projects a total Federal expenditure of less than $800 million from 1994 through 2000. This expenditure is designed to induce $60 billion in private investment over the same period, the fruits of which, the Administration calculates, would produce an annual reduction in total greenhouse gas emissions equivalent to nearly 440 million tons of carbon dioxide by 2000 -- and a cumulative total of nearly $286 billion in energy savings between 1994 and 2010.
The emissions reduction, according to the Administration's original calculations, would bring total United States emissions back in line with the 1990 figure of something more than five billion tons of carbon-dioxide equivalent. But with faster economic growth and lower energy prices unexpectedly boosting emissions, Mr. Gore said, "we can fairly say" that the country will miss the 2000 target the way things are now going, even with no budget cuts.
 
Tough Issue
Lack of Consensus On Motor Vehicles
The glaring omission in the Administration's plan is its lack of any significant measure to rein in motor vehicle emissions, which account for a third of all the carbon dioxide spewed out and are growing faster than emissions from any other source.
Perhaps made gun-shy by its early failure to secure Congressional passage of an energy tax, the Administration included in the action plan only a few small measures to encourage less driving. It has proposed no gasoline tax or increase in Federal gasoline mileage standards, the two measures most often advocated to cut fuel use and emissions significantly.
Instead, the Administration entered a yearlong discussion with the automotive and petroleum industries and environmentalists that broke up in September after failing to reach a consensus. A major reason was opposition from industry to taxes or tightened gas mileage standards.
The Administration is considering what to do next about motor vehicles. "We don't view it as that the problem is intractable or that solutions don't exist," Mr. Gore said.
One possibility is to raise the mileage standard for light trucks -- pickups, sport utility vehicles, vans and minivans -- like the Explorer in Montclair. They have replaced station wagons as the big gas drinker in many driveways, wasting both power and fuel on short trips to school or supermarket.
Light trucks average only 20 miles a gallon of gas, while passenger cars average 28, yet the trucks have now taken over 40 percent of the domestic market, causing overall fleet mileage to decline. At the same time, more miles are being driven. Theresult is that automotive carbon dioxide emissions continue to rise.
But the prospects for raising the mileage standards are muddy at best, since Republican-sponsored legislation would prevent any such action.
The Administration is pinning many of its longer-term hopes on a collaboration between the Federal Government and the auto industry to develop, in the next decade, a prototype family-size car that would be three times as energy-efficient as today's.
There is wide agreement that it is critical to invest now in research and development along a broad front, including eventual alternatives to fossil fuels, before the next long-term investment cycles lock in obsolete technology.
In the case of the hoped-for "super car," some environmentalists note that the industry has not yet committed itself explicitly to producing any of the new vehicles. They say the project is an industry ploy to delay taking meaningful action on emissions.
Mr. Gore disagreed, saying, "You can be certain that such a vehicle will be produced when the ability to make it is demonstrated." He said he had considerably more optimism about this project than about shorter-term efforts to reduce automotive emissions. The prototype should be ready within eight years, he said, "maybe before."
In the meantime, political skirmishing over climate change continues. Representative Rohrabacher said last summer that he assumed global warming "at best, to be unproven and, at worst, to be liberal claptrap, trendy but soon to go out of style in our Newt Congress."
In recent interviews, he said that after reading and hearing more about global warming, "I'm now even more inclined to think it's liberal claptrap," adding that "far too many people in the Government and media are far too willing to listen to and amplify any claim of doom by someone who's wearing a white coat."
For his part, Mr. Gore said of the effort to reduce emissions that nobody "is under any illusions about how tough this is going to be."
"It's at the outer boundary of what is possible in our world," he added, "but it is possible." As the evidence of climate change "inexorably accumulates," he predicted, "the degree of difficulty in getting support for effective responses will decline."
 
The Air in 2000
A future article will examine the looming effects on global warming posed by China, with its vast coal reserves and rapid economic growth.
