HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Blue Chips Keep Climbing, But Nasdaq Is Down Again
A rally in bonds helped to lift the Dow Jones industrial average to another record-breaking advance; it surged 22.04 points, to 5,070.88, its 63d record close for 1995. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.35 points, to 601.32, barely surpassing the record of 600.24 set last Tuesday. But the Nasdaq index continued to lag the blue-chip rally, easing 0.85 point, to 1,029.32. [Page D10.]
 
Bonds rose on reports of sluggish weekend retail sales and yesterday's report that sales of existing homes fell in October. [D17.]
 
Concerns About Intel's Sales
Intel's stock fell $3 a share, to $60, after a disclosure that a large customer could not pay its $470 million account and that Intel had converted part of that bill into a loan. Analysts grew concerned that slow sales by the client, believed to be Packard Bell, could hurt Intel's results. [D2.]
 
Home Resales Stop Rising
Sales of previously owned homes slipped 1.9 percent in October, the first drop in six months, the National Association of Realtors said. Still, October was the third consecutive month that sales remained at an annual rate of more than four million. Trade-up buyers are re-entering the market, which has recently been dominated by first-time buyers, the association said. [D2.]
 
Emissions Goal Is Slipping
The United States is faltering in efforts to cut emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000, as it has pledged to do. Progress is being made in some areas, like energy-efficient lighting in office buildings, but there is backsliding elsewhere, such as in the fuel efficiency of sport utility vehicles. [A1.]
 
The Mark Falls on Rate Speculation
The dollar rose to a seven-week high against the German mark, aided by speculation that Germany's central bank would soon lower interest rates. [D9.]
 
Single Currency, Many Squabbles
A meeting of European finance ministers showed that, though the European Union is moving toward the creation of a single currency, the process will be fraught with backbiting and squabbles. [D7.]
 
Former Tobacco Executive Silenced
A judge maintained a temporary restraining order barring a former Brown & Williamson executive from disclosing corporate secrets. The executive, Jeffrey Wigand, has been at the center of a controversy since "60 Minutes" canceled an interview with him. [A20.]
 
Exclusive Pact Ending for Prudential
The American Association of Retired Persons plans to end its exclusive arrangement with Prudential Insurance when the pact expires. Prudential's 5.6 million association clients account for more than a third of its customers for health insurance. [D4.]
 
A G.M. Strategy Is Vindicated
To stem the erosion of sales in California, General Motors initiated a "value pricing" strategy in 1993. G.M. says the approach has helped to raise its market share in California to nearly 23 percent. [D4.]
 
Starting a New Studio
Mike Medavoy, the former chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, said he would form a new entertainment company with Sony Pictures and two other backers. [D8.]
 
Time for Action on Losing Stocks
Investors with long-term losses in their portfolios might want to dump those stocks this year. Or, to take advantage of a tax maneuver, today may be a good day to buy more shares if they think those losing stocks will rise. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D10.]

HEADLINE: In Brooklyn, Wake for Slain Child Is a Forum of Grief, Shock and Rage

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

 BODY:
They waited in line for an hour, sometimes longer, their anger palpable just beneath their grief. They formed a battalion of women, mothers from Bushwick, Brownsville and Manhattan.
Few of them knew 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo, who was beaten to death last week, but they came to her wake anyway, a crowd 300 people strong, in an unorchestrated gesture of grief and outrage. 
 In a city where the deaths of abused children are not uncommon, Elisa's pain seemed somehow to overwhelm people -- and it seemed to affect most deeply the mothers of New York's poorer neighborhoods, who know just how difficult raising children in the inner city can be.
With their sons and daughters in tow yesterday, they raged against neighbors who heard but did not act, a family who knew but could not help, and a system that they said ignored telltale signs of a deeply troubled home life.
Many of those at the wake had themselves felt the pain of drug addiction, unemployment and domestic violence. But as mothers, they could not forgive -- or even comprehend -- what is said to have occurred in Awilda Lopez's home last week. Ms. Lopez is charged with murdering Alisa, her third oldest child.
"How can a mother kill her daughter?" asked Carmen Delgado, whose own son was shot to death on the streets. "I have a daughter myself and it's wrong, just wrong."
As they filed past the small coffin at the Ponce Funeral Home in Bushwick, Brooklyn, most of the mothers wept with little restraint; some of them gasped. Elisa Izquierdo lay with her white frilly dress, white stockings and white shoes, her face heavily made up to cover the bruises on her skin. Behind her a Barbie doll rested on the coffin's satin cover. A pile of stuffed animals, brown, white and black, spilled over the sides, resting playfully on Elisa's legs.
After walking by Elisa in her coffin, Carmen Luna held back her tears and spoke about the child's tug on the community of mothers. "No one here knows her, but she's like my little girl," Ms. Luna said. "She's everyone's little girl today."
Keisha Causell, who came all the way from Brownsville to get a glimpse of Elisa, reserved her harshest words for the child welfare system that was in charge of monitoring the Lopez family. She asked: "How many kids have to be returned to their family only to wind up here? She's just another file to them, not a human."
The system, Ms. Causell said, is broken and it should not have taken Elisa's battered body to fix it. "I know that and I don't have a Ph.D. or nothing," she said.
Others were there as testament to their own hurt and strength. Sandra Reyes said she also battled with drug addiction and lost her children for nearly two years. But with help from her mother and through her own determination the Bushwick mother got her life in order. "I felt her pain," she said, referring to Ms. Lopez. "But there is always a way for you to get out of whatever situation you are in." And where, she asked, was her family?
Friends and relatives also crowded the room through the night. Barbara Simmons, Elisa's teacher from the Y.W.C.A., came from Georgia, shattered by the news that her favorite student had been killed. She walked into the funeral home unprepared to see Elisa's frail body laid out. "She's not the flower I once knew so well," Ms. Simmons said, choking back her tears.
Relatives of Gustavo Izquierdo, who had cared for Elisa until his death, said they want Elisa to be buried with her father and were trying to resolve that with Ms. Lopez's family. "He loved her so much," said Maria Crespo, a friend of Mr. Izquierdo's.
But in the viewing room and the lobby, Mr. Izquierdo's family and co-workers kept to themselves, maintaining their distance from Ms. Lopez's family, who they said shared the blame for Elisa's death. Yet they, too, were full of regret that they had not been able to save her.
"I tried and I failed," said Elsa Canizares, who had attempted to get custody of Alisa after her father's death. "I tried but I failed."
While family and friends mourned inside, the women continued to arrive outside. They were unshakable in their belief that no crime is worse than the crime of a mother against her own child. "I have eight kids and I would never do anything like that to them," said Sandra Rosario, of Bushwick. "No matter how high she was on drugs, she knew what she was doing. The poor little innocent. A child like that has no devil inside her. The mother is the one with the devil inside."

QUESTIONS IN GIRL'S DEATH

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD: IN BELGRADE;
The Serb's Hopes Rise As the Sanctions Fall

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Nov. 27

 BODY:
He started with a dream and a whisk, stirring the ingredients himself in a metal pot to make ketchup on a two-burner electric stove.
Now, three and a half years later, 41-year old Vojin Starcevic owns Polimark, a company that has 65 employees working in three shifts, seven days a week, producing 3.5 tons of ketchup a day on modern machines. 
 Polimark's dramatic growth is even more remarkable because it came while Yugoslavia, which consists of Serbia and Montenegro, was subject to economic sanctions.
The lifting of the sanctions by the United Nations Security Council last week should reduce Polimark's costs. Both tomato concentrate and the ingredients to make plastic bottles can now be legally imported, thus eliminating the bribes Mr. Starcevic said he has had to pay to get them into the country. And Mr. Starcevic dreams of exporting his ketchup, which he could not do under the sanctions.
But lifting the sanctions has created some paradoxes. Polimark, which took advantage of the monopoly market at home created by the sanctions, faces competition from European and American companies that can now come back.
"We are apprehensive," said Radovan Cokic, Polimark's marketing director. "But I would call that creative apprehension."
The sanctions on Yugoslavia went into effect in May 1992 -- one month after Mr. Starcevic started his company. They were lifted after the signing of the Balkan peace agreement in Dayton. The Yugoslav Government quickly announced a series of economic measures intended to make the economy more market-oriented. But many powerful politicians do not share Mr. Starcevic's entrepreneurial spirit, finding it easier to make money under the old socialist system.
At first glance, this country does not appear to have suffered undue hardship under sanctions. "We managed to live better under sanctions than most people do without them," said Ljubila Depeljkovic, 60, walking across the grass at her high-rise apartment complex, where boys were playing basketball.
Shops in downtown Belgrade are well stocked with fashionable clothes, food, computers and electronics equipment. People generally did not have to sell their possessions to get money, or to burn their books to heat their apartments, as they have, for example, in struggling Armenia in recent winters.
But everything is relative. Yugoslavs remember the days when they went to Italy to shop. And while consumer goods were smuggled in while the sanctions were on, selection was limited and the prices were high, especially for people without wages because the sanctions had shut down the factories where they worked.
Electricity was rationed. One young man said that often meant he could not read at night. And when Lijlana Mantrak took her newborn son home from the hospital last winter, it was 60 degrees in her apartment, she remembered, as she pushed him in a stroller bundled against the bitter cold.
In another paradox, the end of sanctions has brought lines -- not because of shortages, but because of plenty.
On each of the last two days, drivers have waited patiently in mile-long lines at gas stations. While sanctions were in effect, the stations were closed. Drivers bought gas from roadside vendors who had smuggled it into the country. They sold it at high prices, often after diluting it with water.That gasoline ruined many a car engine.
In addition to giving companies like Polimark a market opportunity, sanctions had another side effect. Many inefficient state-owned companies that were remnants of the system in operation before the breakup of the former Communist state have been driven to near-death. Before the sanctions were imposed, these state-owned companies accounted for about 90 percent of the gross domestic product; today, they account for about 60 percent, said Miroljub Labus, an economics professor at the University of Belgrade.
The measures announced by the Yugoslav Central Bank to stimulate the economy after the sanctions were lifted eased restrictions on imports and exports. They also devalued the dinar, the Yugoslav unit of currency, from one dinar to one German mark to three to one, close to the market rate. Almost overnight, that has put black-market currency vendors out of business.
An editorial cartoon on Monday in Nasa Borba, an independent Belgrade daily, showed the governor of the Central Bank in a small car towing a bus that was trying to go in the opposite direction. The bus carried several politicians, including Mira Markovic, wife of President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia. The cartoon indicated that the battered bus with flat tires had been headed toward Mongolia, considered a symbol of austere Communism.
Many Serbian politicians remain wedded to the past system, though, for political reasons and private economic ones.
Managers of state-owned companies owe their loyalty to the politicians who gave them their jobs. And the state-owned companies, even though grossly inefficient, get money from the state, which politicians siphon off for their own ventures.
Ms. Markovic has spoken publicly against privatization, and the Central Bank's economic package does not even mention privatization of the state-owned companies.
While he said that the economic program was a step in the right direction, Mr. Labus, the economics professor, added, "Our real problem lies with the state enterprises, and that has not been addressed at all."
The contrast between state and private industries is starkly visible at Polimark. It has leased space at Jugostroj, a state-owned manufacturer of refrigerated display units.
"Look at this," said Nikola Cicic, an engineer for 32 years with Jugostroj, as he pointed to display cases rusting in an open-sided shed adjacent to Polimark's spotless factory.
"Jugostroj is owned by the state so nobody cares," he said
Before sanctions, when Jugostroj was operating at full capacity, it had 1,100 employees, but only 500 were actually necessary, Mr. Cicic said. Sanctions have reduced production to a fraction of what it was, but there are still 700 employees, many of whom come in, get a company supplied breakfast, and then leave, he said.
As Mr. Starcevic, Polimark's owner, took a visitor on a tour of his factory -- after having him put on a spanking-clean white smock -- Mr. Cicic noticed how nicely Mr. Starcevic treated the workers. "He knows he depends on their willingness to work," Mr. Cicic said. And they must work to get paid.
Mr. Starevic once worked for a state-owned company that produced automobile tires. How did he go from that to making ketchup?
"Don't you believe in dreams? he said.

HEADLINE: Atlanta Fed Chooses No. 2 To Be Its Chief

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 27

 BODY:
The Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank today named Jack Guynn, its vice president and chief operating officer, to be its president and chief executive. The appointment ends a months-long search after the current president, Robert P. Forrestal, announced his retirement.
At a news conference where his appointment was announced, Mr. Guynn, 52, said the Fed's top priority must be fighting inflation. He added that while inflation had slowed during the last 15 years, it should be slowed further. 
 Mr. Forrestal will step down on Jan. 1 some 10 months before he turns 65, the mandatory retirement age for Fed presidents. Mr. Forrestal is capping a 12-year career as one of the nation's regional Fed presidents.
Mr. Guynn had been a leading candidate for the Atlanta Fed post, although Sheila Tschinkel, a senior vice president and director of research at the Fed branch, had been cited as a strong contender by some.
While Mr. Guynn expressed satisfaction with the 2.9 percent yearly inflation rate during the first 10 months of this year -- the same pace as the two earlier years -- he said he would like to see even smaller price increases.
"My main emphasis is on price stability," Mr. Guynn said. "Price stability is that point when price issues don't get in the way of basic business development."
Mr. Guynn said there was little chance of a rising wage-price spiral because scattered labor shortages earlier this year had dwindled.
Also, inflation may be even slower than it appears, he said.
The Atlanta branch is headquarters for the Federal Reserve Bank's sixth district covering Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, Mississippi and Louisiana.

HEADLINE: HAITI ACCUSES U.S. OF HOLDING DATA RECOVERED BY G.I.'S

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Nov. 27

 BODY:
After landing in Haiti last year, American troops seized more than 150,000 pages of documents from the headquarters of the Haitian Armed Forces and the country's most feared paramilitary group. Now the Haitian Government wants the records back and accuses Washington of stalling.
The issue is becoming an increasingly sore point in relations between the two countries. 
 Haitian officials say the return of the documents is indispensable to their efforts to restore political stability in the country by disarming and prosecuting human rights violators connected with the former military rulers in Port-au-Prince.
American officials are divided over whether the Aristide Government is legally entitled to the documents, officials in Washington said today. The Pentagon insists that the documents belonged to the ousted military rulers, not the Aristide Government, and became American property when United States troops seized them last year.
The dispute over the documents has surfaced during a time of growing discord in relations between the Clinton Administration and Mr. Aristide. Advisers to the Haitian leader said he regarded Washington's unwillingness to return the records as one of the main causes of his Government's inability to halt a wave of violence, crime and political killings.
In a fiery, tearful speech Nov. 11 at the funeral of a cousin and close political associate who was slain by gunmen who have not been identified, Mr. Aristide criticized the United States and the United Nations for failing to disarm the remnants of paramilitary groups.
For their part, American policymakers have expressed concern that Mr. Aristide may choose to remain in office for three more years instead of stepping down in February, as he had pledged earlier.
Relations between the two countries have also been strained recently by Mr. Aristide's failure to carry out promised economic reforms, like privatization of state-owned companies, and the subsequent suspension of American economic aid.
The exact contents and size of the collection of seized documents have never been disclosed. But Haitian officials said the records are likely to contain data about the finances, membership and criminal activities of the Haitian Armed Forces and the paramilitary groups it supported, as well as information about the location of arms caches the Aristide Government says have been hidden around the country.
"The United States is not sharing the intelligence it has, and that is very frustrating," an adviser to Mr. Aristide complained earlier.
The United States, Haitian officials have charged, has been unwilling to hand over the papers because it fears the disclosure of information that is likely to embarrass American intelligence agencies.
In the past, American intelligence agencies have voiced suspicions of Mr. Aristide and have nurtured ties with the Armed Forces high command that overthrew the Haitian president in September 1991. One famous but now discredited Central Intelligence Agency report, apparently based on misinformation supplied by the Haitian military, described Mr. Aristide as mentally unstable and dependent on mood-altering antidepressant drugs.
Haitian Government officials and foreign diplomats said the American Embassy in Port-au-Prince does not appear to be opposed to handing over the papers and has in fact lobbied to secure their return in hopes of defusing the tension. The resistance to the turnover, those officials said, is coming mostly from Washington -- in particular, the Pentagon and the Defense Intelligence Agency.
Administration officials express concern that the Aristide Government, or at least its more extreme supporters, might seek reprisals against supporters of the military rulers listed in the documents.
"I understand their impatience, but on the other hand there's a big volume of material," a senior State Department official said. "I don't think we're trying to stall."
Mr. Aristide's chief of staff, Leslie Voltaire, estimated that American troops seized more than 100,000 pages of documents from military headquarters shortly after they landed on Sept. 19, 1994. Other officials said that an American military raid on the headquarters of the main paramilitary group -- the Front for the Advancement and Progress of Haiti, or Fraph, -- on Oct. 3, 1994 netted an additional 60,000 pages.
Almost as soon as it was founded in 1993, Fraph became the most brutal and infamous of many Haiti's paramilitary groups, which are believed to have been organized, directed and financed by the Haitian Armed Forces. Human rights groups have estimated that at least 3,000 people were killed during Mr. Aristide's three years in exile and blame Fraph for many of those deaths as well as for thousands of other incidents of rape, torture, and arson.
After the October 1994 raid, American soldiers from the 10th Mountain Division told of finding gory "trophy photographs" pasted on the walls of the Fraph headquarters showing members of the group with the people they were killing or torturing.
Haitian prosecutors said they regard the 60,000 pages of Fraph documents as essential in building a criminal case against the group's founder, Emmanuel (Toto) Constant, who fled the country after the arrival of American forces and made his way, under circumstances that are still unclear, to the United States, where he was eventually apprehended. An immigration judge in Baltimore recently ordered Mr. Constant deported, but his lawyers are appealing that decision.
During Fraph's reign of terror, Mr. Constant, a former diplomat whose father was army commander during the dictatorship of Francois (Papa Doc) Duvalier, often boasted of links to American intelligence agencies. According to press reports published shortly after the American invasion, Mr. Constant had earlier been a paid informant for the C.I.A. and was urged by the D.I.A. to engage in intelligence activities against Mr. Aristide.
An American official said "there may be legitimate national security reasons for withholding" the documents and expressed concern that their release could "encourage violence" in Haiti. Given the lack of an effective police force and the scheduled withdrawal of United Nations troops in February, there is a danger "these documents might be used to target people" in acts of vigilante justice, he contended.
Haitian Government officials said they learned of the existence of the Fraph documents only indirectly, as the result of a suit filed in the United States by a woman who had been mutilated in an attack by paramilitary units. Responding to a request for information that might relate to the case, an American Government lawyer disclosed the existence of the 60,000 pages.
"No one has ever offered an explanation for why the documents were taken out of the country," said Ira Kurzban, a Miami lawyer who handles legal matters for the Aristide Government in the United States. "Obviously the faster they are returned, the more they can be useful in tracking down people who still maintain weapons and are now attempting to destabilize the Government."
 
47 Haitians Drown at Sea
 PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 27 (AP) -- As Haitians resumed risky sea voyages to reach American shores, 47 drowned off the north coast of Haiti, Radio Metropole reported today.
The private station said all those aboard a sailboat drowned Friday night when it capsized in the channel between Port-de-Paix and La Tortue Island in a storm.
Seven bodies were found washed up on a La Tortue beach, and 40 other people were presumed drowned, the station reported.
The refugees were to have boarded a larger craft bound for Florida.
United States Coast Guard cutters have intercepted and repatriated a growing number of Haitians in the last two months.
Coast Guard officials say the flood of Haitian refugees slowed after President Aristide returned a year ago. A recent resurgence was blamed on the country's failure to achieve economic recovery.

HEADLINE: BALKAN ACCORD;
Clinton's Words on Mission to Bosnia: 'The Right Thing to Do'

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Clinton's remarks on Bosnia tonight, as recorded by The New York Times. 
 Good evening. Last week the warring factions in Bosnia reached a peace agreement as a result of our efforts in Dayton, Ohio, and the support of our European and Russian partners. Tonight I want to speak with you about implementing the Bosnian peace agreement and why our values and interest as Americans require that we participate.
Let me say at the outset, America's role will not be about fighting a war. It will be about helping the people of Bosnia to secure their own peace agreement. Our mission will be limited, focused and under the command of an American general. In fulfilling this mission, we will have the chance to help stop the killing of innocent civilians, especially children, and at the same time to bring stability to central Europe, a region of the world that is vital to our national interests. It is the right thing to do.
From our birth, America has always been more than just a place. America has embodied an idea that has become the ideal for billions of people throughout the world. Our founders said it best: America is about life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.
In this century, especially, America has done more than simply stand for these ideals, we have acted on them and sacrificed for them. Our people fought two world wars so that freedom could triumph over tyranny. After World War I we pulled back from the world, leaving a vacuum that was filled with the forces of hatred. After World War II we continued to lead the world. We made the commitments that kept the peace, that helped to spread democracy, that created unparalleled prosperity. And that brought victory in the cold war.
Today, because of our dedication, America's ideals, liberty, democracy and peace, are more and more the aspirations of people everywhere in the world. It is the power of our ideas, even more than our size, our wealth and our military might, that makes America a uniquely trusted nation.
With the cold war over, some people now question the need for our continued active leadership in the world. They believe that, much like after World War I, America can now step back from the responsibilities of leadership. They argue that to be secure we need only to keep our own borders safe and that the time has come now to leave to others the hard work of leadership beyond our borders.
I strongly disagree.
As the cold war gives way to the global village, our leadership is needed more than ever because problems that start beyond our borders can quickly become problems within them. We're all vulnerable to the organized forces of intolerance and destruction, terrorism, ethnic, religious and regional rivalries, the spread of organized crime and weapons of mass destruction and drug trafficking. Just as surely as Fascism and Communism, these forces also threaten freedom and democracy, peace and prosperity. And they too demand American leadership.
But nowhere has the argument for our leadership been more clearly justified than in the struggle to stop or prevent war and civil violence. From Iraq to Haiti, from South Africa to Korea, from the Middle East to Northern Ireland, we have stood up for peace and freedom because it's in our interest to do so and because it is the right thing to do. Now that doesn't mean we can solve every problem.
My duty as President is to match the demands for American leadership to our strategic interests and to our ability to make a difference. America cannot and must not be the world's policeman. We cannot stop all war for all time but we can stop some wars. We cannot save all women and all children. But we can save many of them. We can't do everything, but we must do what we can. There are times and places where our leadership can mean the difference between peace and war and where we can defend our fundamental values as a people and serve our most basic strategic interests. My fellow Americans, in this new era there are still times when America and America alone can and should make the difference for peace.
The terrible war in Bosnia is such a case. Nowhere today is the need for American leadership more stark or more immediate than in Bosnia. For nearly four years a terrible war has torn Bosnia apart. Horrors we prayed had been banished from Europe forever have been seared into our minds again: skeletal prisoners caged behind barbed-wire fences, women and girls raped as a tool of war, defenseless men and boys shot down in the mass graves, evoking visions of World War II concentration camps, and endless lines of refugees marching toward a future of despair.
When I took office, some were urging immediate intervention in the conflict. I decided that American ground troops should not fight a war in Bosnia because the United States could not force peace on Bosnia's warring ethnic groups: the Serbs, Croats and Muslims.
Instead, America has worked with our European allies in searching for peace, stopping the war from spreading and easing the suffering of the Bosnian people. We imposed tough economic sanctions on Serbia. We used our air power to conduct the longest humanitarian airlift in history and to enforce a no-fly zone that took the war out of the skies. We helped to make peace between two of the three warring parties: the Muslims and the Croats.
But as the months of war turned into years, it became clear that Europe alone could not end the conflict. This summer, Bosnian Serb shelling once again turned Bosnia's playgrounds and marketplaces into killing fields.
In response the United States led NATO's heavy and continuous airstrikes, many of them flown by skilled and brave American pilots. Those airstrikes, together with the renewed determination of our European partners and the Bosnian and Croat gains on the battlefield, convinced the Serbs finally to start thinking about making peace.
At the same time, the United States initiated an intensive diplomatic effort that forged a Bosnia-wide cease-fire and got the parties to agree to the basic principles of peace. Three dedicated American diplomats: Bob Frasure, Joe Kruzel and Nelson Drew lost their lives in that effort. Tonight, we remember their sacrifice and that of their families. And we will never forget their exceptional service to our nation.
Finally, just three weeks ago, the Muslims, Croats and Serbs came to Dayton, Ohio, in America's heartland, to negotiate a settlement. There, exhausted by war, they made a commitment to peace. They agreed to put down their guns, to preserve Bosnia as a single state, to investigate and prosecute war criminals, to protect the human rights of all citizens, to try to build a peaceful, democratic future.
And they asked for America's help as they implement this peace agreement. America has a responsibility to answer that request, to help to turn this moment of hope into an enduring reality.
To do that, troops from our country and around the world would go into Bosnia to give them the confidence and support they need to implement their peace plan. I refuse to send American troops to fight a war in Bosnia, but I believe we must help to secure the Bosnian peace.
I want you to know tonight what is at stake, exactly what our troops will be asked to accomplish, and why we must carry out our responsibility to help implement the peace agreement. Implementing the agreement in Bosnia can end the terrible suffering of the people: the warfare, the mass executions, the ethnic cleansing, the campaigns of rape and terror. Let us never forget a quarter of a million men, women and children have been shelled, shot and tortured to death. Two million people -- half of the population -- were forced from their homes and into a miserable life as refugees. And these faceless numbers had millions of real personal tragedies, for each of the war's victims was a mother or daughter, father or son, a brother or sister.
Now the war is over. American leadership created the chance to build a peace and stop the suffering. Securing peace in Bosnia will also help to build a free and stable Europe. Bosnia lies at the very heart of Europe, next door to many of its fragile new democracies and some of our closest allies. Generations of Americans have understood that Europe's freedom and Europe's stability is vital to our own national security. That's why we fought two wars in Europe. That's why we launched the Marshall Plan to restore Europe. That's why we created NATO and waged the cold war. And that's why we must help the nations of Europe to end their worst nightmare since World War II now.
The only force capable of getting this job done is NATO, the powerful military alliance of democracies that has guaranteed our security for a half century now. And as NATO's leader and the primary broker of the peace agreement, the United States must be an essential part of the mission. If we're not there, NATO will not be there. The peace will collapse, the war will reignite, the slaughter of innocents will begin again. A conflict that already has claimed so many victims, could spread like poison throughout the region, eat away at Europe's stability and erode our partnership with our European allies.
And America's commitment to leadership will be questioned, if we refuse to participate in implementing a peace agreement we brokered right here in the United States, especially since the Presidents of Bosnia, Croatia and Serbia all asked us to participate and all pledged their best efforts to the security of our troops.
When America's partnerships are weak and our leadership is in doubt it undermines our ability to secure our interests and to convince others to work with us. If we do maintain our partnerships and our leadership, we need not act alone. As we saw in the gulf war and in Haiti, many other nations who share our goals will also share our burdens. But when America does not lead the consequences can be very grave, not only for others but eventually for us as well.
As I speak to you, NATO is completing its planning for IFOR, an international force for peace in Bosnia of about 60,000 troops. Already more than 25 other nations, including our major NATO allies, have pledged to take part. They will contribute about two-thirds of the total implementation force, some 40,000 troops. The United States will contribute the rest, about 20,000 soldiers. Later this week, the final NATO plan will be submitted to me for review and approval. Let me make clear what I expect it to include and what it must include for me to give final approval to the participation of our armed forces.
First, the mission will be precisely defined with clear realistic goals that can be achieved in a definite period of time. Our troops will make sure that each side withdraws its forces behind the front lines and keeps them there. They will maintain the cease-fire to prevent the war from accidentally starting again. These efforts in turn will help to create a secure environment so that the people of Bosnia can return to their homes, vote in free elections and begin to rebuild their lives. Our Joint Chiefs of Staff have concluded that this mission should and will take about one year.
Second, the risks to our troops will be minimized. American troops will take their orders from the American general who commands NATO. They will be heavily armed and thoroughly trained. By making an overwhelming show of force they will lessen the need to use force. But unlike the U.N. forces they will have the authority to respond immediately and the training and equipment to respond with overwhelming force to any threat to their own safety or any violations of the military provisions of the peace agreement.
If the NATO plan meets with my approval I will immediately send it to Congress and request its support. I will also authorize the participation of a small number of American troops in a NATO advance mission that will lay the groundwork for IFOR. Starting some time next week they will establish headquarters and set up the sophisticated communications systems that must be in place before NATO could send in its troops, tanks and trucks to Bosnia.
The implementation force itself would begin deploying in Bosnia in the days following the formal signature of the peace agreement in mid-December. The international community will help to implement arms control provisions of the agreement so that future hostilities are less likely and armaments are limited while the world community, the United States and others, will also make sure that the Bosnian Federation has the means to defend itself once IFOR withdraws. IFOR will not be a part of this effort.
Civilian agencies from around the world will begin a separate program of humanitarian relief and reconstruction, principally paid for by our European allies and other interested countries. This effort is also absolutely essential to making the peace endure. It will bring the people of Bosnia the food, shelter, clothing and medicine so many have been denied for so long. It will help them to rebuild, to rebuild their roads and schools, their power plants and hospitals, their factories and shops. It will reunite children with their parents and families with their homes.
It will allow the Bosnians freely to choose their own leaders. It will give all the people of Bosnia a much greater stake in peace than war so that peace takes on a life and a logic of its own.
In Bosnia we can and will succeed because our mission is clear and limited and our troops are strong and very well prepared. But, my fellow Americans, no deployment of American troops is risk-free and this one may well involve casualties. There may be accidents in the field or incidents with people who have not given up their hatred. I will take every measure possible to minimize these risks but we must be prepared for that possibility.
As President my most difficult duty is to put the men and women who volunteered to serve our nation in harm's way when our interest and values demand it. I assume full responsibility for any harm that may come to them. But anyone contemplating any action that would endanger our troops should know this: America protects its own. Anyone -- anyone -- who takes on our troops will suffer the consequences. We will fight fire with fire, and then some.
After so much bloodshed and loss, after so many outrageous acts of inhuman brutality, it will take an extraordinary effort of will for the people of Bosnia to pull themselves from their past and start building a future of peace. But with our leadership and the commitment of our allies the people of Bosnia can have the chance to decide their future in peace. They have a chance to remind the world that just a few short years ago the mosques and churches of Sarajevo were a shining symbol of multiethnic tolerance, that Bosnia once found unity in its diversity. Indeed, the cemetery in the center of the city was just a few short years ago, the magnificent stadium which hosted the Olympics, our universal symbol of peace and harmony.
Bosnia can be that kind of place again. We must not turn our backs on Bosnia now.
And so I ask all Americans, and I ask every member of Congress -- Democrat and Republican alike -- to make the choice for peace. In the choice between peace and war, America must choose peace.
My fellow Americans, I ask you to think just for a moment about this century that is drawing to close and the new one that will soon begin. Because previous generations of Americans stood up for freedom and because we continue to do so, the American people are more secure and more prosperous. And all around the world more people than ever before live in freedom. More people than ever before are treated with dignity. More people than ever before can hope to build a better life. That is what America's leadership is all about.
We know that these are the blessings of freedom and America has always been freedom's greatest champion. If we continue to do everything we can to share these blessings with people around the world, if we continue to be leaders for peace, then the next century can be the greatest time our nation has ever known.
A few weeks ago, I was privileged to spend some time with His Holiness John Paul II when he came to America. At the very end of our meeting, the Pope looked at me and said, "I have lived through most of this century. I remember that it began with a war in Sarajevo. Mr. President, you must not let it end with a war in Sarajevo."
In Bosnia this terrible war has challenged our interests and troubled our souls. Thankfully we can do something about it. I say again, our mission will be clear, limited and achievable. The people of Bosnia, our NATO allies and people all around the world are now looking to America for leadership. So let us lead. That is our responsibility as Americans.
Good night and God bless America.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices of Treasury Issues Higher in Quiet Trading

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury prices edged higher in quiet trading yesterday after a report showed sluggish home sales last month.
Prices rose in early trading after the National Association of Realtors, an industry trade group, said that the number of previously owned homes sold last month fell 1.9 percent, to an annual rate of 4.07 million, the first decline in six months and less than the expected annual rate of 4.15 million. 
 Evidence that the economy is faltering increases the odds that the Federal Reserve will cut short-term interest rates sooner rather than later, traders and analysts said.
"The more weak numbers we get, the more arguments" in favor of an interest rate cut when Fed policy makers meet in December, said Garth Nisbet, who manages $1 billion of bonds at Crabbe Huson Group in Portland, Ore.
Treasury prices were also bolstered by signs that this year's holiday shopping season got off to a slow start over the weekend.
"If we get indications that sales are no better than last year, it will be good for bonds," said Zane Brown, who oversees $10 billion of bond funds at Lord Abbett & Company in New York.
The International Council of Shopping Centers said sales rose 5.8 percent on Friday, smaller than last year's 9 percent gain. And Telecheck Services Inc. of Houston, a check-acceptance company, said Friday's same-store retail check sales fell 4.8 percent.
Bond investors watch consumer spending because it drives about two-thirds of the nation's economy. Slower spending would suggest a lesser threat of accelerating inflation, which erodes the value of bonds' fixed payments.
A weakening economy could also spur the Fed to lower interest rates in an effort to keep the country from sliding into a recession.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 11/32 , to 10822/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.22 percent, from 6.24 percent on Friday.
Prices of shorter-term maturities also rose, driving the yield of the two-year note down to 5.45 percent from 5.47 percent, and the yield of the 10-year note down to 5.87 percent from 5.90 percent.
Some market participants had expected prices to fall yesterday because of the amount of new supply coming to market this week. Today, the Treasury will auction $18.25 billion of two-year notes. The Treasury will auction $12 billion of five-year notes tomorrow.
Yesterday, at the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, rates were mixed. The Treasury sold $14.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.36 percent, up from 5.29 percent last week, and $14.7 billion of six-month bills at an average discount rate of 5.29 percent, down from 5.31 percent. The three-month bill rate was the highest since 5.43 percent on Aug. 21. The six-month bill rate was the lowest since 5.27 percent on Sept. 25.
In the corporate bond market, trading was slow yesterday, but several companies began marketing debt deals.
Martin Marietta Materials, which is 81 percent owned by the Lockheed Martin Corporation, plans to raise at least $125 million by selling 30-year securities in its first sale of public debt.
The company joins a growing list of borrowers who tapped the corporate bond market for the first time this month, including ITT Destinations Inc., Foster Brewing Group Ltd. of Australia and the Dover Corporation.
Companies selling bonds today can lock in rates that are almost two percentage points lower than if they borrowed a year ago at the same yield premium, or spread.
In another deal, Time Warner Capital I, a financing unit of Time Warner Inc. is planning to sell $250 million of securities that combine features of preferred stock and debt later this week.
In the municipal market, the California School Cash Reserve Authority sold $70 million revenue notes yesterday.
The notes were priced to yield 3.8 percent for securities maturing Dec. 20, 1996. For an investor in the 31 percent tax bracket, the notes have a yield equivalent to 5.51 percent, once Federal taxes are taken into consideration.
Proceeds from the sale will be used by 125 school and community college districts in California to meet their cash flow needs.
Following are the results of the Treasury's regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: With a European Currency, The Currency Is Conflict

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Nov. 27

 BODY:
Though Europe is moving toward creating a single currency sometime around the end of the century, the path will be fraught with dispute, backbiting and squabbling.
That was plainly demonstrated at an important meeting of European finance ministers here today. Representatives of the Continent's two biggest economic powers, Germany and France, bickered for much of the day over procedural issues and tried to win support for their positions from other Governments of the European Union. 
 The issues debated included which economic figures were reliable to show whether a country qualified for participation in the single-currency arrangement, how quickly national debt should be issued in the new currency, how soon to make the new currency legal tender, and how soon European leaders should decide who would be the first nations to join in the common currency.
And almost invariably, France and Germany were at odds.
But despite the disagreements, officials were optimistic that in Madrid next month, the leaders of the 15 European Union countries would be able to sign perhaps the most important economic accord since the Maastricht treaty of 1992, an agreement that clears the way for the creation of the first stage of a new currency on Jan. 1, 1999.
"There are some issues that are not resolved, but we are in a position to take a package to Madrid for approval by heads of state where the final issues will be resolved," Finance Minister Pedro Solbes of Spain said at a news conference.
While there are skeptics, including those who think that Germany will pull out at the last minute, not wanting to give up the mark, officials of European Governments are doing more than just putting down agreements on paper for such a currency. Many are making painful cuts in their budget deficits to meet a tough set of economic-performance criteria set out in the Maastricht treaty.
The two most rigorous standards require a country to have a budget deficit of less than 3 percent of its gross domestic product by the end of 1997 and total debt not exceeding 60 percent of G.D.P. Only Germany and Luxembourg now meet those criteria, but almost a half-dozen other countries are expected to bring down their deficits over the next two years to qualify.
Most economists agree that without German and French involvement, a European currency would be meaningless. The two together would create a big economic market -- one that could draw in Britain, which is skeptical about giving up the pound, as well as other European countries. Eventually, it is envisaged, a monetary bloc roughly equal to the United States would emerge.
But between now and 2002, the projected date when the new bank notes could be in full use and old national currencies no longer accepted as legal, there will be plenty of moments that can weaken and slow the process.
Today was one such time. France, for instance, wanted a decision on which countries qualified for monetary union at the end of 1997, using projections for debt levels that year. Germany wanted to delay the decision until early in 1998 to have confirmed figures on 1997 economic performance.
In addition, France wanted countries that will use the single currency to begin issuing all debt in that new currency as of early 1999. Germany wanted that decision left to the individual governments. Both disputes were put off, to be decided by the heads of government in Madrid over the weekend of Dec. 16.
A big decision in Madrid will be the name of the new currency. Though the French want the name ECU -- the current European Currency Unit, used in many accounts and already the issuance of some debt -- the Germans insist on Euro, a name its Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, floated in September when the finance ministers last met.
Delegates predicted that Germany would prevail in most of the disputes with France, including the dispute over the currency's name.
"I think Euro's won, even though it's a terrible name," a Brussels official said today.

HEADLINE: Remember the Nixon Doctrine

BYLINE: By James Webb; James Webb was an Assistant Secretary of Defense and Secretary of the Navy in the Reagan Administration.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va.

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's insistence on putting 20,000 American troops into Bosnia should be seized on by national leaders, particularly those running for President, to force a long-overdue debate on the worldwide obligations of our military.
While the Balkan factions may be immersed in their struggle, and Europeans may feel threatened by it, for Americans it represents only one of many conflicts, real and potential, whose seriousness must be weighed, often against one another, before allowing a commitment of lives, resources and national energy. 
 Today, despite a few half-hearted attempts such as Gen. Colin Powell's "superior force doctrine," no clear set of principles exists as a touchstone for debate on these tradeoffs. Nor have any leaders of either party offered terms that provide an understandable global logic as to when our military should be committed to action. In short, we still lack a national security strategy that fits the post-cold-war era.
More than ever before, the United States has become the nation of choice when crises occur, large and small. At the same time, the size and location of our military forces are in flux. It is important to make our interests known to our citizens, our allies and even our potential adversaries, not just in Bosnia but around the world, so that commitments can be measured by something other than the pressures of interest groups and manipulation by the press. Furthermore, with alliances increasingly justified by power relationships similar to those that dominated before World War I, our military must be assured that the stakes of its missions are worth dying for.
Failing to provide these assurances is to continue the unremitting case-by-case debates, hampering our foreign policy on the one hand and on the other treating our military forces in some cases as mere bargaining chips. As the past few years demonstrate, this also causes us to fritter away our national resolve while arguing about military backwaters like Somalia and Haiti.
Given the President's proposal and the failure to this point of defining American stakes in Bosnia as immediate or nation-threatening, the coming weeks will offer a new round of such debates. The President appears tempted to follow the constitutionally questionable (albeit effective) approach used by the Bush Administration in the Persian Gulf war: putting troops in an area where no American forces have been threatened and no treaties demand their presence, then gaining international agreement before placing the issue before Congress.
Mr. Clinton said their mission would be "to supervise the separation of forces and to give them confidence that each side will live up to their agreements." This rationale reminds one of the ill-fated mission of the international force sent to Beirut in 1983. He has characterized the Bosnian mission as diplomatic in purpose, but promised, in his speech last night, to "fight fire with fire and then some" if American troops are threatened. This is a formula for confusion once a combat unit sent on a distinctly noncombat mission comes under repeated attack.
 We are told that other NATO countries will decline to send their own military forces to Bosnia unless the United States assumes a dominant role, which includes sizable combat support and naval forces backing it up. This calls to mind the decades of over-reliance by NATO members on American resources, and President Eisenhower's warning in October 1963 that the size and permanence of our military presence in Europe would "continue to discourage the development of the necessary military strength Western European countries should provide for themselves."
The Administration speaks of a "reasonable time for withdrawal," which if too short might tempt the parties to wait out the so-called peacekeepers and if too long might tempt certain elements to drive them out with attacks causing high casualties.
Sorting out the Administration's answers to such hesitations will take a great deal of time, attention and emotion. And doing so in the absence of a clearly stated global policy will encourage other nations, particularly the new power centers in Asia, to view the United States as becoming less committed to addressing their own security concerns. Many of these concerns are far more serious to long-term international stability and American interests. These include the continued threat of war on the Korean peninsula, the importance of the United States as a power broker where historical Chinese, Japanese and Russian interests collide and the need for military security to accompany trade and diplomacy in a dramatically changing region.
Asian cynicism gained further grist in the wake of the Administration's recent snubs of Japan: the President's cancellation of his summit meeting because of the budget crisis, and Secretary of State Warren Christopher's early return from a visit to Japan to watch over the Bosnian peace talks.
Asian leaders are becoming uneasy over an economically and militarily resurgent China that in recent years has become increasingly more aggressive. A perception that the United States is not paying attention to or is not worried about such long-term threats could in itself cause a major realignment in Asia. One cannot exclude even Japan, whose strong relationship with the United States has been severely tested of late, from this possibility.
Those who aspire to the Presidency in 1996 should use the coming debate to articulate a world view that would demonstrate to the world, as well as to Americans, an understanding of the uses and limitations -- in a sense the human budgeting -- of our military assets.
Richard Nixon was the last President to clearly define how and when the United States would commit forces overseas. In 1969, he declared that our military policy should follow three basic tenets:
Honor all treaty commitments in responding to those who invade the lands of our allies.
Provide a nuclear umbrella to the world against the threats of other nuclear powers.
Finally, provide weapons and technical assistance to other countries where warranted, but do not commit American forces to local conflicts.
These tenets, with some modification, are still the best foundation of our world leadership. They remove the United States from local conflicts and civil wars. The use of the American military to fulfill treaty obligations requires ratification by Congress, providing a hedge against the kind of Presidential discretion that might send forces into conflicts not in the national interest. Yet they provide clear authority for immediate action required to carry out policies that have been agreed upon by the Government as a whole.
Given the changes in the world, an additional tenet would also be desirable: The United States should respond vigorously against nuclear proliferation and state-sponsored terrorism.
These tenets would prevent the use of United States forces in commitments more appropriate to lesser powers while preserving our unique capabilities. Only the United States among the world's democracies can field large-scale maneuver forces, replete with strategic airlift, carrier battle groups and amphibious power projection.
Our military has no equal in countering conventional attacks on extremely short notice wherever the national interest dictates. Our bases in Japan give American forces the ability to react almost anywhere in the Pacific and Indian Oceans, just as the continued presence in Europe allows American units to react in Europe and the Middle East.
In proper form, this capability provides reassurance to potentially threatened nations everywhere. But despite the ease with which the American military seemingly operates on a daily basis, its assets are limited, as is the national willingness to put them at risk.
As the world moves toward new power centers and different security needs, it is more vital than ever that we state clearly the conditions under which American forces will be sent into harm's way. And we should be ever more chary of commitments, like the looming one in Bosnia, where combat units invite attack but are by the very nature of their mission not supposed to fight.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
In Europe, Philip Morris beats the drum against government regulations on smoking.

BYLINE: By Nathaniel C. Nash 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
TRAVEL in an airplane, eat in a restaurant, go to a bar or a sporting event, and it's unmistakable. Europeans smoke more than Americans do.
Almost 100 million people on the Continent and in Britain spend $90 billion a year lighting up. Unlike the United States, where anti-smoking fever has made it unfashionable to smoke, Europe has far fewer restrictions -- public or private -- on smoking. What is referred to as "European tolerance" has so far prevailed. 
 Still, there are many attempts each year to regulate smoking in Europe, either by central or regional governments. And as in the United States, big tobacco interests fight these efforts aggressively.
They are led by Philip Morris Europe, a unit of the American tobacco giant. For the second time in seven months, the company has begun its own European blitz, buying full-page ads complaining about the threat to smokers from what it sees as excessive regulation.
In May, its ads in publications like The Financial Times, The Economist and The International Herald Tribune depicted street maps of Brussels, London and other big cities with tiny areas outlined. The ads warned, "The passion to regulate down to the finest detail of people's lives can lead to infringements of personal liberty."
Another message was that the Ten Commandments were expressed in 179 words and the United States Declaration of Independence required 300, but European regulations on smoking need 24,942.
More recently, Philip Morris, whose biggest-selling cigarettes in Europe are Marlboro, Chesterfield and L & M, has added more of a human touch. Last week, it began its second big campaign with full-page ads showing office workers standing in the rain on a street outside their building, lighting up. The caption reads, "What sort of policy forces these people outside?"
Philip Morris brings in nice, fuzzy words like "courtesy" and "consideration," suggesting that smokers and nonsmokers can work out their differences without government intervention. A similar campaign has been running in the United States.
While company officials in Europe say their campaign is aimed at the many attempts by governments to regulate smoking, the primary target seems to be the headquarters of the European Union here in Brussels.
European Union officials say it was no accident that the campaign began just as the organization's Commissioner for Social Affairs, Padraig Flynn, was trying to organize support for banning almost all print and billboard advertising of cigarettes across the 15-country organization.
He cites figures that 500,000 Europeans lose their lives to "tobacco-related diseases" each year, and argues that passive smoking increases the risk of lung cancer among nonsmokers by 20 percent to 30 percent.
Since 1989, the European Union has banned television advertising of cigarettes and now Mr. Flynn wants to expand the rule to other forms of public advertising.
Mr. Flynn would like to see the ban approved on Thursday at a meeting of the health ministers of the European Union. But his aides say there is almost no chance of that happening, primarily because Germany, Britain and the Netherlands are opposed.
Officials at Mr. Flynn's office say the three countries oppose the ban because they all have big tobacco interests. Germany is the biggest maker of cigarettes in the European Union, while the Netherlands is the largest exporter of tobacco products and Britain is the home of some of the industry's giants.
But British officials say they are motivated by other reasons. They say that their country is among the strictest in the European Union in banning advertising and restricting smoking in public places, and that they do not see a total advertising ban as reducing consumption.
"The statistics simply show that the countries where there is the highest smoking-related illness rate are where cigarettes are cheapest," a British official said. "It's a correlation with the prices of cigarettes, not advertising. So you have to raise the duties."
The European countries where smoking seems most pervasive are often those where the bans on cigarette ads are the tightest. In Italy, France and Portugal, all ads are banned except indirect advertising, for products like Camel lighters and Marlboro brand clothing.
David I. Greenberg, vice president for corporate affairs at Philip Morris in Brussels, said more than 40 national and local laws "dictate where and when people can smoke," with many more being proposed each month.
The company says these range from bans on smoking on the beach at Damp, Germany, to a rule that workers in Solihull, England, not be able to take a cigarette break until they have been working for at least two and a half years, to a requirement that workers in Derby, England, not smoke in parks where they serve on maintenance crews.
"We think it's a modern-day horror story that a group of people is literally being banished and sent out into the cold," Mr. Greenberg said. "We believe there is more tolerance in Europe than that, and that is why we have begun to speak out."
Philip Morris officials declined to state the cost of the campaign, except to say that it was in the millions of dollars and that it was a small fraction of the company's overall advertising budget in Europe.
Mr. Greenberg advocates that smokers and nonsmokers work out their differences on the local level and points to the restaurant association of Madrid, which recently agreed with the City Council that all restaurants set aside 25 percent of their tables for nonsmokers.
But those minding Europe's purse strings may have economic reasons not to restrict smoking. Taxes on cigarettes account for an enormous amount of European governments' revenues. In 1993, for example, tobacco excise taxes represented 5 percent of all government revenue in Germany, and 6.2 percent in Greece. For the 12 countries that were then part of the European Union, tobacco taxes totaled 3.5 percent of government revenue.
Still, Mr. Flynn promises to fight for the advertising ban and against the message of the Philip Morris campaign.
"The public should not be misled by this publicity," he said in a statement last week. "The interests of smokers and nonsmokers are not equal. When a person chooses to smoke, they are not only harming their health but also the health of other people who are exposed to their smoking. Nonsmokers have every right to object to being exposed to such dangers."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises to a 7-Week High Against Mark on Rate-Cut Talk

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday to a seven-week high against the German mark, bolstered by new speculation that Germany's central bank would soon lower interest rates.
The dollar managed a small gain against the Japanese yen in light dealing, as many traders were still returning from last week's holidays in the United States and Japan. 
 "The main feature of the day is Deutsche mark weakness against everything," said Chris Iggo, an international economist with the Chase Manhattan Bank.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4360 marks, up from 1.4193 on Friday. The last time it was higher was Oct. 4, when the dollar touched a high of 1.444 marks.
It also rose to 101.71 Japanese yen from 101.41 yen, and to 1.1580 Swiss francs from 1.1437 francs. The British pound slipped to $1.5535 from $1.5595.
Speculation about a rate cut was spurred by fresh evidence of low inflation in Germany. The state of Bavaria reported that its consumer price index was unchanged in November, putting it up 1.5 percent for the year.
This was preceded by reports last week from other German states of little or no inflation. Speculation began then, and became the dominant theme yesterday, that the central bank would cut interest rates as early as Thursday's policy-setting meeting.
Central banks typically reduce rates to stimulate their economies, especially when there is little fear of a resurgence in inflation. Lower interest rates, however, make a country's assets less attractive, and traders become less likely to acquire that country's currency, which is needed to buy the assets.
"This whole issue about the German rate cut seems to be prevailing in the market," said Peggy Reed, a currency vice president at Credit Agricole.
The mark fell against all major European currencies and the yen in thin trading. It fell, as well, against a rallying Swedish krona after weekend reports that Sweden would join the European Exchange Rate Mechanism. "It doesn't take a whole lot of volume to move it," Ms. Reed said.
Most of the dollar's action against the mark occurred in the period when the European and North American trading sessions overlap.
The dollar's upward move against the yen was blunted by yen-buying above 102 yen, Mr. Iggo of Chase Manhattan said, noting that there were no fundamental reasons for dollar-yen trading to go in either direction.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Sacrifice Of Hands, Heart And Soul

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY 

 BODY:
The politically and socially committed left-wing Group Theater did not survive long. Founded in 1931, it disbanded in 1940, but not before it had provided a kind of prewar staging area for some of the American theater's most militant talents. Among them: Elia Kazan, John (then Jules) Garfield, Luther Adler, Robert Lewis, Martin Ritt, Howard da Silva and Lee J. Cobb.
All of these and others appeared as actors in "Golden Boy," the 1937 Clifford Odets play, which under the direction of Harold Clurman became one of the Group's most successful productions. It's still an effective piece, at least to read: a visceral and gritty tale of a poor but gifted young violinist, Joe Bonaparte, who sells out a promising career in music to get fame as a boxer, as well as fortune and a fancy Duesenberg. 
 "Golden Boy" was less overtly political than most of the Group's projects. For all of its realistic details, it takes a rather romantic view of social despair. Yet it's a fascinating artifact both of the Group's work and Broadway theater during the Depression. As Clurman noted years later, it's also prescient in the way it predicts the arc of Odets's declining career after he went to Hollywood.
These are probably the most cogent reasons to see the Blue Light Theater Company's earnest revival, which opened last night at the 45th Street Theater, the usual home of Primary Stages. Under the direction of Joanne Woodward, the production itself has a lot of shaking down to do before it acquires a living, breathing identity of its own. The elements are there, but time is limited. The run ends Dec. 16.
"Golden Boy" is a big play in three acts (played in two here) and 12 scenes with 19 characters, though in the mid-30's even the economically pressed Group Theater could manage the financing. It's dated but in the best sense: watching it is like rediscovering the manners, obsessions and locutions of our theater's past. Yet unless the director can find a decisive, coherent style for it, the drama remains distant and unnecessarily archaic. Today's audience is part of the problem. As movies and television have usurped the kind of linear narratives that once were commonplace on Broadway, we expect live theater to be more condensed, less realistic, more intense and less banal. Among the more interesting aspects of this revival is that Odets's so-called realistic speech seems to have aged less well than his big, poetic outbursts, which used to be so enthusiastically parodied.
"Hallelujah!" Joe Bonaparte (Greg Naughton) exults after winning a crucial fight but breaking his hand. "It's the beginning of the world!" Also surprisingly affecting today is a park scene in which Joe and Lorna Moon (Angie Phillips), the sad, self-described "tramp from Newark," declare their love. It's the sort of poetic moment that once was obligatory in such prole theater. Yet as Odets wrote it, the scene is more dramatically effective than those depicting the fight racket and Joe's uneasy relations with his immigrant father (Spiro Malas).
"Golden Boy" fits gracefully onto the small, narrow stage at the 45th Street Theater, though the scenic design might benefit by being even more minimal than it is. Scenery is not the point of this production; the play and its performers are. There's no need for the high, center-stage platform that sometimes passes for the ring in the gym where Joe works out. It just clutters up the movement.
A standout in the large cast is Ms. Phillips in the role originally played on Broadway by Frances Farmer. Though she looks more like a Manhattan post-debutante than a refugee from Newark, she acts Lorna with a melancholy and fragile toughness that perfectly evokes the romantic tone of the play.
Mr. Naughton, a lithe young actor, seems actually to grow in heft within the performance as Joe transforms himself from musician to contender. Also very effective are James Naughton (Greg Naughton's father), as Tom Moody, Joe's married manager, who keeps Lorna on the side; Joe Grifasi as Tokio, Joe's trainer; Lee Wilkof as Tom Moody's partner, and Bruce MacVittie as Eddie Fuseli, the gangster who buys a piece of Joe's contract and behaves as much like a lover as a gun-packing investor.
Though all of the actors are good, and the events unfold with dispatch, "Golden Boy" still seemed unfinished at the preview I attended. It had nothing to do with people not knowing their lines, but with their not yet feeling at home with one another or within the play's scheme. Too often they appeared simply to be hanging around, waiting for cues. Work is needed.

HEADLINE: G.M. Sales on the Rise in California

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif.

 BODY:
When Ann N. Pattyn arrived in California from Detroit to assume the job of trying to improve sales of General Motors cars and trucks here, she was stunned at what she didn't see. There were plenty of Toyotas, Hondas, Mazdas and Subarus, but G.M. vehicles were scarce. "It was very sobering when you drove the neighborhoods and expressways," she said.
That was two and a half years ago, when the market share of the General Motors Corporation in California was suffering through a 10-year slump and seemed to know only one direction -- reverse. 
 Ms. Pattyn's mission was to implement the company's California comeback strategy, which involved equipping certain models with popular options, discounting the prices and ending further discounts and rebates. As an example of how it works, the suggested sticker price for a 1996 Pontiac Grand Am SE coupe is $14,995 in California, about 7.6 percent lower than the $16,234 list price elsewhere.
Call it "no haggle pricing," "value pricing," or simply price cutting, G.M. said that the approach implemented in August 1993 had helped turn California sales around. Despite some resistance from dealers and even some G.M. divisions, the company said it had managed to raise its anemic market share in California to nearly 23 percent this year.
G.M.'s California market share is still 10 percentage points below the company's nationwide figures. But industry analysts said the company's market share has seen a remarkable resurgence, after dropping 10 points since 1982 and reaching a low of 19 percent in 1991.
And the price cutting has caught on, as other dealers and brands have used it selectively. (All Oldsmobile models are sold this way as are many Chevrolet models nationwide. G.M.'s Saturn division has used the approach since it introduced its cars in 1990.)
But analysts said the strategy would ultimately squeeze profit margins. Dealers complain that sales of some models have not increased enough to recoup the profits that have been given up. And many experts are skeptical that G.M. can sustain its sales surge in California with this tactic alone. They also question whether consumers will continue to trust the program.
"The car industry is being pressured by the expectations of consumers, who expect better for less cost," said Donald L. Keithley, a partner with J. D. Power & Associates, citing as an example the declining prices for increasingly powerful personal computers.
G.M. initiated the California battle plan with $75 million for advertising and sales training. It has since been expanded to nearly all G.M. models, including hot sellers such as the GMC Yukon sport utility vehicle and the Buick Regal. The few exceptions are the high-priced cars and trucks in each G.M. line, most Cadillacs and budget-priced Geos.
Ms. Pattyn, 42, said that to lure back buyers, the the auto maker had to abandon its view of the United States as a single market and respond to car-buying tastes in specific areas, like California, where foreign cars have been hugely popular for years.
Including fleet sales, imports hold more than 40 percent of the California market, compared with about 26 percent nationwide, according to Automotive News. G.M., which saw a 4-point improvement in retail sales during the last model year, said it now has 22.9 percent of the California market, compared with 22.3 percent for Ford and 9.9 percent for Chrysler.
Prices of Japanese cars sold in the United States have risen, pushed by the sharp decline in the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen, and more buyers are turning to domestic makes.
"We are being opportunistic in reverse," Ms. Pattyn said. "This is a window of opportunity with the yen relationship."
Melaine A. Johnson chose a Chevrolet truck over a Japanese truck last month because of its lower price. "I think I got a lot more in my Chevy than in a Toyota," she said.
Ms. Johnson, 25, paid $14,000 for a 1996 Chevrolet pickup equipped with air bags, power steering and a stereo, options that she said would have added $5,000 to the cost of a comparable Toyota truck. "I got what I wanted without having to pay extra for it," she said.
G.M.'s strategy forces dealers to accept lower profit margins, but some some dealers said it had not lifted sales of Buicks, Oldsmobiles and Cadillacs, whose buyers are generally older and still expect big discounts.
"If value pricing really worked, all sales should have gone up," said Robert R. Longpre, whose dealership in Westminster, sells Pontiac, Lexus and Suzuki models.
Mr. Longpre said G.M. was misreading its customers by focusing on price instead of quality. "As a stockholder, I'm not sure I got my $75 million worth," he said. "You vote your paycheck and my Pontiac sales have gone down."
Other dealers said customers preferred the approach. James J. Smythe, 41, vice president of the Santa Clara dealership owned by his father, said he welcomed the idea because it allowed salespeople to focus on service. But he estimated that only half of the state's G.M. dealers were smitten with the campaign. "It's very controversial," he said, because volume on some lines has not increased to make up for profit margins that have sunk to 6 percent from as much 18 percent.
Some dealers, he said, have abandoned the pricing strategy when they were overstocked, resorting to old-fashioned discounting. "There are three other G.M. dealers within three minutes of us," Mr. Smythe said. "It's difficult to compete with the guy who cuts prices."
