HEADLINE: Making the 'Invisible' Clearly Visible

BYLINE: By Janet Maslin

 BODY:
Billy Golfus was a Minneapolis rock-and-roll radio personality before the motor-scooter accident that left him brain-damaged and partly paralyzed more than a decade ago. His professional irreverence is very much intact in "When Billy Broke His Head . . . and Other Tales of Wonder," a spiky, vigorous and often caustically funny documentary about problems faced by the disabled. 
 Serving as director (along with David E. Simpson), writer and acerbic narrator, Mr. Golfus outlines the frustrations that confront this country's largest minority group. There may be nearly 50 million disabled Americans, he notes, "but we're as invisible as Casper the ghost." 
 This hourlong film, which won a prize at last January's Sundance Film Festival, was shown on PBS several months ago and opens today for a two-week run at the Film Forum, does a lot to rectify that situation. It visits brave, interesting people who have learned to deal ably with handicaps they see as both physical and political. Mr. Golfus strongly attacks the practice of funneling Medicaid money for the disabled into nursing homes, maintaining that most handicapped people could live more happily and economically with home care. 
 Naturally, Mr. Golfus uses his own example whenever possible, beginning with an account of his own physical difficulties. Photographed trying to hit a punching bag, he moves so slowly that he seems to be underwater. "You lose your ability to make money, to survive and to have fun," he says. "You never get asked anywhere. You never get told anything. You lose stuff that you can't even name: the things that gave your life stability and meaning." Mr. Golfus also outlines his professional problems, showing off a wall decorated with rejection letters "from some of the best magazines in America." And he films some painful encounters with his own father. 
 The senior Mr. Golfus implies that his son needs more determination, and manages to suggest that paralysis is a fate worse than death. It's typical of this documentary's sardonic outlook that this idea is lampooned with melodramatic movie clips, patronizing snippets from a Jerry Lewis telethon and an excerpt from "Star Trek." "My life as a Klingon is over!" proclaims the extraterrestrial who learns he has been paralyzed in that scene. 
 Meanwhile, the film visits disabled people who hate the idea of being stigmatized. "Packaging is everything," says Mr. Golfus about the ways in which physical handicaps create image problems. Among his stereotype-busting interview subjects are Joy Mincy-Powell, a beautiful young woman who performs dance routines from her wheelchair, and Ed Roberts, nicknamed Special Ed, who is seen starting the day after a night's sleep in an iron lung. After that, he takes a karate lesson. 
 Mr. Roberts, who died in March, had been deemed a hopeless case and denied employment assistance from the California Department of Rehabilitation; he was appointed director of that same state agency 14 years later. 
 As the camera observes some remarkable coping mechanisms (one woman who cannot speak or move without huge difficulty has been driving a van safely for years), it also shows how hard it can be for the disabled to make their needs understood. Mr. Golfus films a visit to his own caseworker, who has 400 other clients and no great personal interest in explaining why Mr. Golfus's government benefits are being cut. In another scene, a woman shows off the extensive government paperwork she must complete. Since her disability is extremely poor eyesight, she can't read a single word. 
 If this film's subjects feel like outsiders, they're well matched with the main character in "Franz Kafka's It's a Wonderful Life," this year's Academy Award-winning short subject. Originating in a slip of the tongue by its writer and director, Peter Capaldi, this Scottish film is more Kafka than Frank Capra and more Tim Burton than either of them. Alone in his lair, Kafka (Richard E. Grant) struggles with the first line of "Metamorphosis," wondering whether Gregor Samsa shouldn't wake up as a giant banana. From its macabre wit to its Christmasy ending, Mr. Capaldi's film is gratifyingly bizarre. Crispin Letts revels in the banana and cockroach role.

WHEN BILLY BROKE HIS HEAD. . . AND OTHER TALESOF WONDER

Produced and directed by Billy Golfus and David E. Simpson; written by Mr. Golfus; director of photography, Slawomir Grunberg; edited by David E. Simpson. At the Film Forum, 209 Houston Street, South Village. Running time: 58 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Billy Golfus (narrator and interviewer) and interviews with Wade Blank, Kay Gaddis, Larry Kegan, Barb Knowlen, Paul Longmore, Joy Mincy-Powell, Ed Roberts, Robin Stephens and Lee Swenson.

Written and directed by Peter Capaldi; director of photography, Simon Maggs; edited by Nikki Clemens; music by Philip Appleby; production designer, John Beard; produced by Ruth Kenley-Letts; released by Manga Entertainment. At the Film Forum, 209 Houston Street, South Village. Running time: 24 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Richard E. Grant (Kafka), Crispin Letts (Gregor Samsa), Ken Stott (Woland), Elaine Collins (Miss Cicely) and Phyliss Logan (Frau Bunofski).

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Big Drug Maker Pleads Guilty to Criminal Charges
Warner-Lambert pleaded guilty to criminal charges and agreed to pay $10 million for concealing faulty manufacturing processes in several drugs. One was Dilantin, a widely used epilepsy treatment. The fine is one of the largest against a brand-name drug maker.
Also, the former vice president for quality control was indicted on criminal charges. He faces penalties as high as 19 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines. [Page A1.]
 
Technology Stocks Lead a Rebound
Stocks again closed higher, with technology issues leading a 2 percent rise in the recently battered Nasdaq composite index. The market overcame a sharp early selloff, enabling the Dow Jones industrial average to set its fifth consecutive record, closing up 7.22 points. The Standard & Poor's 500 index also set a record. Among technology issues, Netscape soared 20, to 131. [D8.]
 
Money flowed into stock funds in October, but at a slower pace, and market timers began to head for the exits. Market Place. [D8.]
 
Home Construction Off
Construction of new homes and apartments fell 3.7 percent in October, for the third straight decline, despite lower mortgage rates. The month's weakness was primarily in apartment construction. Separately, consumer confidence perked up. [D2.]
 
A Tough Stretch for Packard Bell
Packard Bell seems to be falling behind in the personal computer market. Analysts say it underestimated the demand for powerful machines and is burdened by an inventory of lower-powered PC's. [D2.]
 
Disney Earnings Rise 17%
Disney's fourth-quarter earnings increased 17 percent, as rising profits at its theme parks offset a decline in film earnings. But the company's shares fell $1.375, to $61.50, as investors were concerned that earnings growth was slowing. [D8.]
 
Religious conservatives are protesting Disney's entertainment values and pressing for boycotts of its movies and parks. [A20.]
 
I.R.S. Retreats on Frequent Flying
The I.R.S., beating a retreat, indicated that it would not tax the legions of business travelers who garner frequent-flier bonuses. [B14.]
 
Brown & Williamson Sells Brands
Brown & Williamson agreed to sell six of its discount cigarette brands to Lorillard, but said it was unable to sell three premium brands, as required by the F.T.C. [D3.]
A Mississippi judge cleared the way for Brown & Williamson's former research chief to give a deposition today. But a Kentucky court has barred him from any disclosing sensitive information about his work. [A20.]
 
CBS Management Stays
Westinghouse promised to rebuild CBS and move it into new businesses. It retained much of the top management of the network. [D4.]
 
Budget Talks Resume
The White House and top Republicans began budget talks, to try to avert another Government shutdown. Congress, meanwhile, is continuing to cut the 1996 budget. [B10.]
 
Gartner Group Expanding
Gartner Group agreed to buy Dataquest for about $80 million. Both companies sell analysis of information technology. Gartner has focused on users, particularly at big companies. Dataquest sells mainly to hardware and software producers. [D2.]
 
Another 100-Year Bond
A BellSouth subsidiary sold $500 million of 100-year bonds, in the largest offering for debt that only two years ago was considered just a novelty. [D15.]
 
Court Victory for Unions
The Supreme Court ruled that paid union organizers who take jobs with nonunionized employers are protected by labor laws. [B11.]
 
A Tussle of the Charge Cards
American Express and Diners Club are battling for the business of high-spending executives, charging annual fees of $300. Business Travel. [D6.]

HEADLINE: China's Inevitable Dilemma: Coal Equals Growth

SERIES: THE AIR IN 2000: Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: TAIYUAN, China

 BODY:
Within a 300-mile radius of this energy capital, hundreds of thousands of coal miners are shredding subterranean seams thicker than ocean liners and hauling a black treasure to the surface to power the economic rise of China.
From the great forest of chimneys that punctures the haze of China's industrial landscape, a nimbus of carbon- and sulphur-based gases is billowing into the atmosphere. It is mixing with the buildup of the century-long industrialization of Europe and North America and, many scientists say, it is contributing to the overall warming of the earth's atmosphere. 
 And as the evidence hardens that global atmospheric warming is a result of human activity, especially the production of gases from the combustion of coal, oil and natural gas, questions are growing about whether China can change course.
China's heavy reliance on coal, along with its inefficient and wasteful patterns of energy use, will make it the largest single producer of climate-warming carbon dioxide by the second or third decade of the next century.
As it surpasses the United States and other industrial countries as a cause of the problem, China seems certain to come under strong international pressure to curb its reliance on its vast, cheap coal reserves.
And China itself may face serious consequences from global warming, as a rise in sea levels inundates coastal zones. Right now, many of its citizens are choking on the air pollution produced by the widespread burning of coal.
But coal development on a vast scale appears inevitable. China's dilemma is repeated, on a lesser scale, in India, Brazil and the rest of the developing world, where diverting scarce funds to meet global environmental goals is seen as a rich country's luxury.
For China's leadership, it is simply a question of capital, massive amounts of it. Already, Beijing's leaders face a daunting array of demands to build highways, railroads and modern industries to compete for export markets with the developed world and to provide the economic growth China's expanding population will expect.
Some efficiency improvements will pay for themselves, but with its huge reserves of coal, China sees any energy alternative that costs more or requires more up-front capital as a threat to development.
"You try to tell the people of Beijing that they can't buy a car or an air-conditioner because of the global climate-change issue," said Li Junfeng, a senior energy researcher for the State Planning Commission in Beijing. "It is just as hot in Beijing as it is in Washington, D.C.
"If we reduce our emission of gases, it means we must reduce our energy consumption," Mr. Li said. "When people get rich, they want to buy an air-conditioner or a car; that will increase energy consumption."
It already has.
Between 1970 and 1990, energy consumption rose 208 percent in China, compared with an average rise of 28 percent in developed countries during the same period.
More than five million Chinese are now engaged in the largest coal extraction enterprise in human history, feeding China's enormous thirst for energy and pushing toward fulfillment of the national goal of quadrupling the country's economic output between 1980 and 2000.
Last year, China's national honeycomb of mines produced 1.2 billion tons of coal, more than any other nation, and the numbers are only growing, perhaps nearly tripling to 3.1 billion tons annually by the year 2020, when China will be overtaking the United States as the largest source of waste gases being pumped into the atmosphere.
Still, despite the possible economic cost, the Chinese have plenty of impetus to change.
 
The Emissions
Whose Are They, And Who Pays?
 Researchers at the Chinese Academy of Sciences now say they believe that global climate changes during the next 30 to 50 years could cause a 1-meter rise in sea levels that, when magnified by storm tides, would inundate an area the size of Portugal on China's coastal plain, including the important manufacturing centers at Shanghai and Guangzhou, forcing 67 million people to abandon their land and homes.
Equally vulnerable is China's straining agricultural base, which must nearly double its harvest to feed the 1.6 billion Chinese who will live here 30 years from now.
Though uncertainties abound in these projections, profound concerns about the potential impact of global climate change has mobilized China's scientific community and elevated climate research, monitoring and computer modeling to a high-priority national effort.
"We are paying a great deal of attention to this issue," said Sun Honglie, a senior Government scientist in Beijing and a member of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, China's Parliament.
But for China's Communist Party leaders, the question of who should bear the burden of reducing the enormous volume of warming gases rising from the Americas, Europe and Asia draws a fiercely nationalistic response, and quickly turns to the rancor-filled question of whether the West, led by the United States, is seeking to limit China's emergence as a great power.
"Developed countries discharge more carbon dioxide than developing countries on a per capita basis and the United States discharges 10 times more than China on a per capita basis," Qin Zhongda, the vice chairman of the environmental protection committee of the National People's Congress, said last month during a news conference at the Great Hall of the People.
For many Chinese, the question of whether the rest of the world will accommodate China's coal-burning juggernaut is a question of fundamental equity, and the country's political leaders have been thus far unwilling to enter serious negotiations about their future emissions.
"China has not recognized that they are going to have increasing obligations for the future," said Timothy E. Wirth, the State Department's undersecretary for global affairs who visited China last year seeking to broaden cooperation on strategies to combat climate change.
"We may have fouled the atmosphere in the past," he continued, "and that's our responsibility. But we both are fouling the atmosphere for the future and that is both of our responsibilities."
China disagrees.
"Two hundred years after the Industrial Revolution, the world economy has greatly advanced and the developed countries are the main beneficiary," said Lin Zongtang, a former head of China's Aero-Space Ministry and now vice chairman of the environmental protection committee of the National People's Congress. "About 80 percent of the world's pollution is caused by developed countries and they should be responsible for these problems."
That means, Chinese officials say, that the developed countries should help pay for cleaner coal burning technologies in the third world, as well as helping to finance capital-intensive hydro-electric projects, nuclear power stations and alternative energy sources like wind and solar.
Many Western and Chinese scientists say they believe that despite China's dependence on coal for the foreseeable future, China's emissions of carbon dioxide could be held to a doubling of output, instead of a tripling, during the next 30 years by increasing efficiency and investment in alternative energy sources.
But that, in itself, would require a huge mobilization of capital, technology and political commitment.
 
The Attitude
So Many Burners, One Thing to Burn
 Here in China's coal capital, miners, mine bosses, engineers and power plant operators all seem to believe that China is resigned to a heavy dependence on coal for decades, even though this dependence may have serious consequences for China and the rest of the world.
"We are a developing country and we started out without a very good foundation," says Zhang Fengtong, the senior engineer at the Gu Jiao mine complex 50 miles north of here. "We have so few choices and no funding, so our industries are going to rely heavily on coal for a long time to come."
Farther north, on the road to Datong, another coal capital, Yang Zeguo peered out from under the chassis of his parked Liberation-brand truck looking incredulous at a visitor's question about China's dependence on coal.
He was in the process of transporting his 27-ton load of raw coal to the market of neighboring Hebei province when he stopped for lunch and repairs at a dusty truck stop littered with coal carriers and prostitutes draped across the doorways of one-table diners.
"If we don't burn coal, what else can we burn?" he asked. "We can't find anything else to burn."
In one sense, he was right. Even if China improved the efficiency of all of its electric power plants, much of the coal burned in China is consumed in small industrial and municipal boilers and in millions of cooking stoves and household heaters, for which no alternative fuels are currently available.
"You really have to change the culture to have any impact," said Vaclav Smil of the University of Manitoba in Canada, one of the leading experts on China's environment.
"They have this coal; they have to use it," Prof. Smil said. "But they could use it in a proper way. Much of the coal is now coming from these very small coal mines, but there is no sorting, no cleaning or washing and this kind of coal generates a tremendous amount of pollution. It meets the needs of today, but it doesn't meet the needs of tomorrow."
The decentralization of economic power in China has made it more likely, not less, that boilers for heat, steam or electrical generation will be smaller and less efficient.
At Yuanping, a scruffy crossroads town sandwiched between mountain ranges in central Shanxi, Gong Gaoshou is the deputy manager of the local power station, whose chimney was spewing a black plume visible in the next county on a recent afternoon.
Yuanping's power plant is rated at six megawatts, less than one-100th the size of a standard power station in the West, and its boiler is among the least efficient for clean burning or for the economies that accrue to large-scale power production.
But even though national policy now forbids the construction of such plants, China's provincial leaders continue to underwrite them because they are the most affordable on provincial budgets.
"We don't have any money," Mr. Gong said. "The price of electricity is too low and the price of raw materials is increasing greatly. What can we do? We are trying our best."
Susan E. McDade, a United Nations energy specialist in Beijing, said China could reap the same benefit Western countries did when sharp increases in energy prices during the 1970's and 1980's led to a host of efficiency improvements and conservation measures that cut energy consumption.
Electricity prices in China are half those in many developed countries.
"Liberalizing energy prices would be the single most effective policy to promote energy efficiency," Ms. McDade said.
From the lowliest coal miner to the most senior scientist, it is this sense of inevitability that China's energy economy will be dominated by coal that impels China to insist that the world must make room.
"The most important thing for China is to modernize the economy, and after that occurs, we will have more money to deal with environmental issues," said Mr. Li in Beijing. "But it must follow economic development" and, he added, "we can't change the energy situation."
 
The Alternatives
Hey, Buddy, Can You Spare a Reactor?
 China is working with the World Bank, Japan and the United States Department of Energy to fund an assortment of projects that could improve the efficiency of Chinese power plants and develop alternative energy sources like hydroelectric power, solar, wind and the burning of biomass, or plants.
Earlier this year, a joint study team of Chinese scientists and experts assembled by the World Bank and the United Nations Development Program concluded that China could marshal the technology to ameliorate significantly the global effects of its coal economy.
"By the year 2020," the team concluded, "large-scale adoption of low-carbon energy sources such as hydro, nuclear, gas, biomass, solar and wind technologies could displace a substantial quantity of coal, particularly for electric generation."
Mr. Li of the planning commission's energy institute said that even if there were no fear of climate change, "We are trying to increase our efficiency."
Ever quick to remind an American of the nationalistic tensions that persist, he added: "The United States has so many nuclear power stations that it has given up on. Why not sell them to China and help China reduce its greenhouse gas emissions and develop its economy?
"If you don't sell nuclear equipment to China, the demand is still going to be there," he added, "and people will build with coal."

HEADLINE: Gartner to Acquire Dataquest In $80 Million Bid to Expand

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 28

 BODY:
In a move to broaden its market in the analysis of information technology, Gartner Group Inc. has agreed to buy Dataquest Inc., a unit of the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, for about $80 million in cash and securities.
Gartner, which announced the deal late Monday, is itself 51 percent owned by Dun & Bradstreet. 
 Both Gartner and Dataquest provide research and analysis of computers, software and other information technology, but they serve different customers. Gartner, which is based in Stamford, Conn., has focused on users, primarily the information systems managers of large corporations, while Dataquest, based in San Jose, Calif., has sold its services to vendors, primarily computer hardware and software producers. Sometimes those customers have overlapped, but the two concerns have not been direct competitors.
Gartner shares surged $6.125 today, to $45.25, on Nasdaq, while shares of Dun & Bradstreet rose $1.375, to $62.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts said the acquisition was not risk-free because it would send Gartner into a new sales area, but they said it could bolster Gartner's position as the leading provider of independent analysis of information technology.
"On balance this would appear to be a very positive acquisition for Gartner, though it's got to raise the risk-reward profile of the stock a bit," said Steven Eskenazi, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons in San Francisco. "It gets Gartner critical mass in Asia/Pacific, where Dataquest is strong, and it gets them into a new business," he said. Gartner has managed smaller acquisitions well in the past, he said.
The terms of the acquisition call for Gartner to pay Dun & Bradstreet $15 million cash, plus 1.5 million shares of Gartner common stock, valued on Monday at about $60 million. Dun also receives warrants to buy another 300,000 shares, valued at about $5 million.
Gartner plans to lay off about 100 of Dataquest's 500 employees, primarily in administrative and oversight functions, said Dennis G. Sisco, executive vice president of Dun & Bradstreet. Gartner has about 1,000 employees.
Judith H. Hamilton, Dataquest's president and chief executive, will also leave the company, because her position will be eliminated. The sales forces of the two companies would be combined, Mr. Sisco said.
"The sales process is very much the same for this type of information," Mr. Sisco said. "We have ahead an instant opportunity to bring Gartner's 300-plus sales force together with Dataquest's 50-plus sales force for a coordinated package of offerings."
He said that after the initial integration period, both companies would probably add new positions.
Gartner's acquisition of Dataquest follows an acquisition by the company's founder, Gideon Gartner, who left in 1990. He recently bought BIS Strategic Decisions, a Dataquest competitor, and renamed it Giga Information Group. One executive close to the Gartner Group, who insisted on anonymity, said the timing of the two deals was not coincidental.
Another factor that could have driven the Dataquest deal, the executive said, was that Manny A. Fernandez, Gartner's chief executive, ran Dataquest during the 1980's.
Dataquest was not consistently profitable then or in the early 1990's. It has become profitable in the last two years, under Ms. Hamilton.
"About three years ago, on significantly lower revenues, we were losing large amounts of money," Ms. Hamilton said. "We will have revenues this year of $69 to $70 million, with operating income securely in double digits," she said.

HEADLINE: House Acts to Protect Gift Arrangement Used by Charities

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The House of Representatives yesterday unanimously approved two bills that would shield charities from the antitrust and securities regulations that apply to businesses. The Senate is expected to pass similar legislation quickly.
The legislation is a response to an unusual class-action lawsuit against the American Red Cross, United Way of America, the Salvation Army, Mount Holyoke College and about 1,900 other charitable institutions. The suit asserts that these charities violated antitrust laws by colluding on the rates of return they pay donors who make gifts to them and who wish to earn income on those gifts for as long as they live. 
 The suit also contends that charities are breaking securities laws by even offering the arrangements, known as charitable gift annuities, which are usually sold by licensed insurance agents and brokers.
Charities and Congressional sponsors hope that the legislation will make the lawsuit moot. A trial is scheduled for February, unless the case is dismissed.
"Without this common-sense protection, charitable organizations would lose a much-needed and useful tool for raising funds, and that would be a tragedy," said Representative Henry J. Hyde, Republican of Illinois, who was a co-sponsor of the bill that would give charities antitrust protection in setting payout rates -- that is, the gift's yield, paid to the donor. A companion bill deals with the securities law issues.
The gift annuity is a popular arrangement, particularly among older givers, because it allows them to take an immediate tax deduction by making a donation and still receive income for as long as they live. Donors do not get to take their full gift as a deduction, since in return they receive income and often some principal back as well.
The lawsuit that prompted the legislation was brought last year in the Federal Court for the Northern District of Texas on behalf of Louise T. Peter, an elderly Texas woman. It was initiated by Dorothy Ozee, a great-niece who cared for Ms. Peter for many years. A probate court had found Ms. Peter, who is now 96 and lives in a nursing home, mentally unable to handle her own affairs.
The lawsuit argues that charities should set payout rates on gift annuities individually, without reference to an industry standard.
Ms. Peter, whose grandfather helped found a denomination of the Lutheran Church in Texas nearly 150 years ago, is a retired secretary who never married. She inherited about $2 million from a brother who owned land on top of oil reserves, and she has been a frequent donor to Lutheran charities. In 1988, she gave $200,000 to the Lutheran Foundation of Texas, setting up a gift annuity arrangement with an interest rate of 13.4 percent, which was the rate recommended at the time by the American Council on Gift Annuities.
In October, a Federal judge, Joe Kendall, allowed the suit to be brought as a class action against 1,900 charities. The suit, which alleges antitrust and securities violations, asks that all money donated to charities through charitable gift annuities be returned, along with double that amount in damages.
The American Council on Gift Annuities, which was founded in 1927 to help charities that want to use gift annuities, publishes standard rates for those annuities, and is also a defendant in the lawsuit. The rates, which are based on actuarial calculations by a consulting group, are reviewed only every three years, and sometimes changed less frequently.
The aim, the council says, is to recommend a payout rate that takes into account the life expectancy of the donor and what the charity is likely to earn by investing the money, and to leave at least 50 percent for the charity after the donor's death -- the amount required under some state regulations. Currently, the council suggests that an 85-year-old donor be given a 10 percent payout rate, while a 75-year-old donor be given a 7.7 percent rate. Insurance company executives say their annuities are structured somewhat differently and so are not really comparable.
In fact, the charities argue that their rates are not meant to be competitive, since the main goal of the donor is to help the charity, not to maximize income. And they say that this is an important reason why they should not be subject to antitrust regulation.
"If the donors' primary concern is income, they are not going to be looking at charitable gift annuities," said Judy Norris, a lawyer with Thompson & Knight in Dallas who represents the council.
Robert Elkin, a lawyer with McKool Smith in Dallas, who represents the plaintiff in the case, declined to comment.
There are no figures on how much money all charities have collected through gift annuities, but a survey by the American Council on Gift Annuities found that the 706 charities that responded had received $1.2 billion from them, including $316 million in 1993.
"Charitable annuities are a very big part of giving, especially with major gifts," said Helmer N. Ekstrom, president of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel in New York.
And charities have been fighting hard to keep the annuities, both in defending themselves against the lawsuit and in pressing for the protective legislation. Tal Roberts, executive vice president of the Baptist Foundation of Texas and president of the American Council on Gift Annuities, estimated that charities had been spending more than a million dollars a month on the suit.
"It is just outrageous to be spending this kind of money on a lawsuit," he said, "but it is one we cannot take lightly."

HEADLINE: Spending-Cap Issue In Connecticut Court

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Nov. 28

 BODY:
In an unusual case that tests the balance of powers in the Connecticut government, the State Supreme Court was urged today to force the Legislature to put into effect a spending cap that voters overwhelmingly approved three years ago.
The problem facing the justices is that it is far from clear what the voters had in mind and whether the Supreme Court is responsible for figuring that out. 
 At issue is a 1992 amendment to the State Constitution decreeing that "general budget expenditures" should grow by no more than the percentage increase in personal income or inflation, whichever is greater. Left up to the Legislature was how personal income and inflation should be measured and what areas of spending would be exempt.

HEADLINE: Bowing To Profits, Reluctantly

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman 

 BODY:
IT is 21 years since the release of "The Taking of Pelham One Two Three," and, unless the Transit Authority is sitting on a great secret, no one has imitated that popular movie by hijacking a New York subway train and holding its passengers for ransom.
Cinematic depictions of horror do not lead automatically to copycat crimes in real life. There may be evidence that the phenomenon does sometimes occur, but it is difficult to predict. True, a President was killed in Dallas only a year after "The Manchurian Candidate" filled theaters. It seems quite a stretch, though, to say that Lee Harvey Oswald simply mimicked that movie's assassination theme. 
 The depressingly familiar question of what to do when life appears to imitate art is with us once again because of Harry Kaufman, fighting for his life after being set aflame in his token booth by degenerates who may or may not have taken their cue from the movie "Money Train."
Perhaps the copycat issue is not the right one to raise, as has been done since the weekend. Maybe it is time to ask whether the city and related agencies like the Transit Authority should be collaborating at all on movies like this one, in which violence energizes a central plot of stealing the subway system blind. After all, the authority itself said in early 1994 that it would no longer allow producers to film scenes in the subways that suggest the system is "out of control."
Attitudes like that have long driven city officials wild because the New York subway is a big scene-setting attraction for Hollywood. These officials consider the Transit Authority to be obstructionist, and they do not want to hear even a whisper that may be interpreted as hostility to movie makers and their megabucks. Indeed, the authority's resolve in 1994 lasted only a day, until Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani waved off restrictions on movie makers as smacking of censorship.
In the first hours of Mr. Kaufman's ordeal, the Mayor said unequivocally that his position had not changed. (When Mr. Giuliani became such a First Amendment absolutist is not clear. It had to be either before or after he decided that shops selling pornographic videos were not fit to operate in residential areas.)

 IN this atmosphere, and with City Hall keeping up the pressure, transit officials say that they, too, had to give priority to keeping New York a Hollywood-friendly place. So even though they technically could do whatever they want -- it is their subway system -- they felt they could not keep out "Money Train" despite serious misgivings that security officials say they had about the script.
"You can't say that you're not going to fully cooperate," an authority official said. Cooperation in this case might strike some as a moral tap dance -- that is, giving Columbia Pictures a good deal of help on its $60 million project but drawing the line at filming the most violent scenes underground.
It left unanswered the broader question of whether there are times when the proper response is no, full stop, to a movie that is excessively long on slam-bang violence and short on brains even by modern Hollywood standards.
Does the city or an agency like the Transit Authority have to give its stamp of approval to almost anything in the name of free expression? How about a film on a vicious killer who slithers from one New York landmark to another and, with no redeeming social value to his actions, dispatches his victims with maximum gore?
The short answer is yes, says Commissioner Patricia Reed Scott of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting.

 THERE may be logistical to-ing and fro-ing, but "we shouldn't be in a position of censorship," Ms. Scott said yesterday. "If you're saying that we should determine what everyone else sees or reads, that's stepping over the line." Her position was echoed by Martin Bregman, producer of New York-based movies like "Serpico" and "Carlito's Way."
"You can't have attempts at censorship and create a film industry," Mr. Bregman said, striking at the economic heart of the matter.
Without question, a big fear at City Hall is that Hollywood, if pushed too hard on content, will simply walk away, as it did a few years ago to protest New York's high costs and complicated union rules. That would be an enormous loss. This is an industry that made 157 feature-length movies here in 1994, not to mention hundreds of television shows, commercials and music videos. Those productions were worth $1.75 billion to the local economy, Ms. Scott says.
That is enough to make a First Amendment true believer out of anyone. Too bad Harry Kaufman can't add his voice to the debate.

HEADLINE: City Seeks Renewal In Absence Of Bomb

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: LOS ALAMOS, N.M.

 BODY:
A casual visitor to this isolated mesa might find local real estate advertisements a bit off-key for a town long associated with designing nuclear Armageddon.
"Excuse me, but is this heaven?" one advertisement asks a visitor, who may be breathless from the 7,424-foot altitude or from a multihued Southwest sunset. "Actually, it's Los Alamos! Once upon a time Los Alamos was a secret town. Now, the cat's out of the bag. A great place to live." 
 In fits and starts, a town that calls itself the nation's premier Atomic City is adjusting to a new stage of life. Since the 1940's, when the Federal Government built and tested the first atomic bomb here, Washington has subsidized many local services. But with the end of the cold war and budget-cutting fever high, the flow of Federal money is drying up, bringing change to this dry, windswept town 35 miles northwest of Santa Fe.
Some locals predict that here, where scientists endured cold showers and barracks life to design the atomic bomb, tourists will enjoy hot tubs and organic food after rock climbing, river rafting or exploring ancient Indian cliff dwellings.
"We could turn Los Alamos into a quasi resort town, like Taos," mused Matthew Albright, administrator of the town Community Development Committee.
But skeptics sporting "Conehead Cafe" T-shirts joke about the challenge of luring tourists to a town that has the nation's only fully operational plutonium plant, part of the Los Alamos National Laboratory. And behind the jokes, there is worry about the effect of Federal cuts on Los Alamos, which has historically been recession-proof.
"We're a one-company town -- 100 percent dependent on Washington," said Fred Brueggeman, the county's community development director. "When the lab sniffles, the rest of the community gets pneumonia."
Half a century of Government money for nuclear weapons research magically transformed Los Alamos, New Mexico's smallest county, into its wealthiest, with an average household income of $68,000 a year.
Originally a secret city, Los Alamos once had guarded gates that, until 1957, cut the city off from the outside world . Only in 1962 did President John F. Kennedy sign legislation allowing private citizens to own property here.
Today, with Federal and state land accounting for 88 percent of Los Alamos County, one-acre housing lots sell for $300,000. And Los Alamos is New Mexico's most expensive city, with the cost of living 23 percent above the national average.
On Nov. 30, this town of 18,000 is to see the final stage in a four-month layoff of 1,000 contractors and employees at the laboratory, or 10 percent of its work force. While research programs have come and gone in the past, this is the first time that deep cuts have been made in lab jobs that many locals have considered lifetime positions.
Moreover, next June will bring the expiration of Federal contracts that have provided annual payments of $8 million to Los Alamos public schools and $2.8 million to Los Alamos County for road maintenance.
Starting with grants from the Atomic Energy Commission in the 1950's, Washington has traditionally paid for a third of the school system's budget, helping to put the county's spending per pupil 15 percent above the state average. Federal money also helps Los Alamos High School offer such atypical courses as simple robotics and computer-aided manufacturing.
"How else do you attract people to the biggest cul de sac in the world?" asked Jim Anderson, Los Alamos superintendent of schools. "The school district is a top reason for people coming here and staying."
Indeed, Los Alamos County has the greatest concentration of Ph.D.'s in the country, local officials say. And last year Los Alamos students scored higher on Scholastic Assessment Tests than students in the school district of Princeton, N.J., a university town that is the headquarters for the company that develops the tests.
Residents defend the large Federal subsidies as compensation for taxes that would be paid by private industry if the Government's presence was not so overwhelming.
Today, this legacy of Government dominance hinders efforts to attract high-technology companies that would profit from research at the $5 billion Federal laboratory.
"This is a town of 18,000 people without a Wal-Mart, without a Kmart, without a car dealership," Mr. Anderson said. "Retail companies can't afford to pay people $10 an hour."
As part of its golden legacy from the cold war era, Los Alamos has a municipal ski area and the nation's highest-altitude Olympic-size swimming pool.
On Trinity Drive, a showcase avenue named after the first atomic bomb test, Federal budget levels ultimately determine the volume of cash flowing into the McDonald's, a gallery selling Native American pottery and a boutique selling T-shirts bearing mushroom clouds and "The Atomic City."
Indeed, the most powerful figure walking the mesa today is a diminutive, mustachioed man who came to this country after his father died fighting for Germany in World War II. As the director of the Los Alamos laboratory, the man, Siegfried Hecker, oversees a 43-square mile empire of 2,224 buildings.
Dr. Hecker believes that this immense laboratory has an important post-cold war role. The laboratory stopped designing nuclear weapons in 1989, but about 60 percent of its $1 billion budget is for defense-related work. Most of the money goes for dismantling nuclear weapons and for insuring the safety and reliability of the nation's nuclear arms stockpile.
"We are cleaning up the legacy of 50 years of nuclear weapons," Mr. Hecker said in an interview. "If you look to the nuclear future, the lab will continue to have an extremely important role to play. Los Alamos is going to be here for a long, long time. We still attract the best scientists in the world."
While the laboratory's future level of financing is a perennial topic of debate here, the city is witnessing its largest private investment since the Manhattan Project took over the mesa in 1943. Two local banks are moving into new headquarters and two shopping malls have been renovated. Spurring business confidence, the Department of Energy has promised to transfer parcels of Federal land to the county for private use.
Even tourists are responding to promotional appeals to "discover the secret that is Los Alamos." The Bradbury Science Museum, which tells the history of the Manhattan Project, is expected to draw 130,000 visitors this year, a higher attendance than any museum can claim in Santa Fe, a city more commonly associated with New Mexico tourism.
One recent evening, Michael Smith, a third-generation Los Alamos entrepreneur, talked amid the hubbub of his new Central Avenue Grill.
"There is always uncertainty in a single-industry town," said the proprietor, who seemed far from uncertain himself. "My grandfather bought the PX here, and then the Korean War ended. We thought, Los Alamos is over for sure."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Los Alamos is coming to grips with life after the cold war, though it has not forgotten its past. A visitor with a full-size statue of J. Robert Oppenheimer of the Manhattan Project in the Bradbury Science Museum. The tranquillity of Ashley Pond in Los Alamos, N.M., today belies the nature of the work that went on in the buildings that surrounded the pond half a century ago. In those buildings, during World War II, scientists working for the Manhattan Project designed and built the first atomic bomb. (Photographs by Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Polish Leader Vexed by Final Hurdle: His Past

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Nov. 28

 BODY:
President-elect Aleksander Kwasniewski, the model of a media politician in his Oxford-cloth blue shirt, smart tie and suit, says he is annoyed that as he tries to hitch Poland to the West he faces a huge obstacle: his image as a former Communist.
"I can imagine in the United States people asking, 'Since the post-Communists won the election in Poland does Poland want to be a Communist country again?' " he said in an interview today. "It's a stereotype. Totally wrong, totally wrong." 
 Mr. Kwasniewski, 41, who first rose in the Communist Party as a newspaper editor, sat in an elegant damask-covered chair in his transition headquarters and spoke in English of his plans for convincing skeptics that such labels do not matter.
Since defeating Lech Walesa, Poland's first democratically elected President and a staunch anti-Communist, Mr. Kwasniewski (pronounced kvash-NYEFF-skee) has kept a low profile, trying to allow passions at home to cool. But he has tried to make the case to President Clinton in a telephone call and to West European leaders that he will push forward on political and economic reforms.
To show he is serious, Mr. Kwasniewski resigned his membership on Saturday from the political party that he founded on the rubble of the former Communist organization and that carried him to the presidency.
But he knows, he said, that the "ex-former-post Communist" label will stick a while longer. "I'm irritated, sure," he said. "Not because I wasn't a member of the party. I was, of course. But first, from an ideological point of view, I was never a Communist. In Poland I've seen very few Communists, especially since the 1970's. I met a lot of technocrats, opportunists, reformers, liberals."
Mr. Kwasniewski has been called all those things himself. But he insists he has been a social democrat for the last six years, leading his party to support privatization and heading the commission that is drafting a new constitution.
He will reinforce his separation from his past and party, he suggested, by choosing his Foreign and Defense Ministers from outside his political camp. Those appointments are seen by Washington as the most critical as Poland continues its drive to join the European Union and NATO.
A Clinton Administration official said Washington had told Mr. Kwasniewski that the "door is open, but you've got to walk through it by reaching beyond your base."
But Mr. Kwasniewski backed away from the idea, favored in Washington, that those positions be filled by leading figures in the anti-Communist Freedom Union.
"It's difficult to think of the leadership of this opposition in the Government," Mr. Kwasniewski said. This would lead to "some kind of schizophrenia," he said. Instead, he would choose more politically neutral officials for the two posts. "We need candidates with credibility and well prepared and not connected with our political groups," he said.
Poland has said it will send about 800 soldiers to Bosnia to help NATO enforce a peace accord there, something Mr. Kwasniewski said he views as building Poland's credibility.
"If we want to speak seriously about NATO membership, Poland should participate," he said. "It's extremely important."
On relations with the Roman Catholic Church, which has been hostile to him, he said he was not seeking a fight with the bishops. He said earlier this week that he was brought up in a Catholic household, that his mother was religious and that he would work so hard for Poland that he would "earn God's blessing."
He hoped to win a "compromise" from the Church on wording in the new constitution that would call for the state to be "impartial" in Church matters, a posture for which, officially, the Church has shown little enthusiasm.
On abortion, Mr. Kwasniewski was clear: He would sign a law liberalizing the restrictions enacted after Communist rule ended in 1989. "It is a deep illness and something is wrong," he said of Polish society, if women had to resort to organized trips abroad to get abortions and the police were wire-tapping the organizers in an effort to convict them.
"I'm against abortion as abortion," he said, "but if we want to solve the question more has to be done in the economic, psychological and educational fields."
Mr. Kwasniewski gives the impression of being an adept politician who, during his travels in Western Europe and the United States, has learned how to be convivial but also how to sidestep questions. His staff ran an almost textbook American-style campaign.
It also successfully defined his image after a close study of the 1960 Nixon-Kennedy television debates. Like John F. Kennedy, Mr. Kwasniewski came across as a freshly minted candidate against the tired war horse, Mr. Walesa. Mr. Kwasniewski said today he had deliberately arrived late in the studio to unsettle Mr. Walesa, who was waiting by himself before the first debate.
In 1976, as a 22-year-old student, Mr. Kwasniewski crisscrossed the United States for three months, earning his way by delivering cars for an auto agency. He visited New York during the bicentennial celebrations, Los Angeles and San Francisco, and saw parts of 33 states in all. He had already worked in Sweden and had been to London. He was impressed by the different cultures in New York.
"To see blacks, whites, Indians, Orthodox Jews -- it was unbelievable -- people working together and having tolerance for each other," he said. It was also extraordinary, he said, to visit the Smoky Mountains in Tennessee and talk to a white store owner who complained that it was no longer legal to refuse to serve a black customer.
Asked to name his political heros, Mr. Kwasniewski started with the Polish list: Jozef Pilsudski, the general who forged the rebirth of Poland after World War I; Wladyslaw Gromulka, first secretary of the Polish Communist Party from 1956 to 1970, because "he was the first man to say Poland should go on its own way" from the Soviet Union -- a characterization many Poles would take issue with; Edward Gierek, the Communist leader from 1956 to 1970, "because he opened Poland" to the West, another reading non-Communist Poles would dispute; and Wojciech Jaruzelski, the last Communist leader.
As for his recent opponent, "I have big respect for Walesa as leader of Solidarity rather than as President," Mr. Kwasniewski said.
Among foreign leaders, Mr. Kwasniewski said he admired Felipe Gonzalez, the Prime Minister of Spain, for having "reconciled Spain with its Franco past, modernized Spain and led the country into the European Union."
Mr. Kwasniewski said he faces similar challenges. He is planning a vacation this week in Spain.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices End Lower On Concerns About Budget

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, after paring most of their earlier losses.
Strong demand for new two-year Treasury notes and comments by a top Federal Reserve official suggesting that the Fed could still lower short-term interest rates in the coming months helped attract buyers yesterday. 
 But concerns over the budget negotiations in Washington hampered prices.
"Basically we had a succession of good news and the market has responded to it," said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company. "But we still have budget uncertainties. I think there is a limit to how far the market can go."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 2/32 of a percentage point, to 108 23/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.23 percent from 6.22 percent.
Prices began bouncing back yesterday after the Treasury said it had sold $18.25 billion of new two-year notes at a yield of 5.479 percent, better than the 5.5 percent that market participants had expected. In one sign of the strong demand for the notes, the bid-to-cover ratio -- a comparison of bids submitted with bids accepted -- was 3.01, up from an average of 2.54 at the last 10 auctions.
"The two-year note auction was pretty good," said Josh Stiles, senior bond strategist at IDEA Inc., a consulting firm.
Today, the Treasury will auction $12 billion of five-year notes.
Comments by the the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan S. Blinder, reinforced the market's perception of a slowing economy. Mr. Blinder said the Fed might need to cut rates in the future because monetary policy was acting as a drag on economic growth
In an interview, Mr. Blinder also said big budget deficit cuts could lead to sizable falls in interest rates. He also said that he saw some signs the economy was softening too much, calling those signs worrisome.
Economic data released yesterday gave the market mixed signals.
Early in the day, the market took in the positive news of a 3.7 percent drop in October housing starts, which was followed by negative news on consumer confidence, which jumped to 101.4 in November from 96.3 in October.
"The data was mixed," Mr. Stiles of IDEA said. "With housing weakness versus a big jump in consumer confidence."
Astrid Adolfson, an conomist at the consulting firm MCM Money Watch Inc., said, "It was another shaky day for the market, with a lot of mixed indicators."
Analysts said Treasury prices were expected to stay in a trading range over the next few days, awaiting fresh news on the deficit reduction plan to come out of Washington
In the corporate bond market, prices followed Treasury securities lower.
The BellSouth Corporation issued $500 million of 100-year debentures.
The noncallable debentures were priced at 99.72 to yield 7.02 percent, or 70 basis points over a comparable Treasury security. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Columbia Gas began the exchange of $2 billion of debentures following its emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection yesterday.
The company set seven issues of debentures ranging in maturities from 5 to 30 years at spreads of between 78 and 135 basis points over comparable Treasury securities.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Trades Broadly Lower While the Pound Is Hit Hard

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar slipped yesterday against most leading currencies as traders took profits after two days of gains.
The dollar was also buffeted by trading between other currencies as the market focused on a new budget in Britain. The pound sterling weakened when the Conservative Government's budget proposals failed to satisfy the markets. 
 The dollar's fall against the German mark and the Japanese yen seemed almost incidental to other moves. "The dollar sort of took a breather as attention moved elsewhere" during a day of thin trading, said Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst with Smith Barney.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.4335 marks, down from 1.4360 on Monday. The dollar surged on Monday, reaching a seven-week high against the mark, on expectations that the German central bank would cut interest rates this week, thus reducing the attractiveness of some mark-denominated investments. Some of those expectations waned yesterday, as currency traders tried to guess the German central bank's strategy.
The dollar slipped to 101.15 yen from 101.71 and to 1.1569 Swiss francs from 1.1580 francs. But the British pound fell to $1.5430 from $1.5535.
The pound and British Treasury bonds, known as gilts, fell sharply after the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, raised his forecast for Government borrowing in the next year to 29 billion, or $45 billion, from 23.5 billion. In addition, the forecast for 1996-97 was revised sharply higher, to 22.5 billion from 16.1 billion.
Stocks in London were little changed yesterday, with the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 leading issues falling two-tenths of 1 percent, to 3,648.8.
But currency traders were disappointed by the higher than expected borrowing needs, saying that there had not been enough spending cuts.
"The market is continuing to wonder about the possibility of a Bank of England base-rate cut, and that is leaving the pound kind of weak," Ms. Finstrom of Smith Barney said.
The pound fell to 2.2136 marks in New York yesterday from 2.2322 marks on Monday.
The strength of the mark helped pull down the dollar as well, as traders sold currencies for marks.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Price of Gold Increases on Signs Of Strong Demand and Shortage

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Gold prices jumped on the Commodity Exchange of New York yesterday on signs of a shortage of bullion.
On other markets, cotton prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 0.20 point, to 241.12. 
 Gold lease rates, which are charged for borrowing gold, have more than doubled during the last week, indicating a lack of gold available to make loans. The average one-month lease rate reached 6.16 percent yesterday, according to estimates by four London banks, compared with 1.98 percent at the end of October.
Jewelers, who use about 70 percent of the new gold supply, are in their busiest manufacturing season of the year. The strong demand pushed supplies of gold in Commodity Exchange warehouses to an 18-year low earlier this month.
"There isn't that much gold around," said Lenny Kaplan, vice president and chief trader with the Imperial Bank in Los Angeles. "Now that there is good demand for gold, people are going to have to pay more for it."
Part of the reason gold supplies are low is that central banks have been unwilling to lend gold for short periods. In addition, those banks often scale down their lending operations at the end of the year as they "close their book," said Helen Junz, a director of the World Gold Council's economic service.
Gold for February delivery, the actively traded month, rose $3.10, to $388.90 an ounce. Other precious metals were mixed. The December silver contract fell 0.4 cent, to $5.198 an ounce, while on the New York Mercantile Exchange, January platinum gained 50 cents, to $416.30 an ounce.
Cotton prices fell after a Government report showed that consumption in the United States dropped 22 percent in October.
The Census Bureau said domestic mills used 795,499 bales of cotton in October, down from 1,020,212 bales during September. High cotton prices, weak retail sales and high debt levels are holding down sales of textiles, traders said.
March cotton fell 1.1 cents, to 84.2 cents a pound, on the New York Cotton Exchange.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing Fall 3.7% In Biggest Drop Since March

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments fell surprisingly for the third straight month in October, the Commerce Department said today, raising doubts about the housing sector's ability to support economic growth.
Despite falling mortgage rates, housing starts dropped 3.7 percent in October, to an annual rate of 1.34 million, seasonally adjusted. Analysts said that while starts were weaker than anticipated, the drop was concentrated in apartment construction, which plunged 11.2 percent, to an annual rate of 238,000. Single-family home building fell 2 percent, to 1.10 million units a year. 
 Meanwhile, applications for building permits also weakened, but only by seven-tenths of 1 percent, to a rate of 1.40 million.
"Housing construction activity is certainly slowing a bit, but we all knew that was going to come," said David Lereah of the Mortgage Bankers Association. "We couldn't sustain the level of the past few months, so last month's figures are a yellow warning flag."
Housing was a source of economic vitality in the late spring and summer, with starts rising from April through July. But waning sales and construction fit a pattern of gradual slowing in economic activity in this year's final quarter.
Separately, the Conference Board in New York reported that consumer confidence perked up in November, with its index rising to 101.4 from a revised 96.3 in October. This differed from other reports indicating a slowdown in consumer spending.
"This latest rise in confidence suggests that holiday spending could be reasonably lively," said Fabian Linden, executive director of the Conference Board's Consumer Research Center. "Gains in confidence have traditionally signaled stronger-than-anticipated retail sales during the holiday season."
David Seiders, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, said the slowing pace of home building will sap the economy in the fourth quarter and in early 1996.
"The starts number itself may hold up fairly well, but as an engine of growth the housing sector may well have had its spurt," Mr. Seiders said. Other sectors, he said, are going to have to pick up some of the economic momentum.
Last month's fall in housing starts followed a revised decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in September and a 2.8 percent drop in August. The October fall was the sharpest since March, when starts dropped 6.5 percent, the department said. Previously, the department said starts fell one-tenth of 1 percent in September.
Sales are also losing steam. On Monday, the National Association of Realtors said October sales of existing, or previously owned, homes dropped for the first time in six months.
Mortgage rates that were above 9 percent for a 30-year loan at the beginning of the year averaged 7.48 percent in October, down from 7.64 percent in September, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Total starts during October were 7.9 percent lower than they were in October 1994, when they were running at a rate of 1.451 million a year.
The only region in which housing starts improved was the Northeast, where they were 7 percent higher than in September. By contrast, they dropped 8.9 percent in the Midwest and were down 1.5 percent in the South. Starts fell 6.5 percent in the West.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Yanks First In Average Salary

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: AVENTURA, Fla., Nov. 28

 BODY:
In a season when the average major league salary computed by the Players Association dropped by 5 percent, the Yankees became the first team to hit the $2 million mark.
According to figures the union presented to its executive board today at the first session of its annual winter meetings, the Yankees had an average salary of $2,000,271, eclipsing the record of $1,827,539 the Yankees established last year. 
The player relations committee, the clubs' labor arm, has not computed final average salaries, but on its list the Yankees should fall short of $2 million. The latest committee figures, which did not include bonuses for post-season awards, had the Yankees at $1,960,351.
The players and the clubs differ on their figures because the union enhances the value of signing bonuses. The players' average salary for the 1995 season came to $1,110,766. The incomplete player relations committee average was $1,089,621, but will move closer to the players' average when the post-season bonuses are added.
The players' average fell 4.9 percent from the 1994 average of $1,168,263. It marks only the second time since the Players Association began computing average salaries in 1967 that the average dropped. In 1987, when salaries were affected by the owners' collusion against free agents, the average slipped a minuscule .016 percent, from $412,520 to $412,454.
The decrease this year was a result of the economic losses the owners suffered from the players' eight-month strike. When clubs signed players last winter and spring, they induced players to accept smaller salaries because of their losses.
Based on their record average salary, the Yankees had no such problem. But another factor was involved in their precedent-setting number.
Both clubs and players compile salary data based on Aug. 31 rosters and disabled lists. They also include in players' salaries pro-rated shares of signing bonuses, whether or not the players received their bonuses from their present club.
The Yankees acquired David Cone July 28. They paid only the last two months of his $5 million salary, about $2 million, but they were charged not only with his entire salary, but also with a one-third share of the $9 million signing bonus the Kansas City Royals gave him three years ago.
With their inflated valuation of signing bonuses, the Players Association listed Cone at about $8.5 million instead of the about $2 million the Yankees actually paid him.
Second on the players' list were the Atlanta Braves at $1,917,599.
The averages of 11 clubs went up; 17 clubs' averages dropped. The Mets, 27th of 28 on the list, had the largest decrease, from $1,193,288 to $465,891. The Montreal Expos were 28th at $411,142, down from $750,840. Their average was the lowest since the San Diego Padres averaged $378,471 in 1993.

HEADLINE: Personal Health

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
AIR bags save lives: more than 911 in the United States since 1987, and 374 last year alone, according to the National Center for Statistics and Analysis. More important, perhaps, just in the terms of numbers, they have prevented many thousands of serious and deforming injuries. A friend said she would never again drive a car without an air bag after witnessing a brutal accident in which the driver would almost certainly have been killed but instead walked away with a few bruises because he had been protected by an air bag.
The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety reports that there are 23 percent fewer deaths than expected among drivers involved in head-on and front-angle crashes of cars equipped with air bags. The devices are more effective at savings lives among those driving large cars (a 30 percent reduction) than among those driving small cars (a 14 percent reduction). 
 A four-year study of 2,300 accidents in New Jersey conducted by plastic surgeons at the Robert Wood Johnson Medical School in New Brunswick showed that motorists who used both lap and shoulder belts and drove cars equipped with air bags reduced their risk of serious facial injuries by 75 percent. Such drivers were also 90 percent less likely to require intensive hospital care following an accident.
There are now more than 33 million cars on the road equipped with driver-side air bags, and 15 million also have bags to protect front-seat passengers. All passenger cars manufactured after Sept. 1, 1997, will have to be equipped with air bags for both the driver and front-seat passengers. However, nearly all manufacturers are now installing driver-side air bags, and many are also adding passenger-side air bags in all new cars, sports utility vehicles and light trucks.
 
Improving Air Bags
But air bags are not perfect, and neither are the drivers and passengers who ride in cars with air bag protection. Air bags have inflated and injured and even killed passengers in vehicles involved in nothing more than a fender-bender that in all likelihood would not have injured anyone. For example, one child died of a broken neck caused by an air bag that inflated when his grandmother bumped into a concrete wall while parking the car.
Those at greatest risk of injury caused by an air bag are small children, short or obese adults, disabled people and anyone who drives or rides unbelted. Those who sit close to the steering wheel are likely to be struck with great force by an inflating air bag.
Although 43 percent of air bag deployments have resulted in at least one air-bag-related injury, the overwhelming majority of these injuries have been minor.
For example, a review of 614 injuries published earlier this year in the Annals of Emergency Medicine showed that 96 percent were minor, 3 percent were classified as moderate and fewer than 1 percent were considered serious. Scrapes and bruises were the most common injuries. A few cases involved minor cuts, fractures of the forearms or wrists, burns and, rarely, retinal detachments, caused by the force of impact, and hearing loss, caused by the noise of inflation.
The industry is currently working furiously to improve these long-awaited devices so that inappropriate inflations and other preventable air bag accidents will not occur. The next generation of air bags, called "smart bags," will employ sensors that can adjust inflations depending on whether occupants are belted, on their position in their seats, including the distance from the steering wheel or dashboard, and even on their size and weight. Several companies are also considering installing additional air bags to protect occupants in side collisions.
 
Occupants Need Work, Too
The occupants of vehicles also need improvement. In a country in which only 40 to 50 percent of drivers and front-seat passengers use lap-shoulder belts and 35 percent of young children ride unrestrained, air bags threaten to induce even further complacency about buckling up. Yet the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration advises that seat belts remain the main source of protection in any kind of accident, while air bags offer "supplemental protection" only in front-end collisions. Air bags do not protect drivers or passengers in side and rear-end collisions and rollovers; seat belts do. Last year, the administration estimates, seat belts alone saved almost 9,200 lives and prevented more than 211,000 moderate to critical injuries.
The four drivers who have suffered fatal air bag injuries to their heads, chests or both were unbelted when the accidents occurred.
Furthermore, Americans tend not to read directions or heed warnings, especially when they think "there's nothing to it," as might seem to be the case with self-activated air bags. Despite two years of repeated warnings and instructions posted since August 1994 on vehicle visors and infant car seats and in owner's manuals stating that babies in rear-facing car seats should not ride in the front seat of a vehicle with a passenger-side air bag, several infants have been killed by air bags because these warnings were ignored.
The child who died in his grandmother's car was sitting in the front seat and was not buckled in, which allowed the air bag to hit his head with undue force. This child was one of about half a dozen-air bag-related fatalities among small children who were riding unbelted in the front seats of vehicles involved in low-speed crashes that the youngsters might otherwise have survived.
 
The Safest Journey
Even if your vehicle has dual air bags, never neglect to fasten the lap-shoulder belt when driving or riding in the front passenger seat. Infants under 20 pounds should always be placed in a rear-facing infant seat in the back seat of the vehicle. For vehicles that have no back seat but have a passenger-side air bag, a manual device should be installed to allow the driver to disengage the passenger-side air bag when an infant is sitting in the front. All children under 12 should ride in the rear and always be buckled in. Make it a rule of the road: the car does not start until everyone's seat belt is properly fastened, and that includes the shoulder belt, when there is one.
The presence of an air bag should not be taken as a license to drive faster or take extra chances on the road. Even with the fullest protection currently available -- a lap-shoulder belt properly fastened and an air bag installed -- fully half the accidents that could result in fatalities still do.
Dr. Ricardo Martinez, the nation's traffic safety administrator, cautions that "no safety device is a panacea," and that it remains a driver's responsibility to drive safely and never to drive even a short distance when impaired by alcohol or drugs.
