HEADLINE: A Society Decides It Can't Go It Alone

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
After a three-year scramble back from the brink of insolvency, the New-York Historical Society has virtually given up hope of remaining independent and is actively seeking a merger or partnership with another institution.
Although the society is in better financial shape than it has been in years, thanks in part to auctioning off pieces of its collection, life there is still hand-to-mouth. And now, officials say they have hit a financial dead end that seems to rule out further substantial progress toward a hoped-for $40 million endowment or much chance of winning $1 million a year in government support. 
 Today, the society will try to woo one potential partner, the Museum of the City of New York, in talks at the office of New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, Schuyler Chapin. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani supports the talks. And while the society has failed at merger talks before, it says that now it is truly interested -- and a much more attractive partner financially than it was a few years ago.
"If the merger doesn't happen, we're not going to go under, but we're going to have to find other partnerships," said Betsy Gotbaum, the society's executive director. "The alternative to a merger is to keep going at this level or lower," she said, calling that path "unacceptable."
All of this is happening while the society is preparing to auction off more of its collections -- some 24,000 items from its library, which is regarded as one of the top historical research libraries in America. To the chagrin of some scholars and archivists, arrangements for the sale are proceeding even while the merger talks progress.
The materials, ranging from comic books to Remington engravings, are expected to sell for less than $1 million, a fraction of the $17.6 million realized from the society's much-debated sales of paintings and other artworks this year. But officials at the society say they feel obligated to raise everything they can, under the strategy developed by their advisory committee and approved by the New York State Attorney General.
That strategy has taken the society a good distance since 1993, when the endowment had shrunk to $6 million and its doors were closed to the public. The society has renovated and reopened its grand old limestone building on Central Park West at 77th Street. It has built its endowment to more than $22 million. And after a period in which its future seemed so uncertain that foundations and other contributors stayed away, it has once again begun to attract private support, like a $7.5 million grant from the Henry Luce Foundation five months ago.
But as Ms. Gotbaum and her trustees now acknowledge, the society is functioning in a bare-bones fashion, and it takes constant begging to keep it even at that level. Although it is not running a deficit, its $5 million budget is the same size as when it was closed. The highly regarded library collection is open only 15 hours a week (Wednesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 P.M.). And there is no way it can list its holdings on line electronically so scholars elsewhere can know what it holds, since there is no money for cataloguers.
Two crucial aspects of the society's financial strategy have not worked out. Although the society received $12 million in emergency money from New York State and New York City and some additional program support, it has failed to secure any permanent government funds. The advisory committee had determined that annual government support of about $1 million was critical to the society's future.
The committee's recommendation that the society develop the empty property in its backyard to bring in another $15 million and raise the endowment to about $40 million also appears unfeasible because of community opposition to any sizable building. Without those extra funds, the society will remain constantly strapped for money, Ms. Gotbaum and others say.
Wilbur L. Ross Jr., the investment banker who headed the society's advisory committee in 1993, does not express surprise that all of the pieces did not fit neatly into place. But he says "it was the only strategy that had a chance to work."
"There were always concerns voiced about individual parts of the package," he said. "The idea was to try to present it as a seamless whole, because in that way you could try to make sure it would all work."
But the idea of a merger with the Museum of the City of New York holds some appeal for him, too. "A combination was not feasible at that time," he said. "But if it is now possible for the two to get together, I think it would be an excellent solution. It is a perfect match. And in this world of much-rationed resources for culture, I think you are going to see more and more mergers."
Raising money to support historical collections and scholarly libraries has always been difficult. Art museums can draw huge audiences with blockbuster shows featuring Picasso or Matisse, and ballet companies can pack their seats with "The Nutcracker" or "Swan Lake." Historical societies and research libraries appeal largely to scholars, a tiny group without deep pockets.
"We're all in trouble to varying degrees," said Charles T. Cullen, president of the 108-year-old Newberry Library in Chicago, the second-largest research library in the United States, after the New York Public Library.
In "The Charitable Nonprofits," William G. Bowen, president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, and three associates concluded that historical societies as a group were less able to earn money from admissions or sales than any other group of nonprofit institutions they examined. This makes them more dependent on endowment income and grants and other private donations than other museums, performing-arts groups, or colleges and universities, they said.
For most historical societies, including the New-York Historical Society, it has also led to a public emphasis on their museum holdings. But while old textbooks and almanacs may be less glamorous than glass paperweights or portraits of Inca kings, the society's strength and reputation among historians have long been in its library. The museum contains some items, like its Audubon watercolors, that are special, but the research library is ranked among the top handful in the nation.
"For me as a graduate student, going to the New-York Historical Society library was like a Little League baseball player getting to play with Mickey Mantle," said Douglas Greenberg, president of the Chicago Historical Society.
The problem of a limited public appetite for historical books and manuscripts also explains why the society is unlikely to raise sizable sums as it auctions off materials from its library of some three million books, manuscripts, newspapers, maps and other holdings.
"Their holdings are irreplaceable, but you can't value them in dollars," said Kevin Guthrie, a former research associate at the Mellon Foundation, whose book on the society is due out in January.
That is not to say there is no market for the books and manuscripts, but it is a limited one. George S. Lowry, president of Swann Galleries, which is handling the library sales, estimates that they will bring in about $500,000 to $700,000, far less than the $17.6 million earned by the sale of its art.
Swann has already begun to move the items from the society and to catalogue them. New York museums and libraries, which are eligible for preferential treatment, have until Dec. 1 to indicate interest. The first public auctions are set for March.
The list of the library items to be sold was actually drawn up two years ago and approved by the Attorney General last year. Hendrik Edelman of Rutgers University, an outside consultant and bibliographer who had assessed the library's holdings in 1989, worked with library employees on what might be sold.
The society's internal acquisition committee and its trustees' collections committee both gave their approval, and the Attorney General's office signed off in September 1994, at the same time that it approved the art sales, although no public disclosure of what was to be sold was made before now.
The society describes the materials being sold as multiple holdings or works that do not relate to its redefined mission of focusing more narrowly on New York and the surrounding region. The choices were made conservatively, and the society's staff was protective of the collections, said Margaret Heilbrun, director of the society's library.
Pointing to a 16th-century "View of the World," a watercolor on parchment adorned with gold leaf that is displayed in the reading room, she said, "That shows how hard we tried to keep things in scope."
But scholars say they cannot judge for themselves because no public list has been issued yet.
"I hope above all that they had good advice," said Patricia U. Bonomi, of New York University, a regular user of the society's library.
The announcement of the sale that was sent to museums and libraries last month contained only a general list of 13 categories to be sold. These included 15,000 British and Continental books from the 16th to 20th centuries, 250 maps of Europe and South America, 130 comic and science fiction books, sheet music from World War I and modern times, children's books from the late 19th and 20th centuries, and wood engravings by Frederic Remington. But even by moving these items from their shelves, the huge library will remain costly to operate.
That is why a merger looks so attractive to the society. A combination would offer some economies of scale and the prospect of enhanced stability that donors care so much about. For the society, a merger with the Museum of the City of New York, which is one of the 31 members of New York City's Cultural Institutions Group, would also make it eligible for the support those institutions receive.
Some historians have suggested that the New York Public Library might offer a more congenial home for the society's library holdings, but the library is not part of the cultural institutions group and would not offer automatic coverage of maintenance and energy costs, although it does receive city money. Ms. Gotbaum said that a deal with the public library, which assessed the society's library last summer, would be "much more complicated."
But a merger with the Museum of the City of New York would not necessarily be trouble-free either. The museum faces its own challenges. While New York City pays for its building costs, it has had trouble maintaining some of its collections, and its building is badly deteriorated. It is now trying to cobble together $18 million in private money to match government money that would support an overhaul and expansion of its space. And it, too, has a scanty endowment (about $8 million), most of it restricted.
Robert R. MacDonald, director of the museum, said he would attend the meeting today. But he made it clear that any merger must be accompanied by enough money to pay for the upkeep of both collections.
"Where are the resources?" he asks. "That's a very real question."

HEADLINE: Chemical to Keep Center, and Its 2,500 Jobs, on Long Island

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Chemical Banking Corporation, the largest private employer on Long Island, intends to keep its credit card processing center in Hicksville, along with the center's 2,500 jobs, after Chemical's pending acquisition of Chase Manhattan, people familiar with the banks' plans said yesterday.
Chase moved all of its credit card facilities to regions with lower costs years ago, and Long Island politicians were worried that the combined bank would take the Chemical jobs out of the state as well. 
 "As soon as I learned of the merger back in August and realized the potential for the loss of jobs, I wrote a letter to Chemical asking them to make every effort to retain their staff here," the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, said last night.
"Clearly the fact that they have decided to stay here, after being lured by other areas of the country, is proof that Long Island is a good place to live and work," said Mr. Gulotta, a Republican.
The Long Island economy has been beset by job losses, including drastic reductions in employment by Grumman Corporation after the aerospace concern was acquired by Los Angeles-based Northrop Corporation last year. Another major bank, Natwest Bancorp, moved operations from Long Island to Scranton, Pa., earlier this year.
Thus Chemical's announcement is seen as a boon to Long Island, even though the bank is not promising to add any new jobs in Hicksville. The bank is expected to announce its decision at a news conference today that will be attended by Gov. George E. Pataki, Attorney General Dennis Vacco, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and a raft of bank officials.
"At a time when they could have followed the lead of the businesses that moved thousands of jobs out of New York during the last 12 years, the banks have illustrated their commitment to New York and Long Island," Governor Pataki said.
A Chemical spokesman reached last night declined to comment.
Chemical was under intense political pressure to keep the Hicksville facility open. For one thing, Long Island is the home of Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato, the chairman of the powerful Senate Banking Committee.
A number of New York politicians have asked the Federal Reserve to block the acquisition, complaining that the two banks have not promised to lend enough to poor neighborhoods.
The Hicksville facility was originally built by Manufacturers Hanover Trust, and became a Chemical operation when those two banks merged in 1992. In the 1980's, Manufacturers Hanover had successfully lobbied New York State to raise its interest rate ceilings in return for a promise to keep its credit card operation in Hicksville. Charles Walsh, the executive who ran Manufacturers Hanover's credit-card unit and later Chemical's, is seen as a proponent of the Hicksville facility and has been named to run the same business for the combined bank.
The bank, which will largely be run by Chemical management but will use the more prestigious Chase name, will be the country's third largest credit card issuer with 20 million card holders, representing about $21 billion in credit card debt.
Chemical and Chase expect to close 100 branches and eliminate 12,000 of 75,000 jobs a result of the merger, as many as half of them in the New York area. These moves will save $1.5 billion a year.
Chase maintains credit card operations in Tampa, Fla., Tempe, Ariz., and Wilmington, Del., and Chemical has another facility in Matteson, Ill. None of these operations is likely to close after the merger, and new jobs are likely to be added in Chase's Arizona facility, the one built most recently, people familiar with the bank's plans said.

HEADLINE: Pension Funds Reverse Decade Of Deterioration

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Corporate pension funds moved into a much better position last year to pay promised retirement benefits, reversing more than a decade of deteriorating finances, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said yesterday.
Last year, about 8,000 companies with Government-insured pension plans -- about one-fifth of the total -- fell approximately $31 billion short of covering what they owe to roughly eight million workers and retirees, the Government agency said. That is a sharp improvement from 1993, when about 10,000 companies faced a gap of some $71 billion. In 1983, the shortfall was $10 billion, or about $15.4 billion in today's dollars. 
 Another 37,000 companies covering 24 million workers have pension plans with enough money set aside to cover their obligations or even to generate a surplus. As a group last year, they had 16 percent more money than they needed to pay retirement benefits already earned, compared with a scant 1 percent surplus in 1993. Still, these plans were in far better shape in 1988 -- before the recession of the early 1990's -- when the overall surplus among healthy pension plans was 48 percent.
"Traditional pensions are getting stronger and that is good news for workers and retirees," said Martin Slate, executive director of the pension agency.
Mr. Slate attributed the narrowing of the pension funding gap to three factors: higher interest rates, extra infusions of cash by companies and an early warning program in which the pension agency starts negotiating with companies at the first sign that a plan is in financial straits.
But for all the improvement, the Labor Secretary, Robert B. Reich, warned yesterday that the mammoth catch-all budget bill passed by Congress could reverse this trend and cause a sharp deterioration in the overall health of the traditional defined benefit pension system under which retirees are paid a guaranteed monthly stipend. Under a provision in the bill, companies with surplus assets in their pension plans would be allowed under certain circumstances to use some of that money for other purposes. President Clinton plans to veto the bill but many of its provisions are likely to survive any compromise legislation.
"We have finally put pension funding on the right track," Mr. Reich said. "But if Congress persists in allowing tens of billions of dollars to be taken from pensions it could derail pension security for America's working men and women."
Supporters of the legislation, however, say that some plans have such huge surpluses that companies should be allowed to tap them to pay for other employee benefits. Companies also argue that allowing pension plans to serve as potential nest eggs for hard times will encourage the survival of defined benefit plans.
James B. Lockhart, an investment banker who ran the pension agency during the Bush Administration, called Mr. Reich's remarks "fear mongering," arguing that only the healthiest plans -- not the shaky ones that are underfunded -- would be eligible to make withdrawals.
The improvement in the ability of companies to finance their pensions can be traced to both temporary and permanent sources.
Interest rates were higher in 1994, but they declined again this year. When rates go up, the future value of current obligations goes down and money invested in bonds generates a higher return. Raymond Sharp, an actuary at Buck Consultants, a leading pension consulting company, said a 1 percent rise in interest rates could reduce pension liabilities by 10 to 15 percent. Improvements in the stock market also make it easier for companies to meet their pension obligations.
Companies have also taken steps in recent years to fill the gap for good. In 1994 employers put an extra $12 billion into pension plans with shortfalls. The biggest infusion came from the General Motors Corporation, which put up $9.6 billion above its normal annual contribution. Other companies making extra payments into their pension plans included Goodyear, $165 million, and Loews, $157 million.
G.M.'s contribution shifted the biggest concentration of pension shortfall from the auto industry to the steel industry. Last year, less than one-twentieth of the shortfall was in the auto industry compared with one-third in 1993. The steel industry accounted for slightly more than 20 percent of the $31 billion gap.
The troubled plans had 87 percent of the funding needed in 1994, up from 82 percent in 1993.
While the overall funding gap was narrowed substantially, some big plans remain in serious jeopardy. Mr. Reich and Mr. Slate said that 1.2 million workers were employed at 150 companies with bonds rated below investment grade, suggesting that the companies could be in serious trouble if the economy falters. These 150 companies, which cover about 15 percent of the workers whose pension plans face a shortfall, account for one-third of the gap.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexican Stocks Rise 4%, Accelerating a 2-Week Recovery

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29

 BODY:
Mexican stocks surged to their highest level in 13 months today, in a rally that has propelled the market upward on 9 of the last 10 trading days and all but dissipated the gloom that prevailed here last month.
"It's been really incredible, the strength of this thing, and how fast it has whipped around," said Robert J. Pelosky, director of Latin American research at Morgan Stanley. 
 The main Mexico City stock index increased by 109.04 points, or 4.17 percent, in heavy volume today, closing at 2,724.50. With that increase, the index has risen 21.55 percent in two weeks.
In New York, American depository receipts of Telefonos de Mexico, the giant state telephone company that makes up about one-fourth of the market capitalization, rose 27/16 , to 347/16 in trading of 12.9 million units. In the last seven New York sessions, the price of Telmex has increased more than 29 percent. Other Mexican issues, including the industrial holding company Desc, Grupo Televisa and Grupo Tribasa, also made steep gains.
"This is a highly volatile market," said Jorge Mariscal, chief strategist for Latin American equities at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "It had been three or four very bad weeks, and now we have a good couple of weeks. I just wish it would even out."
Traders said the market began climbing today immediately after its opening and got a strong boost at midmorning when 38 of Mexico's top corporate executives announced in a meeting with President Ernesto Zedillo that their companies would collectively invest $6.2 billion in Mexico during 1996, an increase of 40 percent over this year.
"That had a strong impact immediately," said Araceli Espinosa Elguea of the brokerage Probursa.
Also fueling the market surge were a stronger peso, lower interest rates and an announcement that the Government had increased a planned $500 million bond offering in Europe to $1.5 billion because of strong demand, analysts said.
The peso strengthened by nearly 2 percent, closing here at 7.475 to the dollar, compared with 7.615 on Tuesday. A stronger peso increases the value of peso-denominated stocks.
Lower interest rates also fed the market rally. On Tuesday, the demand was high for 28-day Mexican treasury bills, which determine how much companies and Mexican consumers will pay to borrow short-term money, and yields fell, declining 128 basis points, to 53.46 percent from 54.74 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent.
The high demand in the European bond offering, involving a one-year, variable-rate issue, suggested that investors might be putting aside lingering worries over the heavy losses they had suffered in the peso devaluation last December.
"The Government is being able to tap the debt market in a very sizable amount, and at a lower cost," said Luis R. Luis, managing director at Scudder, Stevens & Clark. "That's always stimulative for the stock market, and it's very good news for Mexico."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Surge; Yields at Nearly 2-Year Low

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday, driving yields down to their lowest levels in nearly two years, as a sale of five-year notes came close to expectations.
Some of the early buying was attributed to anticipation of strong demand at the sale of $12 billion in new five-year notes. And indeed the yield at the auction was slightly lower than expected, at 5.625 percent, and the lowest since Feb. 24, 1994. 
 While the results were not as impressive as those at Tuesday's auction of new two-year notes, they were still considered strong, helping to keep prices firm through the afternoon.
Also bolstering prices yesterday was optimism among some market participants that interest rates would soon be lowered in the United States and in Europe. Lower interest rates overseas would make United States securities more attractive.
Still, traders noted that some gains yesterday could be attributed to end-of-the-month buying.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 15/32 , to 109 6/32 , pushing its yield down to 6.19 percent, from 6.23 percent on Tuesday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. Yesterday's long bond yield was the lowest since Jan. 12, 1994, nearly a month before the Federal Reserve started a series of increases in short-term interest rates.
Today, the market turns its attention to a report on durable goods orders in October and a survey by the Chicago Purchasing Management Association.
Donald Fine, chief market strategist for Chase Securities, said he expected a decline in durable goods in October following strong gains in both August and September. But while the rate of growth for durable goods orders is still noticeably positive, he says, it nevertheless is running at about half the pace of last year.
The Chicago purchasing managers' index is also expected to show a decline in November after a sharp rise in October.
"Looking at the broader picture, economic growth appears to be slowing both in the fourth quarter and in terms of the longer-run trend rate of growth," Mr. Fine said, "all of which is taking place in an inflationary environment that can only characterized as subdued, benign and nonthreatening."
"In my view the chances of the economy accelerating and producing an inflation threat have lessened, while at the same time the chances of a further deterioration in economic growth have increased, although not to a point where a recession would become an significant risk," he said.
As a result, Mr. Fine said, he expects the Fed will lower short-term interest rates when policy makers meet on Dec. 19.
In the futures market, traders shifted their attention yesterday to the March bond contract, which is now the most active contract. The Chicago Board of Trade uses only four months for its bond contracts: December, March, June and September.
The March bond contract managed to close above the top of its previous multiweek range, at 1188/32 . The high was 1189/32 and the low was 11726/32 .
Robin Mesch, an officer at Thomson Research of Boston, said:
"There are signs all over the technicals that a bullish picture is perservering.
" And I see a 120 price on the bond futures contract by the end of December or early into the new year. There's just nothing there to say that it isn't going higher."

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Hondo Oil's fortunes brighten, but some investors are wary.

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson 

 BODY:
AT the beginning of the year, it looked as if Robert O. Anderson, the former chief executive of ARCO, had run out of luck in founding the Hondo Oil and Gas Company instead of kicking back on his New Mexico ranch to enjoy his retirement. Having sold off most of what he owned to pursue a single natural gas project in the foothills of the Colombian Andes, he had only a vague idea of how much he would find. He had no customers. Creditors and short-sellers were closing in.
But in the last few months, almost everything has gone right for Hondo. A second well has indicated that the project is probably sitting on 9 to 12 trillion cubic feet of gas, about twice the earlier estimates, analysts said. That amount of gas would be valued at billions of dollars, even before counting petroleum liquids that might be worth almost as much. 
 Hondo, based in Roswell, N.M., has also found a buyer for the gas. The company reached an agreement to sell 80 million cubic feet of natural gas a day, most of what the two wells can produce, to a refinery owned by Ecopetrol, the Colombian state oil and natural gas company. The refinery will then be able to substitute natural gas for fuel oil in its own operations, freeing the oil for other domestic uses or export.
Amoco, which holds a 60 percent interest in the Colombia project to Hondo's 30 percent, brings the skills and financial strength to build the $100 million, 55-mile pipeline needed to transport gas to the refinery. The pipe has already arrived in Colombia and Amoco expects to begin laying it next year, although the completion date is uncertain.
Hondo's major creditor was Lonrho, the British conglomerate, to which Mr. Anderson had personally guaranteed $35 million. He has settled Hondo's debts and his own by giving Lonrho about 27 percent of the company, raising Lonrho's stake to about 66 percent and cutting his own to 12 percent.
Hondo also has some assurance now that its good news will be publicized on Wall Street. It was nearly bereft of analyst attention at influential investment firms until August, when Paul Hayes, with Oppenheimer & Company, began coverage by recommending it. After the stock had sunk as low as $8.50 earlier this year, it rose to a peak of $24.375 in August.
Since then, Hondo has dropped back, and closed yesterday on the American Stock Exchange at $14.625, off 12.5 cents. There are still many reasons investors remain squeamish. Given Amoco's interest and the Colombian Government's rights to half the profits under the project agreement, Hondo would receive only a fraction of any payoff. And because emptying such a huge natural gas reservoir just to power the oil refinery would take a few centuries, Amoco and Hondo hope to find broader markets. The plan: develop power plants for a nation that needs more electricity, and then fuel the power plants with natural gas. It is a strategy practiced around the world, but one always fraught with political and economic risks.
Hondo's progress has scared away only some of the short-sellers. These investors, who sell borrowed shares in the hopes of a price drop, at which point they buy back the shares to repay the loan and pocket the difference, have reduced their positions but are still short about 750,000 of the 13 million shares outstanding. "They don't know as much as I do," Mr. Anderson said with a chuckle. "I don't envy them."
Mr. Anderson, Hondo's chairman and, he said, its "resident dreamer," wants to build the first natural gas pipeline through Central America, but others in the industry call this at best a very long-range plan.
Hondo will try to strike oil, far easier to market than natural gas, with the project's third well, likely to be completed by late next summer. Otherwise, Mr. Hayes sees no earnings until the third quarter of 1997. But if Mr. Anderson, at age 78, is willing to make a long-term bet, investors who are patient and better diversified than he is might want to as well.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Pound and Mark As Traders Expect a Rate Cut

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar rose to a 16-month high against the British pound and gained against the German mark as expectations grew that interest rates in those two countries would soon be lowered.
The pound slumped on speculation that British policy makers would have to cut interest rates soon if they intended to meet the economic growth forecasts set forth in the Government's 1996-97 budget, which was announced on Tuesday. 
 "Sterling was the main event today," said Kevin Lawrie, foreign exchange manager at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. "We had a selloff after that unspectacular budget."
The pound tumbled as much as 1.2 percent, to a 16-month low of $1.5253, before recouping some of its losses. In New York trading late yesterday, it was at $1.5336, down from $1.5430 on Tuesday.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, who must approve British rate changes, said yesterday that the Government's growth forecast did not require a cut in the base lending rate, which is now 6.75 percent.
But analyst and currency traders were skeptical. In its budget, the Conservative Government forecast annual economic growth of 3 percent in the coming year.
"The only way the Government can come even remotely close to making this budget work out as planned is to cut base rates, fast," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics.
The dollar was bolstered against the German mark ahead of a policy meeting by the Bundesbank today. Recent evidence that German inflation remains subdued has fueled expectations that the central bank will cut interest rates, perhaps as early as today.
Those expectations were not dampened by a surprise increase in Germany's 14-day securities repurchase rate, an important money-market rate. The rate rose 1 basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, to 3.98 percent at the central bank's weekly money market transactions.
The president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said the rise in the rate did not signal a change in monetary policy.
The dollar rose to an eight-week high of 1.4411 marks before settling to 1.4366 marks, up from 1.4335 late Tuesday.
In other trading, the dollar rose to 101.58 Japanese yen from 101.15.

HEADLINE: Toyota Truck Plant Expected in Indiana

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 29

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation is expected to announce on Thursday that it has selected southwestern Indiana, an area hurt by a declining coal industry, as the site for a $1 billion pickup-truck plant with 1,300 jobs.
Toyota scheduled "a major business announcement" for Thursday afternoon in Princeton, Ind. State and local officials, cautioning today that a deal had not yet been signed, were nonetheless cheered by the prospect of new jobs. 
 Press reports in Indiana said Toyota had chosen a site just outside Princeton, about 20 miles north of Evansville, Ind., and about midway between Louisville, Ky., and St. Louis.
The community is served by two railroads, CSX Transportation and Norfolk Southern, and by two utilities, PSI Energy, a unit of the Cinergy Corporation, and the Southern Indiana Gas and Electric Company. With such competition, Toyota is expected to be able to reach favorable terms for power and rail service.
Among states also seeking the plant were New Jersey, Ohio, Michigan and Kentucky. Doug Smith, Toyota's vice president for government affairs, said geography had worked against New Jersey because auto-parts suppliers were concentrated in the Midwest.
Toyota has said that its fourth plant in North America will produce T100 midsize pickup trucks, which are now made only in Japan. Toyota produces passenger cars in Georgetown, Ky., and Cambridge, Ontario, and at a plant in Fremont, Calif., jointly owned with General Motors.
The company has said that its new pickup plant, to be completed in 1998, will be able to make 100,000 trucks a year for sale in North America.
Fred Nation, a spokesman for Gov. Evan Bayh of Indiana, estimated that combined state and local incentives for the plant would amount to less than $75 million, adding that Toyota was still negotiating over local incentives like property taxes. The state's portion, he said, totaled $29.8 million, including $2.8 million in worker-training grants.
The Indiana Department of Work Force Development will help provide job candidates for the nonunion plant, including skilled but unemployed miners. Demand for Indiana's high-sulfur coal has declined with Federal clean-air requirements, eliminating jobs in the region's once-dominant coal industry.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Toyota is expected to announce today that it will build a pickup-truck plant in southwestern Indiana, its third solely owned factory in the United States. A surveyor's stake and a spray-painted arrow were evident yesterday at the expected location of the plant, on farmland just outside Princeton, Ind. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
With Japan hurting, the U.S. mutes chauvinist trade fears.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
SOMETIMES the news from Washington is not what they say but what they don't say: Have you noticed that the Clinton Administration has stopped bashing Japan? It's possible, of course, that the White House has simply been distracted by more urgent matters like the budget and next year's election.
But the true explanation, it seems, was signaled earlier this month in a speech by Lawrence H. Summers, the Deputy Treasury Secretary. Without quite saying so, he suggested that the sophomoric notion of trade as war had lost its appeal now that the Japanese economy has been badly wounded by recession. "Prosperity, unlike power, is not a zero sum game," he said. 
 Michael Aho, an economist at Prudential Securities, interprets the Administration's less antagonistic disposition toward Japan more bluntly. "This is just not the same Godzilla that was eating our lunch," he said. Indeed, the myriad problems facing the Japanese economy -- by contrast the American economy, for all its problems, has enjoyed relative success in recent years -- raise the issue of whether Tokyo is up to the challenges of economic maturity.
Japan, so long the Energizer bunny of national economies, has barely twitched in the last four years. And no wonder: the real estate and stock markets, both prone to speculative excesses, have crashed and burned.
Consequently, many of Japan's largest banks are effectively moribund, with total unfunded liabilities that far exceed the bill for bailing out depositors in America's savings and loan debacle. The overvalued yen has made Japanese exporters far less competitive in world markets, pushing thousands of smaller companies into bankruptcy, forcing dozen of larger ones to drop lifetime employment guarantees and leaving the unemployment rate, while still low by international standards, at nearly double its traditional level.
Worst of all, weak elected governments unable to sway the conservative bureaucracies that control the levers of power have failed to rise to the occasion.
No mechanism has been created to bail out edgy bank depositors. Cuts in interest rates, which have fallen so low there is little room for further reductions, failed to cheer securities markets. Tokyo's half-hearted fiscal stimulus packages, which did not rescue the economy, have actually made things worse by convincing many people that nothing can be done at all.
Indeed, while hundreds of billions of dollars worth of productive capacity sit idle and Japanese manufacturers are shifting plants to Jakarta and Kuala Lumpur, Tokyo remains preoccupied with the budget deficit. The last thing the Japanese economy needs is a tax increase, yet consumption taxes are still set to rise in 1997. "The Ministry of Finance is brain dead," John Makin of the American Enterprise Institute concluded.
Mr. Makin argues that the Japanese economy will not climb back until Tokyo accepts the need for fundamental change. He advocates tax changes that favor long-suffering consumers, deregulation that breathes enterprise into inefficient service industries and a looser monetary policy that drives down the value of the yen by another 20 to 30 percent.
Others are not as pessimistic. Mr. Aho predicts a weak recovery in 1996 with 2.5 percent growth. Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan, reminds us that Japan is still blessed by a strong work ethic, a superbly trained labor force and a high savings rate. "I don't think there is anything so structurally wrong with the economy that would lead to three more years as bad as the last three," Mr. Saxonhouse said.
Still, it is hard to find anyone who expects Japan to get back on the fast track any time soon. Mr. Saxonhouse alludes to the "bicycle theory" of economic development -- the idea that rapid growth is relatively easy to keep going, but hard to restart once it stalls.
The parochial question is what Japan's expulsion from the Eden of fast-growing economies means for America. Sophisticated analysts, including some members of the Clinton Administration, never equated Japan's success with America's failure. Quite the opposite: "We'd all feel better if Japan were coming out of recession," Mr. Saxonhouse said, giving it the wherewithal to buy more American products.
A subtler question -- and the focus of Mr. Summers's analysis -- is whether the stagnation of the heavily regulated Japanese economy makes free-wheeling, American-style capitalism the more attractive model for rich nations. It is certainly true, as Mr. Summers puts it, that "American firms have emerged as leaders in almost everything that one associates with the post-industrial economy." Left to be answered is whether America's poor schools and weak savings -- the mirror image of Japan's devotion to education and thrift -- will drag the economy down over the long haul.
The hope, buoyed by Mr. Summers's olive branch, is that the Administration will stop playing to chauvinist trade fears that highlight peripheral issues. Then, the countries can focus on the real problems bedeviling their economies.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Seagram Reports a Deficit Of $55 Million in Quarter

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The Seagram Company said yesterday that it took a pretax charge of $290 million in the third quarter to trim its wine and spirits business, resulting in a loss of $55 million.
The charge, which was higher than what analysts had expected, will cover job cuts and closing some warehouses, bottling plants and distilleries, mostly in Europe, where business has been weak. 
 The company reported a loss of $55 million, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter, which ended on Oct. 31, compared with a profit of $199 million in the quarter a year earlier. Although based in Montreal, Seagram, a beverage and entertainment company, reports in United States dollars.
Revenues increased 92.8 percent, to $2.92 billion from $1.51 billion, reflecting Seagram's acquisition of 80 percent of MCA Inc. in June and the juice beverage business of the Dole Food Company in May.
The charge amounted to about $211 million after taxes, or 57 cents a share. Without it, Seagram would have earned $156 million, or 42 cents a share.
The gain was more than the average estimate of 40 cents a share from five analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.
Shares of Seagram rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $37.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"The engine for this quarter was filmed entertainment," Edgar Bronfman Jr., Seagram's chief executive, said from his office in New York. He said the success of MCA's "Casper" and "Apollo 13" was primarily responsible for the third-quarter growth.
Under MCA, Seagram runs Universal Pictures, theme parks, MCA Records, Geffen Records and a television production unit.
Seagram financed the purchase of MCA from the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company by selling most of its stake in E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company back to Du Pont for $8.8 billion. Dividends from the Du Pont holding helped bolster earnings in the quarter a year earlier.
In the most recent quarter, Seagram's operating cash flow -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- rose to $481 million from $257 million. Analysts consider operating cash flow to be an important gauge of a media company, although Seagram is still chiefly a beverage company.
The cutbacks in Seagram's wine and spirits business come as the company's profit in Europe has been hampered for some time by weak economic growth, declining consumption and price competition, particularly from Guinness P.L.C., analysts said. Results have also been weak in Venezuela, Brazil and Japan, they said.
Most of the steps will be completed in six to 12 months, Mr. Bronfman said. He said the resulting savings "will far exceed the charge we are taking today."
He said he hopes Seagram's spirits and wine business will post double-digit gains in operating profit after the changes.
Seagram began making changes at its beverage division last year and took a fiscal year 1995 pretax charge of $35 million to cover the costs, Mr. Bronfman said.
Brian Lomas, an analyst at Scotia McLeod in Montreal, agreed. "Ultimately, this will improve beverage margins," he said.

HEADLINE: Apple Computer Co-Founder Strikes Gold With New Stock

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29

 BODY:
In the world of high technology, which keeps score in part by tracking the ups and downs of the stock market, Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder of Apple Computer, re-emerged today as a captain of industry.
Mr. Jobs's company, Pixar Animation Studios, the maker of the blockbuster movie "Toy Story," offered its stock to the public today, and by the end of trading the shares had almost doubled in price. As such, his Pixar stake of 80.2 percent was worth more than $1 billion on paper -- more than the value of his Apple stock at any time during the eight years he ran that company. 
 The windfall for Mr. Jobs is yet another example of the stock market's extraordinary upward momentum this year, particularly in shares of technology companies. Indeed, the market reached another record today as the Dow Jones industrial average rose 27.46 points, to 5,105.56, its 65th high of the year. [Page D10.]
Mr. Jobs invested $60 million in Pixar and spent nine years waiting for his payoff and his story does have mythic overtones for the computer industry. Mr. Jobs, 40, has long been a mercurial figure in Silicon Valley's hot-house culture, which values entrepreneurs with vision and personal drive -- but which also sees most of its start-up ventures end in failure.
With his gains, Mr. Jobs joins the ranks of technology billionaires in just one day. Most recently, James H. Clark, the founder of the Netscape Communications Corporation, saw his paper wealth pass the $1 billion mark, as his Netscape shares climbed from their initial offering price of $28 on Aug. 8 to $140 today.Mr. Clark invested only $4.1 million to start his company 19 months ago.
With Stephen Wozniak, Mr. Jobs founded Apple in a Cupertino, Calif., garage in 1976. By the early 1980's, Mr. Jobs had risen to international prominence as the personal computer began to transform society.
But that was not to last. In 1985, he was driven from Apple by John Sculley, who Mr. Jobs had hired several years earlier as Apple's president. The following year, Mr. Jobs started Next Inc., which has tried with little success to compete with Apple. As such, Mr. Jobs largely fell out of the industry limelight in recent years.
It was almost as a footnote that Mr. Jobs bought Pixar, a tiny computer company specializing in ultrahigh-resolution computer animation technology, from Lucasfilm for $60 million in 1986.
But today, that footnote symbolized the long-heralded convergence of Hollywood and Silicon Valley.
Pixar's stock was initially priced at $22 a share on Tuesday by the underwriters taking it to the public market. That meant Mr. Jobs's stake was already worth on paper roughly $660 million -- assuming the offering of six million Pixar shares was successful.
And it certainly was. Pixar's shares shot up to $45.50 during their first hour of trading today on the Nasdaq market. Trading had to be delayed because there were too many orders to buy and not enough sellers. The stock eventually traded as high as $49.50 before falling back to close at $39 in heavy trading of 4.8 million shares.
Today, at the close of trading, Mr. Jobs's roughly 30 million Pixar shares were worth about $1.17 billion on paper, a one-day profit of more than $500 million. Of course, there is no guarantee that Pixar's shares will continue to trade as high as $39.
Pixar, which is based in Richmond, Calif., across the bay from San Francisco, is a digital animation studio that relies on computers rather than cameras to make movies. "Toy Story," which was Pixar's first full-length computer-animated effort, was the top box-office draw last weekend, grossing $38 million. The Walt Disney Company, which is distributing "Toy Story," has also hired Pixar to create two other movies.
The success of "Toy Story" is spreading. Toys related to the movie are already on sale for the Christmas season. And a CD-ROM version of the movie is in the works for next Christmas.
Silicon Valley industry watchers said Mr. Jobs's financial reward -- even if it turns out to be fleeting -- was well deserved, since he held onto his Pixar investment through a difficult decade.
"The entrepreneur side of me says, 'Hey, this guy put $60 million into the deal and took a major risk, now he's getting his payback,' " said Anthony Perkins, editor in chief of The Red Herring, a technology and entertainment business magazine based in San Francisco.
When Mr. Jobs first bought Pixar, the company was a manufacturer of specialized high-end graphics computers and software. Only in recent years has he transformed it into a digital movie production company, following the original vision of Pixar's founders, a small group of computer researchers who were pioneers in computer animation.
Mr. Jobs contended today that the money did not mean much to him. Instead, he said he was much more ecstatic that the movie was getting widespread positive reviews.
"There's no yacht in my future," he said. "I've never done this for the money, but I'm grateful that people are believing in our dream and the reality of our achievements."
At Apple Computer, Mr. Jobs and Mr. Wozniak each initially had 8.3 million shares that were worth $28.75 apiece on Dec. 13, 1980, the first day Apple's shares were traded. That gave Mr. Jobs, who was then 25 years old, a worth on paper of $239 million.
Apple's stock peaked in 1987 at $82.25. At that point, Mr. Jobs's original shares would have been worth $683 million. But after losing a bitter battle for the control of Apple in 1985, Mr. Jobs quit and then quickly sold out while Apple's shares were trading below their initial offering price. Industry executives have estimated that he left the company with about $100 million.
In a way, Mr. Jobs's experience at becoming a billionaire parallels that of Mr. Clark of Netscape. Both are remarkable Silicon Valley comeback stories, in a competitive environment in which two-time winners are unusual. Indeed, Mr. Clark founded Netscape last year only after he left the work station maker Silicon Graphics, another company he founded, after a falling-out with its president.
"The two guys were both Silicon Valley outsiders and they've both come booming back," said Michael Murphy, editor of the California Technology Stock Letter. "You can never count anyone out."
But both men still face imposing challenges in proving they can sustain Wall Street's early interest in their ventures. Pixar needs to show that it is not a one-hit wonder.
"The future value of Pixar is a very simple function of their ability to produce another great movie," said Roger McNamee, general partner of Integral Partners, a Menlo Park, Calif., investment firm.
And although the market is treating Pixar as a technology play today, the economics of its business are now far different from most technology companies.
"Pixar needs to be considered in a very different light than any of the big Silicon Valley success stories," said Jim Breyer, managing general partner of Accel Partners, a venture capital firm. "This is fundamentally an entertainment model."
Pixar has lost money in each of the last five years, based on revenues that have ranged from $3.35 million in 1990 to $5.59 million in 1994. The company can still look forward to making at least two more movies for Disney. But Pixar said its second animated movie would not be out before the end of 1998 at the earliest.

HEADLINE: Tensions Build Again in Haiti, Imperiling Peace

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 29

 BODY:
Even as the United States prepares to send troops to Bosnia, the Clinton Administration suddenly finds itself struggling to prevent the unraveling of a fragile peace that began here barely a year ago with the arrival of 20,000 American soldiers at the head of an international peacekeeping force.
In little more than a month, the American commitment to Haiti and to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, whom American military might restored to power in an effort to rebuild democracy in Haiti, has gone from showcase to headache. 
 Relations with the Aristide Government are deteriorating, political violence has re-emerged, the economy is on the skids and Haitians have begun expressing dissatisfaction with the foreign presence here.
"If you blancs are not going to help President Aristide, then you should just leave us alone," said Gerard Joseph, a university student who was taking part in a pro-Aristide demonstration outside the National Palace this morning, using a Creole word that means both "foreigners" and "whites."
Now Washington may also have to contend with a resurgence of the "boat people" problem that provoked the American intervention. More Haitians have been picked up in the Caribbean over the last week than during the entire year following Mr. Aristide's return to office on Oct. 15, 1994. Today 577 were brought back here on a pair of United States Coast Guard cutters,
Even the reasons for the discord are a matter of dispute, with each side citing different instances of the other's supposed perfidy.
"All the buried resentments are suddenly coming to the surface," said a Latin American diplomat here. "The potential for this whole operation coming apart is growing by the day."
As the United States sees it, Mr. Aristide is engaged in a dangerous flirtation with a movement that wants him to cancel a presidential election scheduled to take place in less than three weeks and remain in office three more years, in contravention of an agreement he made last year with the United States.
Those concerns were heightened by an incendiary speech he delivered this month, urging his followers to "go to the neighborhoods where there are big houses and heavy weapons" to help the police disarm paramilitary thugs.
Haitians, on the other hand, point to a lack of support by Washington for their disarmament efforts and its delay in returning more than 150,000 pages of documents seized last year by American troops from the Haitian military and paramilitary groups and now in the hands of American intelligence agencies. They also resent the recent suspension of economic aid by the United States to show its displeasure with Mr. Aristide's economic policies.
The dispute has jeopardized the objective that has motivated American policy since troops first landed here on Sept. 19, 1994: carrying out a credible presidential vote this Dec. 17 and a peaceful transfer of power next Feb. 7 to Mr. Aristide's democratically elected successor.
On Thanksgiving Day, Anthony Lake, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, spent more than three hours with Mr. Aristide here, discussing the transition timetable and seeking an ironclad commitment that the Haitian leader will indeed step down.
"Aristide told Lake that he will leave, but said that he has to do it his way," an American official here said when asked to summarize the meeting.
One day later, however, the Haitian leader cast doubts on those assurances when he told a conference of his supporters that "if you want three more years, I will not turn my back on you" and "I want what you want."
The uncertainty about Mr. Aristide's intentions remains, and his Government continues to send mixed signals. The newspaper Libete published an interview today quoting the President as saying he will leave office when his term ends on Feb. 7, but Government officials said a regularly scheduled Cabinet meeting discussed a proposal that he stay on, and well-organized demonstrators this morning paraded in front of the National Palace with banners demanding "three more years" for the President.
"I am leaving on Feb. 7," Mr. Aristide said in the interview with Libete, a Creole-language weekly affiliated with the same "theology of liberation" wing of the Roman Catholic Church to which Mr. Aristide belonged during his priesthood.
When asked if he supported Rene Preval, the candidate of the governing Lavalas movement, Mr. Aristide replied, "Wait, watch and observe."
In an interview here, a senior adviser to Mr. Aristide dismissed the Clinton Administration's concerns as groundless. Much of what the Haitian leader has been saying and doing recently is "for internal consumption," he said, and is not intended to disturb relations with the United States and the United Nations.
"He is in a phase where everyone is saying he is a puppet of the foreigners, and if he is seen as a puppet, Preval will also be seen as a puppet, and the opposition can denounce that," the adviser said. "He has to take the electorate with him and say, 'I am my own man, and I know what I am doing.' "
But most opposition political parties, including the one under whose banner Mr. Aristide ran in 1990, are boycotting the election, leaving an undistinguished field that one European diplomat here caustically described as "a dauphin and 13 pretenders." One candidate, Dieuveuil Joseph, claims to be a reincarnation of the Virgin Mary.
Those political uncertainties have further weakened the Haitian economy, which has failed to attract foreign investment since Mr. Aristide's return and now faces the threat of a cut off of foreign aid because of his failure to privatize inefficient state-owned companies. The gourde lost 20 percent of its value before the Government began last week to prop it up, dipping into its small stock of foreign reserves to the tune of $1 million a day.
With the growing weakness of the economy has come an upsurge in the number of people trying to reach Florida in unseaworthy vessels.
Fewer than 300 "boat people" were intercepted in the 13 months ending Nov. 15, but the Coast Guard has since picked up more than 1,100 aboard two large freighters, and 47 more are believed to have drowned when a smaller ship sank last weekend.
"We don't think that it represents a trend," Stanley Schrager, a spokesman for the American Embassy, said in an interview at the port here as the Coast Guard cutter Northland unloaded the first group of Haitians. "We're obviously concerned, having had 1,000 people intercepted in the last week," he continued, "but we can't say we have a problem."
Mr. Schrager linked the increase in interceptions on the high seas to the end of the hurricane season and described the returnees as "economic refugees" rather than people fleeing political strife.
"There is no reason to believe the election, the security situation or the recent surge of violence have spurred these boat people," he added.
As they waited in line for bus fare back to their homes, several of the returnees -- who were mostly young men -- attributed their decision to leave Haiti to what they called "la misere."
Echoing remarks by several others, one young man, who like the others would speak only on the condition of anonymity, said, "There is no work, and we have no food."

HEADLINE: Officials Assure Democrats of a Veto of the Welfare Bill

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29

 BODY:
Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, today catalogued the Administration's objections to a Republican welfare bill in an effort to reassure Democrats who fear the President may ultimately sign the measure.
Leon E. Panetta, the White House chief of staff, has said Mr. Clinton will veto the bill. But Democrats in Congress and even some Administration officials say they are unsure of the President's intentions because he has shifted position on the issue in the last two years. 
 Dr. Shalala set forth the reasons for a veto in a speech today to the National Association for the Education of Young Children, saying the legislation would not guarantee child care for welfare recipients who would be required to work.
"Child care must be the foundation of any real approach to welfare reform," she said. "A car won't run without an engine. A jet won't fly without wings. And welfare reform will not work without good child care."
Many provisions of the welfare bill have been incorporated in a separate bill to balance the Federal budget in seven years. In addition, Republicans expect to send Mr. Clinton a freestanding welfare bill.
After Mr. Clinton met with Democratic senators in the Capitol on Tuesday, Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska, said of the President: "He doesn't like the welfare bill. He will veto that by itself."
Mr. Kerrey's report cheered officials at the Departments of Health and Human Services, Agriculture and Labor. They have been urging Mr. Clinton to veto the welfare bill, but say they fear he may approve a revised version.
An Administration official said Mr. Clinton wanted to send a clear signal to Democrats that he would veto the welfare bill and would not undercut them by signing the measure if they fought against it.
Referring to the Republicans, Dr. Shalala said: "They want to reduce or eliminate assistance for more than one million disabled children each year. They propose slashing billions of dollars from foster care, adoption assistance and child abuse prevention programs, placing hundreds of thousands of vulnerable children at additional risk. And who would be hardest hit by their $33 billion in cuts to the food stamp program? Fourteen million needy children."
The Secretary also asserted that the Republican proposals would weaken Federal standards for child care. They "take us back to the days when we spent more energy guaranteeing the safety of hairstyling salons than the safety of child care," she said.
On Tuesday, Senator John H. Chafee, a Rhode Island Republican who had expressed reservations about the welfare bill, signed a conference report recommending passage of the legislation. But an aide to Mr. Chafee said he was not enthusiastic about the bill and had not decided whether to vote for it on the Senate floor.
Senator Richard G. Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is chairman of the Agriculture Committee, refuses to sign the conference report because of a dispute with the House over the school lunch program.
House Republicans, led by Representative Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, want to allow each state to take a lump sum of Federal money and operate its own school lunch program, free of Federal supervision. But Mr. Lugar opposes such block grants, saying the Federal Government must preserve "a safety net for child nutrition programs."
A block grant undermines the Federal commitment to provide nutritious meals to schoolchildren, Mr. Lugar asserted. "It does not provide more money when recession and unemployment push more families toward the poverty line," he said. "In times when assistance is most needed, it will be less available."

HEADLINE: Panel of Experts Urges Government to Revamp Science Budget

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
A panel of scientists called on the Federal Government yesterday to reinvent the way it finances science and technology research, describing the current system as a haphazard one that worked well for decades when budgets were growing but that could damage the nation now that science dollars are being cut.
In the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30, the Government spent $69 billion on scientific research, broadly defined, doing everything from fighting AIDS to probing distant planets. The science budget is down from a peak of $73 billion in 1990, in dollars adjusted for inflation. 
 The downturn is a reversal of decades of fairly steady growth in Federal science money, which by some estimates may decline by as much as a third in the next five years.
The blueprint for a new budget method was made public in Washington by a panel of the National Research Council, a private group chartered by Congress to advise the Government.
The panel in essence called for the current untidy process to be made more rational with the aim of preserving excellence during a time of contraction, although a risk in that approach, some science analysts say, is that new rationality and visibility might give budget cutters tempting new targets.
The panel's report, "Allocating Federal Funds for Science and Technology," was requested by Congress last year.
"By any measure, the Federal Government's investments in science and technology since World War II have been a spectacular success, producing enormous benefits for the nation," said the panel's chairman, Dr. Frank Press, former president of the National Academy of Sciences. "However, the question now facing the country is how best to continue this success when factors such as the severe budget deficit, the end of the cold war and the growth of global competition are bringing unprecedented changes to society and to science and technology."
In its report, the 18-member panel made more than a dozen recommendations for changing the budget process, mainly by merging the budget's disjointed parts into a single picture. It rejected the idea of a Federal department of science, saying deft adjustments within the existing Government structure would accomplish more than would a new agency.
As a first step, the report said, the Government should calculate its spending on science and technology more accurately. Last year's figure of $69 billion is misleading, the report said, since almost half of that was spent on things that have nothing to do with the creation of knowledge or technologies but instead help establish production lines and develop new kinds of aircraft and weapons. The true Federal science budget is more like $35 billion to $40 billion, the report said.
In addition, it said, the White House should develop an advisory apparatus to help it and Congress understand the nation's standing in various international fields and to insure that the United States leads in those that are especially promising or important to national goals.
The report also recommended that preference be given to financing projects and people rather than institutions, thereby promoting the quality and flexibility of research.
It said academic research, characterized by intense competition for Federal grants, should take priority over that done by industry or Government laboratories, increasing flexibility and quality control and helping train the next generation of scientists.
Further, it said, Federal laboratories should undergo renewed scrutiny, with the possibility of redirecting or eliminating their resources.

HEADLINE: Japan's Invisible Minority: Better Off Than in Past, but Still Outcasts

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: KYOTO, Japan

 BODY:
A 23-year-old woman had just given birth to her first baby when she learned something devastating about her husband. He was secretly a burakumin, a descendant of outcasts.
So the woman refused to touch her own baby. She returned to her parents' house and abandoned her husband and child forever. 
 That was a generation ago, in Nagano Prefecture in central Japan, and the incident underscores a legacy of discrimination in Japan that has parallels in the United States.
Even today, there is no better way for young Japanese to give their parents heart palpitations than by suggesting a marriage to a burakumin, and most burakumin still live in segregated neighborhoods riven by crime, alcoholism and unemployment.
Yet Japan is also remarkable for the progress it has made.
Today almost two-thirds of burakumin (pronounced boo-RAH-koo-min) say in opinion polls that they have never encountered discrimination. About 73 percent now marry non-burakumin, and most dismiss the possibility that the Japanese police might treat burakumin unfairly.
The E-word -- Eta, or "much filth," the traditional word for burakumin -- has been banished from discourse, so that virtually no Japanese ever uses it.
"I haven't ever encountered discrimination myself," said Masuharu Okuda, a prosperous 53-year-old who was standing outside his dry-cleaning shop in a burakumin neighborhood in Kyoto.
Mr. Okuda proudly pointed to his daughter-in-law, a woman in her 20's who was busy ironing shirts in the shop. "My son married a girl from outside the neighborhood, and she moved in here with us," he said. "There've been no problems."
Yet Japan has not overcome its divide. For if the three million burakumin, amounting to a bit more than 2 percent of the population, are now rarely burdened by overt discrimination, they face the same problems as some minority groups in America: disproportionate poverty, high crime rates, low education levels, many single mothers, dependency on welfare benefits and resentment from a public that believes they are getting special help.
The issues are those that Americans associate with race; in Japan the burakumin are not a different race at all.
They are an occupational minority group rather than a racial one. Indistinguishable in appearance from other Japanese, they were discriminated against simply because they were the descendants of people whose jobs were considered ritually unclean, like butchering animals, tanning skins, making leather goods, digging graves and handling corpses.
A related group of outcasts, also ancestors of some of today's burakumin, were hinin, or nonpersons. They were given tasks like torturing suspects, crucifying Christians and sawing off the heads of criminals for public display.
Outcasts were legally barred from marrying outside their group or from living outside their slums. These slums were called buraku, or hamlets, and that remains the term for a burakumin neighborhood.
In Japan, the outcasts were formally emancipated in 1871, but for decades after that they were effectively barred from ordinary jobs or any life outside the slums. Some Japanese shopkeepers so loathed the burakumin that they would wash their coins upon being paid.
Such behavior has vanished, but contempt still survives in some households. A university-educated housewife in Tokyo was scandalized when asked if she would allow her daughter to marry a burakumin.
"Never, never, never!" she said. "Even if she wanted, I could not allow it. They're dirty. And they're not really Japanese."
Yet attitudes are changing in most families. A housewife in Mie Prefecture noted that the best friend of her teen-age son is a burakumin, and she said this had been a problem until the death of her mother-in-law a couple of years ago.
"My mother-in-law was a very good woman, but she had a terrible prejudice," she said. "So I could never tell her where my son's friend lived, even though he visited us all the time. She would have been furious. She would have said things like, 'He can't be allowed in the house! He can't touch the plates we use!' "
Now the boy eats with the family often, and the mother says she does not know if her son even realizes that his friend is a burakumin.

Invisibility
A Minority Hard to Identify
Some Japanese say the reason that their country has made progress with the burakumin is not broad-mindedness, but rather the inability to figure out who is a burakumin.
Members of another minority group, ethnic Koreans, are more easy to distinguish. Perhaps as a result, Koreans still face enormous discrimination in Japan.
Burakumin are not easily identifiable by their jobs, for only a few of them now work in traditional fields like leather-making. The other big clue to who is a burakumin -- an address in a buraku -- is also less useful now, because burakumin have been pouring out of their neighborhoods while other Japanese have been moving in.
Kenichiro Tatsumi, the head of the Buraku Liberation League in Kobe, said the buraku in which he lives did not have any non-burakumin residents until 1980. "Now half the people who live there are outsiders," he said.
The burakumin are also invisible because there is a virtual taboo on discussing the issue. Newspapers and television stations virtually never mention the word buraku, partly because buraku organizations have sometimes denounced publishers for insensitivity when they have written about buraku issues.
"There've been arguments in which burakumin said some very tough things, and so people became afraid of us," Mr. Tatsumi said.
Most Japanese clam up in horror when the topic is broached, and so most young Japanese know far more about discrimination against blacks in America than about discrimination against burakumin in Japan.
Some junior high school students in the town of Omiya, where there are many buraku, looked puzzled when the topic of burakumin came up.
"Who are they?" a teen-age girl asked. "I've never heard of them."
Even many burakumin students themselves find out only in their mid-teens that they are burakumin.
"Most parents don't tell their kids," said Masahiro Takino, a city administrator in Kobe. "They say, 'Don't wake a sleeping baby.' "
Mr. Takino, who is in his 40's, first learned that he was a burakumin in the third grade, when he went to visit a friend's house. The friend's mother told her son, loud enough for Mr. Takino to hear, never to play with a boy from a buraku.
Japanese corporations used to search the backgrounds of potential employees to make sure there was no trace of burakumin heritage. Parents hired private detectives to investigate the pedigrees of their children's boyfriends or girlfriends.
Such searches are becoming rare now. Strangers are now banned from looking at other people's family registration certificates, where past home addresses are recorded. Private detective agencies are barred in some areas from checking on family backgrounds.

Poverty
Social Problems Are Persistent
In the 1960's, the buraku were immediately recognizable as slums: dilapidated hovels leaned over tiny alleys, open sewers carried waste water into the rivers, and old people blinded by contagious disease sat hopelessly in the open doorways.
Now that has all changed. A torrent of Government investment has improved the buraku so they are no longer slums.
Yet average income for buraku families is still only about 60 percent of the national average, and social problems are proving to be far more persistent than discrimination.
Buraku leaders acknowledge that alcoholism is a disproportionate problem in their communities. Poverty and alcohol, in turn, weaken the family in the buraku.
Single parents are almost twice as common in the buraku as in the nation as a whole. Five percent of burakumin are on welfare, seven times the rate in the overall population.
A 35-year-old study in Japan found that buraku children had lower I.Q.'s than non-buraku children in the same public schools. Scholars who examined the data say the differences reflect general apathy and lack of self-esteem, a result of discrimination and contempt from society as a whole.
In the field of education, burakumin have made stunning progress. But they also remain stunningly far behind.
Truancy rates in elementary school in 1960 were 12 times as high for buraku children as for others. Now they are twice as high.
Burakumin have almost caught up with their peers in the proportion who graduate from high school, a tremendous achievement. But only about 24 percent of burakumin go to college, compared with 40 percent of other Japanese.

Crime
High Membership Among Gangsters
Social workers say crime is a disproportionate problem among young burakumin, but the issue is so sensitive that no Japanese scholars have conducted research on it. One rare statistical study, conducted by Americans in the 1960's, found that burakumin youths were three times as likely as non-buraku youths to be arrested for crimes.
One explanation is that young burakumin sometimes feel that they are outside the umbrella of middle-class society. Denied the benefits by society, they also spurn the responsibilities.
Another explanation, aside from high rates of poverty and unemployment, has to do with one of Japan's open secrets: burakumin and ethnic Koreans dominate the organized crime gangs known as the yakuza. More than three-quarters of the members of the Yamaguchi Gumi, Japan's biggest underworld organization, are said to be burakumin or ethnic Koreans.
In the buraku of Kobe, the nicest houses -- gaudy American-style homes with wide porches and Mercedes-Benzes in the driveway -- belong to yakuza bosses. As a result, the "success stories" whom children in the buraku see as they grow up are often mobsters.
To be sure, there have been many brilliant buraku youngsters who have grown up to be doctors, lawyers, athletes and politicians. But they melt away into the overall society, keeping their background quiet, and so they do not serve as role models.
One of Japan's best-known politicians is secretly a burakumin, according to several buraku social workers. This politician, who has held major Cabinet posts, was horrified when a reporter called his office to ask for an interview on the subject. By all accounts, the buraku connection could still hurt him at the polls, and so he refused to go public.
Partly because burakumin are so invisible, and because mobility is breaking down the barriers that used to keep them apart, many Japanese believe that burakumin will become assimilated over the coming decades.
Yet for now, the progress is only partial.
The daughter-in-law of Mr. Okuda, the dry cleaner, was initially happy to talk about how she had married a burakumin and moved into the buraku. She even posed for a photo in the dry cleaning shop, a symbol of integration in the new Japan.
Then she decided she did not want people to know after all that she had moved into a buraku.
"So," she said, "don't use my name or my picture in the paper."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The minority burakumin of Japan still suffer from problems of poverty and crime. They are physically indistinquishable from other Japanese, as in this mostly burakumin class at an elementary school in Kyoto. (Fumiyo Asahi for The New York Times)
